SABATHIA HAS RIVERA'S VOTE Speaking generally, Mariano Rivera said the Yankees must improve their pitching staff if they are to make the playoffs next season. But speaking specifically, Rivera endorsed the team's interest in the free agent left-hander C. C. Sabathia. ''Definitely, if you ask me personally, definitely, I would like to have him,'' said Rivera, speaking Thursday night at a charity event at a Fifth Avenue jeweler to benefit his foundation for underprivileged children. ''But I'm not one to say what the Yankees should do or not. I think they have the experience, I think they have the ability to recruit whoever they think is going to be the best for the team.''

BENOWITZ--Lillian , 98, November 3, 2008. Born Lillian Huriash (Libby Uriash) in Kalvarija, Lithuania in 1910. Beloved wife of 68 years to Benjamin, mother of Paul, Larry and Martin, mother-inlaw of Sondra and Brooke. Grandmother of Scott, Isaac, Miriam and Daniel. Longterm teacher in New York City School system, devoted alumna of Long Island University, member of Workmens Circle. Lillian will be remembered for her wit, love of travel, and complete devotion to her family. Funeral was on November 5. Shiva at home of son Larry, Newton, MA. Donations in Lillian's memory can be made to UJF or Long Island University.

KERNO--Ivan V. , international lawyer and oil executive, dies at 80, after battle with cancer. Born in Geneva, Switzerland in July 1928, Ivan V. Kerno came to the United States in 1947 after his father was appointed to the United Nations as Assistant Secretary General in charge of the Legal Department. He graduated from Harvard College in 1950 and Harvard Law School in 1953, where he met his future wife, Nicole E. Nay, also a Harvard Law School student. While in service with the United States Army, they were married at St. Patrick's Cathedral in 1954 and settled in Washington, DC where their three sons were born. Following ten years with an oil and gas law firm, he joined Mobil Oil Corporation in New York City in 1964. He then served as General Counsel for Mobil Oil Franaise in Paris and Managing Director of Mobil North and West Africa Group from 1969 to 1973, responsible for the marketing and refining activities in 17 French-speaking countries in Africa. He then served two years in Copenhagen as Managing Director of Mobil Oil Denmark during the first oil crisis. This was followed by eight years as General Counsel for Mobil Europe in London. He ended his career with Mobil as Assistant General Counsel for the international division in New York. After his retirement, he was of Counsel for a New York law firm in association with a Paris international lawyer. He is survived by his wife Nicole, his sons Ivan-Jacques, Philippe and Nicolas, and three grandchildren. A service will be held at the Church of the Holy Family, 315 East 47th St., New York City, on Saturday, November 8th at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the United Nations Children Fund (UNICEF).

THE CALL FOR REVIEW Umpires used instant replay to review seven home run calls over the last five weeks of the season, Jimmie Lee Solomon, baseball's executive vice president for baseball operations, said Thursday at the general managers' meeting. Two of the calls were reversed, Solomon said. Baseball began using instant replay at the end of August to review home run calls. Solomon said the commissioner's office had not received any complaints about the new system. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

KAMEN--Samuel E. , M.D., August 17, 1912 -November 6, 2008. Loving and devoted husband of Cynthia, father of Margaret and Katherine; stepfather of Jodi and Jonathan; grandfather of Lydia, Charles and Nicholas. After being graduated from CCNY and the prestigious Berlin Medical School, Sam returned to New York in 1938 where he served a residence in Bellevue Hospital, specializing in radiology. He served with distinction as Captain in the Pacific area during World War II. On a beachhead in Okinawa, he witnessed the first Kamikaze raid -on a battleship. His versatility and resourcefulness was obvious, when he created a makeshift viewer on the beach by stringing x-rays of the wounded on a line, reading them with the aid of sunlight. After the war, Sam returned home and got married. The union produced two daughters, Meg and Kathy. Following the death of his first wife, Sam met and married the love of his life, Cynthia in 1954. With her he raised Jonathan and Jodi, ran a successful radiology practice in Brooklyn and headed the Department of Radiology at Sea View Hospital, Staten Island. There he made a significant contribution to the cure of Tuberculosis, then rampant in New York City. Additionally, he was medical director of the Midwood HIP Group in Brooklyn as well as Chief Radiologist of the outpatient VA Clinics in Brooklyn and Queens. Sam was a quiet scholar all his life engaging himself in biomedical research and developments in medical technology. He was an avid fan of Lincoln and his collection boasts a library of Civil war books and memorabilia. He lived a wonderful 96 years, earning the love, respect and admiration of his peers, both social and professional. His generosity of spirit made him a remarkable human being. His deeds and effortless compassion personified grace and goodness as he embraced life in all its aspects. He had the ability to relate to the world in a quiet, unassuming manner. His stature belied the giant he was in character and loving-kindness. After 55 years of a wonderfully happy marriage, his final words to Cynthia, spoken in a loud, clear voice were ''words cannot tell how much I have loved you.'' He showed the greatest of courage as her devoted companion and every effort he made for his family was with great commitment and enthusiasm. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 7205 West Atlantic Avenue, Delray Beach, FL 33446 on Sunday November 9 at 2:00pm. Graveside funeral follows at Beth Moses, Long Island, New York on Tuesday November 11 at 2:00pm.

Braving the economic maelstrom, a crowd of 62 dealers from Asia, the United States, the Middle East and Europe are assembled at Pier 92 for the Asian Contemporary Art Fair. The fair's size, look and feel are not all that different from last year, or for that matter from other fairs in this setting. It is a temporary mall for highly sophisticated shoppers, with rows of spacious, elegant and well-lighted booths lining carpeted aisles.

FOR CHILDREN 'BEAUTY AND THE BEAST' (Sunday and Tuesday) The story may be ''a tale as old as time,'' but many children today probably believe that Disney invented it. Literally Alive Children's Theater has revived its musical version, with book and lyrics by Brenda Bell, which adheres more closely to the original story, restoring the heroine's selfish sisters. The show doesn't have debonair Frenchmen or motherly cooks, but it does have hummable tunes by Mark McGee. (Through Dec. 30.) A preshow art workshop is at 10 a.m.; performance at 11 a.m.; Players Theater, 115 Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 352-3101, literallyalive.com; $25; $20 for children; $5 for the workshop, which is free for adults.

As dusk fell on Iowa City and Daniel Murray's 31-yard field goal fluttered through the uprights, the college football world outside of the Big Ten conference let out a collective yelp. An undefeated Penn State looked like a near certainty to reach the national title game in what could be Joe Paterno's swan song in Happy Valley. But its 24-23 loss at Iowa means that Penn State's season will likely end in the Rose Bowl, provided that the Nittany Lions beat Michigan State at home in two weeks.

Sunday puzzles have titles and this one, Sounds Like It's Cold in Here, immediately implied the theme for me, but two things saved it and made it a satisfying solve. First, it's tougher than a typical Sunday. I solved in pen and made A MESS. Your mileage may vary, and if you raced through it in record time, congratulations. Second, the theme answers that were supposed to be amusing actually were amusing. That's not always the case for simple-substitution themes. Once again, that adage about variable mileage applies. Southern California left guard Jeff Byers is an academic All-American candidate. He is a two-year starter and is in his second year in U.S.C.'s Marshall M.B.A. program. He talked with Thayer Evans recently about the Trojans' outlook for the rest of the season, why he voted for John McCain and what it's like to have Will Ferrell visit practice.

For its occasional Q&A with the top movers and shakers in college sports, The Quad welcomes the Oregon State men's basketball coach, Craig Robinson. These days, he is best known as the brother-in-law of President-elect Barack Obama and the brother of Michelle Obama, the First Lady to be. (The former Princeton Coach Pete Carril, Craig Robinson's former coach, likes to say Michelle Obama has "that Robinson smile.") Craig Robinson celebrated on stage with the Obamas on Tuesday night. He played an integral part in the campaign, delivering speeches and making appearances. Robinson was a two-time Ivy League Player of the Year at Princeton under Carril and had a successful career in finance before deciding to make a career change and get into coaching nine years ago. Less than 24 hours after he celebrated with his family on stage in Grant Park in Chicago, Robinson sat down for an extensive interview. Robinson discussed everything from the family's last dinner before the election results came in to his afternoon hoops game with Barack Obama on election day to who has a more formidable challenge -- Barack Obama rebuilding the country or Robinson's rebuilding job in his first season at Oregon State.

Rau‚Äôshee Warren, the world champion flyweight, has decided to stay in the amateur ranks for four more years in an attempt to become the first three-time Olympian in United States history. Warren, a three-time national champion, was the first two-time American Olympic fighter in 30 years when he lost a 1-point decision in his Beijing opener.

Jimmie Johnson moved a step closer to a third consecutive Sprint Cup title by winning the pole at Phoenix International Speedway. Johnson, the defending race winner, turned a lap of 134.725 miles per hour in his Chevrolet to earn the top starting spot Sunday. If he gains 57 more points than Carl Edwards, Johnson will need only to start the season finale to become the first driver since Cale Yarborough (1976-78) to win three titles in a row.

China's record on its reatment of prisoners came under intense scrutiny on Friday, with members of the United Nations Committee Against Torture questioning the way the government carried out laws barring abusive practices. The review, which is being conducted at the United Nations in Geneva and is the first in seven years, focused on numerous detention issues. Felice Gaer, the investigator for the committee, said there was a serious lack of information in China's responses to questions that were raised, according to a summary of the proceedings released to the news media. The Chinese ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, Li Baodong, told the committee that his country had made progress in recent years on banning torture, with law enforcement officials undergoing training in the rule of law and human rights. The committee is expected to issue its findings in two weeks.

Barack Obama's election in the United States has fired imaginations around the globe, perhaps nowhere more than in the Middle East, where people wonder how the future president's approach to the Arab world will differ from that of his predecessor. For the moment, Arabs are mainly excited about Mr. Obama's victory, and have much good will toward him and the country that chose him. But Middle Easterners are more skeptical than anyone else about American politicians and their intentions, and already it seems Mr. Obama is no exception.

The opening statement of President-elect Barack Obama on Friday at a news conference in Chicago, as recorded by Federal News Service. A full transcript of the news conference: nytimes.com/washington This morning we woke up to more sobering news about the state of our economy. The 240,000 jobs lost in October marks the 10th consecutive month that our economy has shed jobs. In total, we've lost nearly 1.2 million jobs this year, and more than 10 million Americans are now unemployed. Tens of millions of families are struggling to figure out how to pay the bills and stay in their homes. Their stories are an urgent reminder that we are facing the greatest economic challenge of our lifetime, and we're going to have to act swiftly to resolve it.

REICH--Geraldine . The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the passing of Geraldine Reich, beloved aunt of our dear friend and board member Seymour D. Reich. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Reich family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President and CEO REICH--Geraldine, on November 6, 2008, at age 96. Devoted sister of Esther Reich Klein (z''l), Abraham Reich (z''l), Mac Rich (z''l) and Bernice Graziani, and beloved aunt of Lorraine Firstman (z''l), Rhoda Carp and Seymour Reich. Although ''Aunt Gerry'' never had children of her own, in reality, her nieces, nephew and all of her grandnieces, grand-nephews and cousins, whom she loved and cared about very much, were her children. May her memory be a blessing for all of us. A graveside funeral will be held at noon at Sunday, November 9, at the Wellwood Cemetery in Pinelawn.

SCRIVANI--Steven S. , D.D.S., Special Lecturer in Dental Medicine and a member of the faculty of the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine (CDM) for almost 60 years, passed away on November 5, 2008. Dr. Scrivani earned his D.D.S. from the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery (now CDM) in 1948, served in the U.S. Navy (1943-45) and the U.S. Army (1949-51), and completed a hospital residency at Goldwater Memorial Hospital (1948-49). He joined the CDM faculty as an Assistant in Dentistry (1949) and rose to Professor of Clinical Dentistry in 1978, a rank he held until his retirement in 1992. He was a friend and mentor to generations of dental students at Columbia. Our thoughts and prayers are extended tohis son, Dr. Steven J. Scrivani, and other members of his family. Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., M.M.Sc. Dean Richard M. Lichtenthal, D.D.S. Chair, Section of Adult Dentistry Columbia University College of Dental Medicine

An article in some editions last Saturday about Sarah Lawrence College misidentified the city in which it is located. The error also appeared in the dateline. The school is in Yonkers -- not in the village of Bronxville, N.Y., which the college uses as a mailing address.

SKAGGS--Merrill Maguire , died at dusk on Monday, November 3, at the age of 71, after a struggle with Waldenstroms Syndrome, a rare, chronic cancer of the immune system. A resident of Madison, NJ, for nearly 40 years, Merrill was the Baldwin Professor of Humanities at Drew University until retiring in May. Merrill specialized in American literature, with an emphasis on the writing of Willa Cather; served as the dean of the Drew Graduate School from 1986 to 1992; and was the author, co-author, or editor of nine books and the author of some fifty essays and articles on American Literature. Merrill was a member of the Society for Values in Higher Education, and served for many years on the board of the Willa Cather Foundation. She was a member of the Summit-Chatham Quaker Meeting, where her ashes will be interred. A public Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, November 23, 2008, at 2pm in the S.W. Bowne Great Hall at Drew University. She is survived by her daughter Sylvia Skaggs McTague; son Adam Skaggs; grandchildren Emma and Tara McTague; former husband Calvin Skaggs; sister Martha Worsley; and brother John Maguire. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation in her name to the Drew University Library Book Endowment in support of the American Literature Collection.

British Airways sent a glimmer of hope across a stricken aviation industry by raising its revenue forecast a notch, though some analysts were skeptical that any significant improvement was in store. The company had a net loss of ¬£42 million ($66 million) for its first half, April through September, compared with net profit of ¬£500 million a year earlier. Revenue was up 6.4 percent, to ¬£4.7 billion. The chief executive, Willie Walsh, said the airline was raising its revenue forecast for the current year to ''at least 4 percent,'' from 3 percent before, as a result of fare increases and a stronger dollar against the pound. ''This is a good performance given the incredibly difficult trading conditions,'' Mr. Walsh said. ''This six-month period will be remembered as one of the bleakest on record.''

(HBO) SWEENEY TODD: THE DEMON BARBER OF FLEET STREET (2007) Johnny Depp, left, his skin pale and his eyes odd, stars as this vengeful barber (and earned a best actor Oscar nomination for the effort) in Tim Burton's film of the Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical. Helena Bonham Carter is Mrs. Lovett the piemaker, who disposes of Sweeney's victims, and Alan Rickman is the malignant judge who transported Sweeney to Australia, stole his wife (Laura Michelle Kelly) and now has guardianship of his teenage daughter. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''as dark and terrifying as any motion picture in recent memory, not excluding the bloody installments in the 'Saw' franchise,'' adding, ''It is also something close to a masterpiece, a work of extreme -- I am tempted to say evil -- genius.'' Noting the fuss over Elliott Carter's impending centenary, partisans of Milton Babbitt's music are getting their ducks in a row. Mr. Babbitt is 92 and apparently in good health, and 2016 will be upon us in no time. So on Wednesday evening the Miller Theater devoted a Composer Portraits program to Mr. Babbitt's string quartets. The composer was on hand for an informal postintermission discussion with James Levine, long an avowed Babbitt fan. And Mr. Carter was seen in the audience, probably to hear what the young whippersnapper was up to. The Zukofsky Quartet, a young group that has made a specialty of Mr. Babbitt's music, played the six works Mr. Babbitt composed between 1948 and 1993 -- or, really, five and a bit: all that remains of the lost Quartet No. 1 (1948) is a pair of fragments from the first movement. The group performed those sumptuous, Berg-like shards, remnants of an almost Neo-Romantic moment in Mr. Babbitt's career, and dove into the more energetic String Quartet No. 2 (1954) without stopping for applause.

WIESENTHAL--Gladys H. , born March 13, 1925, passed away November 6. She was born in New York City to Theodore and Lee Heilig, and educated at Hofstra University. She married Jerome M. Wiesenthal, who prede ceased her only recently, on January 5, 1947. She is survived by her three children, Andrew, Douglas and Amy, and her daughter-in-law Billie Wiesenthal and son-in-law Michael Liss. She is also survived by three grandchildren: Benjamin, Daniel and John Liss. She was predeceased by her younger brother Morton Heilig. Her beloved sister, Joan Kahn, survives her. She was loved by her brother-inlaw Mike Kahn and her sisters-in-law Ellen Wiesenthal and Marion Heilig. She was also beloved by her nephews and nieces Douglas and Stephanie Kahn, David Kahn, Rob and Linnea Wiesenthal, Jay and Jane Cohen, and Gregory and Jeffrey Heilig, and their families. There will be a private service. Donations may be made to The Gladys H. Wiesenthal Fund for Lymphoma Research, MSKCC Office of Development, c/o Elise Cooke, 633 Third Avenue 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

SALWEN--Judy , professor, writer and world traveler, died at age 81 Tuesday in Manhattan after being struck by a car. She lived life to the hilt, traveling to 78 countries, teaching early-childhood education until the present, and reveling in all that New York has to offer. She is survived by three loving children -Andrea Salwen and Kevin Salwen (Joan King) of Atlanta, and Valerie Salwen (Stephen Rogowsky) of Scarsdale -and seven grandchildren who marveled at her zany sense of humor. She is also survived by a sister, Sylvia Flexser of Florida. For information about visitation, (914) 595-2029.

In late September, the American Psychological Association reversed a longstanding policy by voting to ban its members from participating in interrogations at United States detention centers, including Guantanamo Bay. Just a year earlier, the association had declined to take this action, but did pass a resolution listing a number of methods of interrogation -- sleep deprivation, sexual humiliation, exploitation of phobias, loud music, harsh lights and mock executions were examples -- with which psychologists should not be involved.

Like 1066, 1776 and 1914, it is a year that everyone remembers. One went to college before 1929, was married after 1929, or wasn‚Äôt even born in 1929, which bespeaks total innocence. A reference to 1929 has become shorthand for the events of that autumn. For a decade, whenever Americans have been afflicted with doubt as to the durability of their current state of prosperity, they have asked: ‚ÄúWill it be 1929 all over again?‚Äù And even after a quarter of a century, this is still a year with a singular political personality. Just as Republican orators for a generation after Appomattox made use of the bloody shirt, so for a generation Democrats have been warning that to elect Republicans is to invite another disaster like that of 1929.

What do you give a woman who has everything? A woman who is not only a baroness and a Rothschild but also the queen of Paris and legendarily difficult to please. Perhaps you‚Äôve heard of Marie-H√©l√®ne? For just shy of four decades, this daughter of a titled Dutch diplomat and an eccentric Egyptian socialite ruled tout Paris through a cocktail of fear and intimidation, a prickly charisma that left its targets exhausted, and fancy-dress balls on a scale and level of inventiveness that died when she did, at the age of 65 in 1996. Married to Baron Guy de Rothschild, the diffident patriarch of the French branch of the banking family, she did not lack for resources, a fact extravagantly affirmed by her wardrobe. Marie-H√©l√®ne reached her sartorial apotheosis at Longchamp in the 1970s, cinching a leopard coat over her small frame and topping her strawberry tonsorial sweep with a bowler.

Some places live up to their names, and London‚Äôs Royal Academy of Arts is one. It‚Äôs posh, scholarly and populated by artists whose work is, well, let‚Äôs just say conservative. But that‚Äôs what‚Äôs going on in the front. Camping out in the back are GSK Contemporary, a temporary gallery, and, as of Nov. 1, the pop-up restaurant Flash. Ignited by Pablo Flack, David Waddington and Tom Collins, the owners of Bistroth√®que in East London ‚Äî where Marc Jacobs and Agyness Deyn are regulars ‚Äî Flash follows their Reindeer restaurant, which briefly surfaced two years ago in a less salubrious location, above a parking lot. Flash will look and feel ‚Äúmore refined,‚Äù as Waddington put it, with a California-influenced menu and an all-star team: the rising architecture star David Kohn built the set from art-storage crates, the fashion designer Giles Deacon created a ‚Äúpsychedelic Death Star‚Äù chandelier, and the Wedgwood china has been customized by the illustrator Will Broome. Most everything will be auctioned on eBay when Flash closes on Jan. 19, and a chunk of the proceeds will be donated to the Royal Academy. For information, go to bookflashnow.com. She recently worked on a catalog for the artist Lari Pittman (she‚Äôs standing in front of his ‚ÄúUntitled No. 1‚Äù), helped organize Andrea Zittel‚Äôs High Desert Test Sites for the 2008 California Biennial and is currently exhibiting the photographer Wolfgang Tillmans‚Äôs new work. Despite the event‚Äôs reputation as the art world‚Äôs version of spring break, Regen says: ‚ÄúI try not to go out too much when I‚Äôm down there. And I‚Äôm not just saying that because I‚Äôm on the selection committee.‚Äù[?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

‚ÄúEveryone has that in-between room,‚Äù says the interior designer Celerie Kemble. ‚ÄúYou know, that 13-by-8-foot space that has to be an office, guest room, everything.‚Äù While she‚Äôs known for kitting out some grand spaces with updated classics (hence the title of her new book, ‚ÄúTo Your Taste: Creating Modern Rooms With a Traditional Twist‚Äù), Kemble, who works in New York and Palm Beach, Fla., was game to try her hand at an all-purpose room on a catalog budget. Because, as she put it, ‚ÄúI think about the necessities before I think of the identity.‚Äù The following items from West Elm seemed a natural fit.

‚ÄôTemporary / (tem^ pe rer e\) / adj. / lasting for a limited period of time; an abbreviation of ‚Äúcontemporary‚Äù used to describe the feeling of ephemerality surrounding today‚Äôs art and design furniture ‚Äî the objects as well as their respective markets, e.g., ‚ÄúThe Hirst would be great with the Newson sofa, but it might look too ‚Äôtemporary ‚Äî especially since the economy went kablooey.‚Äù.

The expression ‚Äúdon‚Äôt cry over spilled milk‚Äù may be a clich√©, but for the art critic Kenneth Hayes, it‚Äôs a call to arms. His new book, ‚ÄúMilk and Melancholy‚Äù (M.I.T. Press), chronicles the many representations of milk in contemporary art and photography from the likes of John Baldessari and Barbara Kruger to Bruce Naumann. Through a series of semi-opaque inquiries into the liquid‚Äôs myriad manifestations ‚Äî Harold Edgerton photos like ‚ÄúMilk Drop Coronet‚Äù (left) are described as ‚Äúan allegory of the fate of the body in modernity‚Äù ‚Äî the emotive power of the white stuff is, well, milked for all it‚Äôs worth. Don‚Äôt get Hayes started on soy.[?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

What do you get when you combine hungry artists and art-starved foodies? Two very different underground restaurants. In the Bay Area, Open Restaurant was started by art-inclined Chez Panisse staff members to use the restaurant as a means of artistic expression. Their dinners, held at the New Langton Arts Center, focused on themes like dirt (complete with terroir tasting) and urban foraging (make your own salt). Guests are invited to sit on bleachers to observe the spectacle. ‚ÄúThe idea is not to associate food and art but to see the whole restaurant as an art piece,‚Äù says the co-founder Jerome Waag, a performance artist and cook. (For information, go to openrestaurant.org.) In New York, meanwhile, the artist and Lunchbox Chelsea caterer Anne Apparu was invited by the Art Production Fund to turn its front office in the Saatchi & Saatchi building into a monthly restaurant, called the 18th (the date on which it takes place). Here, artists like Nate Lowman and other hipsters eat pumpkin risotto and sip cocktails mixed by the artist Rita Ackermann, while the A.P.F. co-founder Yvonne Force Villareal‚Äôs young son draws (very well) on the paper tablecloth. ‚ÄúHere people get introduced in very comfortable, eye-opening circumstances,‚Äù Apparu says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not an art opening ‚Äî it‚Äôs more like a family reunion.‚Äù (For reservations, e-mail lunchboxchelsea@gmail.com.) [?][?][?]CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

Not so long ago, auction sales were a rarefied world, a silent conversation among experts, punctuated by a gavel, and the corresponding catalogs limited themselves to the facts: a photograph, a lot number, a clinical description. It took an educated eye to navigate their pages and imagine ways to make the treasures on the block relevant in contemporary terms.

It may be a coincidence that three titans of molecular gastronomy have new cookbooks out simultaneously this fall. But if the meticulously designed volumes look better suited to the MoMA Design Store than to Kitchen Arts & Letters, it was very likely intentional. After all, how many of us have the guts, much less the equipment, to attempt Grant Achatz‚Äôs granola in a rose-water envelope, Heston Blumenthal‚Äôs scrambled-egg-and-bacon ice cream or Ferran Adri√†‚Äôs freeze-dried-papaya cotton-candy tree? ‚ÄúThis is not a home cooking book,‚Äù says Richard Schlagman, the publisher of Phaidon‚Äôs artful ‚ÄúDay at elBulli,‚Äù which could pass for a catalog of Swiss graphic design. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd have to be too brilliant to create the dishes. It‚Äôs all there, so you could try, but you‚Äôd have little chance of success.‚Äù Instead, the book (by Adri√†, Juli Soler and Albert Adri√†) indulges armchair chefs by documenting a single day of behind-the-scenes minutiae at the famous Spanish food laboratory, while the recipes are thinly scattered in back. Achatz‚Äôs ‚ÄúAlinea‚Äù(Achatz) and Blumenthal‚Äôs ‚ÄúBig Fat Duck Cookbook‚Äù (above; Bloomsbury) make fewer concessions to nervous cooks, devoting more pages to the actual food and presenting recipes exactly as they‚Äôre used in the restaurants‚Äô kitchens, although both employ breathtaking photography styled to such an extreme that it‚Äôs easy to forget that what you‚Äôre looking at is edible. But when you‚Äôre talking about dishes like the one called Gold, Frankincense and Myrrh, does it really make a difference? [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.

LEVI--Annalina, on November 5, 2008. Loving wife of the late Mario Levi. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Funeral private.

PASSANT--Guy V., 99, of Marlboro, NJ passed away on Wednesday, November 5th, just two days short of his 100th birthday, in Marlboro, NJ. Sadly, his sister Madeline Barbera of Long Island also passed away on the same day. A brother and a sister went to heaven on the same day. Born Gaetano V. Passanante in Brooklyn, NY on November 7th, 1908, he resided in Manhattan for years prior to moving to Toms River, NJ 28 years ago. Mr. Passant served his country in the U.S. Army during World War II. Before retiring in 1974, he served as a Police Reporter for the New York Times for 50 years. He was a member of the New York Press Club, and the American Legion. Mr. Passant was an Adjunct Professor of Journalism at the Columbia University School of Journalism. He was an avid golfer, and he loved Theatre and Music. He was predeceased by his wife Rose, in 2003. Mrs. Passant had also been employed for 50 years by the New York Times. He is survived by several nieces and nephews. A memorial gathering will be held at the Holmdel Funeral Home, 26 South Holmdel Road, Holmdel, NJ, on Sunday, November 16th from 2:00pm to 4:00pm.

Helen was a devoted wife to Peter, a loving mother to Thomas and Stephanie, a beloved grandmother to Elena, Peter, and Terrell, and a dear friend. She was the foundation for both her immediate family and all her relatives. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Monday 6-9pm and Tuesday 6-8pm. The Funeral Service will be at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St., New York City on Wednesday, November 12th at 10am. The Burial will be in Millbrook, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Faith Endowment, 499 Park Ave., 6th Floor, NY, NY or Lenox Hill Hospital.

Mr. Obama's education plan outlined some $8 billion for recruiting, performance pay and other initiatives that represent his approach to updating the education law known as No Child Left Behind. But his plan also offered grand proposals for every level of education, including a $4,000 tuition tax credit that would make college more affordable for millions of students and a $10 billion expansion of early childhood programs. The challenge will be how to finance all these proposals when budgets are extremely tight, experts said.

LOOMIS--Henry. April 19, 1919-November 02, 2008 of Jacksonville, FL. Henry Loomis who, as a young naval officer in Hawaii in World War II taught scores of officers and men of the Pacific Fleet about RADAR, then went on to a long career in government and communications in which he served five presidents. He was 89 and died of Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and Pick's disease after a lengthy illness. Mr. Loomis, a research scientist, grew up in an ideal environment. He was the youngest of three sons of Ellen Farnsworth and Alfred Loomis, a businessman who made a fortune in New York City before the crash of 1929, lived in Tuxedo Park, where he converted an old mansion into a private research laboratory. Some of the world's best scientist worked on projects there. As a teenager Henry worked with his father on brain wave experiments. Mr. Loomis went to Harvard, where he majored in physics. Convinced in his own mind that the United States would be involved in the war, Mr. Loomis left Harvard in 1940 in his senior year to join the Navy. He graduated first in his naval training class and, because of his background, was assigned to the staff of the Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific Fleet at Pearl Harbor. He established and ran the RADAR maintenance school, the RADAR operations school and was senior instructor in the RADAR tactical school for senior officers. At the same time, he served as RADAR officer with carriers, air squadrons and battleships. By war's end, he had been awarded a Bronze Star, the Air Medal and the Pacific Ribbon with 13 battle stars. Mr. Loomis left the Navy in 1946 as a lieutenant commander and went to the University of California at Berkeley, where he did graduate work in physics and was an assistant to Dr. Ernest Lawrence, director of the radiation laboratory. There he drafted a report for the university trustees describing the laboratory's nuclear work during the war. After four years as assistant to the president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Mr. Loomis was called to Washington, where he started a long career in government service. In three successive years, he was a special assistant to the Director of the Research and Development Board of the Secretary of Defense, and served on the staffs of President Truman's Psychological Strategy Board and President Eisenhower's Commission on International Information. Mr. Loomis established and directed the Office of Research and Intelligence at the U.S. Information Agency as Deputy Director and was later named Director of the VOA, a position he held for seven years. In 1959, the VOA broadcast a news program to the rest of the world in English. Mr. Loomis, in survey trips abroad, realized that English was becoming an international language. He wanted to make English easier to understand by VOA's foreign audience, and asked Barry Zorthian, program manager, to devise a way of reaching an audience with a limited knowledge of English. The result was called Special English. Two changes from VOA's standard procedure: the news was delivered at the slow pace of nine lines a minute and the vocabulary was limited to 1,500 words. University critics said it would never work; American embassies abroad demanded the program be taken off the air. With the support of Mr. Loomis, the program stayed on the air and soon hundreds of letters of praise came in to VOA every month from pleased foreign listeners. After a sharp confrontation with President Johnson during the Vietnam War, Mr. Loomis quit as director of the VOA The President had ordered American intervention into Laos and wanted it kept out of the news. Mr. Loomis thought otherwise. In 1972 during the Nixon Administration, Mr. Loomis was appointed president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Critics jumped on the choice because Mr. Loomis had no experience in public television. However, he had built up a reputation as an excellent administrator on earlier assignments, so he weathered the storm and led the CPB for six years. While Mr. Loomis was deeply involved in government assignments from 1950 to 1978, he managed to stay active in his favorite outdoor activities; hunting, sailing, and riding to the hounds with the Middleburg Hunt in Middleburg, Virginia. In his teens, Mr. Loomis and his brother, Lee, built a 35-foot ketch named Lands End, which they sailed on the Atlantic Ocean. Mr. Loomis was a regular participant in the annual wooden boat race off the Down East Shores of Maine at the helm of Lands End. As a hunter Mr. Loomis traveled around the world to countries in South America, Europe and Africa on bird shooting safaris. He shot big game in Kenya. Mr. Loomis served for 13 years with the Mitre Corporation Board, where he was Vice Chairman for five years; the Smithsonian Institution National Museum of Natural History; the Museum of Science and History in Jacksonville, Florida, and the Jacksonville Zoological Gardens. He was a member of the Metropolitan Club of Washington DC, the Riverside Rotary of Jacksonville Florida; the Florida Yacht Club; the Timuquana Country Club. Mr. Loomis attended the Riverside Presbyterian Church. Survivors include his wife of 34 years, Jacqueline Chalmers Loomis of Jacksonville, FL; four children, Henry Stimson Loomis (Toni), Mary Paul ''Pixie'' Loomis, Lucy Farnsworth Loomis, Gordon MacLeod Loomis (Patricia); four step-sons, Charles Judson Williams IV, John Chalmers Williams (Peggy Sue), David Finley Williams (Lisa), Robert Wood Williams (Heidi); seventeen grandchildren, Abby, Andrew H., Andrew W., Beky, Elli, Erin, Finley, Henry, Lindy, Lucy, Maggie, Murphy, Nadia, Nathan, Perry (Dean), Sole (Adam), and Zoe; two greatgrandchildren, Ethan and Noah; the mother of his children, Mary Paul MacLeod and numerous nieces and nephews. Memorial service will be held at 11:00am, on Saturday, November 15, 2008 at Riverside Presbyterian Church, located at 849 Park Street, Jacksonville, FL 32204. In lieu of flowers the family suggests memorials to the Jacksonville Zoological Gardens or the Riverside Rotary of Jacksonville, FL. The funeral services are under the care of Hardage-Giddens Blanding Funeral Home, 5753 Blanding Blvd., Jacksonville, FL 32244.

TAKATA--Gary, Venture capital entrepreneur who founded several firms in the medical and pharmaceutical industries, died November 4, at the age of 73, in Hospice in Manhattan. He and his wife, Louise, have residences in Manhattan and Vero Beach, Florida. Takata was a 12-year survivor of multiple myeloma, a cancer of the plasma cell. He and his wife became financially and emotionally involved in the International Myeloma Foundation, an organization dedicated to improving the quality of life of myeloma patients through prevention and cure. Gary Takata was born in Chicago and grew up in Sunnyside, Queens, and Detroit. He received an MBA from the University of Michigan in 1958. After graduation, he moved to New York City where he took a position with Wall Street brokerage firm, Philips, Appel and Walden, Inc. He was a vice president of the company from 1960-1983. In 1983, he founded Oncogene Science, Inc., the predecessor to OSI Pharmaceuticals, Inc., a drug discovery company which developed several FDA approved drugs. James Watson, the cowinner of the 1962 Nobel prize for his discovery of the double-helix structure of DNA, was Chairman of the Advisory Board. Other companies founded by Takata include TCell Sciences, a privately held biotechnical firm, and Seed Equities, a New York based venture capital firm. He was also very active in founding and funding other public companies. Gary Takata is survived by Louise Jones-Takata, his wife of 22 years; a sister, Carlene Mackay of San Diego; his stepmother, Fumiko Takata, and his half-sister, Tomomi Takata, both of Escondido, California. In addition to the International Myeloma Foundation, Takata's philanthropies include the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation and the Boys Club of Detroit. No funeral services are planned. His ashes will be immured at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, New York.

No legal hurdle would prevent President-elect Obama from pulling out of the North American Free Trade Agreement, a distinction from other trade deals. But trade experts say the political and economic costs of scuttling the deal would be enormous. Even opening it up to renegotiate labor and environmental standards carries risks: Canada might seize the opportunity to renegotiate provisions on energy, while Mexico might push for access for its trucks in the United States.

Mr. Obama pledged to extend the Bush tax cuts of 2001 and 2003 past 2010, when they would expire, for taxpayers making less than $250,000 a year. He would repeal the cuts for taxpayers making more than that, effective Jan. 1, 2010. Mr. Obama considers the extension for those making under $250,000 a continuation of current policy, not a tax cut.

ABRAMS--Hester Holbrook, born June 19th, 1942 in Milwaukee, WI, passed away October 20th, 2008 in Austin, TX. She was the daughter of the late Katharine Brumder Holbrook and Matson Holbrook of Milwaukee, WI. Hester will be sadly missed by her two brothers Matson (Deborah) and William (Rana) Holbrook; the Brumder family of Milwaukee, WI; her niece Sarah (Will) Slaughter and nephews Matson Jr. (Sarah), McLean (Mranda) and Andrews Holbrook and her three children; Amy of Venice, CA, Scott of Peterborough, NH and Timothy Abrams of Boulder, CO. Hester was predeceased by her longtime companion John (Jack) Hogan of Westchester County, NY. Hester attended Milwaukee Downer Seminary (University School of Milwaukee), and was a graduate of Colorado Rocky Mountain School (CRMS) of Carbondale, CO. and Garland Jr. College of Boston, MA. Hester was an accomplished artist who mastered everything she put her hand to -from water color painting and photography to bronzing and sculpting, and finally the intricacies of beadwork jewelry design to which she devoted her last years. Hester embraced life and she is remembered for her infinite capacity to love, to share, to be creative, to support and to show unlimited acceptance and compassion. She was the ultimate champion to her children and she positively affected everyone who was fortunate to know her. In addition to all these qualities, she took pride in coaching Little League Baseball for the Lewisboro Tigers and the Cosmos Soccer team in South Salem, NY in the 1970s. Hester was a natural, graceful athlete with a passion for fly fishing, scuba diving, paddle tennis, tennis, and golf. She was a self taught guitar player, and the harmony when she sang was pure beauty. In lieu of flowers, memorials are suggested to: Brule River Preservation, c/o Susie Isaken, POB 129 Brule, WI 54820, an organization which supports and defends Hester's favorite place on earth. P.S. Hester appreciates everyone who voted for Obama.

THIS WEEK'S RECOMMENDATIONS WOWEE: On Nov. 13, Blizzard Entertainment will release World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King. Check it out atworldofwarcraft.com. ''Such a game is not merely consumed, or even played,'' wrote Seth Schiesel of the massive multiplayer game in The Times. ''It is inhabited.'' Are you ready to move in? Schiesel also recommends a new non-Blizzard game: Warhammer Online: Age of Reckoning. Warhammer evidently improves on the WoW formula with an interesting ''public quest'' framework that brings far-flung players together to accomplish shared goals.

DAVID LETTERMAN Attention passengers, the Straight Talk Express is no longer in service.

AT THE PARTAGAS CIGAR FACTORY, HAVANA, OCT. 24, 2008. John G√≥mez, 33, a lawyer from Salamanca, Spain: ''Cuba is a very rich place culturally, but society is completely submissive to the regime and to the rhythm of life that it has established. In the factory, professional artisans work under conditions that we can't even imagine in a developed country. They use archaic tools and yet produce practically perfect cigars in record time. In Havana, the salaries are ridiculous, and there are shortages of everything. To buy shoes for your child is a month's wages. So they've created a parallel subsistence economy to sell cigars, rum, whatever. On any street corner you can find the factory workers or their friends or family, who will take you to their house and sell you these very same cigars, smuggled from the factory. The best phrase I heard to describe it was what a used-book seller told me. 'In this country, everything's for sale. Just ask.' I had a great experience, because it's a beautiful country. I'm leaving ashamed, though, that we don't appreciate things we have, while here they're appreciative for so little.''

HAMBURGER--Martin, passed away on Friday, October 24 in Miami, FL. He was born in New York City in 1920, graduated from CCNY and received his doctorate in education from Columbia University. He was a long-time professor of counseling at New York University, consultant in career planning and counseling at the New School for Social Research, visiting professor at Hadassah University in Israel and, most recently, instructor at Florida International University. He served as a staff sergeant in the U.S. Army. He was a world traveler and a passionate theater patron, regularly attending productions in London, New York and at regional companies and festivals. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Beverlee Kagan and is survived by brother Samuel, sister Rose De Piola (Frank), stepson Steve Kagan (Ann Marie), stepdaughter Lori Kagan-Moore (Patrick), grandchildren Caroline Kagan, Hannah Kagan Moore and Emma KaganMoore, nieces Leonora De Piola Smook and Roberta Considine, nephews Frank and Joe De Piola and several grandnieces and nephews. A memorial will be held at 2pm November 16 at 3 Grove Isle Drive, Coconut Grove, FL. Donations in Dr. Hamburger's name may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

Mr. Obama has said ''every American has a right to affordable health care,'' but he has not said exactly how he would finance coverage for the 45 million people who are uninsured. The economic slump and the bailout for the financial industry may reduce the amounts available to cover the uninsured. On his Web site, Mr. Obama says his health plan ''will lower health care costs by $2,500 for a typical family by investing in health information technology, prevention and care coordination.'' Health policy experts endorse those goals, but say they are unlikely to produce such large savings.

COHEN--Stuart A., 64, November 6, 2008. Beloved husband of Pearl, father of Seth, Marc, and Chad, and fatherin-law of Jessica. He enjoyed a 33-year career at the Central Intelligence Agency, and served as the acting Chairman of the National Intelligence Council. Upon retirement, he received the Distinguished Career Intelligence Medal. In 2004, he returned home to New York City to teach graduate students at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Stuart passed away at home, surrounded by his family, after a long battle with prostate cancer. Donations can be made in his name to the American Society of Clinical Oncology.

KENJI AOKI The Japanese photographer Kenji Aoki sees beauty in the everyday. ''It is important to realize that all human products -- tables, photographs or even potato chips -- have an expressive power,'' he says. For ''Exercise in Utility'' on Page 90, Aoki shot an assortment of spectacular furniture designed by contemporary artists. His favorite piece was a surrealist table created by Rosemarie Trockel, complete with faux human legs. ''By turning this table into a work of art, the artist actually brings us back to the basics of design: the initial stick-leg of the table,'' he says. Aoki (whose past work can be seen at center and far right) recently experienced a different form of simplicity at the Eiheiji Temple, a Zen Buddhist center in Fukui, Japan: ''Those monks possesed a mental power I was longing for.'' Aside from forthcoming projects for Western-style deities like Nikon, Cartier and Sony, Aoki's plans include opening his first studio in New York.

9 P.M. (13, 49) GOD ON TRIAL Prisoners facing death at Auschwitz convene a rabbinical court and solemnly weigh the evidence against God, whom they accuse of abandoning his chosen people, in this ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' drama from Frank Cottrell Boyce, based on an often told but unconfirmed story. Stephen Dillane plays Schmidt, a rabbi who volunteers to serve on the court; Stellan Skarsgard is a German professor of law who agrees to head the proceedings; Rupert Graves is Mordechai, who insists on being God's chief accuser; Jack Shepherd (above right, with Mr. Graves) is Kuhn, Mordechai's father; and Antony Sher is Akiba, a ''living Torah,'' who has committed the Scriptures to memory. 10:30 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESSValerie Jarrett, who is helping to lead the Obama-Biden transition team, will discuss the changeover.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Where Doves, and the Threat of Danger, Fill the Air,'' Nov. 6: That American hunters go to Mexico to shoot doves in an area where much of humanity is struggling to cross the other way in order to feed their children is rife with ironies. The rich Americans go to shoot the bird that is the international symbol of peace.

There are telling signs that Texas Tech is settling in nicely to its role as a national power. At Market Street, an upscale grocery store best known as the site of Bobby Knight's confrontation with Tech's chancellor, they were selling T-shirts commemorating the Red Raiders' 39-33 victory over Texas last week. At Jones AT&T Stadium, students crowded into their seats and watched the end of the Penn State-Iowa State game on the large video screen.

On energy and climate change, Mr. Obama's focus has shifted markedly over the course of the year as the economy has weakened. An earlier proposal put an economy-wide cap on greenhouse gases, requiring industry and utilities to buy credits from the government to emit carbon dioxide. That plan would produce hundreds of billions of dollars in government revenue and drive up the cost of energy for everyone.
Theater Charles Isherwood

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Serena Williams Won't Vote but Still Has Her Say,'' Nov. 4: How wonderful that Serena Williams enjoys all the protection our Constitution affords to all religions, yet she will not participate in that most basic democratic process that is the bulwark upon which her religious freedom stands: the vote. Gary E. Osius

HOROWITZ--Sidney. Beloved husband of 60 years, cherished father, father-in-law, grandfather, great - grand father, brother and uncle. You lived your life to the fullest. Your spirit, warmth, humor and zest for life will be an inspiration to us all. Grace, Joanne, Richard, Heidi, Jill, Jeff, Lucas, Starr and Chase HOROWITZ--Sidney. Dear Grace, Sid was more than a friend, he was family. He was so proud of Joanne and Richard, Jill and little Lucas. He always told us of all the happiness they gave him. He will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences go out to the entire family. Love, Lois and Bob

NEWTON--Norma S. (nee Simmons), passed away Sunday, November 2, 2008 in New York City after a brief illness. She lived in Houston for a number of years before relocating to New York City. One of the premiere artist /teachers in her field, Norma trained over 50 singers who have gone on to have major careers, including Susanne Mentzer, Laura Claycomb, Barbara Bonney, Ana Maria Martinez, Brett Polegato, Roger Honeywell, Greer Grimsley, and a host of other gifted singers. At the time of her death Ms. Newton was on faculty at Hunter College New York City and Westminster College of the Arts-Rider University in New Jersey, the Amalfi Coast Festival in Vietri sul Mare, Italy as well as maintaining a full private studio. She had previous affiliations with Rice University, Catholic University, The Academy of Vocal Arts, The Houston Opera Studio, Houston Baptist University, Opera in the Ozarks, Glimmerglass Opera, the American Institute of Vocal Studies in Graz, Austria and the National Opera Teheran. During her operatic and concert career spanning two decades, in the U.S. she performed with New York City Opera, Dallas Civic Opera, Chicago Grant Park, Houston Symphony, and with the late Beverly Sills, Norma Treigle, and James King as well as Regina Resnick and Placido Domingo. Ms. Newton lived abroad for 12 years. She performed recitals throughout France, and Iran under the auspices of the United States Information Service and appeared at Welsh National Opera, Hamburg Symphony, Landestheater Hanover, Staatstheater Graz, Stadttheater Kiel, and the Bath Festival (UK) among others. Norma grew up in Little Falls, New York, where she met her childhood sweetheart and future husband. She received her Bachelor Degree in Music from Syracuse University and her Master Degree in Music from The University of Texas. She was a Fulbright Scholar in Paris, a Metropolitan Opera Competition National Finalist in 1962 and was named Singer of the Year with the National Association of Teachers of Singing the same year. She won first place the Dealey competition in Dallas in 1961. She was a Distinguished Alumnus of Sigma Alpha Iota Music Sorority. Her son Christopher Newton, of Katy, Texas, daughter-in-law Jennifer and grandson, Jack survive her. She was preceded in death by her parents and, in 1986, by her beloved husband Robert ''Bob'' Newton. Norma has left behind friends and students too numerous to count. She made an indelible mark on the lives of many people with her style, beauty, patience, talent, humor and generosity. She will be greatly missed. A ceremony for the Life of Norma Newton will take place Sunday, November 16, 2008 at 4pm at the Newton Farm 151 Eyesaman Road, Little Falls, NY 13365-3846. For those who are unable to attend this ceremony, a more festive event will be planned to commemorate her inspirational life in New York City and in Houston.The dates for these celebrations will be determined in the next few months. In lieu of flowers or gifts, the family has requested that a tax deductible donation be made in her memory to: The George London Foundation for Singers, 460 West 49th Street Office, New York, NY 10019. NEWTON--Norma. The George London Foundation for Singers mourns the passing of its esteemed board member. She was admired and beloved by everyone and will be sorely missed. Our deepest condolences go to her family. Nora London, President

TITON--Milton M., 94, of Boynton Beach, FL, joined his beloved wife Teddy (nee Edith Lee Freed) on November 5, nearly two years after her death. For 35 years he had been an executive of Macy's, taking leave for duty during WWII. After retirement, he and Teddy, married for 66 years, traveled the world, always with tennis racquets. He played masterfully into his early nineties. He leaves a son, Jeff, of Providence, RI, a granddaughter, Emily, of Jamestown, RI and a sister, Ethel Sheifer, of Boca Raton, FL.

KANZAKI--Albert Tatsuo, of Bayside, NY, a retired Senior Executive at FujiFilm, USA passed away on November 6th, due to natural causes at age 90. Born in San Francisco, CA in 1918, he spent most of his life in the NYC area. His wife Hisae, his daughter Grace, sons Robert and Arthur, from a previous marriage to Yoneko Kanzaki, and his granddaughter Sarah, survives him. His stepdaughter Miki Matsuda and his sister Kaye and brother Stanley also survive him. Visitations will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York City, on Wednesday, November 12th from 2-4pm and 6-8pm. In lieu of flowers, please make your contributions to the Palliative Care Center, at the North Shore University Hospital.

SCHEERER--William II, died peacefully on November 4th, 2008, born in Orange, NJ on June 8th, 1923. Graduate from The Hill School and from Princeton University with the Class of 1945. Served as a Lieutenant in the Army in WWII. Loving and cherished father of Thomas Scheerer, Jane Parkes, Laura Whitney and Idoline Duke. Proud grandfather of Homer Parkes, Haley Parkes, Sophie Whitney, August Whitney, Eleanor Duke and William Angier Duke. A private family memorial will be held at a later date.

DINKIN--Irving. Beloved Dad, Grandfather, and GreatGrandfather, Irving Dinkin, 90, of Monroe Township, NJ, formerly of Queens, NY, died peacefully on October 19th, 2008. Irving was the son of Louis and Celia Dinkin. During WWII he was wounded in the South Pacific. After the war he started a service station and then worked as a foreman in the transistor industry. He loved golf, tennis, reading, bridge, opera, and most of all, his family. A selfless, loving man, he will be remembered dearly by his sons Larry, and his wife Eliane, and Larry's daughter Lisa, her husband Paul, and their son Rider; and Neil, his wife Karen and their daughter Clara; and Irv's brothers Milt and his wife Roslyn; and Robert; and by his nieces, nephews and friends. His dear wife, Irene, passed away two years ago. They both will be sorely missed.

THOROUGHGOOD--Alton Brooks Jr., passed away peacefully on October 13, 2008 in New York City after a valiant battle with brain cancer. Born in Philadelphia in 1939, Alton graduated from University of Pennsylvania in 1965 and California Western Law School in 1969. After his first wife Carolyn Cochrane passed on, Alton returned East with his two children. A believer in ''love at first site,'' he met Darlene Krier Paris in 1980 and embarked on a new life uniting the Paris and Thoroughgood families. Alton is survived by his beloved wife Darlene, children Alton Brooks III and Daisy Moschitto, step-sons Ricardo, John, and Jorge Paris and grandchildren. The family would like to offer their most sincere gratitude to the doctors and nurses of Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital for the outstanding medical care they provided.

SKAGGS--Merrill Maguire, died at dusk on Monday, November 3, at the age of 71, after a struggle with Waldenstroms Syndrome, a rare, chronic cancer of the immune system. A resident of Madison, NJ, for nearly 40 years, Merrill was the Baldwin Professor of Humanities at Drew University until retiring in May. Merrill specialized in American literature, with an emphasis on the writing of Willa Cather; served as the dean of the Drew Graduate School from 1986 to 1992; and was the author, co-author, or editor of nine books and the author of some fifty essays and articles on American Literature. Merrill was a member of the Society for Values in Higher Education, and served for many years on the board of the Willa Cather Foundation. She was a member of the Summit-Chatham Quaker Meeting, where her ashes will be interred. A public Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, November 23, 2008, at 2pm in the S.W. Bowne Great Hall at Drew University. She is survived by her daughter Sylvia Skaggs McTague; son Adam Skaggs; grandchildren Emma and Tara McTague; former husband Calvin Skaggs; sister Martha Worsley; and brother John Maguire. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a donation in her name to the Drew University Library Book Endowment in support of the American Literature Collection.

Address: 158 Hurlbutt Street The Property: A 1,700-square-foot colonial with four bedrooms, two full baths and an attached garage on half an acre. Built in 1924, the house has been redone; it has a new heating and cooling system, new windows, a well and a deck. The eat-in kitchen has black soapstone counters and high-quality cabinets. A side porch was converted to a family room.

McCURDY--Faith Higgins, 84, of Cold Spring Harbor, NY died peacefully at home on November 8, 2008. The cause of death was cancer. She is survived by three of her children, Ian, Sheila and Charles, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Her husband James A. McCurdy and daughter Hope Olmsted predeceased her. A memorial service is planned for 2:30pm, November 22 at Christ Church of Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The McCurdy Family Foundation to further Faith's commitment to the education and health of women and children. Foundation address: P.O. Box 206, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Game 5 Draws Well, but Series Sets Low for Viewers,'' Oct. 31: More than late starts, bad weather and the absence of big-market teams are to blame for the low World Series TV ratings. Long commercial breaks and more deliberate pitching added length to games. Pitchers are also more deliberate during Series games than during the regular season. Perhaps the rule setting a limit of 12 seconds between pitches should be enforced. Raymond Piccini

To the Editor: I read with exasperation ''Busted in the Park'' (New York Observed, Nov. 2), the account by a cyclist who was given a summons for riding in Central Park after 1 a.m. While the letter of the law was carried out by a zealous police officer, the spirit of the law was bypassed.

AMERICANS with long memories of electric vehicles will recall the brief flowering of the Think City, a plastic-bodied Norwegian-built battery car. Ford bought Think's parent company, then known as Pivco Industries, for $23 million in 1999, but the car did not sell as strongly as Ford had hoped, so the company sold out in 2003.
Art Nicolai Ouroussoff

SCHEUER--Richard Jonas, age 91, died November 7, 2008. Born July 14, 1917 in Long Lake, New York, he was a real estate and construction executive, who devoted much of his time to philanthropic work. He leaves his wife, Joan, his sons Daniel and Jonathan (Debra), his daughter Marian Sofaer (Abraham), and eleven grandchildren, Michael, Helen, Joseph, Aaron, Raphael, Benjamin, Adam, Simon, Matthew, Alexander and Hannah. His son, Richard Scheuer Jr. (Sylvia) died in 1996. Dick graduated from the Fieldston School and Harvard University, class of 1939, where he majored in classics. He later earned an M.A. at NYU in ancient history. During WWII, he enlisted and served as an officer in the Army Signal Corps in Italy. He served as Board Chair of the Jewish Museum, New York, helping to reinvigorate that institution. He was Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Hebrew Union College. With Moshe Safdie as architect, he took a lead role in building the expansion, of HUC's Jerusalem campus on King David Street, Jerusalem. The campus was featured in the Venice Biennale of 1991 as one of the architectural achievements of the period. He was active in archaeology for four decades, serving on the boards of the American Schools of Oriental Research and the Albright Institute of Archaeological Research. He funded important digs and archaeological publications. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek awarded him the highest tribute, Yakir Yerushalayim, for his many services to that city. As a longtime resident of Larchmont, New York, he helped build the local Democratic Party and served as Village Trustee. With Joan, he raced a 210 class sailboat on Long Island Sound, and spent many summers sailing the New England coast with family and friends. Funeral at Larchmont Temple, Monday, November 10, 2008 at noon. SCHEUER--Richard ''Dick'' J. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Dick Scheuer and extend sincere condolences to his family. Abraham B. Stenberg, President

As president, Mr. Obama could simply declare an end to practices that have been widely condemned as torture. He could revoke President Bush's executive order, disclosed in 2007, allowing the Central Intelligence Agency to use more severe interrogation techniques than allowed under the Army Field Manual. To do so, however, he would have to overrule at least some intelligence professionals who have argued that they need more aggressive methods.

KAMEN--Samuel E., M.D., August 17, 1912 -November 6, 2008. Loving and devoted husband of Cynthia, father of Margaret and Katherine; stepfather of Jodi and Jonathan; grandfather of Lydia, Charles and Nicholas. After being graduated from CCNY and the prestigious Berlin Medical School, Sam returned to New York in 1938 where he served a residence in Bellevue Hospital, specializing in radiology. He served with distinction as Captain in the Pacific area during World War II. On a beachhead in Okinawa, he witnessed the first Kamikaze raid -on a battleship. His versatility and resourcefulness was obvious, when he created a makeshift viewer on the beach by stringing x-rays of the wounded on a line, reading them with the aid of sunlight. After the war, Sam returned home and got married. The union produced two daughters, Meg and Kathy. Following the death of his first wife, Sam met and married the love of his life, Cynthia in 1954. With her he raised Jonathan and Jodi, ran a successful radiology practice in Brooklyn and headed the Department of Radiology at Sea View Hospital, Staten Island. There he made a significant contribution to the cure of Tuberculosis, then rampant in New York City. Additionally, he was medical director of the Midwood HIP Group in Brooklyn as well as Chief Radiologist of the outpatient VA Clinics in Brooklyn and Queens. Sam was a quiet scholar all his life engaging himself in biomedical research and developments in medical technology. He was an avid fan of Lincoln and his collection boasts a library of Civil war books and memorabilia. He lived a wonderful 96 years, earning the love, respect and admiration of his peers, both social and professional. His generosity of spirit made him a remarkable human being. His deeds and effortless compassion personified grace and goodness as he embraced life in all its aspects. He had the ability to relate to the world in a quiet, unassuming manner. His stature belied the giant he was in character and loving-kindness. After 55 years of a wonderfully happy marriage, his final words to Cynthia, spoken in a loud, clear voice were ''words cannot tell how much I have loved you.'' He showed the greatest of courage as her devoted companion and every effort he made for his family was with great commitment and enthusiasm. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 7205 West Atlantic Avenue, Delray Beach, FL 33446 on Sunday November 9 at 2:00pm. Graveside funeral follows at Beth Moses Cemetery, Long Island, NY on Monday November 10 at 2:00pm.

ATKIN--Edith Karlin. Born 1907; social worker and author. Died November 6th, 2008 peacefully at home surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Atkin, M.D.; step-mother of Adam (and Pearl) Atkin, June (and Kevin) Sanders. She had many loving nieces, nephews, grandchildren and wide a circle of friends.

SIEGELBAUM--Morton, died at the age of 93 on November 6, 2008. Loving husband of Blanche, father to Steve, Lewis, and Ellen, with six grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren, he was teacher to us all. He taught in the NYC school system until the cowards in the union purged its ranks of those who would not name names. He worked for the next forty years for a variety of electronics firms but retained the pedagogical urge and yen for political activism and debate. Until Alzheimer's did its cruel work, he remained optimistic and loved life. May all those who knew and loved him be comforted. Please donate to the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives jannitto@alba-valb.org

HIRSCH--Kathryn S. died peacefully surrounded by loving family on November 6, 2008. Born in New York City in 1921, daughter of Laurance W. and Martha M. Stern, she was a gem with many facets. A graduate of Mills College of Education and Adelphi University. Kay was a passionate lover and patron of the arts and consummate early childhood educator dedicated to young children and their families. Her curious intellect and joy in sharing life with those she loved enriched the world. She inspired many by the way she lived her values. Kay was deeply loved and will be greatly missed by her son, Robert B. Hirsch and her daughter, Elizabeth (Liz) B. Hirsch and their partners, Karen Hirsch and Karen Pratt, her grandchildren Phillip, Natalie and Ben, as well as her many friends and extended family. She is survived by her sister, Louise S. Graham. A service celebrating Kay's life will be held on Monday, November 10th at 10am at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue in White Plains.

Two images will forever stay in my mind to mark this epoch-breaking Election Day. One is that of Jesse Jackson's face, drenched in tears, in Chicago's Grant Park on Tuesday evening. And the other is a photo that ran in The Times on Wednesday. In it, a black mother and daughter sit on the floor of a church in Harlem. The mother, Latrice Barnes, having heard of Obama's victory, is doubled up in tears; her daughter, Jasmine, is reaching a tentative hand up to soothe her. To me, she looks like the future, reaching out to heal the past.

MARCH--Terry L. March. Founder and CEO of Midwood Securities, a Manhattan brokerage firm specializing in serving institutional investors, passed away November 6 at the age of 63. Mr. March balanced his successful professional career with dedicated service to his alma mater, Susquehanna University in Selinsgrove, PA. Mr. March served as chair of the Susquehanna University Board of Trustees until October 2008. Mr. March was born February 1, 1945 in Newport, PA to Pauline and Kenneth March, where he was raised and graduated from Newport High School in 1963. He graduated with a degree in accounting from Susquehanna University in 1967. His more than 30 year career in the financial services industry began as a staff accountant for Price Waterhouse & Co. He later became assistant controller at Dillon Read & Co. Inc., then a controller and vice president of Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. In 1982 he founded March & Thompson, a consulting and auditing firm in New York City. He sold the firm six years later and founded Midwood. He served as CEO until early 2008 when he appointed his son, Ed, to the post. Mr. March continued as Chairman of the Board at Midwood until his death. Mr. March was active in many industry, educational and community organizations. He was a member of the New York Stock Exchange and the New York area firms advisory committee of the NYSE board of directors. He chaired the Securities Industry Association's institutional brokerage committee and was a director of the Securities Industry Institute at the Wharton School. He was also a member of the USTA's Tennis and Education Foundation board, an equity owner of the Pacific Life Open at Indian Wells, CA, served on the Association of the Southampton Hospital, was a member of the Liberty Leads Advisory Board and was a member of the Council of Chairs of the Association of Governing Boards, a post through which he helped shape governance in higher education. Mr. March leaves his wife, Pauline Maurer March, whom he met in the fifth grade. Pauline was his partner in family, business and service. The Marches most recently made their home in East Greenville, PA, after having resided in Water Mill, NY for many years. In addition to his wife, Mr. March leaves his mother, Pauline; a son, Edward and his wife, Veronica; a daughter, Penelope March-Dole; and three grandchildren, Jonah, Savannah and Elizabeth Ann; a brother, Donald, and his wife, Patricia; a sister-inlaw, Doris Maurer and her husband Jerry Budzik; a brother-in-law Richard Mauer and his wife, Beth; several nieces and a nephew. Friends may call from 7 to 9pm on Monday, November 10 at the C.R. Strunk Funeral Home, 821 West Broad Street, Quakertown, PA and from 10 to 11am on Tuesday, November 11 at Trinity Great Swamp United Church of Christ in Spinnerstown, PA. Funeral services will be held Tuesday at 11am at the Trinity Great Swamp United Church of Christ in Spinnerstown, PA.

Shillady, a United Methodist minister, is to officiate. Dr. Shope, 50, is keeping her name. She is the daughter of Joan Collamer Shope and Glenn E. Shope of Topton, Pa.

As a senator, Mr. Obama supported comprehensive immigration overhaul, and in the campaign he pledged to enhance border security and provide a path to citizenship for millions in the country illegally. And while he said he favored a guest worker program, he also advocated tougher penalties for employing illegal immigrants. But Mr. Obama's proposals are likely to encounter resistance from opponents who contend that they amount to amnesty -- an argument that helped jettison a bill in Congress. And with the economy shedding jobs, opponents will also argue that immigrants are taking jobs from citizens. But experts say Mr. Obama will face pressure to act from the many Hispanic voters who supported his candidacy in part because of his stance on immigration. MICHAEL FALCONE

Mr. Obama initially raised expectations that he would meet with Iran's leaders; he said during the campaign that the notion of not talking to foes was ''ridiculous.'' Since then, he has tempered his words somewhat, indicating that he would send envoys initially and would meet personally with Iranian leaders only if he thought he could advance the American agenda. Mr. Obama also faces the issue of when to reach out. If he makes a move before June, when Iran's presidential election is scheduled, he risks giving President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad claim to a foreign policy victory, to the possible detriment of more moderate Iranian presidential aspirants. But if he waits too long, Iran could get closer to acquiring a nuclear weapon. HELENE COOPER

NEVIUS--Garrett Winder, 94, of Farmington, CT died peacefully November 6th. Beloved husband for 48 years of May Nevius, the former Mary Ellis Peltz. Father of Nancy Bacon, Christy Nevius, John Nevius, and Mary Lansing. Survived by his brother Peter. Preceded in death by his first wife Lowrie Flagg. Garrett was a direct descendant of 1652 Dutch settler Johannes Nevius, a Secretary of the City of New Amsterdam. He grew up in New York City, attended Collegiate School, Episcopal High School, Princeton University 1936, and Columbia Law School, 1939. A Lt. Colonel active in WWII, a lawyer and banker, Garrett had wit, charm, and sagacity. He loved the outdoors, and his summers on Sutton Island in Maine.

LUSTIG--Laurence, 91, of Florida and New York, died October 31, 2008 of a broken heart after the recent loss of his beloved wife, Harriet, having been married nearly seventy years. He is survived by his son, Jonathan, as well as by cherished relatives and good friends. Laurence and Harriet were snowbirds, spending a few months in New York before returning to their condo in Florida. In addition to the photography and art design from which he made a living, Laurence was a talented painter of awardwinning watercolors as well as a talented craftsman of museum quality carvings. He also helped furnish his home with hand-made furniture. Both Laurence and Harriet were excellent cooks who took pleasure in preparing special dinners for family and friends! In addition to a shared interest in good food, both were passionate about politics, reading, music--(until Laurence lost his hearing)--the theater, museums, nature, and travel. Both were daily fans of the New York Times and in Laurence's case, the crossword puzzle! While his wife remained loyal to the paper and pen, Laurence was an enthusiastic early computer hobbyist and one of the first to log on to AOL! He and his son emailed each other daily until shortly before his death! Laurence and Harriet took an active interest in community affairs, their church, and various book groups. They both had a good life filled with interesting people as well as interesting places and things. Laurence, speaking both for himself and his wife over a year ago, knowing that the curtain was beginning to descend said--''We had a good life; we have no regrets.'' There will be a private graveside service in March. In lieu of flowers, please support your local library and consider a contribution to HEIFER International (www.heife.org).

CROSS--Charles T., a retired career diplomat and former ambassador, died on November 2. Born in Beijing in 1922 of missionary parents, in 1943 he was assigned to the 23rd Marines, 4th Marine Division, as intelligence officer and Japanese Interpreter for all the division's landings. Foreign Service included Ambassador to Singapore, Consul General in Hong Kong, first Director of American Institute in Taiwan. His memoir, ''Born a Foreigner'', was published in l999. Cross is survived by Shirley, his beloved wife of 62 years, three children, seven grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren.

ROWE--George Whitney died on the morning of November 5, 2008, as a result of complications following surgery at the age of 67. He is survived by Kate Munson Rowe, his loving wife of 44 years; by his daughter and son-in-law Nina and Charles Ward; by his son and daughter-in-law Will and Happy Rowe; by four grandchildren Charlie, Kate and Nick Ward, and George Rowe II; and by his three sisters Nancy Conner, Jennifer Rose and Whitney Long. George was born in Cincinnati, OH and attended St. Paul's School (1958) and Harvard (1962). Immediately after college, he joined JP Morgan & Co. where he worked for over 40 years, serving as a Managing Director in New York, London and San Francisco. With the formation of JP Morgan California in San Francisco in 1990, he served as its President. In 1999, he retired but served for several more years as a senior advisor to the firm. George was an active participant in civic life. At the time of his death, he was on the Boards of the College Access Foundation of California, Dominican University of California, Episcopal Charities, Garden Conservancy, St. James Community Learning Center, Prout's Neck Country Club, and United States Seniors' Golf Association. Formerly, he served as a Trustee of the San Francisco Ballet, Commonwealth Club of San Francisco, California Historical Society, Timken Museum of Art in San Diego, Center for the Arts at Yerba Buena Garden, and as President of the San Francisco Bay Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America. While living in New York, he was a Trustee of the Boys Club of New York, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, and the Lincoln Center Fund. He was a member of the Cypress Point Club, The PacificUnion Club, the San Francisco Golf Club, and the Prout's Neck Country Club. George will be fondly remembered for his ready smile and positive spirit. Always quick to put others at ease, he had many friends who turned to him often for steady support, wise counsel, and good fun. Whether on the golf course, in a sailboat, at a meeting of fellow Board members or even at grandparents' day, he was always passionate, committed and generous. His life touched many, and we all will miss him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either Episcopal Charities or St. James Community Learning Center. A memorial service will be held at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco, CA at 2pm on Thursday, November 13th.
