ULSTRUP--Jane B. Cumberland, ME. Jane Burr Ulstrup died at home on November 3rd after recently celebrating her 79th birthday. She was born in St. Paul, MN on October 23, 1929. She attended the Summit School in St. Paul, the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, NY, and graduated from Wells College in Aurora, NY. Jane married John D. Lind in 1951, and they lived in New York City where they raised their three children. Jane worked as a volunteer for the Museum of Natural History and the New York Public Library. In 1969, she married Carl C. Ulstrup, a civil engineer who specialized in designing long-span suspension bridges. When Carl retired in 1992, they moved to Cumberland, ME. Jane is survived by her daughter Melissa Libby and her husband Lowell of Portland, ME; her daughter Kate Geoffroy and her husband Mark of Cumberland, ME; her son Tony Lind and his wife MaryJo of Chatham, NJ; her brother George Burr and and his wife Barbara of Brunswick, ME; and six grandchildren. The family is planning a memorial celebration at a later date. So, for now, ''Good bye Lambchop!'' Memorial donations may be sent to the Nature Conservancy of Maine, 14 Maine Street Suite 401, Brunswick, Maine 04011.

Mr. Obama has said repeatedly that he would set a 16-month timetable for troop withdrawal. Some military experts believe that could lead to a reversal of the gains from the surge in troops over the past 18 months, and they argue that the generals running the war should decide how many troops to pull out and when to do it. Mr. Obama appears to have the Iraqi government on his side. Iraqi leaders say his timetable is closer to theirs, which they put at 2010. The Bush administration timetable, which has some wiggle room, is 2011.

The best parties of Election Night were freebies in Times Square and Rockefeller Center, where the vote was tallied in red and blue lights. The weather was warm and the sidewalks and outdoor cafes were jammed with waiting people. At 11, the crowds, realizing that Barack Obama had won, erupted in jubilation. The euphoria continued into the next morning's rush hour. Coffee-cart vendors waved front pages and people scrambled to find copies of their own, tangible proof. But the fashion mood that morning was roll-up-your-sleeves-and-get-to work: an overnight outbreak of trousers and knee-length skirts.

VAAMONDE--Joseph H., 85, passed away in Seattle, WA, on October 30th after a long illness. Born in New York City, Joseph grew up in Puerto Rico and New York. He was an advertising executive for Young & Rubicam, where he opened the Puerto Rico office in 1956 and became vice president and general manager of the Mexico City branch. He later became vice president of marketing for General Cigar Company. In 1979, he co-founded Hispanic advertising agency Font & Vaamonde Associates. As voters streamed to the polls, stocks jumped in their strongest Election Day rally in 24 years, with key indexes up more than 3 percent. Behind the News The economy was the driving issue of the election. In exit polls, 6 in 10 voters chose the economy as the most important issue; most of them voted for Barack Obama. Wall Street historically has enjoyed a bounce in the fourth quarter after a presidential election. But some analysts ascribed the rally more to interest rate cuts, a thaw in credit markets and a growing resiliency of the markets to bad news. ''We don't know if it's the end of the bear market yet, but it looks as though the bear has taken a nap,'' said one analyst. So much for the Election Day rally. The bear woke up. Stocks erased all of their gains, with key indexes falling more than 5 percent. Behind the News The selling began early, after a report showed that activity at the nation's service industries contracted in October, falling at the fastest pace since records began in 1997. Several major businesses reported disappointing earnings; there were also concerns about rising unemployment. Still, some analysts said that after weeks of extreme volatility, Wall Street appeared finally to be reacting predictably to bad news. Perhaps a return to stability was at hand. ''Markets are moving in a more orderly way,'' said one analyst.

HOWE--Edwin A. (Brick) Jr., of Ticonderoga, NY (formerly of Westport, CT and Garden City, NY) died on November 3rd at the age of sixtynine. Mr. Howe, a practicing lawyer for over 40 years, first in New York City and then in Ticonderoga, was also active in many civic and charitable affairs in all the communities where he lived. Mr. Howe was born in Cleveland, OH, on January 21, 1939, to Edwin A. Howe and the former Helen Dorothy Beck. He attended University School, graduated from Yale in 1961, and was awarded an honors degree in law by The University of Michigan Law School in 1964. He also conducted post-graduate studies in law at the London School of Economics. In law school, he was an editor of The University of Michigan Law Review and was awarded the Jason L. Honigman Prize for his accomplishments in that position. He was a member of the Bar of New York State and of the United States Supreme Court. After serving six years at Debevoise & Plimpton LLP, Mr. Howe co-founded the international law firm of Sann & Howe (subsequently Howe & Addington LLP) in New York City in 1970, serving it as a Partner through 1989 and then as Senior Partner for ten years until he became Senior Counsel. In 2004, Mr. Howe joined the Ticonderoga law firm Viscardi Howe & Rudgers LLP. Mr. Howe was also a member of The Counselors of Real Estate and the National Real Estate Forum, which he served as chair and then as Executive Director. A source of particular pride to him was his selection as a Fellow of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Margaret, his three children Christopher, Melissa, and Katie, his son-in-law, Chris Miller, and his two grandchildren, Julia and Beck. Mr. Howe expressed the hope that, if he should end up, spiritually speaking, ''somewhere'' after death, it would be in Ticonderoga and or a place where he could continue to enjoy his memories of Ticonderoga and perhaps even follow the continued activities and progress of its citizens. Anyone wishing to sustain his shade in that endeavor may do so via contribution to Ticonderoga Main Street Partnership, Inc., PO Box 379, Ticonderoga, NY 12883-0379.

The next-door neighbor in my apartment building either hates music or goes to bed at 5:30 p.m. She knocked on my door for the first time at 8 p.m. on a Friday to ask me to turn down the bass. The other day, she resorted to slipping a note beneath my door. I am trying to be nice, so I wrote, ''Sorry'' on her note and slipped it back to her. But I am becoming fed up with her complaints. I am even tempted to drop a pair of ear plugs into her mailbox. Is it outrageous for her to request a lower volume in the early evening?

If Butch Davis was trying to downplay a report out of Knoxville, Tenn., that he was No. 1 on Tennessee's wish list to be its football coach next season, he did little to dismiss the possibility on Sunday. Updated, 11 p.m. | On Election Day, the actor Tim Robbins obtained a court order from a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan directing the Board of Elections to allow him to vote. The bankruptcy filing by Circuit City is unwelcome news to the world's consumer electronics companies. They like retailers that compete against one another -- and that they can play against one another. But in the last few years, the number of financially viable electronics retailers has been dropping.

There are so many reasons to be sad about the passing of the brilliant South African chanteuse Miriam Makeba. Though she was known as a "protest singer," her signature song, "Pata Pata," was more of a rump-shaker than an overt indictment of the sicko regime ruling her country at the time. We'll let others do the heavy lifting on singing Makeba's full praises, and simply take a moment here to bask in the joy of her style. From African headdresses and shoulder-padded caftans, to this very right-now dashiki minidress and go-go boots, Mama Africa's 76-year-old heart may have given out as she was exiting a stage near Naples, Italy, last night, but her look -- and the spirit that inspired it -- keep on keeping on.

One thing is certain about President Bush's scheduled appearance in Manhattan on Tuesday: There will be no "Mission Accomplished" banner in sight. Mr. Bush is due at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum on the West Side of Manhattan for a Veterans Day celebration. The White House plan calls for him to arrive by helicopter on the flight deck of the decommissioned aircraft carrier that houses the museum. For some in this heavily Democratic city, that entrance may evoke memories of Mr. Bush's appearance in 2003 aboard the U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln with a sign proclaiming "Mission Accomplished" as a backdrop, an event often cited by his critics and a comic staple on programs like "The Daily Show," which is taped a couple of blocks from the Intrepid. (Mr. Bush later contended that the message referred to the ship's most recent mission, not the war in Iraq.)

Lexicon | "Derangement syndrome" lived uneventfully as a medical coinage until the conservative columnist Charles Krauthammer, a psychiatrist, came up with Bush Derangement Syndrome in 2003 to refer to what he saw as irrational loathing of the President. Would You Buy These Weird Bulbs? Within the next several months, several of the world's biggest lighting companies, including Osram Sylvania and Philips, will introduce LED replacement bulbs to various world markets, including the United States. While the bulbs will be praised for their energy-saving characteristics and long lives, most consumers will immediately think, ''These things look weird.''

O'GARA--Brother Andrew, FSC died Saturday, November 8, in the community residence at Christian Brothers Academy, Lincroft, NJ. Brother Andrew, 80, had become the first President of Christian Brothers Academy in 1991, a position he held until his death. Prior to that appointment, Brother Andrew had been principal of CBA since 1979. A native of the Bronx, John O'Gara left home to study at the Christian Brothers junior novitiate in Barrytown, New York. In 1946 he received the habit of the Brothers of the Christian Schools and the religious name Brother Andrew of Mary. After studies at Catholic University and Manhattan College, Brother Andrew served as teacher and administrator at La Salle Academy, NYC and Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY. In 1966, he was appointed principal of St. Raymond Boys High School in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, a post he held for 13 years prior to his assignment at CBA where he spent the last three decades of his career. The son of the late Conal and Catherine O'Gara, Brother Andrew was preceded in death by a sister, Sr. Mary Theresa O'Gara, SMR. He is survived by his brother James (Barbara) O'Gara and his sister Catherine (John) Callahan. Eight nieces and nephews, 10 grandnieces and nephews also survive, as do legions of admiring alumni from the schools where he served. Brother Andrew's viewing will be at Christian Brothers Academy, Lincroft, on Tuesday, November 11th from 4:00pm to 8:00pm and Wednesday, November 12th from 4:00pm to 8:00pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated for Brother Andrew on Thursday, November 13th at 10:00am in the McKay Gymnasium at Christian Brothers. Interment will follow at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Marlboro, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Brother Andrew Scholarship Fund at CBA. For any further information contact Higgins Memorial Home, Freehold, NJ.

MILLSTONE--Robert. Cherished father and grandfather, on November 6, 2008 in Naples, FL. To Susan, our son-in-law David and daughter Jennifer, and to Ken, we send heartfelt condolences. We cherish the times we had, and the granddaughter we share. Ronnie and Sam Heyman

Decontee Williams was so excited by Barack Obama's victory on Tuesday night that she started jumping up and down -- and went into labor. Twelve hours later, Barack Jeilah was born at Phoenix Baptist Hospital to Ms. Williams and Prince Jeilah. The baby was 8 pounds 9 ounces and had a full head of hair. ''I love Barack Obama, and I love the name,'' said Ms. Williams, 31, who came to the United States as a refugee from Liberia in 2003. ''In Africa, we call it a blessing. That is a good name.''

WORKMAN--Susan Williams, 72, passed away peacefully at her Florida residence on November 3rd. A Vassar graduate, she was an avid gardener, interior designer, loved to travel and adored all animals, especially her dogs. Beloved widow of David Thorpe Workman, she is survived by her daughters Betsy and Cindy, her brother James DeWolfe Williams and his wife Susan, her brother-in-law Peter Workman and his wife Carolan, her nieces and nephews and their children, as well as her treasured dogs Buddy and Homer. Funeral services will be held Monday, November 10th at 11:30am at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., in Manhattan. Memorial contributions may be sent in memory of Sue Workman to The Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation or The David T. Workman Award Endowment at 1249 Fifth Ave., Suite 907, NY, NY 10029.

Mayor Michael R. Bloombergwill present the 2008 Mayor's Awards for Arts and Culture Monday night at the Apollo Theater, where he will honor six individuals and organizations for their contributions to New York City's cultural life. This year's winners include the Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York, which provides assistance to more than 330 theater companies; the dancer and choreographer Arthur Aviles; and the Rush Arts Gallery & Resource Center and the Corridor Gallery, which present the work of emerging and underrepresented artists. Mr. Bloomberg will also present the Handel Medallion, the city's highest award for achievement in the arts, to Neil Simon. The medallion has been presented sporadically and at the mayor's discretion since 1959; this will be the first time Mr. Bloomberg has presented one. Vanessa Williams (''Ugly Betty'') is the host for the event, which will feature performances by the Queens Jazz Orchestra, an American Sign Language poetry troupe and cast members from ''Hair.''

This week, the novelist Jonathan Lethem reviews ''2666,'' the posthumously published novel by Roberto Bola√±o, left, a Chilean writer who lived in exile, and died at 50 in 2003. ''2666'' is not only a capstone to Bola√±o's ambition, but also a landmark for the novel form in a post-national world, Mr. Lethem writes. Also, Motoko Rich with Notes from the Field, Julie Just on children's books (with a slide show of notable children's book illustrations) and best-seller news from Jennifer Schuessler. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. nytimes.com/books

President-elect Barack Obama is poised to move swiftly to reverse actions that President Bush took using executive authority, and his transition team is reviewing limits on stem cell research and the expansion of oil and gas drilling, among other issues, members of the team said Sunday. As Mr. Obama prepared to make his first post-election visit to the White House on Monday, his advisers were compiling a list of policies that could be reversed by the executive powers of the new president. The assessment is under way, aides said, but a full list of policies to be overturned will not be announced by Mr. Obama until he confers with new members of his cabinet.

SCHEUER--Richard J. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion family records with profound sorrow the death of our beloved Dick Sheuer, Chair Emeritus. Dick had an extraordinary love and loyalty for HUC-JIR, for the state of Israel and the Jewish people, combined with a deep knowledge and appreciation for biblical archeology and history. His was the vision for our Jerusalem campus. The Scheuer name is synonymous with the College for nearly a century. His dedication and that of his family's is an inspiration. Our heartfelt condolences to his devoted wife, Joan, their children and grandchildren. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David Ellenson, President Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Emeritus Barbara Friedman, Chair, Board of Governors SCHEUER--Richard Jonas age 91. Passionate supporter of art, archaeology and architecture. He was kind, wise, modest and generous. His greatest joy was his 62 year marriage to Joan. His zest for life and for quietly helping others inspires his eleven grandchildren. Funeral today at noon, Larchmont Temple.

ATKIND--Leon, 93, passed away on November 7, at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, NJ. He was born in Paterson, NJ, the son of the late Abraham and Mina Atkind. He resided in Clifton, NJ. He was an entrepreneur who founded Leonardo Strassi Knitwear and NBO Menswear with 25 stores. He is survived by his loving wife Belle nee Sharp and his five children, his daughter Lois Harner and his son David and his three stepsons Glenn, Sandy and Todd Greenberg. He also left behind 39 grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his grandson Russell Atkind. Chapel services were held Sunday November 9th at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton with interment following at the King Solomon Cemetery in Clifton. In lieu of Shiva gifts or flowers, the family kindly asks that memorial donations in Leon's memory be made to the Russell Atkind Memorial Philanthropic Fund, Jewish Community Foundation of Metro west NJ, Whippany, NJ 973-929-3000 or the Hebrew Free Loan Program, Jewish Family Service of Metro west, Florham Park, NJ.

GARONZIK--Fredric B., 66, on November 8, 2008. Beloved husband of Anne, father of David and Sam, brother of Neal. Rick had many loving cousins and nephews. He was born in Gloversville, New York to the late Ruth and Harold and attended Gloversville public schools before matriculating at Deerfield Academy, from which he graduated in 1960. He received an A.B. degree in political science from Brown University in 1964. After receiving his degree, he worked for a year for the Superb Glove Company of Johnstown, New York, then attended the Wharton School, where he received his M.B.A. in 1967. He worked for Grey Advertising as an account executive before moving to the financial services industry, joining Goldman, Sachs & Co. in 1972, where he had a long and distinguished career in New York and London. He was made a General Partner of Goldman, Sachs in 1984 and retired in 1998 as co-head of the Fixed Income Currency and Commodities Division. Rick was a trustee of Brown University, and headed its Investment Committee. Over the years, he served on the boards of the Union Settlement Association, the American Federation for Aging Research and The Buckley School. Rick enjoyed outdoor sports of all kinds, particularly golf. His greatest and most obvious pleasure, however, was enjoying time with his family, who will miss him always. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, November 13, 2008 at 11am at The Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Fredric B. Garonzik Memorial Fund at Brown University, Box 1893, Providence, Rhode Island 02912-1893.

So now the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac say they are going to institute a mortgage modification program. Well, good for them. Announced this afternoon, the plan calls for struggling homeowners with mortgages held by Fannie and Freddie to have their payments reduced to 38 percent of their gross income through a combination of interest rate reductions, principle reductions and longer repayment terms. This comes on the heels of Citigroup's announcement on Monday that it would undertake a mortgage modification program, which came on the heels of a similar announcement last week from JPMorgan Chase, which came on the heels of Countrywide's announcement, and so on.

Sigi Schmid, who took the Columbus Crew from last place in Major League soccer three years ago to the Supporters Shield this season, has been named M.L.S. coach of the year Tuesday. He won the award in 1999, as coach of the L.A. Galaxy, and is only the second coach to win the award more than once. Bob Bradley, the U.S. men's national team coach, won the award in 1998 when he coached the Chicago Fire and in 2006 as coach of Chivas USA. The Maldives, a tenuous chain of 1,200 islets southwest of Sri Lanka best known for its spectacular reef-rimmed lagoons, is considered one of the world's most vulnerable countries in the face of rising sea levels in a warming world. I have a short article in today's paper on how the Maldives, under its first democratically elected president, will establish what amounts to a global warming relocation fund using revenue from tourism. The idea would be to buy land elsewhere as a new home for the country's 400,000 citizens should the worst-case scenarios play out.

Updated, 4:52 p.m. | Just as Social Security has been described as the third rail of federal politics, imposing tolls on the East River bridges -- an idea that has again been revived as the Bloomberg administration seeks to plug a growing budget deficit -- is the third rail of New York City politics. A ride through The Times's archives shows that the debate over bridge tolls has gone on for decades, going back further than Social Security itself.On numerous occasions, politicians have tried to reinstitute tolls on the four bridges -- the Brooklyn (completed in 1883), Williamsburg (completed in 1903) and Manhattan and Queensboro (both completed in 1909). After all, the Brooklyn Bridge charged horse-drawn carriages a toll from the time it opened. But by the Depression, the tolls were a thing of the past.

In the city that never sleeps, a Manhattan hospital has opened New York's first round-the-clock health clinic, hoping to capitalize on its many night owls, workaholics and insomniacs. Some other cities with late-night cultures, like Las Vegas, have 24-hour clinics meant to be quicker and cheaper alternatives to hospital emergency rooms for urgent matters like stitching up cuts or treating heat stroke. In Temecula, a California town whose top employer is the nearby Pechanga Resort and Casino, a former Navy medic opened an all-night operation 14 months ago with physician's assistants and nurse practitioners handling fevers, earaches, migraines and eye infections.

GERTEL--Leon M.D., passed away in New York City on November 9, 2008 at 95 from Parkinson's Disease. He always maintained his warm smile, bright eyes and sparkling personality. Survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Cecile Mayer Gertel and adoring sister, Leonia Nussbaum; missed by his adoring children, Elisa Gertel Barsky and Carl Barsky, Shereen Gertel Rutman and Howard Rutman as well as grandchildren, Samuel, Deborah and Naphtali Barsky and Melissa and Stephen Rutman. He was also very close to his sister-in-law and brother-in-law and his late siblings, as well as many nieces and nephews and their children. Dr. Gertel studied at the Jagellonian University in Krakow and received dental and medical degrees from the University of Munich. A leader of the post-liberation Jewish students' union, he remained active in the Munich University Jewish Alumni Association. After completing his internal medicine and psychiatric training in the United States, Dr. Gertel served as the Medical Director for Mental Health Services at the Catholic Diocese of Central New Jersey and maintained an active private psychiatry practice in East Brunswick. He was treasured by his patients and beloved by his colleagues. In his long psychiatric career, Dr. Gertel provided balance, judgment, wisdom and insight. His kind heart, keen intelligence, warmth and positive outlook throughout his life serves as an inspiration to all who knew him. Funeral services will be on Tuesday, November 11, at 10:30am at Plaza Memorial Chapels, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street and shiva will be at the Rutman and Barsky homes.

GARONZIK--Fredric B., 66, on November 8, 2008. Beloved husband of Anne, father of David and Sam, brother of Neal. Rick had many loving cousins and nephews. He was born in Gloversville, New York to the late Ruth and Harold and attended Gloversville public schools before matriculating at Deerfield Academy, from which he graduated in 1960. He received an A.B. degree in political science from Brown University in 1964. After receiving his degree, he worked for a year for the Superb Glove Company of Johnstown, New York, then attended the Wharton School, where he received his M.B.A. in 1967. He worked for Grey Advertising as an account executive before moving to the financial services industry, joining Goldman, Sachs & Co. in 1972, where he had a long and distinguished career in New York and London. He was made a General Partner of Goldman, Sachs in 1984 and retired in 1998 as co-head of the Fixed Income Currency and Commodities Division. Rick was a trustee of Brown University, and headed its Investment Committee. Over the years, he served on the boards of the Union Settlement Association, the American Federation for Aging Research and The Buckley School. Rick enjoyed outdoor sports of all kinds, particularly golf. His greatest and most obvious pleasure, however, was enjoying time with his family, who will miss him always. The family will receive friends at The Colony Club 564 Park Ave at 62nd St. on Wednesday November 12th from 5-8pm. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, November 13, 2008 at 11am at The Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Fredric B. Garonzik Memorial Fund at Brown University, Box 1893, Providence, Rhode Island 02912-1893. GARONZIK--Fredric B. DNA contains the genetic blueprint for all human cells, but the reading and execution of the blueprint inside each cell is controlled in part by chemical markers attached to the DNA. Scientists have begun to map some of these epigenetic markers, including CpG methylation. CpG Manipulation DNA is a code written with four letters: A, T, C and G, each standing for one nucleotide. In CpG methylation, a small marker called a methyl group attaches to the DNA at a CpG site, where a C and a G nucelotide sit next to each other.

Could the subprime mortgage crisis spread West Nile virus? Unlikely as it sounds, this may be just what happened in Bakersfield, Calif. 9 P.M. (13), 10 P.M. (49) BOOGIE MAN: THE LEE ATWATER STORY They called him the happy hatchet man and the Darth Vader of the Republican Party. In 1989, after masterminding the presidential victory of George H. W. Bush over Michael Dukakis -- including the infamous Willie Horton ad -- Lee Atwater (above right, mugging with Mr. Bush) was the political equivalent of a rock star, basking in the limelight of his new role as chairman of the Republican National Committee and mentoring political operatives like Karl Rove. Two years later Mr. Atwater died of a brain tumor at 41, but not before apologizing for some of his tactics. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis called this ''Frontline'' documentary about his rise and fall ''generous in spirit and nimble in technique.'' 9 A.M. My Thursday column is about education, and reflects my concern that Obama may put education on the back burner in terms of his priorities for the next couple of years. To me, education is intimately connected with other national concerns, from reviving economic growth to reducing income inequality to developing the kind of labor force that can pioneer green technologies. And it also strikes me as profoundly unfair that as a nation we provide good public educations to white children in the suburbs while providing a wretched public education to underprivileged kids in the central cities; the education system reinforces the central divides in our country, rather than undermining them. I'd welcome your comments both on whether education should be a higher priority and what steps we should take to improve it (including who should be secretary of education). But I've closed comments here because comments will be taken beside the column itself. Here's the link to comment.

Aside from the former Deutsche Bank building at 130 Liberty Street, no structural victim of 9/11 better epitomizes the paralysis induced by conflicting agendas than Fiterman Hall, the classroom and office building of the Borough of Manhattan Community College at 30 West Broadway. It has been standing -- damaged and abandoned -- since 9/11. Just about everyone with any say in the site has had a different idea of how to proceed and who should pay for it.As a result, little has happened except for the decontamination of the 15-story structure, immediately north of the landscaped park in front of the new 7 World Trade Center office tower. A replacement building, also to be named Fiterman Hall, has been designed by Pei Cobb Freed & Partners.

I live in a rent-stabilized apartment where I am about to receive a renewal lease. I was once late with the rent check, and the landlord placed a late fee on my next rental bill. Since my lease contract does not provide for imposing a late fee, is it legal for a landlord to do this? If my renewal lease has this included as a rider or handwritten note, is it legal? My original lease did not have this as a term of the agreement.

The theater's heavy reliance on revivals sometimes feels like a steady diet of disillusionment. Plays that seemed risky and fresh a couple of decades ago can seem tame, lame or seriously stale when they're dusted off and remounted today. For firm evidence, see most of the revivals on Broadway this fall. Not so with ''Streamers,'' David Rabe's 1976 drama about the tensions among a group of soldiers contemplating the looming shadow of the escalating Vietnam War. Despite the clarity of the new Roundabout Theater Company production that opened on Tuesday night at the Laura Pels Theater, crisply directed by Scott Ellis, this simmering stew of class and race, sex and violence still seems mighty strange.

LANE--Jordan I . Devoted husband. Beloved father. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. This WWII veteran will be remembered by all for his strong faith, sharp wit and soft heart. PANTIRER--Murray , died peacefully November 7th surrounded by his wife and children. Murray was born on June 15th, 1925 in Krakow, Poland. Of a family of nine, he was the sole survivor of the Holocaust, saved by Oskar Schindler when he was placed on Schindler's List. He immigrated to the United States in 1948 with his wife Louise. With no money and no knowledge of English, he became a successful real estate developer who honored Schindler's deeds and named numerous streets after him. He eagerly supported Holocaust awareness through charity and public speaking. He was a founding member of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, DC, and was appointed to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum Council by both President Ronald Reagan and President George Bush, Sr. He was the founding president of the Holocaust Resource Foundation at Kean University, in New Jersey, where he was awarded an honorary doctorate degree. He was president of the Jewish Education Center of Elizabeth, New Jersey. Murray loved and supported the State of Israel, and also received the Elie Wiesel Remembrance Award for the State of Israel Bonds. He sat on the boards of many philanthropic organizations and educational institutions. He was a fundraiser and a community leader. He loved America and considered it an honor and a privilege to be a U.S. Citizen. He was an avid New York Rangers and Brooklyn Dodgers fan. Murray epitomized the American Dream. He is survived by his wife of 61 years Louise, son Larry and daughter-in-law Nancy, daughter Betty and son-in-law Howard, daughter Elisa and son-in-law Alan, his nine grandchildren, their two spouses and three greatgrandchildren. His wisdom, generosity, and kindness touched the lives of many and he was an inspiration to all those who knew him. His family and his community miss him dearly. PANTIRER--Murray. The officers and staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn with sorrow the passing of Murray Pantirer, a great leader of Holocaust remembrance and education. Murray was one of the courageous survivors of ''Schindler's List''. A fervent supporter of Israel and its economic development, he was a key leader of the Israel Bonds Elie Wiesel Holocaust Remembrance Dinner and a distinguished honoree. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Lucy, son Larry and daughters Elisa Pines and Betty Schwartz. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Joshua Matza, President & CEO Michael Siegal, Chairman of the Board David Halpern, National Chairman

In the general European euphoria over the election of Barack Obama, there is the beginning of self-reflection about Europe's own troubles with racial integration. Many are asking if there could be a French, British, German or Italian Obama, and everyone knows the answer is no, not anytime soon. It is risky to make racial comparisons between America and Europe, given all the historical and cultural differences. But race had long been one reason that Europeans, harking back to the days when famous American blacks like Josephine Baker and James Baldwin found solace in France, looked down on the United States, even as Europe developed postcolonial racial problems of its own.

It took just one day after the presidential race for the Democratic National Committee to issue a memorandum claiming some credit on behalf of its party chairman, Howard Dean, for the election of Barack Obama. The memorandum asserted that Mr. Obama's sweeping victory was, at least partly, the fruit of Mr. Dean's signature strategy to spend the money to establish a Democratic presence in all 50 states. Mr. Dean's interest in making this argument is understandable. The 50-state strategy was applauded by state party chairmen and chairwomen -- who welcomed the influx of Democratic National Committee money that allowed them to hire staff members in their states, but it was strongly criticized by Democratic Congressional leaders in 2006. With the party poised to make big gains, they wanted Mr. Dean to help finance the hard-fought midterm elections. Mr. Dean refused, engaging in some nasty, public fights with party leaders, who accused him of being stubborn and politically reckless.

Being considered for: A senior Defense Department position or national security adviser. Would bring to the job: Legal training, along with years of experience in the nuts and bolts of Pentagon management, in particular personnel issues and how to organize, train and equip the Navy and the Marine Corps. Nascar may reduce or eliminate testing sessions that can cost top stock-car racing teams as much as $100,000 a day as it looks at ways to cut expenses amid lower corporate and consumer spending. It would not consider dropping events from its 36-race Sprint Cup Series or shortening races, Brian France, Nascar's chief executive officer, said. Testing sessions help Nascar teams prepare for races by allowing them to run laps, making changes to a car's chassis and gauging how it responds on the track.

A probationary New York City firefighter who collapsed during training exercises on Randalls Island died on Tuesday, Fire Department officials said. The firefighter, Jamel M. Sears, 33, a lifelong resident of the Bronx, collapsed at 11:30 on Monday morning after completing an 18-minute training exercise. He was in full gear at the time, fire officials said.

LEWIS--Elaine , of Flushing, NY, passed away peacefully with her family at her side. She is survived by her loving children, Bennett Lewis, Shari Lewis-Veltre and Thomas Veltre; her adoring brother, Howard Rinkoff and her cherished grandson Paul Veltre. Services will take place today at 10am at Temple Beth Sholom of Flushing, NY.

Forty pounds might seem expensive for a postcard. But what if the postcard turns out to be an original work of art by the likes of Anish Kapoor, Yoko Ono, Olafur Eliasson, Tracey Emin, or Paula Rego? An annual fund-raising event at London's Royal College of Art, "RCA Secret," gives people the chance to spot the work of famous artists among 2,7000 works on postcards that are for sale. With a good eye and some patience, you may just get an incredible bargain.

The carnage occupies only a fraction of a second of a chase scene with a Humvee and a Ferrari in the 1996 film "The Rock."

The City Council overwhelmingly approved two redevelopment plans that together will provide thousands of new housing units for low- and moderate-income families and senior citizens in Queens. The projects - Willets Point, in what is now a neglected industrial triangle near Shea Stadium, and Hunters Point South, along the waterfront in Long Island City - will offer nearly 4,000 homes to families that make $99,800 a year or less, with 800 units in Willets Point reserved to families with an annual income of less than $38,000.

The Wall Street Journal reports today that its poll of economists showed a consensus that the recession would end by mid-2009. They think that the current quarter will be down sharply, at a 3 percent annual rate, and that there will be a lesser decline in the first quarter of 2009. The second quarter is expected to be up at an annual rate of 0.3 percent, and solid growth will be back in the second half of the year.
A controversy rages in Southern California hockey, where selected Kings and Ducks games have been televised by Fox Sports West and Fox Sports Prime Ticket in what TV executives call "rinkside view."

Several groups, I wrote, such and the Families and Work Institute and momsrising.org were working to bring those issues to the forefront and encourage parents to think of themselves as a voting bloc.
Since the critic and former Book Review editor John Leonard died last week, the eulogies and encomia have been piling up. Talk about a life that got good reviews.

Roosevelt Drive was shut down from about 10:25 to 11 a.m. on Thursday so that President Bush could get from the downtown heliport to the United Nations, the video screens at the newly opened Joint Traffic Management Center in Long Island City, Queens, showed the unusual sight of a city roadway absolutely free of traffic.

Fifty-two percent said they would have backed the former Democratic candidate; 41 percent would have voted for McCain, wider than Obama's 7-point margin over McCain," reports Vaughan Ververs of CBS News.

Inside his gently bobbing houseboat in the World's Fair Marina in Queens, George Anton builds other boats: an array of historical ships that includes a 15th-century Spanish galleon, a 12th-century Chinese war junk, and various clipper ships, racing ships and viking ships.

Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said that he would allow a bill requiring a public referendum on the extension of New York City term limits to go through the normal legislative process. Mr. Silver made clear, however, that he was not necessarily endorsing the legislation, which was sponsored by Assemblyman Hakeem S. Jeffries. The bill would require that any municipality with term limits hold a public referendum before making any changes that would affect how long elected officials can serve. That bill follows a vote last month by the City Council that altered the city's term-limit law, which was enacted after two public referendums. The bill, which was championed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, would allow the mayor and other city officials to seek a third, four-year term rather than the two terms specified in the referendums.

The world seems to be falling apart, and L. Dennis Kozlowski, the disgraced former chief executive of Tyco International, has something to say about it. In an interview from prison that is being shown on the Fox Business Network, Mr. Kozlowski says the government's current financial bailout plan is akin to socialism and his misdeeds at Tyco pale in comparison to what happened at the American International Group, Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns.
We are planning a spring visit to Ireland and plan to fly to Dublin and take the railway throughout the country (no driving). I'd appreciate any suggestions on seeing the best sights via train.

CVS and Rite-Aid, two of the largest pharmacy chains in the United States, will give prescription-drug information to New York customers in six languages and provide phone-based translation services to New York customers who need it, under an agreement announced on Thursday by the state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo.

The CIT Group, the century-old corporate lender, is the latest big financial institution to seek to transform itself into a bank holding company, giving the company access to the Treasury Department's $250 billion capital-infusion program set aside for banks to stabilize the financial system.

The freighter E.M. Ford may not have the same aura of romance as, say, the Edmund Fitzgerald, which was memorialized in Gordon Lightfoot's ballad. But the imminent demise of the Ford, which plied the waters of the Great Lakes for nearly a century, still evokes some wistfulness among maritime historians.

There are fewer nonbelievers these days when it comes to Mike Leach and his Texas Tech football team. Leach has guided Tech to a 10-0 record and the No. 2 spot in the Bowl Championship Series rankings, wowing everyone with an innovative offense that racks up points, and yardage, in breathtaking style (the Red Raiders gained more than 1,200 yards in their last two games -- against highly rated Texas and Oklahoma State). Three years ago, Michael Lewis saw this offensive tsunami approaching when he profiled Leach and the Texas Tech program for The Sunday Times Magazine. In today's Play Magazine newsletter, Lewis talks about the phenomenon he saw in Lubbock and why he thought it would be successful.

Environmental groups have sought to force the federal government to restrict carbon dioxide emissions using the Clean Air Act, the Endangered Species Act (because of threats to polar bears from global warming) and other federal laws, and now they are poised to add the Clean Water Act to the list.

The long-stalled project to demolish and replace Fiterman Hall -- a City University classroom and office building near ground zero that was heavily damaged on 9/11, just a month before it was to open -- will move ahead quickly, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Thursday, now that the city has pledged to finance $139 million of the estimated $325 million cost."The city, state and City University of New York have reached an agreement to finally fund demolition of Fiterman Hall and pay for construction of a new classroom building for B.M.C.C. on this site," Mayor Bloomberg said enthusiastically, to a round of applause, in the main building of the Borough of Manhattan Community College at 199 Chambers Street. The chances of Hoffman and the Padres patching things up are slim and the future Hall of Fame pitcher joins a list of formidable closers available to teams in need of relief.

Sociology | Hard times? Time to check in on the French sociologist Emile Durkheim. His classic 1897 study of suicide developed the notion of anomie -- "the breakdown of the normative frameworks of our lives," a professor says. It's "the malady of infinite aspiration" -- i.e. capitalism. [Humanist]

Two weeks ago, writing about Apple's new flagship laptop, the MacBook, I noted with dismay that Apple appears intent on eliminating the FireWire jack. FireWire is a connector, originally developed and promoted by Apple itself, that lets you import video from a tape camcorder for easy editing. It was a cornerstone of Apple's "anyone can edit video" revolution.

ABC's broadcast of the 42nd annual Country Music Association Awards attracted an average of 15.9 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m. on Wednesday, lifting the network to No. 1 in the night's ratings, according to Nielsen's estimates.

Thank God Helmut Lang refuses to go away. Almost four years after his act of corporate abandonment, the designer still pops up all over the place, from his deconstructed disco ball art installation at the journal gallery to "Helmut Lang: Alles Gleich Schwer" (Walther K√∂nig), a new book documenting his traveling "Alles Gleich Schwer" exhibition of the same name. Ever the forward thinker, Lang is showing the complete exhibition online in an unlikely collaboration with Absolut Vodka on its Web site. But fans worried that Lang's latest venture is a bit too commercial will be relieved to know that visitors to the site can download free, limited-edition exhibition posters until December 31st. And, really, who doesn't want free Helmut Lang?

Five of the nation's most highly paid hedge fund managers testified before a House committee on Thursday, as lawmakers turned their attention to what role hedge funds may have played in the recent financial crisis and whether these private investment pools may need stricter regulation.

Warranty company Squaretrade seems to be cutting it's own throat by releasing a study titled "iPhone More Reliable than BlackBerry, One Year In." The study shows that 6 percent of the fast-selling iPhones failed over the past year compared to 12 percent of all BlackBerry handsets and 18 percent of all Palm Treos.

As Graydon Carter notes in his cover review of the oral biography "George, Being George," the Paris Review editor and pioneering "participatory journalist" George Plimpton also had a side career as a shill for a baffling assortment of mainstream brands. Playing on his patrician authority while sending up the same, he hawked beer, banks and cars in hilariously earnest print and television commercials. Many of these spots are lost to time, or at least trapped in television archives, but YouTube offers up a few gems, such as the ad for Pop Secret popcorn above.

COILED turbans, reflector shades, hair shellacked to stand up like a cockscomb -- they were just a few of the style quirks on view recently at a party for Danielle Levitt at the Deitch Projects gallery on Grand Street in Manhattan. Over the years Ms. Levitt, who photographs street fashion and pop culture figures, has trained her eye on American teenagers. Mainstream or marginal, those adolescents are captured in ''We Are Experienced'' (powerHouse Books), a new collection of portraits. A few of Ms. Levitt's subjects -- skaters and stoners, punks, and cheerleaders with kerchiefs like rabbit ears knotted in their hair -- arrived in full drag, looking as if they had been lifted from the pages of her book.

The National Republican Senatorial Committee is not leaving anything to chance in Georgia, where one of the three outstanding Senate races is heading toward a runoff on Dec. 2. On Wednesday, the group began running a new commercial attacking Jim Martin, top, the Democratic challenger, on his tax record in the Georgia General Assembly. The incumbent, Senator Saxby Chambliss, received a plurality of votes on Nov. 4, but he did not win a majority, making a runoff the next step. The senatorial committee's television advertisement features a bluesy soundtrack and ends with pictures of Mr. Martin, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York and Speaker Nancy Pelosi as an announcer says, ''With unchecked power hanging in the balance, Georgia can't afford another liberal like Jim Martin in Washington.''

OSBORNE--Cheryl . Mary mount Manhattan College mourns the loss of former trustee, alumna and friend Cheryl Osborne. The College is grateful for Cheryl's generosity and leadership in the College community. The president and trustees send heartfelt condolences to her husband Dick and her family. Judson R. Shaver, Ph.D. President Anne C. Flannery, Esq. Board Chair OSBORNE--Cheryl Archibald, died peacefully at home on November 10, 2008 after a long battle with cancer. She was 71. She is survived by her husband Richard de J. Osborne, retired Chairman and Chief Executive officer of ASARCO Incorporated and by her daughters, Leslie Coleman of Rye, New York and Lindsay Vogel of Yardley, Pennsylvania; her sons Nicholas of Woodside, California and Stanley of New York City, her daughters-and sonsin-law, and her eleven grandchildren. Born in New York City, Cheryl was a graduate of Marymount School and Marymount Manhattan College. She enjoyed a successful early career as a model and actress, appearing in the movie ''Cover Girl'' and the Broadway musical ''Love Life''. More recently, she worked as a volunteer in the American Wing of The Metropolitan Museum of Art. She served as a Trustee of Crystal Springs School in Hillsborough, California, Princeton Day School in Princeton, New Jersey and Marymount Manhattan College in New York City. She lived in New York City, Little Compton, Rhode Island and Vero Beach, Florida. Cheryl was dearly loved by her friends and family for whom her humor, kindness and love of life are an inspiration. She will be deeply missed by her husband of fifty-one years, children and grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for 11:00am on November 17th at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street in New York City. Memorial contributions may be made to Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, Weill Cornell Medical Center, Box 123, 1300 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021. OSBORNE--Cheryl Archibald. The Board of Directors and staff of the Tinker Foundation note with sorrow the passing of Cheryl Osborne, the wife of longtime Foundation director Richard de J. Osborne. A gracious and caring woman, Mrs. Osborne was greatly admired for her many philanthropic activities as well as her gentle and loving nature. She will be greatly missed. Martha T. Muse, Chairman Renate Rennie, President

CARLSON--Susan Wood , of West Norwalk, CT and Jefferson, ME passed away November 11 after a courageous battle with cancer. The daughter of the late Roy and Jacqueline Wood of Bellport, NY, she was valedictorian of her class at Bellport High School. She went on to study art at Beaver College in Glenside, PA, where she graduated Summa Cum Laude with a B.F.A. Susan enjoyed a long, successful career in advertising, starting as a Fashion Illustrator/Art Director with Sears, and then as an Art Director at Macy's. She recently retired from BBDO in New York City after 29 years, where she was Senior VP Creative Director working on major accounts such as GE, Gillette, Lever Brothers and others. She won several advertising awards including a Cleo. Susan was an avid world traveler, reader, gardener, dancer, and painter as well as theater and movie nut. She is survived by her husband Albert: son Erik; daughter - in - law Jennifer; granddaughters Isabel and Amelia; aunt Shirley Wood; uncle Armand (Bud) Lubatty; brothers Christopher, Jonathan and Jeffrey Wood and their spouses Sylvia, Maryann and Frances; nieces Courtney and Kate; and nephews Stephen, Christopher, and Robert. Visiting hours will be on Friday, November 14 from 2pm-4pm and 5pm-8pm at Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien, CT. There will be a funeral service on Saturday, November 15, at 11am also at the Lawrence Funeral Home. Susan was loved for her generosity, sense of humor and infectious love of life -and will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK 73123-178.

THE economy may be in shambles, but your dog should never be. ''It's essential to keep your dog well groomed, to keep it healthy and happy,'' said Daisy Okas, a spokeswoman for the nonprofit American Kennel Club. The catch is cost. Depending on size and breed, she said, the expense ''could be as low as $25 for a small dog in a rural area, but over $200 for the 'works' -- nails, teeth, ears -- on a large densely coated dog in Manhattan.'' Basic home grooming of pets is a good option for those who want to save money, Ms. Okas said. But it's more than looks: keeping a dog's hair clean, trimmed and brushed reduces risk of infection, she said, and ensures that skin isn't uncomfortably pulled taut by matted fur. Still, people should try not to get carried away, Ms. Okas said. ''A dog is a dog,'' she said. ''They don't need nail polish and perfume, but they do need a decent shampoo and a good brush.''

According to the NPD Group growth in the gaming industry overall has dropped steeply. Overall revenue was up by 18 percent in the third quarter of 2008; in the same period last year, revenue was up 73 percent.

Rowling and Warner Brothers filed suit against RDR Books, which was preparing to publish ‚ÄúThe Harry Potter Lexicon,‚Äù a guide book written by Steven Jan Vander Ark, a librarian and ‚ÄúHarry Potter‚Äù fan. Patterson Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that there was ‚Äúsubstantial similarity between the Lexicon and Rowling‚Äôs novels,‚Äù and ordered RDR Books to pay damages of $6,750 to the plaintiffs. Ten days after I started the process of turning Sagrantino grapes into wine, and using my feet to hasten things along, it was time to take care of my life back on the East Coast. During the presidential election, YouTube turned from a hectic mosaic of weird video clips to a first-stop source for political everything. Every gotcha moment, spoof, pundit's musing, TV clip, campaign speech, formal ad and handmade polemic cropped up there. Star posters like Brave New Films, Barely Political and Talking Points Memo TV emerged; they cranked out parody and propaganda much faster than the campaigns themselves. Was YouTube just a new place to envision an election that would have gone the same way without it? Or does the unpredictable new form of online video carry its own ideology - a new message to go with a new medium?

This is like that moment in the horror movie where things get quiet as you catch your breath following a terrifying series of events. Clearly, there are no blockbuster match-ups this weekend, (although some ranked teams do play on the road) and two undefeated teams sit atop the rankings. Things seem to be tied up in a neat little package, right? But things are a little too quiet. And, just like watching that horror movie, it should makes you nervous. Something is lurking in the shadows. We are still not sure what it is, but something is out there. It might not happen this weekend, but do you really think Texas Tech and Alabama will be playing for the national title in January? I did not think so.

This weekend doesn't boast any of the marquee matchups of recent weeks, but it will provide a chance for the A.C.C. to show why it's become such an intriguing league this season. And in two matchups that feature teams that have been both disappointing and surprising this season, California will take on Oregon State and Minnesota faces Wisconsin. This weekend may be short of big-name matchups but it's got plenty of intrigue. Who do you think will win? Let us know.

STEGE--Virginia Clee , a resident of Bedford for more than 50 years, died in Danbury Hospital on November 8, 2008. She was 97, and lived in Meadow Ridge Retirement Home in Redding, Connecticut. Mrs. Stege was married to Gilbert Clee for 32 years; Mr. Clee died in 1968. She later married Earl R. Stege, who died in 1981. Mrs. Stege was a member of the Bedford Garden Club and of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, both for more than 50 years. She was an original Board Member of the Adoption Service of Westchester. She was a parishioner of St. Matthew's Church, Bedford for more than 40 years. Mrs. Stege is survived by her daughter, Deborah Clee, of Sarasota, Florida. Another daughter, Hillary Clee Jordan, and a step-daughter, Jill Stege Lehman, predeceased Mrs. Stege. Mrs. Stege was also survived by five grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Mrs. Stege's funeral will take place at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, at 10:00am on Friday, November 14, 2008.

LOOMIS--Henry . April 19, 1919-November 02, 2008 of Jacksonville, FL. Henry Loomis who, as a young naval officer in Hawaii in World War II taught scores of officers and men of the Pacific Fleet about RADAR, then went on to a long career in government and communications in which he served five presidents. He was 89 and died of Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and Pick's disease after a lengthy illness. Mr. Loomis, a research scientist, grew up in an ideal environment. He was the youngest of three sons of Ellen Farnsworth and Alfred Loomis, a businessman who made a fortune in New York City before the crash of 1929, lived in Tuxedo Park, where he converted an old mansion into a private research laboratory. Some of the world's best scientist worked on projects there. As a teenager Henry worked with his father on brain wave experiments. Mr. Loomis went to Harvard, where he majored in physics. Convinced in his own mind that the United States would be involved in the war, Mr. Loomis left Harvard in 1940 in his senior year to join the Navy. He graduated first in his naval training class and, because of his background, was assigned to the staff of the Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific Fleet at Pearl Harbor. He established and ran the RADAR maintenance school, the RADAR operations school and was senior instructor in the RADAR tactical school for senior officers. At the same time, he served as RADAR officer with carriers, air squadrons and battleships. By war's end, he had been awarded a Bronze Star, the Air Medal and the Pacific Ribbon with 13 battle stars. Mr. Loomis left the Navy in 1946 as a lieutenant commander and went to the University of California at Berkeley, where he did graduate work in physics and was an assistant to Dr. Ernest Lawrence, director of the radiation laboratory. There he drafted a report for the university trustees describing the laboratory's nuclear work during the war. After four years as assistant to the president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Mr. Loomis was called to Washington, where he started a long career in government service. In three successive years, he was a special assistant to the Director of the Research and Development Board of the Secretary of Defense, and served on the staffs of President Truman's Psychological Strategy Board and President Eisenhower's Commission on International Information. Mr. Loomis established and directed the Office of Research and Intelligence at the U.S. Information Agency as Deputy Director and was later named Director of the VOA, a position he held for seven years. In 1959, the VOA broadcast a news program to the rest of the world in English. Mr. Loomis, in survey trips abroad, realized that English was becoming an international language. He wanted to make English easier to understand by VOA's foreign audience, and asked Barry Zorthian, program manager, to devise a way of reaching an audience with a limited knowledge of English. The result was called Special English. Two changes from VOA's standard procedure: the news was delivered at the slow pace of nine lines a minute and the vocabulary was limited to 1,500 words. University critics said it would never work; American embassies abroad demanded the program be taken off the air. With the support of Mr. Loomis, the program stayed on the air and soon hundreds of letters of praise came in to VOA every month from pleased foreign listeners. After a sharp confrontation with President Johnson during the Vietnam War, Mr. Loomis quit as director of the VOA The President had ordered American intervention into Laos and wanted it kept out of the news. Mr. Loomis thought otherwise. In 1972 during the Nixon Administration, Mr. Loomis was appointed president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Critics jumped on the choice because Mr. Loomis had no experience in public television. However, he had built up a reputation as an excellent administrator on earlier assignments, so he weathered the storm and led the CPB for six years. While Mr. Loomis was deeply involved in government assignments from 1950 to 1978, he managed to stay active in his favorite outdoor activities; hunting, sailing, and riding to the hounds with the Middleburg Hunt in Middleburg, Virginia. In his teens, Mr. Loomis and his brother, Lee, built a 35-foot ketch named Lands End, which they sailed on the Atlantic Ocean. Mr. Loomis was a regular participant in the annual wooden boat race off the Down East Shores of Maine at the helm of Lands End. As a hunter Mr. Loomis traveled around the world to countries in South America, Europe and Africa on bird shooting safaris. He shot big game in Kenya. Mr. Loomis served for 13 years with the Mitre Corporation Board, where he was Vice Chairman for five years; the Smithsonian Institution National Museum of Natural History; the Museum of Science and History in Jacksonville, Florida, and the Jacksonville Zoological Gardens. He was a member of the Metropolitan Club of Washington DC, the Riverside Rotary of Jacksonville Florida; the Florida Yacht Club; the Timuquana Country Club. Mr. Loomis attended the Riverside Presbyterian Church. Survivors include his wife of 34 years, Jacqueline Chalmers Loomis of Jacksonville, FL; four children, Henry Stimson Loomis (Toni), Mary Paul ''Pixie'' Loomis, Lucy Farnsworth Loomis, Gordon MacLeod Loomis (Patricia); four step-sons, Charles Judson Williams IV, John Chalmers Williams (Peggy Sue), David Finley Williams (Lisa), Robert Wood Williams (Heidi); seventeen grandchildren, Abby, Andrew H., Andrew W., Beky, Elli, Erin, Finley, Henry, Lindy, Lucy, Maggie, Murphy, Nadia, Nathan, Perry (Dean), Sole (Adam), and Zoe; two greatgrandchildren, Ethan and Noah; the mother of his children, Mary Paul MacLeod and numerous nieces and nephews. Memorial service will be held at 11:00am, on Saturday, November 15, 2008 at Riverside Presbyterian Church, located at 849 Park Street, Jacksonville, FL 32204. In lieu of flowers the family suggests memorials to the Jacksonville Zoological Gardens or the Riverside Rotary of Jacksonville, FL. The funeral services are under the care of Hardage-Giddens Blanding Funeral Home, 5753 Blanding Blvd., Jacksonville, FL 32244.

Among the art neighborhoods of Manhattan, the Lower East Side is by far the most picturesque. With its dusty synagogues, squeezed-together tenements, anarchist graffiti and shop signs in Yiddish, Spanish and Chinese, it's a visual event whether you're visiting galleries or not. But the essence of a city is change, and this neighborhood is changing. The synagogues and signs are disappearing, along with the anarchist spirit and artist-friendly rents. Chic little bars and boutiques speak of rampant yuppification, although at the moment -- and a sullen economy could prolong this -- old and new are still trading places.

LEBOWSKI FEST There is something antithetical about Lebowski Fest, the annual celebration of ''The Big Lebowski,'' the 1998 Coen brothers movie that glorified slackerdom in the form of a long-haired stoner-bowler known as the Dude.

From historic to spanking new, intimate to spectacular and minimalist to surrealistic, the art on view in the galleries of SoHo and the lower West Side covers a lot of territory. A gorgeous, museumlike exhibition of works by members of the Zero Group, a loose association of '60s-era European avant-gardists, is at Sperone Westwater, while giant, socially provocative paintings of young men in repose by Kehinde Wiley are at Deitch Projects.

A MATTER Of Principle

Your inner dancer is calling. Its voice, sweet but tough and insistent, pulses in every molecule of the new Broadway musical ''Billy Elliot,'' demanding that you wake up sleeping fantasies of slipping on tap or ballet shoes and soaring across a stage. Few people may have the gift of this show's title character, a coal miner's son in northern England who discovers he was born to pirouette. But the seductive, smashingly realized premise of ''Billy Elliot,'' which opened Thursday night at the Imperial Theater, is that everybody has the urge. And in exploring that urge among the population of a down-at-heels coal town suffering through the British miners' strike of the mid-1980s, this show both artfully anatomizes and brazenly exploits the most fundamental and enduring appeal of musicals themselves. It's been more than three years since ''Billy Elliot,'' directed by Stephen Daldry and featuring a score by Elton John, first sent critics and audiences into a mass swoon in London, where it continues to play. The delay in bringing the show to Broadway hinted at fears that it might not sit comfortably on American soil.

President-elect Barack Obama wants Congress to pass a multibillion-dollar economic stimulus package and a bailout for the sputtering auto industry during a lame-duck session next week. But if the session goes forward, Senator Obama will not be there to vote on the proposals. Mr. Obama announced Thursday that he would resign his Senate seat on Sunday, thus avoiding any obligation to show up next week and cutting short the odd overlap period when the next head of the executive branch is still a member of the legislative branch. This is the first time in nearly a half-century that a sitting member of Congress has been elected president.

Hosts urged, ''Listen to the lyrics'' at the ninth annual Latin Grammy Awards, which were broadcast Thursday night from Houston on the Spanish-language network Univision. This awards show was determined to present music not as an escape from troubles, but as a way to face them, whether those troubles stemmed from the state of the world or from a broken heart. The show began with the Colombian rocker Juanes, whose album ''La Vida Es un Ratico'' won awards for Album of the Year and Best Male Pop Vocal Album. He swept the major awards; his ''Me Enamora'' was named Song of the Year and Record of the Year. He has won multiple Latin Grammy awards for each of his previous three albums.

Like many artists, Robert Battle doesn't like to explain his dances, preferring that audience members draw their own conclusions. He made an exception, though, on Wednesday at Ailey Citigroup Theater, introducing Battleworks Dance Company's winter gala, ''An Evening With Robert Battle: Signature Solos,'' which featured works from 1992 to 2008. His delightfully informal manner suggests that he would make a good ambassador for modern dance. To summarize, in his words, ''Know that whatever you see is valid, whatever you don't like is valid, and whatever you do like is even better.''

VISITING wine country usually brings to mind sun-dappled hillsides dotted with vineyards, winding country roads and stone chateaus. There are always small towns flush with boutiques and fine restaurants tucked down side roads. Galleries with well-known artists on their walls and symphonies with the latest hot musicians seem to call the area home. That's not what you'll find at JC Cellars or Dashe Cellars, a quick exit off the Interstate near downtown Oakland, Calif. Rows of warehouses line nearby side streets. A restaurant supply store sits on the corner and a gas station advertises cheap hot dogs. If the winery that the two businesses share weren't painted dark red, with their names in gold lettering, you might miss it. Yet it is here among the warehouses and parking lots that young winemakers, like Jeff Cohn of JC Cellars and Michael Dashe of Dashe Cellars, are opening shop.

Nearly 20 years after the Salvadoran Army killed six Jesuit priests in one of the most notorious events of El Salvador's civil war, a criminal complaint filed in the Spanish High Court has revived hopes that those behind the massacre could face trial. Human rights lawyers filed a complaint on Thursday against the Salvadoran president at the time, Alfredo Cristiani Burkard, and 14 former members of the Salvadoran military, for their roles in the killings of the priests and two female employees, and in the official cover-up that followed. International outrage over the murders proved to be pivotal in sapping American support for United States military assistance to the Salvadoran Army.

Representative Rahm Emanuel, right, President-elect Barack Obama's chief of staff, called the president of an Arab-American group on Thursday to apologize for comments his father made to an Israeli newspaper that offended some Arabs at home and abroad. In the remarks, Benjamin Emanuel discussed the potential impact of his son's new White House position on American-Israeli relations.

Gunmen abducted an Iranian diplomat in the chaotic city of Peshawar in Pakistan's northwest on Thursday, a day after the assassination of an American aid official there. The diplomat, Hesmatollah Atharzadeh, who was the commercial counselor at the Iranian Consulate, was leaving his house in the suburb of Hayatabad when the gunmen attacked, the police said. His driver was killed.

Michael Jordan will participate in the Golf Digest United States Open Challenge at Bethpage Black, to be televised on NBC next June, according to an editor at Golf Digest. Jordan, who has a 1.4 handicap index, will be joined by two celebrities and an amateur who best explains in a six-word essay why he or she can break 100. The event was born after Tiger Woods said at the 2007 United States Open that a 10-handicapper could not break 100 on an Open setup. At this year's challenge before the United States Open at Torrey Pines, Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo shot an 84; Matt Lauer, the host of ''Today,'' shot 100; and the amateur winner, the Nebraska salesman John Atkinson, shot 114. Jordan, who will have Fred Couples as a caddie, told Golf Digest: ''Tiger doesn't know anything about me doing this. I don't need his advice -- yet.''

Among the art neighborhoods of Manhattan, the Lower East Side is by far the most picturesque. With its dusty synagogues, squeezed-together tenements, anarchist graffiti and shop signs in Yiddish, Spanish and Chinese, it's a visual event whether you're visiting galleries or not. But the essence of a city is change, and this neighborhood is changing. The synagogues and signs are disappearing, along with the anarchist spirit and artist-friendly rents. Chic little bars and boutiques speak of rampant yuppification, although at the moment -- and a sullen economy could prolong this -- old and new are still trading places.
THE DUKES Opens on Friday in New York.

If you are going to hand out rescue packages, it helps to understand how bad the problem is, and to have some grasp of what is needed to fix it. Now the automakers are in line for handouts, and we can only hope the government will have a better understanding of their problems -- and a willingness to force painful changes on the industry -- than it did of the financial industry, where the first round of bailouts were made in a process that is looking more and more absurd.
WAR CHILD Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

WHEN you run an ice cream parlor down the street from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, you expect your customers to chat about stem cell research or trade theories about neutrinos between licks of burnt caramel. But Gus Rancatore, whose Toscanini's shop in Cambridge, Mass., is renowned as much for its deep-thinking clientele as for its sundaes, discovered long ago that catering to the technology-minded crowd could have unforeseen advantages. One day, two M.I.T. students who were ''working in superconductors,'' Mr. Rancatore said, took a good look at his ice cream machine, visible through his shop window, and were ''distressed by the poor engineering.'' So they took it back to their lab and transformed its inefficient gear-drive mechanism into a lean, mean, belt-driven machine. That was 23 years ago. ''We still use the machine,'' Mr. Rancatore said. ''Another generation of M.I.T. engineers just tuned it up this summer.''

Given the last-minute rule changes, it's a little surprising that the Bush administration hasn't made a harder push on snowmobiles in Yellowstone National Park. The Interior Department, after all, has spent eight years seeking to vastly increase the number of snowmobiles, ignoring its own scientists. But now, in response to a court ruling throwing out a plan allowing 540 snowmobiles a day into Yellowstone, the department proposes a compromise: 318 machines a day. The public has until Monday to comment -- yet again.

The Vatican has informed a Roman Catholic priest in the United States that he will be excommunicated next week for participating in a ceremony it considers illicit and invalid: the ordination of a woman as a priest. The priest, the Rev. Roy Bourgeois, 69, has been a member of the Maryknoll religious order for 36 years. He said he was anguished at the thought of excommunication, but could not disavow his actions.

SNOW crunched underfoot as I trekked toward the chute, a shadowed corner pinched between cliffs at 11,000 feet. It was a Monday morning, cloudless and quiet, the sun just poking above distant peaks of the Uinta Mountains in northeastern Utah. ''Looks icy up high,'' said Jeff Burford, pointing with a trekking pole. In the distance, nudged up as a dark pyramid of stone, our goal for the day stood removed miles away and thousands of feet in the sky.

The art world's rolling-in-money days may be dwindling, but you'd never know it from the plethora of substantial gallery shows in Chelsea right now. Maybe the most habitually denounced of all art ZIP codes is staging a last grand stand, signaling its intention to go down fighting or at least to put a good face on things. Maybe it is just pulling out the stops during the fall art auctions, when lots of collectors are in town. Whichever it is, this weekend Chelsea provides an ever-humbling, close to encyclopedic survey of ways of making and showing art. It runs the gamut from blue chip to schlock, die-hard hip to clueless, and good to pedestrian to egregious, often within close proximity. There are two- and three-gallery franchises (Gladstone, Gagosian, Paula Cooper, 303, Matthew Marks) and tiny holes in the wall, especially on 27th Street. Galleries continue to arrive as others relocate to the Lower East Side.

When Marc Simon, a lawyer and filmmaker, started thinking about making a documentary about the famously cutthroat process of gaining admission to New York City's elite private preschools, he had no kids and no plans to have any soon. He had little in common with the parents whom he intended to profile. Then, like so many of them, he found he couldn't get in. Mr. Simon approached an organization coordinating a panel discussion on the admission process to see if he could bring a camera, but got turned down flat. He was told that preschool was a sensitive issue in New York -- very, very sensitive, so sensitive that parents would be terrified to see cameras anywhere in the room.

Even as Al Qaeda strengthens its hub in the Pakistani mountains, its leaders are building closer ties to regional militant groups in order to launch attacks in Africa and Europe and on the Arabian Peninsula, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency said Thursday. The director, Michael V. Hayden, identified North Africa and Somalia as places where Qaeda leaders were using partnerships to establish new bases. Elsewhere, Mr. Hayden said, Al Qaeda was ''strengthening'' in Yemen, and he added that veterans of the fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan had moved there, possibly to stage attacks against the government of Saudi Arabia.

Wang Denggui, father of three, arrived more than a year ago in the palm-lined streets of this southern town with a single goal: toil in a factory to save for his children's school tuition. But the plans of Mr. Wang and thousands of co-workers unraveled at noon on Nov. 1, when the Taiwanese chairman of their ailing shoe factory climbed over a factory wall to flee the country and his debts. That left several American shoe companies with unfilled orders and 2,000 workers without jobs.

AUERBACH--Shay A . Philanthropist, leader in U.S Textiles and the co-founder of The Northwest Company died Tuesday morning at the age of 82. The cause was cancer. Shay Auerbach was born in Brooklyn in 1926, the son of Russian immigrants. Mr. Auerbach graduated from Textile High School and later served in the U.S. Navy Pacific fleet in World War II. After the war he joined his father in the textile industry in the rag business. After many successes, he went on to own and operate various woolen mills in the U.S. In the mid 1960s after recognizing that change would force most mills out of the U.S., Mr. Auerbach entered the men's clothing industry manufacturing men's suits, pants and sweaters and was the first importer of double knit fabrics into the U.S. In the mid 1980s after selling his business and a brief retirement he purchased The Northwest Company with his two sons Glenn and Ross Auerbach. Together with his sons he helped to guide this small business with sales under 1 million dollars into a company with annual sales over 100 million dollars, and the leader in its industry. The Northwest Company is today the largest throw manufacturer in the U.S. and is the decorative home licensee of most of America's finest brands. These brands include the NFL, MLB, Disney, Nickelodeon, and Warner Brothers. The Northwest Company also supports over 100 charitable organizations. Shay Auerbach was a classic Brooklyn boy. Tough: but fair, hard working, loving and caring. A man that was respected by all. Shay Auerbach, devoted husband of the late Florence C. Auerbach, husband of Fran Auerbach, father of Glenn and Ross (Sophia) Auerbach, grandfather of Gabrielle, Daniella, Elex and Alexander, Brother of Henrietta and Sonya and the late Shirley, countless nieces, nephews and cousins. Shay Auerbach saw it all. He watched the world change and he changed with it. And although the world became a very political place, he remained tough and honest. He told you the way it was and everyone knew where they stood with him. He loved life and got to enjoy it as well. They truly do not make men like this anymore. The funeral will take place at 10:00am Friday November 14, at Temple Beth Shalom, 401 Roslyn Rd., Roslyn Heights, NY 11577, 516621-2288. Interment will immediately follow the temple service at Locust Valley Cemetery, Ryefield Rd, Locust Valley, NY 11560, 516-676-5290. Shiva will be held Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at, 24 Fairview Ave., Roslyn, NY 11576, 516625-1219. In Lieu of flowers the family request that donations be made to: The Shay Auerbach Memorial Fund, 49 Bryant Ave, Roslyn, NY 11576.

Africa | Writing generally about Africa makes little sense, a reviewer says. Colonization established "a single idea of Africa in the imagination of the outside world," but not among the nearly 50 sub-Saharan nations. " 'Africa' is a Western invention." The place is too vast and varied. [Guardian]

Literature | Proust is a funny guy, a writer argues. Who knew? But his humor is "subtle and difficult, consisting of many moving parts. It tends to arise from a gradual accumulation of insights that are as shrewd as they are absurd." In other words, you have to be there. [More Intelligent Life]

Books | The literary world is astir over the notion that few women write books about "big ideas." Malcolm Gladwell, Richard Dawkins, Christopher Hitchens -- all have big, thinky books out lately and they're all men. Germaine Greer says, "Brandishing the 'big idea' is a bookish version of male display." Another writer wonders if women are "better at telling stories than propagating ideas." Another blames publishers. Others come up with female authors to undercut the thesis. Oh, it's a fine tizzy. [Independent, Guardian]
