KOREIN--Julius, M.D. The faculty, students and staff of New York University School of Medicine mourn the passing of Julius Korein, M.D., Professor Emeritus of Neurology, at age 80, on November 12. Dr. Korein graduated NYU in 1949 and the NYU College of Medicine in 1953. He completed his neurology residency in the NYU-Bellevue Hospital Center in 1955 and then served as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force for two years. He held an NIH Special Fellowship from 1959-61 and for the next 34 years was Director of the EEG laboratories at Bellevue Hospital. During this period he published over 100 papers and book chapters. He was an early advocate of computers for information processing and retrieval of medical data and achieved renown as an authority on coma and the persistent vegetative state. He developed a radioisotope test of cerebral circulation in defining brain death and served on hospital and medical society committees as a biomedical ethicist. Julie was a warm, generous colleague whose scholarly interest in brain function never diminished. He will be sorely missed by all . Robert I. Grossman, M. D. Dean and CEO, NYU Langone Medical Center Edwin H. Kolodny, M.D. Chairman, Department of Neurology

When a fire ripped through Deyrolle, the beloved taxidermy establishment here, early one morning last February, it was as if a dagger had been plunged into the heart of Paris. Deyrolle has always been more than a shop on the classy Rue du Bac. Founded 177 years ago by Jean-Baptiste Deyrolle, a well-known entomologist, Deyrolle has been a natural history emporium with the look and feel of a museum, except that just about everything was for sale.

OLIVO--Roxanne, daughter of Dr. Morris and Sylvia Berman, sister of Loretta Kuehn, died at 11:20am, Saturday November 8th, 2008 of lung cancer at age 62. Roxanne was First National Chairman of (NARAL) National Abortion Rights Action League. She was the head of voluntary sterilization. President of the Lennox Hill Democratic Club, a member of her community board and founder of comprehensive systems. She was a social activist who cared deeply about justice and women's rights. Now she is with her devoted parents. May the sun pierce her soul with its warmth and may she forever bask in the love and security and memory of her family and friends.

AMES--James Marshall, of Jackson Heights, NY, on November 10, 2008. Beloved brother of the late June Ginnane of Edison, NJ; grandson of James Marshal Ames, owner of J.M. Ames Sand and Gravel of the Bronx. Mr. Ames, born in 1926 in NYC to Charles and Anna Ames, remained an active, involved resident of the city for his entire life. In 1949, James graduated from the U.S. Maritime Academy, Kings Point, NY and went on to serve in the Merchant Marine and Navy during the Korean War. James worked for over four decades for the City of New York as an engineer for the Department of Environmental Protection; he was also a worldwide traveler with a taste for adventure. Mr. Ames was a communicant of St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church, Jackson Heights, NY and a longtime member of the Catholic Alumnae Club. James M. Ames is survived by his sister's children: Anne Marie Ginnane, Patricia Ginnane Joswick, two greatnieces, a great-nephew and extended family. Mass of Christian Burial will be Saturday, St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church, 10:30am. Interment to follow, Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Tarrytown, NY.

As he walked into his office in Brooklyn nearly every day this fall, the Rev. David K. Brawley noticed a photograph on his assistant's desk. It showed Senator Barack Obama, head bowed, as a circle of black ministers gathered around him, touching their hands to his shoulders and uttering prayers. Without even knowing the precise circumstances of the picture -- it had been taken in July during the quadrennial conference of the African Methodist Episcopal denomination -- Mr. Brawley understood the broader context. The hands and the prayers offered to Mr. Obama were an act, in the lexicon of black Christianity, of impartation.

BEING CONSIDERED FOR: Attorney general or secretary of homeland security. WOULD BRING TO THE JOB: Pragmatism and nonpartisanship. Allies and adversaries praise her as having a sharp mind. . As the governor of Arizona, a border state at the center of the immigration debate, she has been vocal about revamping immigration laws.

9 P.M. (Science) BUILD IT BIGGER: REBUILDING GREENSBURG Danny Forster, above, hasn't let a fear of heights stand between him and some of the world's largest structures in this series, which had its debut on the Discovery Channel last year. He begins a new season with a four-part report on the ''green'' rebuilding of Greensburg, Kan., which was devastated by a tornado in May 2007. In ''Architects of the Environment,'' the first episode, students from the University of Kansas design and build a sustainable structure to house a community arts center, and in the process try to gain the first Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design Platinum certification in the state. In ''John Deere Greene,'' at 10, the town's farm tool dealership also strives to go platinum by recycling rain and wastewater and burning used motor oil and corn to heat water in hydronic floors. The third and fourth episodes of the report will be shown on Nov. 22. 8 P.M. (ABC Family) DR. DOLITTLE: TAIL TO THE CHIEF (2008) Kyla Pratt reprises her role as Maya Dolittle, the famed daughter of the doctor who talks to animals. She, it turns out, shares the gift of gab as well. This time around the president (Peter Coyote) enlists Maya to figure out why Daisy, the first dog (voiced by Jennifer Coolidge), is acting up. A marathon of the previous three ''Dr. Dolittle'' films, the first two of which star Eddie Murphy, begins at 2 p.m.

SLIDESHOW: TAXIDERMY PARADISE, BEFORE AND AFTER A slide show of images of Deyrolle, a famous taxidermy shop in Paris, taken before and after a February fire destroyed 90 percent of the store's stock. The slide show also includes photographs of pieces that were sold this week at a fund-raising auction.

WELLES--Leonard R., 91, of San Francisco, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, passed away peacefully on October 29 with his wife Jean of 61 years by his side. He was a devoted husband, beloved father of Barbara Seegal (John), Corinne Welles, and Robert Welles (Bernice), cherished grandfather of Sarah and Laura Seegal. Leonard was born on New York's Lower East Side in 1917 to Fanny and Harry Wolfish, served in the U.S. 5th Army in World War II during the invasions of North Africa, Sicily, Italy (Battle of Cassino) and the Battle of the Bulge. He graduated from New York University with a B.S. and M.S. in education and counseling and spent his career as an educator in New York City public schools. Leonard loved tennis, world travel, opera, and the words of Bellow, Updike and Roth. He will be remembered for his loving kindness, warmth, and unconditional love. In addition he leaves behind his loving sisters Bunny Renz and Estelle Weidmann of Florida. Interment was at Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ.
DEAN--Andy Chen, M.D., Ph.D. 3/26/60-11/15/06. When we think of you we remember your laughter and our good times together. Your Family

BEN-AVI--Joan, daughter of Sophie and Paul Sampliner. She was born in Cleveland, Ohio on May 26, 1923, and died at home in White Plains, New York, on November 11, 2008. She attended Smith College. Joan was an avid reader, an art lover with an innate sense of aesthetics and style. A lover of music and theater, she was a gourmet and took great interest in nutritional and medical matters. She was a true intellectual; interested in a great variety of subjects, and as she often said, had a ''need to know''. Joan was a true friend and a loyal, devoted mother, a truly grand and kind woman. Married to Avrum Ben-Avi, a clinical psychologist, for 36 years. During their marriage they traveled widely, primarily in Europe. The marriage ended in divorce, but the two remained on good terms until their deaths. Joan is survived by her brother, Philip Sampliner, her son Jason Ben-Avi, and her daughters Sigrid Balmer, and Nina Ben-Avi Schreiber; two sons-in-law: Reg Balmer and Marc Schreiber; as well as four grandchildren: Alice and Sarah Balmer, and Julia and Emma Ben-Avi. One of Joan's great delights was an annual family vacation in Nantucket at each summer's end, where she gathered her children and grandchildren at an inn by the sea. This strong, fiercely independent woman who was loved and respected by so many, will be greatly missed.

MOUYIARIS--Apostolos (Pip), November 13, 2008. Beloved husband of Maxine. Devoted father of Kim and her husband John, Helen, Nicholas, Philip and his fiancee Judy. Cherished Papou of Natasha and Matthew. Survived by his dear brothers and sister. He touched many lives with his strength, humanity, and grace. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Visiting at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Service Monday St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church at 9:30am. Interment Flushing Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5pm and 7-9pm.

Jonathan Cohn has the best statement I've seen of the case for a rescue. No illusions -- these are companies that, to a large extent, drove themselves into a ditch. The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies last Sunday, about a decline in the pace of “tear down and build” projects in the state, rendered incorrectly the name of a borough cited as among 85 communities where teardowns are prominent. It is Fair Lawn, not Fairlawn. The article also misidentified the real estate agency that is marketing a new home being built on Park Street in Montclair. It is Rhodes, Van Note & Company, not Re/Max.

I never fully understood the ‚Äúputting lipstick on a pig‚Äù phrase before reading Lauren Zalaznick‚Äôs attempt to place reality television tripe like ‚ÄúReal Housewives‚Äù on the same artistic plane as the incredible work done at Killer Films (Susan Dominus, Nov. 2). I‚Äôm not judging Zalaznick for selling out, but don‚Äôt deny the choices you make. It‚Äôs still a sale if your artistic merit is bought and paid for by a desirable demographic.

Matt Bai‚Äôs joke that Presidents Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton hadn‚Äôt spent enough time in Washington to ‚Äútake the subway without a map‚Äù (The Way We Live Now, Nov. 2) is historically off. The first small segment of the subway did not open until 1976 (the year Jimmy Carter was elected), serving only a few stops between Union Station and DuPont Circle. While the subway was still a dream, Bill Clinton was a young Washington insider as an undergraduate at Georgetown University‚Äôs School of Foreign Service (also my alma mater), where he worked for Senator J. William Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee during the days of the Vietnam War hearings.

Standing in a meadow above the Swiss mountain town of Zermatt, Heinz Julen pointed to a peak in the distance. ‚ÄúThe building will rise up along the sides like this,‚Äù he said, making a triangle for me with his fingers, framing the mountain. ‚ÄúFrom here, you won‚Äôt even recognize it as a building.‚Äù Julen, a 44-year-old self-taught architect, was explaining his designs for a 390-foot-tall glass-and-steel pyramid he hopes to build atop the Klein Matterhorn. The structure will have two viewing platforms, a restaurant and, if it actually gets built, the world‚Äôs highest hotel.

Edge / (ej) / n. / a provocative or unconventional quality, e.g., ‚ÄúWhat I like about the art scene in Tel Aviv is that it‚Äôs got edge. I saw a great sculpture made of barbed wire and Dead Sea salt.‚Äù For travelers, places with edge are an antidote to creeping homogeneity and ahistorical contexts, as in, ‚ÄúThe Mozambican side of Lake Malawi has a real edge to it ‚Äî you see all the scars of war, surrounded by incredible beauty.‚Äù.

WHO‚ÄôS THERE Artists, graphic designers, gallery owners, retailers and restaurateurs are drawn to the dynamic energy created by falling unemployment rates and a relatively buoyant financial outlook. Unlike other European cities, Warsaw isn‚Äôt overflowing with expats (yet), so there‚Äôs a palpable sense of unconsumed authenticity.

In the remote southwestern Ethiopian town of Jinka, Charles Veley and I were drinking araki sorghum whiskey in the bar of a dirt-lane guesthouse full of Mursi tribesmen and their families. Mursi women are usually recognizable by the clay disks that stretch their severed lower lips, but on this night, in an informal setting (where families had paid the equivalent of 20 cents a person to sleep on the packed-dirt floor), most of the women had removed their ocher-painted plates. Their lower lips sagged around their chins as they nursed babies in the dim light; the Mursi men, who had checked their fighting staves at the door, silently watched television and sipped araki.

It used to be that the highlight of a trip to Paris or London was the Tuileries or Trafalgar Square. But as cities around the world have been reshaped by writers, artists, foodies, bons vivants and those who emulate them, the humming little enclaves they create are redrawing the travel map. Call it nostalgia for Greenwich Village in the Beat era or the Left Bank of the Jazz Age: tuned-in travelers are seeking out more local precincts. Not just New York but Williamsburg, not just Tokyo but Harajuku: the neighborhood has become the new elemental unit of cool.

For a cafe that is famous for its coffee, in a city that serves nothing but, Tazza d‚ÄôOro in Tel Aviv has surprisingly tasty ravioli. What gave Sigalit Landau pause, however, was the service charge tacked onto the bill for it. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised they still have this,‚Äù she said, glancing toward the bored young man at the cafe‚Äôs garden gate. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs for the security.‚Äù.

The boom-bust cycle of once-glamorous Eleuthera has been stuck in bust for a while, though you wouldn‚Äôt know that from all the recent hype about a comeback. There is plenty in the works here, but for now the island remains a sleepy backwater with no shortage of stunning, nearly always empty beaches. (Celebrities like Lenny Kravitz and Mariah Carey have bought houses here precisely because it is so quiet.) Eleuthera is 110 miles long, with one main ‚Äî heavily potholed ‚Äî road, so your hotel‚Äôs location is especially important. The Cove, in the north, is a comfortable 26-room cluster of bungalows on a hillside above a small beach (242-335-5142; thecoveeleuthera.com; doubles from $235). It‚Äôs not far from the dock where boats leave for Harbour Island, so you have an easy escape plan, and it‚Äôs a few minutes from Elvina‚Äôs, a fun dive bar with live music on Tuesdays and Fridays. Pineapple Fields, a small condo-style complex set back from a long stretch of white sand (242-332-2221; pineapplefields.com; doubles from $290), is in the island‚Äôs center, so it‚Äôs more convenient for those who want to search out secluded beaches and villages. Tippy‚Äôs (left; 242-332-3331), the resort‚Äôs terrific restaurant, has an unfussy menu of dishes like tuna carpaccio and blackened red snapper, and a piano, where Mariah or Lenny might sit down for an impromptu set.[?][?][?] JEFFRIES BLACKERBY, MAURA EGAN AND NATHAN LUMP.

I was recently invited to a barbecue on the island of Rota. My host was Senator Paul A. Manglo√±a, the island‚Äôs highest-ranking elected official. The affair was low-key, like most social events on Pacific islands. The senator‚Äôs extended family and about a dozen friends sat at picnic tables along the beach, beneath a row of ironwood pines.

Diving Proximity to the world‚Äôs third-largest barrier reef makes Andros a great base for divers: Kamalame Cay (kamalame.com) has a small but expert operation; Small Hope Bay Lodge (smallhope.com) caters to guests and day-trippers. Or, for hard-core diving without the frills, there‚Äôs Stuart Cove‚Äôs (stuartcove.com) on the south side of New Providence.

A few blocks east of Osaka‚Äôs Statue of Liberty, a couple dozen youths are loitering around an open-air square, living some Japanese translation of the American dream. I‚Äôm at the center of Amerikamura, the so-called ‚ÄúAmerican village,‚Äù and the improbable mash-up of fashion here ‚Äî a block away there‚Äôs a bar called Ganja Acid and a boutique called Gothic & Lolita, and those names sum up half the outfits around me ‚Äî confirms this area‚Äôs status as an edgy shopping and cultural district. If the original Statue of Liberty represented France‚Äôs dewy hopes for the young United States, then the replica statue Inconspicuously on duty here in Osaka (she‚Äôs perched rather randomly on the corner of a nondescript midrise tower) might represent this city‚Äôs hopes for itself.

Although the New York gallery owner, art collector and curator Tim Nye lives and works at the National Arts Club in Gramercy Park ‚Äî he rents two floors for his gallery, Nyehaus, and another two for his own pop-art digs ‚Äî he‚Äôs hardly a homebody. In fact, Nye (shown here in the club‚Äôs 19th-century salon) has made a reputation for championing talent farther afield. This means importing new-to-New York work from the German-based art duo RothStauffenberg, playing host to offbeat musical guests like Laurie Anderson and Devendra Banhart at his gallery‚Äôs new music space and taking frequent jaunts to Europe to update his roster. ‚ÄúI prefer left-of-center stuff,‚Äù he says of his curatorial sensibilities. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm always searching for the things that may have slipped through the cracks.‚Äù [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.

As Mexico City‚Äôs bright young things turn their attention to revitalizing the capital‚Äôs historic core, a rough-and-tumble strip of Calle Rep√∫blica de Cuba has become a thumping night-life artery. On the west end of the street, near the main avenue of Eje Central, are Viena (No. 2-E) and Oasis (No. 2-G), two longtime macho gay cantinas back in vogue. Across the street there‚Äôs Las Pecosas (No. 22), with live bands on Thursdays and Fridays, and two recently reopened college-kid hangouts, Cuba Libre (No. 23) and Excelencia (No. 33). Near the intersection with Bol√≠var Street is the always popular R√≠o de la Plata (No. 39) and the legendary La Perla (No. 45), known for its transvestite shows, both re-energized by the neighborhood‚Äôs new weekend revelers. And in the middle of it all is the newcomer Marrakech Sal√≥n (No. 18), an artsy gay club that draws a mixed, dance-hungry crowd. Julio Ortiz, the manager of Excelencia, says Calle Rep√∫blica has never felt more vital: ‚ÄúThe magic of the Centro, like this street, is that all kinds of people converge here.‚Äù[?][?][?] DANIEL HERNANDEZ.

The J. T. Basque Bar & Dining Room, in Gardnerville, Nev., was hopping at lunch, with the bar and slot machines in action and ‚ÄúGot Picon?‚Äù T-shirts ready for sale. The long tables were filled with locals who satisfied my main road-food rule: always choose the restaurant with the greatest number of pickup trucks in the parking lot. The drink of the day was Picon punch, spiked with grenadine, soda, a twist of lemon and a brandy float ‚Äî an acquired taste, to be sure. On the menu were sweetbreads by the cup and a crumbly house-made Basco Burger, but I had come for the full Basque dinner: garlic-topped lamb shoulder steak, thinly sliced and pleasantly greasy, accompanied by an unlabeled bottle of sweet-tart house wine.

Now that Indian fashion is turning heads all over the world, the country‚Äôs shopping options are catching up. The splashiest recent debut is D7, a sprawling Mumbai emporium where seven Delhi designers come together to showcase their work. In one corner are the runway darling Manish Arora‚Äôs psychedelic Kool-Aid colors; in another, some subtly embellished catwalk hits by Rajesh Pratap Singh. Elsewhere are Neeru Kumar‚Äôs silk patchwork shawls and embroidered A-line skirts by Namrata Joshipura, along with the latest lines from such big names as Rabani and Rakha, Pankaj and Nidhi Ahuja, and Moon River. The shop, in Khar (Mumbai‚Äôs West Village), has already become a reliable source for Bollywood starlets and socialites looking to stand out on Page 3 of The Bombay Times. Turning Point Building, Khar Danda Road; 011-91-22-6679-1551.[?][?][?] TANVI CHHEDA.

A new crop of guidebooks has arrived from across the pond. Mr. & Mrs. Smith ‚Äî the best-selling duo who stand in for today‚Äôs everycouple ‚Äî make their American debut this month with ‚ÄúThe Global Shortlist‚Äù (Spy Publishing; $25), a glossy yet pointed assessment of their 30 favorite boutique hotels, from Cape Town to Quintana Roo, supplemented by mini destination guides for each. Going deep instead of wide, Alastair Sawday‚Äôs ‚ÄúGo Slow England‚Äù (The Little Bookroom; $25) is the latest in a series of exhaustively resourceful guides to local secrets. It‚Äôs organized by county and illustrated with maps as well as with many misty-watercolor photos of countryside Britannica ‚Äî the author never met a chicken coop he didn‚Äôt like.[?][?][?] JEFFRIES BLACKERBY.

FOR THE CHIC The pristine, manicured and, yes, pink-tinged Pink Sands Beach on Harbour Island is just the right setting for a crowd of attractive couples lounging on chaises in OndadeMar bikinis and D & G square cuts.

Mobile, Ala., is where I would be by now, but my car is still idling on Interstate 10 in the heart of New Orleans. Both cities are in the early stages of evacuation in advance of Hurricane Gustav, the vaguely Norwegian-sounding low-pressure system that in a week‚Äôs time has shifted from a minuscule Atlantic depression to Category 4 status. I don‚Äôt know what things look like in Mobile, but in New Orleans early evacuation means a stalled exodus of Old Testament proportions. All around me, in moored vehicles, trapped families press up against the window glass, blinking out at one another as if already underwater. Over the highway‚Äôs divide, flatbeds of military Humvees, flotillas of buses and platoons of ambulances stream unheeded into the city. Above the entire scene, in case anyone needs a reminder that this is the anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, rises the pale crown of the New Orleans Superdome.

FISCHBEIN--Alvin Morris, Esq., of Pittston, PA, died peacefully, with his family at his side Monday evening, November 10, 2008. Alvin was born in Brooklyn, NY son of the late Samuel and Dorothy Rubinstein Fischbein and loving brother of the late Ernest. Al was a proud veteran of World War II, graduating from James Madison High School, City College, and Brooklyn Law. Al was an avid ballroom dancer, swimmer with a passion for education. He is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Professor Sylvia Fischbein, sons, Dr. Richard Fischbein and his wife, Susan, Dr. Jeffrey Fischbein, grandchildren, Emily and Rachel and nephews Mark and Paul. Graveside Funeral Services will be held today, at 1pm in Beth David Cemetery, Long Island.

SCHEINER--Ellen, M.D., F.A.C.P., November 5, 2008. Ellen Scheiner, 76, retired attending physician at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, retired Associate Professor of Medicine for Cornell Medical College, and founding board member for the New York GLBT Community Center, died November 5, 2008, in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. She inspired many people with her fierce determination and loving spirit. She was proud of achieving a significant medical career despite having a paralyzed arm from a birth injury. Ellen was born and grew up in Brooklyn, the third child of Moe and Pauline (Harber) Scheiner. She was inspired to become a doctor because, during her multiple childhood surgeries and stays at the Hospital of St. Giles the Cripple in New York, she admired her doctors and felt drawn to help other people in the same way. Ellen was also a passionate lifelong activist for civil rights. For instance, in the vanguard of the equal rights movement, she advocated for salary parity for men and women at the hospital. She practiced medicine and then psychotherapy with love for her patients. While at SloanKettering, Ellen started a program to help young doctors communicate more compassionately with their patients. She served as medical liaison with the hospital chaplain service. She also led pioneering work on medical ethics in treating terminally ill patients. Ellen was a longtime meditator and poet. She is survived by her spouse, Rosemary Hyde, her brother, Harvey Scheiner and his wife Phyllis, her sister, Selma Lurie, and their families. Ellen donated her body to the Lineberger Cancer Center at the University of North Carolina, for research on lobular breast cancer. Services were by Walker Funeral Home, Chapel Hill, NC. She requested that family and friends hold a classic New York cocktail party to celebrate her life by having a wonderful time together. Donations in her name may be made to Project Compassion, www.project-compassion.org

JACOBSON--Richard Ber, age 85, one of The Greatest Generation, died October 31, 2008. He was the son of the late George and Irma Jacobson. He is survived by his brother George, sister-in-law Ronnie, nephew Neil and Neil's wife Deirdre and cousins. A lifelong resident of Manhattan, he loved the city. He had many talents and interests. For decades he was an active member of the West Side YMCA and a member of their Leaders Club. He had a great gift for friendship and will be deeply missed by people worldwide. A partyper Richard's request will be held at a later date.

STEVENS--Joseph B., concessionaire, died November 13, 2008 at 92. Joseph B. Stevens, Jr. was born on October 4, 1916 in Cleveland, OH to the late Joseph B. Stevens, Sr. and Josephine Pearce Stevens. Mr. Stevens was a graduate of Phillips Academy in Andover, MA and Yale University class of 1938. He served in the United States Navy from January 7, 1942 to January 14, 1946. On February 21, 1940 he married Frances Elizabeth Pine and resided in Baltimore; they would later move to New Jersey in 1943. After living in the Princeton Lawrence area of New Jersey for 48 years, he and his wife moved to Chestertown in 1991. His entire business career was with Harry M. Stevens Inc. A family business founded by his grandfather in 1889, who created the baseball score card and the hot dog. As a concessionaire at baseball parks, racetracks, arenas, and stadiums, Mr. Stevens appreciated the business in all working areas from selling peanuts at Yankee Stadium to washing dishes at the Preakness. His first day on the job was at the Timonium, MD Fairgrounds on September 1938. He would later become president of the company in 1965 and was made chairman in 1982. He retired from Harry M. Stevens, Inc. on December 31, 1991. Mr. Stevens was past president of the Heron Point Retirement Community and 2-term board member of the Maritime Museum in St. Michaels, MD. He enjoyed sports, outdoors, camping at their family cabin in the Adirondacks of New York and watching the boats come in at their Perry Cabin home in St. Michaels. Mr. Stevens is survived by; one son, Joseph ''Jobe'' Stevens of Selbyville, KY; two daughters, Brooke Stevens of Cambridge, MA and Sarah Webb of Alstead, NH; five grandchildren, Sarah Stevens, Joseph B. ''Ben'' Stevens III, Elizabeth Stevens, Seneca L. Webb, and Jeremy Webb. One sister, Jane Alloo, and one brother, John P. Stevens, predeceased him. A memorial service will be held at the Presbyterian Church of Chestertown Saturday December 13, 2008 at 1pm, where friends and family may call one hour prior. www.fhnfuneralhome.com

KANTROWITZ--Adrian. Physicians of the Cardiac Institute at Maimonides Medical Center mourn the loss of Dr. Adrian Kantrowitz, a pioneering legend in the annals of cardiac surgery and research. Holder of 23 patents for various medical devices, he had a special interest in the architecture and function of the heart and circulatory system. Dr. Kantrowitz performed America's first human heart transplant and invented the intra-aortic balloon pump, inspiring numerous other breakthroughs in cardiac care. He developed the concept of counterpulsation, a revolutionary means of improving heart function in congestive heart failure patients. His work on artificial hearts, pacemakers and the heart-lung machine was critical in the advancement of open-heart surgery, and his research expanded the knowledge base upon which cardiac care is founded. Dr. Kantrowitz will be remembered with respect and admiration, and we offer our condolences to his loved ones on their loss. Jacob Shani, MD, Chair, Cardiac Institute Edgar Lichstein, MD, Chair, Medicine Joseph Cunningham, MD, Chair, Surgery Stephen Lahey, MD, Director, Cardiothoracic Surgery Maimonides Medical Center KANTROWITZ--Adrian. It is with deep regret that we record the passing of eminent surgeon, teacher and researcher Adrian Kantrowitz. Known most widely as a pioneer in heart transplantation, Dr. Kantrowitz and his contemporaries defined the subspecialty of cardiothoracic surgery. He performed the first human heart transplant in the US in 1967 at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, days after the worlds first in South Africa. Dr. Kantrowitz also advanced the science of neuro-stimulation as an aid to paralysis victims. Among his many contributions to cardiac care, the intra-aortic balloon pump that he developed at Maimonides is perhaps most significant, having saved millions of lives; it continues to be the standard of care for complex cardiac conditions today. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Jean, and the family. Martin D. Payson, Chair, Board of Trustees Pamela S. Brier, President & CEO Maimonides Medical Center

THE NEWS Backing away from proposals to have the government assist a broad swath of homeowners facing foreclosure, the Bush administration instead announced a limited plan to help people who are behind in their payments on mortgages held by Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac. BEHIND THE NEWS The plan would do nothing for borrowers at the heart of the credit crisis, those with subprime mortgages, which are generally not on the books of those agencies. The head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation denounced it as inadequate. The administration said it might also ease rules for a mortgage relief program to induce more lenders to join.

FISCHMAN--Jacob H., longtime resident of Forest Hills New York passed away at the age of 97 after a short illness. Mr. Fischman was a noted Attorney who had been active in the field of government contracts law. Mr. Fischman was a graduate of New York University as well as NYU Law School. He was married to Ruth Brandwein (nee Fischman) and after her death remarried to Sylvia Buchaler. He is survived by his son Mark Fischman and his grandchildren Sarah Fischman and Jeremy Fischman.

WELLES--Leonard R., 91, of San Francisco, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, passed away peacefully on October 29 with his wife Jean of 61 years by his side. He was a devoted husband, beloved father of Barbara Seegal (John), Corinne Welles, and Robert Welles (Bernice), cherished grandfather of Sarah and Laura Seegal. Leonard was born on New York's Lower East Side in 1917 to Fanny and Harry Wolfish, served in the U.S. 5th Army in World War II during the invasions of North Africa, Sicily, Italy (Battle of Cassino) and the Battle of the Bulge. He graduated from New York University with a B.S. and M.S. in education and counseling and spent his career as an educator in New York City public schools. Leonard loved tennis, world travel, opera, and the words of Bellow, Updike and Roth. He will be remembered for his loving kindness, warmth, and unconditional love. In addition he leaves behind his loving sisters Bunny Renz and Estelle Weidmann of Florida. Interment was at Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Herb Score, Derailed by a Line Drive, Dies at 75,'' Nov. 12: I appreciated your recent obituary for the former Cleveland Indians pitcher and broadcaster Herb Score, but I was disappointed that it focused on the batted ball that shortened his playing career and only briefly mentioned that he was the radio voice of the Indians for 34 years. To any Indians fan born after Score's mishap in 1957, it was Score's superb work as a broadcaster that defined his life and reserved for him a permanent place of honor in the Cleveland community, with the line drive a mere historical footnote. David Gunton

Correction Appended IN Chiapas, the southernmost state in Mexico, green is never simply green. From the air, green rolls over the unending mountains, intense and damp where there are forests and nubbly like rough felt when the trees end. In the streets of San Crist√≥bal de las Casas, the hill town in the middle of Chiapas's central plateau, it's a shiny layer of Kelly spread thickly across the facade of a Spanish colonial home. In the church of San Juan de Chamula, it's the toasted green of pine needles strewn across the floor, and it's the thin threads woven almost invisibly into the white wool tunics of indigenous Chamulan men.

ON Tuesday, The Associated Press reported that gas prices fell for the 17th straight week since July 4. In some states, prices are now below $2 a gallon. Which makes one wonder if vehicle loyalties are about to change. After all, if higher gas prices led to frenetic demand for smaller, fuel-efficient cars, by the same logic lower gas prices should reverse that trend.

Cherished mother to daughters Terry Jean Ruben and husband Steve and Pamela Eve Brodie and husband Howard. Adored grandchildren Jon David, Phillip Seth, Andrew Lee, David Lewis, Nathaniel Saul and Joel Isaac. Exemplary, admired teacher with Dewitt Clinton High School, 1944-1978. NICASTRO--Olga, 91, died October 15, 2008. Former executive assistant and Community Services Board liaison to the New York City Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services. Predeceased by her husband, Vincent. Survived by her children, Thomas Nicastro (Margaret) and Linda Jean Siciliano (Robert); sister, Anna Jaros; granddaughters, Karen Siciliano Lucas (Kevin), Lauren Siciliano, Gabriella Kingsley (David), Elizabeth Nicastro; and great-grandson, Charles Vincent Lucas. RICHSTONE--May, defying Dylan Thomas, went gentle into that good night, dying peacefully on November 7th, just six days shy of her 101st birthday. Educated, intelligent and exceptionally witty, she wrote light verse and essays professionally, and was published frequently in periodicals such as the Saturday Evening Post and The Wall Street Journal. She never complained, was always there for others, and she saw the best in everyone. She had a very loving husband David, and an adoring family who took care of her when he no longer could. She leaves behind an immediate and extended family grateful for her long, healthy life and painless death. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 23rd at 3pm at Etcetera Etcetera Restaurant at 352 W. 44th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to Hadassah.

THE unofficial anthem of Quebec separatists includes the line, ''Mon pays ... c'est l'hiver,'' which translates roughly to ''my country: it's winter.'' So it is perhaps fitting that the province will become the first in Canada to require winter tires on all cars beginning on Dec. 15. The new law, prompted by recommendations from a coroner's report on the traffic death of a 21-year-old motorist in 2004, has been applauded by safety experts. But as the Dec. 15 deadline approaches, the law is proving to be a headache for some procrastinating car owners and a bonanza for tire shops and thieves.

9 P.M. (National Geographic) UNLOCKING THE GREAT PYRAMID For seven nights, National Geographic will take viewers on missions around the planet and into outer space during its Expedition Week. In this program the architect Jean-Pierre Houdin discusses his new theory of how the Great Pyramid, above, was built. Two other programs examine the life and times of King Tutankhamun, starting at 8 with ''King Tut and the Lost Dynasty,'' in which a team led by Dr. Zahi Hawass tries to resolve the fate of Queen Nefertiti, and continuing at 10 with ''King Tut's Final Secrets,'' which unravels some of the intriguing circumstances surrounding the young Egyptian pharaoh's death and uses 3-D imaging to reconstruct his face. 10 A.M. SLIDESHOW: GRASS-ROOTS LABOR FOR BUFFALO'S ARCHITECTURE A slide show of landmarks in Buffalo, home to some of the greatest American architecture of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. A grass-roots movement driven by part-time preservationists, amateur historians and third-generation residents has made reclaiming the city's history a deeply personal mission. KRASNER--Irving, July 7, 1924-November 15, 2008. Irving Krasner died of heart failure after a long and happy life. In WWII he served in the U.S. Navy from 1941 to 1945, where he piloted a PBY Catalina, also called a Black Cat, on submarine patrol on the U.S. West Coast and in the Pacific theatre. Upon returning to civilian life, he built a successful business in wholesale Kosher provisions. His reputation for honesty, integrity and reliability was the trademark of both his business and his life. Even his competitors were his close friends. In March of 1950 he married Selma Katz and their union was strong for 58 years. He is survived by his wife and his daughter Vivian, and was predeceased by his daughter Laura in 1970. His generosity extended beyond his country and family to his community. As a loyal Mason, he was Master of Felicity Lodge, #

GOLDMAN--George S., M.D., one of the first Americanborn and trained psychoanalysts, who practiced psychiatry for more than 55 years in New York City, died suddenly and peacefully at home in McLean, VA on November 8, 2008. He was 102. Dr. Goldman obtained his M.D. from Yale University in '29 then trained at the NY Psychoanalytic Institute. During WWII, Dr. Goldman (Lt. Col., Army) trained psychiatrists to treat battle fatigue, and served as advisor for renowned psychiatric training films: John Huston's Let There Be Light ('46) and Shades of Gray ('48). He was president, Assn for Psychoanalytic Medicine ('59-'61), and was one of the founders of Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, where he served as Director ('61-'71). He married Jeanne Gordon, a Broadway and opera singer, in 1941. Dr. Goldman practiced until 1991, when he and his wife moved to live with daughter S. Amber Gordon, son-in-law Mark J. Estren, and grandchildren Meredith and Nick Estren. His wife died in 1998. Loving survivors include daughter Kathryn Goldman-Schuyler, son-in-law Jim Schuyler (San Francisco, CA), and many nephews, nieces, and cousins. George Goldman always put others' needs ahead of his own. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, for the George S. Goldman Award (given annually to a psychoanalyst for outstanding achievements), 1051 Riverside Dr., New York, NY 10032. A memorial service will be held Sunday, December 7, 1pm, at Field School, 2301 Foxhall Rd. NW, Washington DC, 20007.

SCHWARTZ--Mark . Stephen. Former Oklahoma City Councilman Mark Stephen Schwartz, 58, ended a courageous two year battle with cancer on November 13th. Born in New York City, he spent his formative years in New York and returned often. Mark was preceded in death by his father, Irving Schwartz, D.D.S. He is survived by his devoted mother Roz, brother Jay Goodman and wife Elaine, nieces Michelle and Danielle, special cousin Geraldine and husband Sheldon Markel and other loving relatives. Mark drew strength from the love and support of his adored companion, Gail Meltzner and her daughters Jamie and Leslie. Mark served many years on the Oklahoma City Council, was President of the National League of Cities and later Deputy General Counsel at the Dept. of Energy. Funeral services will be 1pm, Tuesday, November 18th at the Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 N Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to ZERO: The Project to End Prostate Cancer http://www.zerocancer.org/ index.html, or Temple Bnai Israel in Oklahoma City http://www.thetemple okc.org/

''He had all these ladies coming in with their girly kitten heels, and I saw the opportunity to do something different -- something more aggressive,'' Mr. Kirkwood said. Good decision. In the three years since he started his line of amped-up, architectural, sky-high shoes, Mr. Kirkwood has collaborated with Chlo√©, Phillip Lim, Gareth Pugh and Rodarte; landed a job designing footwear for the newly revived Italian label Pollini; and garnered the adoration of influential fashion players like Anna Dello Russo of Japanese Vogue, Cecilia Dean of Visionaire, and Sarah

DESPITE the fact that no one seems to be buying anything at the moment, Lindsey Thornburg chose an auspicious time to introduce her line of hooded blanket coats. ''I think people right now want to feel protected,'' she said. ''They want to wrap themselves up in a magical security blanket.'' Bonus points, she added, if they can look chic doing it. Her coats, created from vivid South American wools and lined in silk, were inspired by a trip to the highlands of Peru. There, women bundle babies and groceries in brightly patterned blankets, and ''it just seemed applicable to the city,'' Ms. Thornburg explained. ''Cloaking yourself in layers, but at the same time looking fashion-forward and colorful and fun.''

She leaves a niece, Beth and six nephews: Paul, Alex, Bob, Tom, Nick and Mike: two step-children: Jack Musgrove, Jr. and Melissa Smith; and four grandchildren: Cameron, Corin, Madison and Virginia. Susan was smart, funny, wise and a great dance partner. She will be greatly missed. A Memorial Service will be held at the Wellesley College chapel on November 22 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Wellesley College or to cancer research.

KOREIN--Julius M.D., 65 years of friendship and love can not vanish in a moment. The laughter, the craziness, the achievements, the shared triumphs, will continue into perpetuity and will remain emblazoned in our hearts forever. Judy and Jerry Hornig KOREIN--Dr. Julius, a noted neurologist, died on November 12. He was 80 years old. Dr. Korein was best known for his work on brain death, including his testimony on the Quinlan case. He did extensive research in biofeedback, including treatment of Tortocollis and Dystonia and other diseases. Dr. Korein spent most of his professional life as a professor of neurology at NYU and as a research physician at Bellevue Hospital. But his lifelong passion was to understand the nature of the universe and the brain. He had an abiding belief that these systems were governed by scientific laws, and he strove to find them. He was a major coin collector, and he created the world's most complete collection of Gobrecht Dollars, which he donated to the American Numismatic Society. He was also chairman of the Korein Foundation, a charitable organization which supports scientific, environmental and educational causes. In addition, he was an avid scuba diver for many years and explored reefs around the globe. He leaves his significant other, Gillian Hee, former wives Frances Korein and Joan Miller, his sister Elysabeth Kleinhans, three children, James, Jonathan and Beth, nine grandchildren and a great-granddaughter. He will be missed. A memorial service will be held at ''The Riverside'' at 76th and Amsterdam in Manhattan on Sunday, November 16 at 12:45pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Korein Foundation c/o Glenmede, Att: Nina Cohen, 1650 Market St., Suite 1200, Philadelphia, PA 19103. KOREIN--Julius, M.D. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and esteemed client, Dr. Julius Korein, and send heartfelt condolences to his family. He was a gentleman of the highest order and will be greatly missed. Lawrence N. Friedland Samuel P. Ross Warren R. Gleicher

OLIVO--Roxanne, daughter of Dr. Morris and Sylvia Berman, sister of Loretta Kuehn, died at 11:20am, Saturday November 8th, 2008 of lung cancer at age 62. Roxanne was First National Chairman of (NARAL) National Abortion Rights Action League. She was the head of voluntary sterilization. President of the Lennox Hill Democratic Club, a member of her community board and founder of comprehensive systems. She was a social activist who cared deeply about justice and women's rights. Now she is with her devoted parents. May the sun pierce her soul with its warmth and may she forever bask in the love and security and memory of her family and friends.

CAPTURING A CLOSE-UP, CHITRAL, PAKISTAN, JUNE 28, 2008 David Braid, 32, a high school teacher from Melbourne, Australia, photographs a Kalash girl on her way to school in the Bumboret Valley of the Hindu Kush mountains. ''My sister has this business that helps the ladies of Pakistan by buying their traditional fabric to make clothes that she sells. She spends a lot of time in Chitral, and my girlfriend and I came over to visit and traveled around that area. The Kalash -- they're not Muslim; they're a sort of tribal people native to that area -- they're cut off from the rest of the world for five to seven months of the year. Lots of them dressed like that girl, and they still live in the traditional houses that they've been living in for thousands of years. I guess slowly they're getting integrated -- the women are marrying Muslim men, their lifestyle is changing. But they're still there. I don't know how much longer their culture is going to be there like that, but it's just amazing that it is like that now.''

BEN-AVI--Joan, daughter of Sophie and Paul Sampliner. She was born in Cleveland, Ohio on May 26, 1923, and died at home in White Plains, New York, on November 11, 2008. She attended Smith College. Joan was an avid reader, an art lover with an innate sense of aesthetics and style. A lover of music and theater, she was a gourmet and took great interest in nutritional and medical matters. She was a true intellectual; interested in a great variety of subjects, and as she often said, had a ''need to know''. Joan was a true friend and a loyal, devoted mother, a truly grand and kind woman. Married to Avrum Ben-Avi, a clinical psychologist, for 36 years. During their marriage they traveled widely, primarily in Europe. The marriage ended in divorce, but the two remained on good terms until their deaths. Joan is survived by her brother, Philip Sampliner, her son Jason Ben-Avi, and her daughters Sigrid Balmer, and Nina Ben-Avi Schreiber; two sons-in-law: Reg Balmer and Marc Schreiber; as well as four grandchildren: Alice and Sarah Balmer, and Julia and Emma Ben-Avi. One of Joan's great delights was an annual family vacation in Nantucket at each summer's end, where she gathered her children and grandchildren at an inn by the sea. This strong, fiercely independent woman who was loved and respected by so many, will be greatly missed.

BOHR--David F., 93, Hypertension Expert. David F. Bohr, Professor of Physiology, University of Michigan died November 4, 2008 in Ann Arbor. Bohr was known for his pioneering work explaining the role played by the vasculature in hypertension. He received many awards including: the Ciba Award for Hypertension Research and the Gold Heart Award from American Heart Association; and the Lifetime Achievement Award, University of Michigan. Dr. Bohr served many societies including the Council for High Blood Pressure Research and the American Physiological Society. Dr. Bohr, preceded in death by his wife Kathleen, is survived by a son, John Nicholas Bohr, two daughters, Ann (Barbara) Bohr Benner, and Louise Ann Bohr, and two grandchildren Thomas Bohr Benner, and Jack Allen Benner. Family, friends and students enjoyed his ready sense of humor, his compassion, optimism and love of learning. His mentoring was extraordinary. A memorial service will be held on January 31, 2009 in Ann Arbor at the Michigan League, noon to 4:00pm. Contributions should be made to the David F. Bohr Quasi Endowment, Dept. of Molecular and Integrative Physiology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109 (physiology.med.umich.edu).

Mendocino, Calif., 1986. Sunrise. Vernon looks at Charlene; Charlene looks at Vernon. Lying in bed, they're surrounded by a paradise of their own making -- an organic garden, freely ranging chickens and pigs, a growing reputation as slow-food artistes. Two small caveats: Charlene is eight and a half months pregnant; Vernon hates their growing reputation as slow-food artistes. Vernon looks at Charlene. He says, ''Let's leave.'' She nods. Into a satchel they throw two vases, a Hobart mixer, some Mason jars of preserves. They drive away in a borrowed car. Vernon and Charlene, gone forever from Mendocino, leaving behind a restaurant, a house, equipment, art, fixtures, wine, broken promises. (''Just things,'' Vernon says now with a shrug, ignoring the promises.) Charlene and Vernon met at Chez Panisse, where she was a cook, he a budding wine guru. This was the late '70s, when Alice Waters was remaking American cooking into a cuisine de bonne femme crossed with a Heideggerian reverence for Mother Earth. Charlene and Vernon worshiped Alice but preferred Mother Earth. ''What they were talking about, we were doing,'' Charlene says. ''We actually lived it.'' The couple decamped to Mendocino, planted a garden, opened the New Boonville Hotel, and soon the restaurant had a cult following. ''Ruth Reichl did an article,'' Vernon says, ''and suddenly we had a lot of publicity.''

The painter Geoffrey Raymond recalls standing outside the offices of Bear Stearns in the spring, offering a marker to a laid-off employee. He watched as she took the marker and scrawled some words on an image of James E. Cayne, the company's chairman. Bear Stearns's situation had become so dire that it was being forced to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase. ''My blood is boiling,'' the former employee wrote.

Address: 201 West 89th Street (at Amsterdam Avenue), No. 4G The Property: A classic two-bedroom two-bath prewar co-op in Chester Court with a gracious foyer, a dining room that could be easily converted to a third bedroom and a washer and dryer. It is in a doorman building with a gym, basketball court and roof deck, and mail delivery to the apartment door. The living and dining rooms face another part of the building, but the bedrooms look out onto the lovely courtyard of neighboring Astor Court. The monthly maintenance, $1,248, includes utilities.

WORTHINGTON--Carol Ann, daughter of Ellen Ann Anderson - Worthington and Clarence Jacob Worthington. Born on July 30, 1947. Passed away November 4, 2008, from a heart related disorder. She spent her growing up years in New Jersey. Studied design at New York Schools. Became a designer for Bernardo Sandals in 1967. Spent most of her career working in the footwear industry for corporations such as Stride-Rite and Reebok. She had a true gift for life and all who knew her, marveled at her artistic abilities. After moving to California in 1987, she retired from Reebok and became a wine country artist specializing in gold leaf plates. Her culinary abilities were legendary among her many friends. A true bon vivant and grande dame, the likes are not soon to pass our way again. Sadly missed and held in our hearts forever. She is survived by her husband, James F. Bershad of Novato, CA and her brother, James Worthington of Flemington, NJ.

GERTEL--Leon M.D., passed away in New York City on November 9, 2008 at 95 from Parkinson's Disease. He always maintained his warm smile, bright eyes and sparkling personality. Survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Cecile Mayer Gertel and adoring sister, Leonia Nussbaum; missed by his adoring children, Elisa Gertel Barsky and Carl Barsky, Shereen Gertel Rutman and Howard Rutman as well as grandchildren, Samuel, Deborah and Naphtali Barsky and Melissa and Stephen Rutman. He was also very close to his sister-in-law and brother-in-law and his late siblings, as well as many nieces and nephews and their children. Dr. Gertel studied at the Jagellonian University in Krakow and received dental and medical degrees from the University of Munich. A leader of the post-liberation Jewish students' union, he remained active in the Munich University Jewish Alumni Association. After completing his internal medicine and psychiatric training in the United States, Dr. Gertel served as the Medical Director for Mental Health Services at the Catholic Diocese of Central New Jersey and maintained an active private psychiatry practice in East Brunswick. He was treasured by his patients and beloved by his colleagues. In his long psychiatric career, Dr. Gertel provided balance, judgment, wisdom and insight. His kind heart, keen intelligence, warmth and positive outlook throughout his life serves as an inspiration to all who knew him. Funeral services were held on Tuesday, November 11th and Shiva will conclude on Sunday evening at the Rutman home.

AT Maryam Nassir Zadeh, a boutique on the Lower East Side, customers can walk out with an art book or an Ohne Titel tribal print dress; a potted plant or a Peruvian blanket. There are Erickson Beamon crystal cuffs, a stack of old Panama hats, Argentine suede ponchos and a tabletop of vintage Ala√Øa belts -- and that's just in one corner. It is an eclectic mix of inspired pieces, artfully arranged in a raw, white space; and it makes for an exceptional new shop. ''The intention was to create a sensory overload in a well-curated way,'' said Maryam Nassirzadeh, who opened the store last month with her fianc√©, Uday Kak, an art director. ''It's not about trends, it's about mixing things we find beautiful, in a way that would surprise people.''

It‚Äôs a dream come true for fans of Bruce Springsteen: the blue-collar bard of Asbury Park, N.J., will release his newest album, ‚ÄúWorking on a Dream,‚Äù on Jan. 27, days before he plays the Super Bowl halftime show, his publicist said in a press release. The new album, recorded with the E Street Band, will be the 24th of Mr. Springsteen‚Äôs career, and the fourth to be produced by Brendan O‚ÄôBrien, who also produced Mr. Springsteen‚Äôs recent albums ‚ÄúThe Rising,‚Äù ‚ÄúDevils and Dust,‚Äù and ‚ÄúMagic.‚Äù Among the 12 songs (plus two bonus tracks) included on the album are the title song, which Mr. Springsteen first performed at a ClevelandColumbus, Ohio, rally for the presidential campaign of Barack Obama, as well as ‚ÄúThe Wrestler,‚Äù from the Darren Aronofsky movie of the same name. Mr. Springsteen and the E Street Band are scheduled to play the halftime show of Super Bowl XLIII on Feb. 1 in Tampa, Fla.

The comedian Katt Williams has sought medical attention and has canceled a coming concert, his publicist, Yvette Shearer, said in a statement. The Item newspaper of Sumter, S.C., reported that the police had been summoned to take Mr. Williams to an area hospital.

The Oregon Ballet Theater has become the latest regional arts company to find itself affected by the tightening economy. The ballet, based in Portland, has announced that to cut costs it will use recorded music instead of a live orchestra at 10 of its 16 performances of ‚ÄúThe Nutcracker‚Äù in December, The Oregonian reported. Donations to the ballet are down 20 percent this year, and nine staff members at the company have taken 5 percent paycuts, while productions cuts have saved about $300,000, or 5 percent of the ballet‚Äôs $6.7 million annual budget. ‚ÄúThis is the stark reality of these times,‚Äù Jon Ulsh, the executive director of the ballet, told The Oregonian.

As we learned in ‚ÄúBody Heat,‚Äù Kathleen Turner likes her men not too smart, and apparently she appreciates them in drag, too: the actress has joined the cast of Charles Busch‚Äôs coming off-Broadway play ‚ÄúThe Third Story,‚Äù in which Ms. Turner will appear opposite Mr. Busch, who plays the show‚Äôs other female lead. The casting announcement was made by the show‚Äôs producers, MCC Theater. ‚ÄúThe Third Story,‚Äù a satire of gangster movies, science fiction and fairy tales, is written by Mr. Busch and directed by Carl Andress; it will begin preview performances at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Jan. 14 and open on Feb. 2, continuing through Feb. 28. It is the first off-Broadway show for Ms. Turner since ‚ÄúMr. T‚Äù in 1977.

KCRW, the Santa Monica, Calif., public radio station, has named Jason Bentley its new music director and host of its influential ‚ÄúMorning Becomes Eclectic‚Äù program, effective Dec. 1, the station said. Mr. Bentley, who has worked for KCRW in various capacities (including as a phone volunteer while still in college) has also worked as a music producer and record executive, and as the music supervisor for the soundtracks to the ‚ÄúMatrix‚Äù movies. He will take over the position and the hosting duties from Nic Harcourt, the British-born DJ who, as host of ‚ÄúMorning Becomes Eclectic‚Äù program, helped introduce audiences to artists including Coldplay, Norah Jones and Franz Ferdinand. Mr. Harcourt is resigning to pursue other projects, but will continue to host a Sunday night show on the station.

Reports of the demise of ‚ÄúLipstick Jungle‚Äù look like they were premature. The NBC drama about well-heeled women in New York, starring Brooke Shields, was shuffled off to Friday nights two weeks ago amid reports that the show was canceled and the remaining finished episodes would not get on air. But as of this week, ‚ÄúLipstick Jungle‚Äù is breathing again. The reason: it showed signs of life on Friday, and it picked up 50 percent more viewers when delayed viewing (from DVRs and other devices) was included in the ratings for the episode broadcast a week earlier. Ben Silverman, the co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, said that NBC will now definitely finish the 13 episodes that the network originally ordered ‚Äî it has 4 more episodes to run ‚Äî and may order more if the show ‚Äúgrows more.‚Äù

A vast fleet of pianos is expected to arrive in Cincinnati next month, part of the largest order ‚Äî by number of instruments ‚Äî ever filled by the Steinway & Sons piano company. The College-Conservatory of Music of the University of Cincinnati said it is plunking down $4.1 million for 165 pianos, to be delivered over the course of the academic year. (That‚Äôs 14,520 keys, for whoever‚Äôs counting.) The purchase was to be considered by the school‚Äôs board on Tuesday. If approved, the purchase will make Cincinnati an ‚Äúall-Steinway‚Äù school. The idea is partly to help raise the school‚Äôs profile in the conservatory world, where it is not always viewed as in the top rank, said Douglas Knehans, the dean. ‚ÄúIt sends a deep message about our seriousness and credibility,‚Äù he said.

During the Olympics, Ritan Park was a designated "protest zone", but no one ever got permission to protest and crews of old ladies were employed to lurk around the park watching for potential disturbances. Before the Games, one of the park's seedier attractions also shut down and has remained closed: Maggies bar. Maggies had existed for more than a decade in several locations and was notorious amongst Beijing expatriates for its Mongolian prostitutes who catered exclusively to foreign men, a business decision that kept the cops from the door, at least until the pre-Olympic clean up campaign.

Today we have a guest post by Michael Melcher, a career coach and frequent contributor to Shifting Careers. He offers some advice on how to handle the silence people often face in response to calls and e-mails sent in connection with a job search. Though he came up with these tips specifically to help those looking for new jobs, the advice also applies to any situation in which you are making a contact and hoping for an answer -- from pitching a product or service to setting up informational interviews or raising money for a new venture. -- Marci

Jim Grosfeld, the former chief executive of Pulte Homes, and a board member at BlackRock, the investment firm, has become one of my regular correspondents. Along with a small handful of others, he has spent much of his time recently trying to come up with ideas to help homeowners avoid foreclosures, which remains the country's most pressing economic problem. Until the rate of foreclosures slows, the crisis simply will not come to an end (though you would never know that from the government's appalling lack of urgency). Continued foreclosures hurt housing prices for everyone -- and that, in turn, will mean continued multi-billion write-downs on Wall Street, further jeopardizing the financial system.

Just as the fierce Santa Ana winds that had fanned three major wildfires in Southern California were abating, a small earthquake -- 4.1 in magnitude -- shook the area around San Diego early Monday morning. A seismologist with the California Institute of Technology told the Associated Press that the quake could be felt from San Diego to Palm Desert. It did little or no damage, but did serve as a reminder.

"But I see this as a perfect time," said David Blumenthal, president of Lion Brand Yarn Company, which on Tuesday is opening the first retail store in its 130-year-old history as a wholesaler.

For some reason, November has become flower give-away month in New York City. It happened last year with children in a public art project, and it happened again on Monday morning, as the Colombian flower industry decided to shower New York commuters with 100,000 blossoms. More than 100 volunteers, most of them Colombian-Americans living in the region, distributed the flowers in busy commuter locations including Wall Street, Pennsylvania Station, Grand Central Terminal and Times Square.

For fans here, watching players arrive at Beaver Stadium in a chain of blue buses is another game day staple.

A sequel to the ballyhooed debate in 2007 over the motion that "Global Warming is Not a Crisis" has been scheduled in New York City in January, this time exploring a new premise: "Major Reductions in Carbon Emissions are Not Worth the Money." Those in favor of the motion (some additions may come, organizers say) will be the "skeptical environmentalist" Bjorn Lomborg; Philip Stott, the British biogeographer who has become a prominent critic of global warming worriers; and Peter W. Huber, the Manhattan Institute scholar, lawyer and mechanical engineer who has written that energy waste is unavoidable and beneficial.

Less than a day after Goldman Sachs said its top executives would give up their bonuses this year, UBS announced Monday that its chairman, Peter Kurer; its chief executive, Marcel Rohner; and members of its executive board would also have a bonus-free 2008.

"Nursery University," the new documentary about the cutthroat, only-in-New-York, ritualized frenzy involved in getting 2- and 3-year-olds into nursery school, had its New York City premiere before a packed audience on Saturday evening as part of the Margaret Mead Film and Video Festival at the American Museum of Natural History.

Will Shortz, the crossword puzzle editor of The New York Times, was on last night's episode of "The Simpsons," helping to heal a rift between Homer and Lisa. Media | Anyone listening to conservative talk radio lately knows how galvanized the right would become were Democrats to try to bring back the "fairness doctrine," requiring equal time for viewpoints in broadcasts. Internet | Get up to speed with the view of blogs as descended from Renaissance "cabinets of wonder," or Wunderkammern. Back then, they were encyclopedic, idiosyncratic collections of objects whose categorical boundaries were yet to be defined by modern science. Bloggers, too, "present a collection of images, ideas, and objects in a style and order specific to his or her own vision: a personal taxonomy." [Cabinet of Wonder, Julian Dibbell]

Maybe it was the tombstone that did it. Even as Wall Street burned, Silicon Valley seemed strangely sanguine. Then a PowerPoint presentation from Sequoia Capital prophesying Armageddon - featuring an "R.I.P. Good Times" headstone - made the rounds. A month later, venture capital firms are slashing investments and counseling portfolio companies to cut jobs. Sequoia's warning may reflect the technology industry's woes, but it's more notable for what it says about venture capital.

Analysts, investors and media around Asia expressed concern Monday that a weekend summit of world leaders aimed at tackling the global financial crisis -- and preventing future debacles -- was high on symbolism but low on action, the Associated Press reported.

9 P.M. (National Geographic) DIRECT FROM THE MOON The Apollo astronaut Buzz Aldrin watches breathtaking images of the Moon's craters and haunting plains, and observes an Earth-rise in this second ''Expedition Week'' installment. The episode looks at the Selene, a Japanese lunar orbiter custom-built to map the Moon's surface and measure its magnetic and gravitational fields. For the last year it has been beaming high-definition images back to Earth. NASA scientists discuss the challenges involved in and innovations under way for establishing a lunar outpost. 8 P.M. Kevin J. Martin, above, is certainly trying to make his last weeks as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission eventful. (Mr. Martin doesn't have to step down when a new president takes office, but that is the tradition.) Mr. Martin is poking at rates for cable television service. He sent a letter to 13 big cable and telephone companies, asking about recent changes they have made to pay-TV prices and service tiers.

The Commerce Department reported a record retail sales decline in October, down 4.1 percent from October 2007. Earnings reports last week deepened the dark retail outlook, as stores like Abercrombie & Fitch, Neiman Marcus, the Gap and Saks Fifth Avenue reported double-digit sales declines in October. Traffic to retail Web sites rose significantly over 2007, with substantial increases at Walmart, QVC.com, Home Depot and Lowe's. Traffic was up at most of the sites in the retail category, although the numbers don't reveal whether people were buying or window shopping. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Warner Brothers is scaling back its DVD sales in South Korea because of rampant illegal movie downloading. But at the same time it is greatly expanding its authorized Internet movie distribution. It will now start renting movies over the Internet two weeks before they are released on DVD, making South Korea the first market in the world where movies will appear online before they hit store shelves.

NOBLE--Carolie Woods, 81, died peacefully at her home in Mystic, CT on November 12, 2008. Mrs. Noble was the daughter of Colonel Arthur H. Woods and Lt. Colonel Helen H. Woods. Her beloved husband Marshall Hays Noble predeceased her in 2002. An accomplished artist and sculptor, Mrs. Noble graduated from Scripps College in 1947 and did graduate work at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. She recently completed a bronze head of her son, Valentine Hollingsworth III. Mrs. Noble was the sponsor of the submarine U.S.S. Alexander Hamilton, which was launched on August 18, 1962. This connection to the submarine service and her strong belief in the value of a college education led her, with her first husband Valentine Hollingsworth, Jr., to establish The Thresher Fund in 1963 to provide educational scholarships for the children of the submarines who perished on the U.S.S. Thresher in April of that year. She is survived by her brother, John P. Woods, of South Harpswell, ME, five children, Tracy Hollingsworth of Alexandria, VA, Helen Hollingsworth of Wayland, MA, Valentine Hollingsworth III of Dover, MA, Laura Hollingsworth of Farmington, CT, and Arthur Hollingsworth of Dallas, TX, their spouses and numerous nieces and nephews. She was the proud grandmother of fourteen grandchildren. Services will be held Monday, November 24, 11:00am, at the Calvary Church, 27 Church St., Stonington, CT. Contributions will be appreciated by the Dolphin Scholarship Foundation to benefit submarines and their families, 4966 Euclid Road, Suite 109, Virginia Beach, VA 23462 or the National Foundation for Cancer Research, 4600 East West Highway, Suite 525, Bethesda, MD 20814. 1-800-321-CURE (2873). www.buckler - johns ton.com for online condolences and shared memories.

KRACKLAUER--William F., died on November 6, 2008, at age 45. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, he earned a BA in political science and French from the University of Notre Dame, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. A Rotary Foundation Ambassadorial Scholar in Geneva, Switzerland, he also received his JD from the Columbia University School of Law. He began his career as an associate at the law firm of White & Case and subsequently joined the firm of Christy & Viener, later serving as Assistant General Counsel to Primedia, VP and General Counsel to Yellow Book USA, and Senior VP, General Counsel, and Corporate Secretary to Hooper Holmes. An active member of the University Club of New York since 1993, he was most recently Club Secretary and an Officer of the Council. An avid horseman, he took particular pleasure in riding with his family in the countryside surrounding Katonah, NY. Mr. Kracklauer is survived by his wife, Liane Pei; his son, Matthew Pei Kracklauer; his parents, Frederick and Patricia Kracklauer; and sisters Julie Tomer and Beth Kracklauer. A memorial service is scheduled at the University Club, 1 W. 54th St., NY, NY, for Monday, December 15 at 1pm. In Mr. Kracklauers honor, donations earmarked to benefit the retired horses of the NYPD Mounted Unit can be sent to the NYC Police Foundation, 345 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10154.

When Google released its Flu Trends service last week, the Drudge Report flashed a headline that read: ''Sick Surveillance: Google Reports Flu Searches, Locations to Feds.'' Google sought to avoid this kind of reaction by talking about how Google Flu Trends protects the privacy of its users. The service relies ''on anonymized, aggregated counts of how often certain search queries occur each week,'' Google said.

It is not only retail stores that are feeling the pinch as shoppers close their wallets just ahead of the holiday season. E-commerce sales, though still growing faster than traditional retail, are hurting, too. Online spending growth slowed to 6 percent in the third quarter over the year before, down from 13 percent in the second quarter, according to comScore. Growth rates have declined every month since April, and September's rate of 5 percent was the lowest recorded by comScore since it started tracking e-commerce in 2001. Sales of consumer electronics, computers and cellphones were flat, and sales of clothes, toys, jewelry, music and movies were down from a year ago.

Look around Joann Ritter's apartment in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn and you will see an entire room of hand-me-downs. Her sister gave her the bed and the portable closet; her nephew gave her the television set; the microwave oven came from a neighbor who was about to throw it out; the kitchen chairs, she found on the street. ''Everybody tried to help us,'' Ms. Ritter, 52, said the other day. ''We had nothing -- or less than nothing. We were sleeping on the floor.''

Always ready to laugh at himself, the family joke was: He never discriminated; he treated everyone the same! He'll be missed by many who knew him as outgoing, always ready to help.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve never been a fan of ‚ÄòStar Trek,‚Äô‚Äù J. J. Abrams told a movie theater full of journalists on Monday night ‚Äì a perfectly reasonable sentiment, except that Mr. Abrams happens to be the director of the big-budget, high-stakes ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù film that Paramount is releasing in May.

The cellist Yo-Yo Ma has been named musician of the year by Musical America, the industry publication announced. Mr. Ma was awarded the honor for his mastery of ‚Äútraditional classics from the baroque to the moderns‚Äù and for his Silk Road Project, which ‚Äúhas extended the normal boundaries of his instrument toward infinity,‚Äù Stephanie Challener, the publisher of Musical America, said in a statement. Musical America also announced that Christopher Rouse had been named its composer of the year; Marin Alsop, of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, was chosen conductor of the year; the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe was named vocalist of the year; and the Pacifica Quartet was selected as ensemble of the year.

Dan Fogler, start working out your vocal cords: the burly actor (a Tony winner for Broadway‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee‚Äù) has been cast to play the vociferous comedian Sam Kinison in a biographical film for HBO, Variety reported. The film, ‚ÄúBrother Sam,‚Äù will tell the story of Kinison, the one-time Pentecostal preacher turned standup performer, who died in a car accident in 1992 at the age of 38. It is adapted from the memoir of the same name, written by Kinison‚Äôs brother and manager, Bill, and Steve Delsohn, and will be directed by Tom Shadyac (‚ÄúThe Nutty Professor,‚Äù ‚ÄúBruce Almighty‚Äù). A script has been written by Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini, the writers and directors of the film ‚ÄúAmerican Splendor,‚Äù about the comic-book writer Harvey Pekar.

When final box-office figures were reported for ‚ÄúQuantum of Solace,‚Äù the new James Bond movie saw its record-breaking numbers stirred, but not dramatically shaken: ‚ÄúSolace,‚Äù the 22nd official entry in the Bond franchise, earned $67.5 million in its opening weekend, according to the box-office tracking firm Media By Numbers. That‚Äôs slightly lower than the $70.4 million in ticket sales estimated on Sunday afternoon, but still a personal best for any Bond movie in the 46-year history of the series. It‚Äôs also a strong improvement over the $40.8 million take of the 2006 release ‚ÄúCasino Royale,‚Äù in which Daniel Craig made his debut as 007, and ‚ÄúDie Another Day,‚Äù the previous record-holder, which opened with $47.1 million in 2002.

The 2009 national tour of ‚ÄúDreamgirls,‚Äù the musical by Henry Krieger and Tom Eyen oh-so-loosely based on the history of Motown Records, will have its premiere at the Apollo Theater in Harlem, the tour‚Äôs producers announced. The ‚ÄúDreamgirls‚Äù tour, to be directed and choreographed by Bobby Longbottom with co-choreography by Shane Sparks, will begin performances at the Apollo Theater in November 2009, as part of the theater‚Äôs 75th anniversary. The show‚Äôs producers previously announced that open auditions for the lead roles of Deena, Lorrell and Effie, of the fictitious girl group the Dreams, would be held at the Apollo on Saturday. The original Broadway production of ‚ÄúDreamgirls‚Äù ran for 1,522 performances from 1981 to 1985; the show was also adapted into a hit 2006 film that starred Beyonc√© Knowles.

A lawyer for Michael Jackson said that the pop star may be too sick to travel to London to testify in a suit filed against him by a Bahrainian prince, The Associated Press reported. Sheik Abdulla bin Hamad Al Khalifa, the second son of the king of Bahrain, filed suit against Mr. Jackson for $7 million. He is seeking repayment for money he gave to Mr. Jackson beginning in 2005, including $2.2 million dollars to cover Mr. Jackson‚Äôs legal bill in a child-molestation trial in Los Angeles that year; Mr. Jackson contends that those payments were gifts. A lawyer for the sheik plans to play in court a song written by the sheik and recorded by Mr. Jackson as proof of their close collaboration; Mr. Jackson is seeking to give his testimony by video from the United States.

The district attorney‚Äôs office of Clark County, Nev., is seeking criminal charges against the hip-hop mogul Marion (Suge) Knight, The Associated Press reported. On Monday, a criminal complaint was sent to the Las Vegas Justice Court, charging Mr. Knight with two counts of felony drug possession and one count of misdemeanor battery. The charges stem from an incident in August when Mr. Knight, the founder of the now-bankrupt label Death Row Records, was arrested after officers said they saw him beat a woman while brandishing a knife in a parking lot near the Las Vegas Strip. Mr. Knight was also charged with possession of a controlled substance, and later released after posting $19,000 bail.

National Public Radio announced that it had chosen the firm Hickok Cole Architects to design its new headquarters in Washington. Hickok Cole, led by Michael E. Hickok and Yolanda Cole, was chosen over three other contenders for a design that will incorporate an existing four-story building at 1111 N. Capitol Street NE (built in 1927 for the Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Company) within a new ten-story structure. The new 360,000-square-foot headquarters will include a 60,000-square-foot studio, as well as a studio space for public events, and an exhibition called ‚ÄúThis is NPR.‚Äù No start date was announced for construction.

Hey, Marissa, welcome back to the Sixties: Marissa Jaret Winokur, who originated the role of Tracy Turnblad in the Broadway musical adaptation of ‚ÄúHairspray,‚Äù will return to the show for its final month of performances, its producers announced. Ms. Winokur, who won a 2003 Tony Award for her portrayal of the spunky, plus-sized Tracy, will return to ‚ÄúHairspray‚Äù on Dec. 9. There, she‚Äôll rejoin her fellow founding cast member Harvey Fierstein, who has returned to the show in the outsize role of Tracy‚Äôs mother, Edna Turnblad. ‚ÄúHairspray‚Äù is scheduled to play its final show at the Neil Simon Theater on Jan. 4.

In honor of that, I thought I'd look at a remark that a friend recently made: "We spend so much time wailing about extinction, but we never celebrate new species."

Update | 8:43 p.m. With most of the remaining ballots counted in Alaska, Anchorage Mayor Mark Begich appears to have unseated long-time Senator Ted Stevens, widening the Democrat's lead to 3,724 votes. The new count pretty much closes the door on Mr. Stevens' hopes of re-election. According to the latest official count by the Alaska Division of Elections, Mr. Begich has 150,728 and Mr. Stevens trails with 147,004.

It has been noted that the Steelers' 11-10 victory on Sunday was the first N.F.L. game to end with that score. But occurrences of unique final scores are not exactly unusual. The blog at pro-football-reference.com reckons they happen several times a season. Besides 11-10, this season has already produced the never-seen-on-a-scoreboard finals of 48-25, 48-29*, 56-35*, 40-26, 48-41, 37-32, and 47-3*.

Inside the church of San Juan de Chamula, a fine cloud of smoke filled the air. It rose in wisps from hundreds of thin, white candles, perched delicately on the floor in ranks of 5, 10, 20, 40. Scattered around them lay a loose carpet of pine needles, the green arcs overlapping in dizzying patterns. The scents of pine resin, melted wax and burning wick mingled in my nose, and the chanted prayers of the indigenous Chamulans - who knelt before the candles, with bottles of Coca-Cola and pox, a homemade sugar-cane liquor pronounced posh, at their sides - made me feel as if I'd entered another, more mysterious universe.

I got a call on Monday from Sheila Bair, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Michael H. Krimminger, the F.D.I.C.'s special adviser to the chairman for policy. They had a point they wanted to make. Contrary to what I have heard -- and written -- in their opinion, whatever difficulties there are in modifying mortgages, the problem is not the fact that so many subprime mortgages are trapped in securitization pools.
