Don Garber became the second commissioner of Major League Soccer on Aug. 4, 1999. Since then, he has presided over a period of growth that has seen the league increase its number of teams and number of owners while putting in a foundation intended to last. There have been ups and downs along the way, but Garber is unabashedly bullish about the M.L.S. of today and of the future. He spoke with The New York Times during the week leading up to the league championship game, M.L.S. Cup '08, between the Red Bulls and Columbus Crew at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif., on Nov. 23.

The legendary investor John C. Bogle, who founded the Vanguard Group and created the first index mutual fund, has some reservations about Henry M. Paulson Jr. and his performance as Treasury secretary.

The Lincoln Tunnel has three tubes, each about a mile and a half long, 21 and a half feet wide and 13 feet high. The walls of each tube are covered with tiles. If your phone doesn't have voice commands, you can now add it through the BlueAnt V1 Voice Control Bluetooth earpiece. The 10-gram earpiece can recognize a short list of commands, provided you say exactly the required phrase listed in the instructions. It offers a nifty built-in tutorial (say "teach me") as well as a reminder of commands ("What can I say?"). It will also tell you roughly how much charge remains on your phone's battery. The earpiece holds 10 memorized numbers. Five are predetermined - voicemail, home, office, favorite and GOOG411. The other five spots are left for you to program as speed-dial numbers, although you'll have to remember who is assigned to each--the dial command only accepts "Call speed dial six," not the name of the person assigned. Two annoyances; the V1 misunderstood my commands pretty frequently, and it also won't cancel a process once it has begun. Both are illustrated by this exchange:

Shares of Atmel fell as much as 24 percent on Tuesday after ON Semiconductor dropped out of its hostile joint bid with Microchip Technology to buy the chipmaker for $2.3 billion. But Atmel's shares recovered a fair amount of their losses later in the day.

Coming off a tough road trip to face the Minnesota Golden Gophers, then ranked fifth, No. 6 New Hampshire returned to the East Coast over the weekend. But the results only got worse. With freshman goalie Matt DiGirolamo between the pipes, the Wildcats gave up eight goals at UMass-Lowell and the same number at Boston College the next night. New Hampshire wasn't the only top squad to drop two on the weekend. No. 4 Denver was swept on the road at St. Cloud State, losing 4-2 on Friday and 2-1 on Saturday. The Huskies had not won a conference game going into the series.

LOS ANGELES -- Against a backdrop of tumult in the automobile industry, the Los Angeles auto show kicks off this week at the downtown convention center. Press previews begin early Wednesday morning with a keynote address by Carlos Ghosn, chief executive of Nissan and Renault. The show opens to the public on Friday, Nov. 21, and continues through Nov. 30.

So they nailed Mark Cuban. They say his sale saved the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks $750,000, and it is seeking fines that will undoubtedly exceed the $2 million or so he has been fined over the years by the National Basketball Association for complaining about poor officiating.

Drawing an average of 19.7 million viewers, ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" delivered Monday night's largest television audience, according to Nielsen's estimates. Cuomo of New York is definitely on the warpath over executive compensation, and he asked the American International Group on Tuesday whether it was actually still planning to give out bonuses or raises after the government provided about $150 billion in loans to rescue the insurer from collapse.

ALBANY -- Gov. David A. Paterson canceled the emergency legislative session he had convened to address the state's widening budget deficit on Tuesday after failing to reach a consensus with legislative leaders. Mr. Paterson sat for over an hour in the Capitol with the leaders of both parties for a highly unusual public meeting that was by turns emotional, contentious and playful. By the time the meeting ended -- with Mr. Paterson agreeing to back off his insistence that the Legislature act on his deficit reduction plan -- it was clear that no action would be taken this year to plug the $1.5 billion hole that has opened up in the state budget.

I apologize in advance. An e-mail is going around coffee circles linking to "The Truth," a four-minute mockumentary by the Storyville Coffee Company, a Seattle roaster that started operations three years ago. In the video, artfully lighted whistle-blowers rail against "Big Coffee," the companies that overroast beans and then charge you more to cover the charred flavor with elaborate toppings of frothy milk and flavorings. They say there's a conspiracy with "Big Dairy," "Big Vanilla" and "Big Hazelnut." (I wonder why they didn't mention "Big Caramel.") To see it you need to click through Storyville's Web site to the video sidebar.

An article on Friday about a decision by the Food and Drug Administration to block products from China that contain milk misstated the effects of melamine, the potentially toxic chemical that has been discovered in some Chinese goods. ROSENBLUM--Lince (nee Karlstein) born December 2, 1911, wife of the late Dr. Benjamin William Rosenblum, passed away on November 16, 2008 after a brief illness. A graduate of Hunter College and a retired New York City school teacher, she lived in Brooklyn for 65 years prior to moving to Walden, New York. She was a true matriarch of her extended family and strove first and foremost to protect them, while also insisting they perform to the best of their abilities. Throughout her life she was an avid champion of the right for human dignity amongst all people. She possessed a keen intellect and was well read and politically informed. Even in her later years, when she combated numerous physical disabilities, she maintained her intellectual vigor, for to her an active mind was a gift to be cherished and nurtured. She is survived by her children Ina (Arnold Nager), Martin Jay (Carol) Rosenblum, grandmother of Brett (Alison) Weisberg, Lori (Chuck) Waddington, Jennifer (Danny) Rosenthal, and Benjamin Rosenblum. Great-grandmother of Cameron, Heather, Elise and Sarah, and aunt of many beloved nieces and nephews. Graveside service at 1:30pm Wednesday at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Josephine Louise Public Library, 5 Scofield St., Walden, New York, 12586, and the Walden Jewish Community Center, 20 Pine St., Walden, New York 12586.

A 7.5-magnitude earthquake jolted eastern Indonesia on Monday, killing at least four people, damaging hundreds of homes and briefly setting off a regional tsunami warning, officials said, according to The Associated Press. Above, villagers in Tolitoli, on the island of Sulawesi, carried the wall of a house that had been toppled by the quake. Right, a quake victim was carried to a funeral in Gorontalo, a city on the island. The United States Geological Survey said the quake struck 85 miles from Gorontalo.

8 P.M. (13); 9 P.M. (49) THE BIBLE'S BURIED SECRETS ''Nova'' presents the latest in archaeological scholarship from the Holy Land. The program explores the beginnings of modern religion, the origins of the Old Testament and questions including: Who wrote the Bible? When was it written and why? And how did the worship of one God -- the foundation of modern Judaism, Christianity and Islam -- emerge? This two-hour special visits excavation sites throughout the Middle East and features a hand-made, illustrated Bible commissioned by ''Nova'' and digital animation intended to bring to life sacred places like the long-lost Temple of Solomon. Above, Sharon Zuckerman and Amnon Ben-Tor of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem at an excavation site in Israel. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Is there a doctor in the house? RUBINSTEIN--Jacques (Jack), of New York died of cancer on November 15, at 95 years of age. A dedicated teacher, he nurtured in many a love of music. He leaves a brother, Samuel Rubinstein, of Salem, MA, three children and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, December 7, 2008 at 2pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

A federal judge ordered the government to make public search warrant documents that could shed light on why F.B.I. anthrax investigators spent years pursuing the wrong man, Steven J. Hatfill. Judge Royce C. Lamberth wrote that ''American citizens have a legitimate interest in observing and understanding how and why the investigation progressed the way that it did.'' Last June, the government agreed to pay $4.6 million to settle a lawsuit filed by Dr. Hatfill, who worked from 1997 to 1999 at the Army's biodefense laboratory at Fort Detrick, in Maryland. Prosecutors later announced that they believed another Fort Detrick researcher, Bruce E. Ivins, who killed himself in July, had mailed the anthrax-laced letters that killed five people in 2001. The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times had asked the court to release the documents, which include affidavits setting out investigators' reasons for searching Dr. Hatfill's apartment. A Justice Department spokesman said prosecutors were reviewing the ruling.

WALL-E Pixar's gallant little robot arrives in five editions from Disney DVD: single disc ($29.99), three-disc special ($40.99), three disc Blu-ray ($40.99), two-disc Blu-ray ($35.99) and Spanish language ($29.99). Each and every one is rated G. ''We've grown accustomed to expecting surprises from Pixar, but 'Wall-E' surely breaks new ground,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times in June. TROPIC THUNDERBen Stiller's ruthless satire about preening Hollywood stars (himself, Robert Downey Jr. and Jack Black) stuck in a Vietnam movie that turns too real; among the extras is a scathing ''making-of'' documentary that parodies ''Hearts of Darkness.'' ''Mr. Stiller doesn't kill jokes: he stomps them to death,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in August in The Times. DreamWorks is releasing four editions: single-disc, R-rated theatrical cut, also available in Spanish (both $29.98); the unrated ''director's cut'' two-disc set ($34.98); and Blu-ray ($39.99).

An Egyptian judge has banned media coverage in the trial of Hisham Talaat Mustafa, a member of Parliament charged with ordering the killing of the Lebanese singer Suzanne Tamim, left, in a case that has riveted the Arab world. The judge, al-Muhammadi Qunsuwa, allowed journalists into the courtroom but prohibited them from reporting on anything or taking notes. He gave no explanation, prompting suspicion that the decision was politically motivated. Mr. Mustafa is a member of President Hosni Mubarak's governing party. ''This decision and similar ones and the news blackout imposed on this case are purely for political and personal reasons,'' said a statement from the Arabic Network for Human Rights and Information, a Cairo-based advocacy group.

Add Lifetime to the growing list of media companies that have filed suit over ‚ÄúProject Runway,‚Äù whose fate remains in limbo pending a judge‚Äôs decision. Reuters reported that on Tuesday Lifetime filed a countersuit in a Manhattan federal court against the Weinstein Company (which produces ‚ÄúProject Runway‚Äù), Bravo (which previously broadcast the show), and NBC Universal (Bravo‚Äôs parent company), seeking exclusive rights over the reality series, whose new season Lifetime had scheduled for December. That new season of ‚ÄúProject Runway‚Äù is now up in the air, as NBC Universal has sued the Weinstein Company, arguing it has the right of first refusal on the show, and the Weinstein Company has sued Bravo, saying the cable channel tried to sabotage the value of the series.

Having proven his aptitude writing about teenagers who think they‚Äôre the most powerful people in the world, Josh Schwartz will soon be writing about teens who really are. Mr. Schwartz, a creator of the prime-time soap operas ‚ÄúThe O.C.‚Äù and ‚ÄúGossip Girl,‚Äù has been signed by Twentieth Century Fox to write ‚ÄúX-Men: First Class,‚Äù a new entry in the comic-book movie franchise, Variety reported. Mr. Schwartz‚Äôs script, adapted from the Marvel comics about super-powered youths, will chronicle the early days of the Xavier Institute for Higher Learning, when heroes like Cyclops and the Beast were still learning the ropes. Youthful reinventions of fantasy franchises are becoming increasingly popular in Hollywood; J.J. Abrams‚Äôs ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù prequel, about the first adventures of Kirk, Spock and McCoy, will open in May.

A refugee from the abortive Gerard Mortier era at the New York City Opera has landed on her feet. Jane M. Gullong, the company‚Äôs former executive director, has been appointed president of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, the orchestra said. Before withdrawing as the City Opera‚Äôs general director this month, Mr. Mortier had eliminated Ms. Gullong‚Äôs position at the opera, where she had worked since 1994, first as the chief fund-raiser. Her departure was announced at a time of staff cuts, although a spokesman said Mr. Mortier had eliminated her position because he did not usually have an executive director in his previous posts.

The artistic director of the Orlando Ballet abruptly resigned Saturday night and was replaced Monday morning, The Orlando Sentinel reported. Bruce Marks, who had been the artistic director of the ballet since 2006, was replaced by Robert Hill, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater. The executive director and the development director of the Orlando Ballet have also recently left the company, which ended its 2007-08 season with a nearly $500,000 deficit, the newspaper said. Elsewhere, Hernando Cortez, the artistic director of Verb Ballets in Cleveland, left that position, The Plain Dealer reported. Mr. Cortez did not give a reason for his departure, but The Plain Dealer reported that an internal e-mail from a board member of the Verb had called for the ‚Äúimmediate termination/resignation‚Äù of Mr. Cortez.
Clive Barnes, a former dance critic for The New York Times, died early Wednesday morning from complications of cancer. He was 81.

A federal jury in Manhattan has found Alberto W. Vilar, the art patron and investment adviser, guilty on 12 counts of investment adviser fraud, securities fraud, mail fraud, wire fraud and money laundering. The government alleged that Mr. Vilar diverted millions of dollars from his investors for his personal use and for business expenses, and transferred part of the money to a foreign account.

Cornell's Jon Jaques is back on The Quad. Jon, as many of you know, gave us a behind-the-scenes look at Cornell's N.C.A.A. tournament experience last season. Then, during the summer, he showed us what the California leagues are like when the best college players come home to play. The word is out that Madrid's Sunday morning flea market - known as the Rastro - has grown bigger, busier, and more bustling than ever, with an estimated 25 percent more pedestrian traffic in recent months. Gorgeous fall weather has combined with a global financial crunch to get folks out early on Sunday, either sifting for bargains or selling yesteryear's apparel for quick cash to help with rising mortgage payments. In hard economic times, Spaniards are imminently practical and yet still highly social, so why shouldn't one Madrile√±o's budgetary squeeze yield another's fall finds, with beer and tapas just around the corner to wash away any buyer's - or seller's - remorse.
Melena Ryzik reports from an annual benefit for the Moth, an organization dedicated to the art of oral storytelling.

Mike Mussina had a charmed season in 2008, and he knew it. Mussina's stuff was diminished, but he had the guile to win more games than he ever had in a season. He was healthy -- remarkably lucky to be so, he thought -- and observers noticed him pitching down and in more effectively, changing speeds like a master.

My Thursday column is from Tbilisi, Georgia, which I keep thinking would be better named "Gorgia" after all the country's lovely gorges. Georgia is of course one of the places where a resurgent Russia has been most badly behaved, for years now, and so President-elect Obama seems to join the general American enthusiasm for bringing Georgia into NATO. But as I argue in the column, that would be a bad idea. We need to try to engage Russia politically and economically, not militarily, and pushing NATO would just amount to poking the bear without actually improving Georgia's security.
It will take the efforts of China and other emerging nations to lead the global economy out of what is likely to be a long and painful recession, according to a gathering of economic experts.

Alex A asks what made me think of Valentina, the Russian-born designer who was a dominate force in American fashion in the middle of the last century. I admit it was an emotional flash to the simplicity and slight drama of the Maria Pinto dresses worn by Michelle Obama. I was probably also making an unconscious connection to Ms. Obama's shape and height and to her evident self-confidence, qualities in a woman that were enhanced by a Valentina dress or coat. Then, the other day, I opened some mail from Rizzoli and found a brochure for Kohle Yohannan's upcoming book about Valentina (due in early February). I just love the cosmic forces.

Food | Corn is the common denominator in much of fast food, a new study finds. It did carbon-signature analysis of hundreds of burgers, chicken sandwiches and fries from McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's, and found that the meat came almost exclusively from corn-fed animals, while Wendy's fries were deep-fried in corn oil. [Toronto Star]

CBS's "NCIS" and "The Mentalist" were down slightly on Tuesday, one week after posting their best ratings on record, but the crime shows remained popular enough to lift CBS to No. 1 for the night over all.

Like millions of others, I have long been troubled by the philosopher Martin Heidegger's political associations: he was an enthusiastic supporter of Hitler and, for a while at least, a member of the Nazi Party. Shelves of books have tried to work through the connection between his thought and his politics, and though I personally don't have any easy answers, what I do know is that as much as I value his ideas, I would never praise him for his "spirit of independence, integrity, courage and indefatigability," or be happy to see a major educational institution name an award in philosophy after him. These thoughts came to me when I learned that the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard University has recently established an I. F. Stone Medal for Journalistic Independence.

After two weeks away, I returned to the Pellegrini Family Vineyards in Sonoma County and to my Sagrantino wine-making project. When I last saw the bin of fermenting wine, its temperature was 79 and the degrees Brix was 13. Now the temperature had fallen to 66 degrees and the Brix reading was at -1 - scientific evidence that fermentation was petering out. In a short time, the wine would be totally dry.

As I've written before, more than a third of the world's human population has no sanitary place to defecate, and this contributes to water contamination that kills or seriously sickens millions of children (and adults of course) each year. This newspaper story describes the consequences for slum dwellers in Kampala, Uganada, when pit latrines are too scarce or pricey. One result? "Flying toilets."

I have always known that stale bread is the very best thing to feed a duck. As it turns out, it's a pretty great thing to feed a girlfriend, too, or anybody else for that matter. Forget lobster, caviar and champagne. If you truly want to impress the ones you love, rock-hard, week-old bread is the only way to go.

David Vitter, and he's still a sitting Republican senator in good standing," a blogger writes. And it's not like we don't have a lot of other adulterous pols running around. [Political Animal]

Drugs | Liberal Vancouver has overhauled its police and social services to treat drug abuse as primarily a public health issue, not a criminal one. It's now, for better or worse, the continent's most drug-tolerant city -- an experiment radically at odds with the American war on drugs. [Alternet]

Herszenhorn reported.

Internet | When does a cyberattack become an act of war, rather than just a nuisance? It's not an academic question, as the recent Russia-Georgia conflict illustrates. But we haven't gotten a handle on it, international law experts say, and that's dangerous. The problem is how to tell who's doing the hacking, and from where. [Foreign Policy]

Sheik Abdulla bin Hamad Al Khalifa, the second son of the king of Bahrain, filed suit against Mr. Jackson seeking repayment for money he gave to Mr. Jackson beginning in 2005, including $2.2 million dollars to cover Mr. Jackson‚Äôs legal bills in a child-molestation trial in Los Angeles that year; Mr. Jackson contends that those payments were gifts. A vast fleet of pianos is expected to arrive in Cincinnati next month, part of the largest order ‚Äî by number of instruments ‚Äî ever filled by the Steinway & Sons piano company. The district attorney‚Äôs office of Clark County, Nev., is seeking criminal charges against the hip-hop mogul Marion Knight, known as Suge, below, The Associated Press reported. The charges stem from an incident in August when Mr. Knight, the founder of the now-bankrupt label Death Row Records, was arrested after officers said they saw him beat a woman while brandishing a knife in a parking lot near the Las Vegas Strip. MEBANE--George Allen , IV. Columbia University Medical Center and its Board of Visitors mourn the passing of the board's esteemed member, George Allen Mebane IV. Mr. Mebane, who also was a member of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Health Sciences Advisory Council, will be remembered for his intelligence, wit, generosity, and genuine compassion for others. Mr. Mebane brought to Columbia University Medical Center his deep knowledge of business as a leader in the textiles industry, first as cofounder, CEO, and chairman of two firms, Throwing Corporation of America and Universal Textured Yarns, then as co-founder, CEO, and chairman of Unifi Inc., a North Carolina manufacturer of nylon and polyester that became the largest producer and processor of textured yarns in the world, with plants in the United States, England, Brazil, and Ireland. Mr. Mebane retired in 2000 to focus on his philanthropic interests and established the Mebane Charitable Foundation, which supports education and learning technology initiatives. As a generous benefactor of CUMC's College of Physicians & Surgeons, he was a lead supporter of the Division of Digestive and Liver Diseases, and provided major support to Cardiology, Ophthalmology, and Urology. His counsel and financial gifts to Columbia provide a legacy that will serve as a reminder of his many contributions toward our work in education, patient care, and research. We extend our condolences to his wife, Marianne, his children, and other family members. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine P. Roy Vagelos, M.D. Chairman, Board of Visitors Columbia University Medical Center

Nick Swisher used to swing sledgehammers, haul tractors and level walls as part of his off-season training regimen. He also struck out 135 times.

KANTROWITZ--Adrian , M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Adrian Kantrowitz. Dr. Kantrowitz was a renowned surgeon who performed the first human heart transplant in the United States in 1967 here at Maimonides Medical Center. He was at Maimonides Medical Center from 1955-1970 where he served as Director of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Director of Surgical Research and as Director of Surgery. He returned in 1998 to be the guest alumni speaker at the Maimonides Day Scientific Session. His knowledge of cardiology and surgery was passed on to thousands of physicians. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his wife and entire family. W. Wexelman, M.D., Pres. S. Farber, M.D., Pres. Elect H. Wasserman, M.D., Sec. E. Fitzpatrick, M.D. ,Treas. KANTROWITZ--Adrian. 9 P.M. (National Geographic) THE REAL GEORGE WASHINGTON Founding father, commander of the Continental Army, America's first president -- and spy? This ''Expedition Week'' installment, which includes period re-enactments, above, travels to the recently discovered ruins of George Washington's childhood home, where a meticulous exploration of the site, including two cellars, reveals a trove of artifacts like secret codes, invisible ink and documents filled with misinformation intended to deceive the British, as well as reminders of Washington's intimate relationship with slavery. Later forensic investigators set aside the romantic notions of painters and sculptors to create a realistic likeness of his face. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYCarla Bruni-Sarkozy, the model turned pop singer turned first lady of France, performs.

FEDERMAN--Elizabeth (Betty) . Columbia University Medical Center and its Board of Visitors mourn the passing of Elizabeth Federman, wife of Board of Visitors member Daniel D. Federman, M.D. Mrs. Federman trained in nursing at Massachusetts General Hospital, where she was appointed the youngest head nurse in the hospital's history. She trained generations of student nurses, Harvard medical students, and interns and residents in humane medicine. Mrs. Federman was accepted by house staff as a peer in diagnostic acuity and therapeutic sensibility and was recently honored by Harvard Medical School alumnae who paid tribute to ''Betty's support of young physicians, especially women.'' We extend our condolences to her husband, Daniel, the Carl W. Walter Distinguished Professor of Medicine and Medical Education at Harvard Medical School, and to her children, grandchildren, and other family members. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine P. Roy Vagelos, M.D. Chairman, Board of Visitors Columbia University Medical Center

The Lincoln Tunnel has three tubes, each about a mile and a half long, and the walls of each tube are covered with tiles. A British court that nearly had to settle for video testimony from Michael Jackson will instead receive the king of pop in person. In cross-examination on Thursday, Mr. Khalifa described Mr. Jackson as ‚Äúa fantastic intellectual.‚Äù Mr. Jackson‚Äôs lawyer asked, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing unusual about him?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Mr. Al Khalifa replied.

Ms. Cornwell, the best-selling crime-fiction author whose books include the Kay Scarpetta novels, has made a commitment of $1 million to the museum‚Äôs Straus Center for Conservation and Technical Studies, the museum announced. The institution will use that money, as well as a matching grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, to endow a position called the Patricia Cornwell Conservation Scientist. Two regional symphonies have experienced very different fortunes amid the economic downturn. On Saturday, the board president of the Charleston Symphony Orchestra in South Carolina announced during a concert intermission that the orchestra was facing a $250,000 shortfall, The Post and Courier reported. The symphony‚Äôs musicians and board members began making emergency phone calls for donations on Monday; The Post and Courier said that $250,000 would sustain the orchestra through December, but would not be enough to cover its January payroll. Elsewhere, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra has announced that it has raised more than $48 million toward an $80 million goal to repair and enhance its home at Heinz Hall, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported.

Paul W. Thompson, the director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, is stepping down to become the new rector, or president, of the Royal College of Art, London, the museum is expected to announce on Friday.

In that suit, Mr. Browne said that the campaign used his song ‚ÄúRunning on Empty‚Äù without his permission in an advertisement criticizing Mr. Obama‚Äôs energy plan. In their motions, Mr. McCain‚Äôs lawyers say the ad was covered by fair-use standards, and that its use of ‚ÄúRunning on Empty‚Äù would ‚Äúlikely increase the popularity of this thirty year-old song,‚Äù Reuters said.

Over nearly three years and 13 issues, Play magazine has had a clear mission: to cut through the 24/7 chatter that‚Äôs being served up seemingly anywhere and everywhere these days ‚Äî the scores and stats; the injury reports and trade gossip and rap sheets; the tidy, anodyne up-close-and-personals‚Äîand take a fresh, ambitious look at the people, ideas and forces at work in the world of sports. Along the way we‚Äôve been able to plumb the lives of some remarkable characters, examine some thorny issues, and lift the veil a bit on how many of our favorite games are played. Last spring, in our first year of eligibility, we had the good fortune to be named a finalist for the National Magazine Award for General Excellence, the biggest editorial prize in our business. Over the course of 2007, Play published the top two ‚Äî and three of the top five ‚Äî most-viewed sports stories on The New York Times Web site. Our photography and design have won awards of their own, and a number of our writers‚Äô stories have been anthologized.

As I. F. Stone's biographer, I share Barry Gewen's bemusement that establishment institutions, most recently the Nieman Foundation at Harvard, have embraced Stone - who was a radical all his life. Though his many admirers in the mainstream media make what might be deemed a heroic effort to overlook or airbrush out his radical commitments, my sympathies as a historian are always with those who would correct the record. I'll leave it to Times readers to decide whether it is really honorable to compare someone who was, however briefly, a journalistic "fellow traveler" to Martin Heidegger, who not only welcomed the Nazi Party's rise to power, but remained a proud member of the Nazi Party until the end of the war.

Despite a near-constant drumbeat of layoff announcements by big companies, the unemployment rates for New York City and New York State dipped to 5.7 percent last month, according to the State Labor Department. But the increase of 13,800 jobs in the city was 40 percent less than the average October job gain over the last 10 years.

The new Walgreens sign going live in Times Square Thursday is not the largest LED-based sign in the world, but its developers believe that it is the most complex, both in terms of its construction and operation. Rising 340 feet high, the 17,000-square-foot sign wraps most of the facade of the One Times Square building. It combines a series of diagonal LED panels, plus 13 60-inch plasma displays to create a single moving image with 20 times the resolution of standard HDTV.

After gyrating wildly for weeks, the stock market lurched lower on Wednesday, falling to its lowest point in nearly six years, as concern spread that the economy might be facing a chronic and debilitating decline in prices, The New York Times's Vikas Bajaj reported.

At the end of my mother's life, for six months, a year at most, Medicaid paid for her care in a nursing home. She was broke by then, after living on a pittance since she was widowed at 58, using the proceeds from her house to pay for six years of assisted living and part of her nursing home stay and never seeing a penny from a long-term care insurance policy that cost a bundle but covered none of what she needed. She had given my brother and me no up-front money to hasten her eligibility for Medicaid and died with $26 to her name and nothing to leave to her children. The good news was we didn't even have to put her will in probate.

President Nicolas Sarkozy of France left the summit meeting on the financial crisis in Washington last weekend in a triumphal mood, declaring that it had tamed the animal spirits of American capitalism. Then he went home and announced that he would hold his own summit meeting in a few weeks in Paris - on the same topic.

Stocks fell sharply Thursday in Europe and Asia, a day after a withering sell-off on Wall Street sent U.S. stocks to their lowest close since 2003, The New York Times's David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.

Art | Connoisseurs pay serious attention to painting, music and literature -- but not great perfume. Why not? a Yale art curator asks. After all, artists "combine natural and, these days, synthetic pigments with media such as oils and resins, much as the perfumer carefully formulates natural and synthetic chemical compounds." And smell is one of the senses too. [TLS]
Four Nordic countries will lend Iceland $2.5 billion (1.98 billion euros) to help the country recover from its economic meltdown, their finance ministries said Thursday.
As the stock market tumbled to its lowest level in nearly six years on Wednesday, Wall Street traders and many ordinary Americans were asking the same question: Where, oh where is the bottom?

Nate Davis threw four touchdown passes, and No. 14 Ball State survived a scare from host Central Michigan on Wednesday night in a 31-24 victory that gave the Cardinals a team-record for wins in a season.

Lindsey Vonn, the World Cup overall and downhill champion, bruised her knee when she fell during a routine training session for a super-G at Copper Mountain in Colorado. She was taken to see Dr. William Sterett, the physician for the United States women‚Äôs Alpine ski team, who said Vonn had sustained a bruised left knee and that there was no ligament or cartilage damage. Vonn, who had never finished among the top three in the slalom, won the World Cup slalom opener Saturday in Finland.

USA Gymnastics has never received a complaint about Bela or Martha Karolyi in the nearly 30 years they have been coaching in the United States, the governing body said, a day after a Romanian gymnast accused the two of abusing her. Trudi Eberle Kollar, a double silver medalist at the 1980 Olympics, said the Karolyis hit her when she was at the Romanian national training center in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The Karolyis coached the Romanian team before they defected to the United States in 1981.

Coach Marcello Lippi equaled a record unbeaten streak when Italy rallied for a 1-1 tie against Greece in an exhibition game. Luca Toni headed in a free kick from Daniele De Rossi in the 54th minute, only four minutes after the substitute Fanis Gekas had given Greece the lead. Lippi guided Italy to the 2006 World Cup title and has not lost as the coach in 31 games in two stints with the squad. He matched the record shared by Javier Clemente of Spain and Alfio Basile of Argentina.

The United States Olympic Committee reorganized part of its management team, a move that will allow the chief operating officer, Norm Bellingham, more time to focus on starting an Olympic television network sometime in the next few months. When the U.S.O.C. hires a chief marketing officer to replace Rick Burton, who resigned earlier this month, that person will report to the chief executive, Jim Scherr, instead of to Bellingham, who is in charge of developing the network.

Freddy Adu scored his first goal as a member of the United States national team, and Jozy Altidore assisted on Kenny Cooper‚Äôs sliding shot, leading the Americans to a 2-0 win over Guatemala in a World Cup qualifier in Commerce City, Colo.

Aaron Schatz and his team at Football Outsiders do an excellent job of statistical analysis, among other things, but the Eagles have proved hard to explain. It's as if the Outsiders have developed a unified theory of the universe and there's a black hole out there that just won't fit the model.

KRYSTEN RITTER, a model-turned-actress who co-stars in the coming movie ‚ÄúConfessions of a Shopaholic,‚Äù doesn‚Äôt see herself as the domestic type. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a girl on the go,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI own six pieces of clothing and one piece of furniture.‚Äù.

He is Roger F. Wicker ‚Äî not Thad Cochran, Mississippi‚Äôs other senator. (Senator Wicker won the Nov. 4 election and will serve the rest of Mr. Lott‚Äôs term, until 2012.).
A capsule summary on Tuesday for an article about the National League‚Äôs most valuable player award misstated the given name of the winner. He is Albert Pujols, not Alberto.

A brief report in the Vital Signs column on Tuesday about a study of the link between gestational diabetes and language delays in children misstated some of the statistical results from the study. Researchers found that 26 percent of the children of diabetic mothers scored below the 15th percentile in two tests of language ability between 18 months and 7 years, compared with 13 percent of children of nondiabetic mothers. They did not find that of children scoring below the 15th percentile, 26 percent had diabetic mothers while 13 percent did not.

An article on Wednesday about the selection of Dustin Pedroia of the Boston Red Sox as the 2008 American League most valuable player referred incorrectly to his standing in one statistical category. He was tied for 10th in the league in on-base percentage; he did not finish out of the top 10.

The Dow may have closed below 8,000 and publishing may be in dire straits, but the board of the National Book Foundation, which gave out its annual awards at a black-tie ceremony on Wall Street Wednesday night, was determined to throw a party that, in the words of the board president and Perseus Books chief David Steinberger, would "celebrate writing and increase its impact on the national culture."

September 2007 Lobes of Steel. One of PLAY‚Äôs most popular features was Gretchen Reynolds‚Äôs Phys Ed column, on sports fitness, which consistently rose to the top of the Times‚Äôs list of most-emailed stories. Perhaps her most fascinating topic involved the affect of exercise on the brain, and a body of research suggesting that exercise could help boost memory and cognitive processing speed. How many people went right to the treadmill after reading that? Here is that column and two others that generated abundant feedback.

November 2006 Most football coaches are lifers, and none more so than Bill Parcells. When Michael Lewis visited him two years ago with the Dallas Cowboys, Parcells had come to peace with the fact that he can‚Äôt find any peace in coaching. The next game is all that matters, and for Parcells, the addiction to it is total. Lewis spent a week with Parcells as he prepared for a game, and found that even in victory Parcells‚Äô lips were pursed ‚Äúas if he has just finished sucking the world‚Äôs largest lemon.‚Äù.

February 2006 ‚ÄúHao qiu!‚Äù That‚Äôs what they‚Äôll say in China, after a good golf shot that hits the fairway. Charles McGrath wished he heard it a little more as he took his game to the People‚Äôs Republic to check in on the state of the sport there. What he found was illuminating: ‚ÄúGolf hasn‚Äôt evolved in China,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúit has arrived more or less full blown, in its high-end and even slightly decadent form.‚Äù Even more than in America, McGrath said, ‚Äúgolf in China stands for money, power and social exclusivity.‚Äù.

August 2008 Fishlike? Before Michael Phelps won eight gold medals in the Beijing Olmpics, Mark Levine took some time to study Phelps‚Äôs ‚Äúfish-ness‚Äù - this uncanny ability to feel so at home in an environment generally unaccommodating to humans. Phelps‚Äôs most fundamental victory, Levine concluded, was not over his swimming rivals, but over this inhospitable element. ‚ÄúFish don‚Äôt have to work at it,‚Äù he wrote. Phelps does, but as Levine pointed out, he seemed uniquely built to thrive in the pool in a way no one ever had.

March 2008 Family dynamics. Baseball. Steinbrenner. This was the combustible mix Jonathan Mahler examined in ‚ÄúOedipus Bronx,‚Äù his look at the rise of George Steinbrenner‚Äôs sons as keepers of the family treasure - the New York Yankees. Few succession processes were as fraught with challenges, Mahler wrote, and he described the Yankee set-up as one where ‚Äúit‚Äôs hard to know exactly who‚Äôs in charge.‚Äù.

September 2006 Federer moments. There‚Äôve been more than a few great ones in the tennis career of Roger Federer, and just as many great writing moments to match in David Foster Wallace‚Äôs fly-on-the-wall portrait of the Swiss star for PLAY two summers ago. Wallace committed suicide two months ago; his writing stands as a testament to the power of observation, here focused on sporting skills that Wallace, after witnessing them first-hand, likened to a near-religious experience.

November 2008 Two minutes of treachery! Could anything be harder, or more dangerously thrilling, than the Hahnenkamm downhill in Kitzbuhel, Austria? Apparently not, say a bevy of skiing experts who helped describe and bring to life a graphic presentation of the world‚Äôs most terrifying ski course.

September 2007 The Outcast. That term certainly described Floyd Landis when Sara Corbett spent time with him in the summer of 2007, as he waited in limbo, hoping for a successful appeal of the positive drug test that had stripped him of his 2006 Tour de France title. With keen insight, Corbett explored for PLAY whether Landis ‚Äúearned his way into hell or was thrown there without a lick of fairness.‚Äù.

June 2008 The Immortal One. That‚Äôs the aura Tiger Woods projects to his legions of fans, and that‚Äôs the aura Chip Brown tried to get inside of as he followed the golfing superstar for several weeks and observed his relationship to a public that aches for him to prevail. Woods, Brown wrote, has ‚Äúthe great champion‚Äôs capacity to carry us beyond ourselves.‚Äù.

LAST spring, when the bathroom of his apartment was being redone, Brian Lichtenberg suggested a design to his landlord. ‚ÄúI thought it would be cool to do it like Givenchy,‚Äù he said, referring to the fashion label‚Äôs blocky geometric logo, which is now rendered in black tile in his shower. Mr. Lichtenberg, 29, is a self-taught fashion designer with an eponymous label of his own, and he has also incorporated elements of his design work throughout the three-bedroom apartment he rents on the top floor of a 1920s house in the Silver Lake area of Los Angeles. The walls of a second bathroom, for example, are painted in a red, yellow and blue drip style, a design he developed for a hooded sweatshirt (the colors drip from the hood). He describes his aesthetic, in both fashion and d√©cor, as ‚Äústark and minimal, but graphic and colorful,‚Äù though his at-home showroom is plain white: ‚ÄúWhite clears your head,‚Äù he said. He liked being part of Mr. Selby‚Äôs project, he added, mainly because ‚Äúit was a good excuse to make the apartment tidy and nice.‚Äù.

AS an interior designer who works primarily with young, affluent bohemian clients, Ryan Korban says he has developed his own ‚Äúdowntown‚Äù decorating style. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a mixture of 1970s Italian, which is similar to midcentury but sexier and more polished,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand traditional 18th century.‚Äù He is big on brass lamps, full-length mirrors, chunky antique furniture and eccentric curios, as evidenced by his own 550-square-foot studio apartment in SoHo.

‚ÄúIN terms of my decorating style, I love stuff,‚Äù Chase Cohl said. ‚ÄúI love really unique and special stuff.‚Äù Ms. Cohl, a 21-year-old poetry student at the New School, has a simple theory about accumulation and d√©cor: ‚ÄúIf you pick up things that your personality is drawn to everywhere you go, you‚Äôre bound to have an interesting space.‚Äù.

ADAM WALLACAVAGE, a 39-year-old artist known for his elaborate and bizarre chandeliers, thinks of his brownstone home in Philadelphia as ‚Äúan ongoing art piece.‚Äù What he describes as an ‚Äúeccentric, Victorian-style‚Äù d√©cor actually verges on the otherworldly. For instance, he created a ground-floor dining room reminiscent of an undersea realm, with a ship‚Äôs porthole looking into a sunroom, aquamarine walls and a chandelier he made from cast plaster with octopus tentacles for arms. Smaller tentacled fixtures nearby repeat the motif. Mr. Wallacavage, whose recent show at the Jonathan LeVine Gallery in New York was dominated by nautical themes, wanted a space with a ‚Äú20,000 Leagues Under the Sea‚Äù look, he said, and this house seemed an ideal place for it. ‚ÄúWhen I called the Realtor about this space eight years ago, he told me the basement looks like a ship, and I knew that‚Äôs the house I wanted,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere was a piano, a bar, portholes and ship paintings.‚Äù.

IN a few cases, Todd Selby photographed his subjects' work spaces rather than their homes, because these were the places into which they had ''put all their creative output.'' Scott Campbell's Saved Tattoo parlor in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is the opposite of the cramped, dimly lighted aesthetic of most ink emporiums. Housed in the 2,000-square-foot ground floor of a warehouse, it has the bright, airy feel of an art-filled loft apartment. Mr. Campbell, 31, lives in a studio apartment a few blocks away that he says has a similar feel on a smaller scale. He used to run a combination tattoo studio and antiques shop nearby, and his love of old things is obvious here. He works on clients in an area furnished with an antique dresser and settee, and he installed subway tile and an old-fashioned sink in the bathroom. For that room's wallpaper, he used rifle targets bought in his native Louisiana; bullet cartridges embedded in a Lucite toilet seat extend the theme. Mr. Campbell said the studio is meant to be welcoming and comfortable -- home-like, in fact --''because obviously getting a tattoo is stressful.''

In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her name to Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart or Princeton Academy of the Sacred Heart.

SANTRY--Julia T. , of Greenwich, Connecticut died of a stroke on November 18, 2008 at the Greenwich Hospital. She was 83 years old and is survived by her five children, Arthur J. Santry, III, Suzanne Cochin de Billy, Peter T. Santry, Charles N. Santry, and Robert T. Santry as well as 16 grandchildren. Born Julia Edna Timmins in Montreal, Quebec, she attended McGill University, graduating with a Bachelor of Science degree. In 1955 she married the late Arthur J. Santry, Jr. of Brookline, Massachusetts who would become Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Combustion Engineering and a Commodore of the New York Yacht Club. In 1985, she christened America II, the Club's challenge entry for the America's Cup in Perth, Australia. She was involved in Greenwich activities including the Green Fingers Garden Club where she served as its President from 1985 to 1987. A favorite pastime, she enjoyed gardening and worked tirelessly on her property in Greenwich. She also loved tennis, skiing, and golf and was an active member of the Round Hill Club, the Lyford Cay Club in Nassau, Bahamas, and the Colony Club in New York City. She was active in the US chapter of the Friends of McGill, an alumni outreach program. Her many friends and family will miss her warmth, positive attitude, and joyful disposition. She always carried herself with dignity and grace. A funeral service is scheduled for Saturday, November 22 at St. Mary's Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, Connecticut at 11am.

ORMONT--Lou, Ph.D . We, the Board, faculty, and students of the Center for Group Studies express profound sadness at the loss of our founder and mentor, Dr. Lou Ormont. A pioneer in Modern Group Analysis, Lou established the Center in 1989 as the first free-standing training program devoted solely to the teaching of modern group process. Lou lived by his creed that ''those successful in group are successful in life'', and because of him we --and through us our patients, colleagues, partners, children, and friends --continue to realize maturational goals, facilitate education, and heal. We extend our deepest sympathy to Joan, his loving and most supportive wife and partner in life and work.

AS nationwide concern grows over childhood obesity and inactivity, fitness products masquerading as toys are being designed to slim and tone the younger segment of the population. In many cases, such items are shrunken, stickered and plastic-encased versions of more mainstream adult apparatus found at gyms or health clubs, such as stationary bikes, treadmills and elliptical trainers. But, as Trina Edwards, a youth fitness expert and registered nurse found, there are a few notable differences to these kid-appropriate, pulse-quickening contraptions -- greater emphasis on safety being one of them. Ms. Edwards, who is the publisher of the online magazine Kids Sports & Fitness, recruited 15 children between the ages of 3 and 7 at the Commonwealth Elementary School in Sugar Land, Tex., to try four exercise products designed specifically for children. She examined workmanship, safety, fitness benefit, and the general level of excitement it generated in the group. Over all, she found that a child's age dictated the success of one product over another and that, in at least one case, the allure of video wasn't as enticing as she had expected. CHRISTOPHER PERCY COLLIER

The Bengals and the Steelers are coming off two strange Week 11 games -- Cincinnati's tie with Philadelphia and Pittsburgh's controversial 11-10 win over San Diego. But the last game between these teams was about what you would expect, considering the Bengals have the league's worst offense and the Steelers have the best defense. Pittsburgh defeated Cincinnati, 38-10, in Week 7, a game that led to animosity after Steelers receiver Hines Ward broke linebacker Keith Rivers's jaw on a block. ERDMAN--John . Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished and longtime member, John Erdman. To his family we express profound sympathy. May beautiful memory comfort those who mourn his passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary ERDMAN--John H., 83, of Mamaroneck, NY, died November 18, 2008. Son of the late Herbert J. Erdman and Edna Kaufman Erdman, he was born in New York City. He was a graduate of the Horace Mann School and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. He is survived by his loving wife of 61 years, Doris Schwartz Erdman, sons John Jr. and Michael, daughters - in - law Phoebe Lawrence Erdman and Mary Madden Erdman and grandchildren Anne, Elizabeth and John III. He served in the US Air force during WWII and retired as a Captain. Founder and President of Brent-Maitland, Inc., his career in the insurance business spanned more than 59 years. His lifelong passion for sports and support of youth sports was personified by 30 years of service as a Westchester County Football Official. John's great senseof-humor endeared him to his family and many friends. A valued friend and confidante to many he was treasured for his integrity and judgement. Contributions to the charity of your choice are appreciated. There will be a private burial service for family and close friends on Thursday, November 20, 2008.

ABC has performed an extreme makeover on its prime-time schedule, telling producers of three struggling programs that it will not be ordering new episodes of their series and shifting the time slots of two other shows, The Hollywood Reporter said. ‚ÄúPushing Daisies‚Äù and ‚ÄúDirty Sexy Money,‚Äù holdovers from last year‚Äôs strike-shortened season, as well as ‚ÄúEli Stone,‚Äù which had its debut as a midseason replacement in January, will finish their current episode orders. ABC has not officially canceled them. Additionally, in January, the crime drama ‚ÄúLife on Mars‚Äù will move to Wednesday night after ‚ÄúLost,‚Äù and ‚ÄúPrivate Practice‚Äù will inherit the Thursday-night slot following ‚ÄúGrey‚Äôs Anatomy,‚Äù from which it was spun off.

It‚Äôs proving an especially difficult season to be a teenager on Broadway. Producers have announced a closing date for the musical ‚Äú13,‚Äù the other Broadway show about the struggles of adolescence (this one set in present-day Indiana, rather than 19th-century Germany). It will play its final performance on Jan. 4 at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater. The show features music and lyrics by Jason Robert Brown (‚ÄúParade,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Last Five Years‚Äù) and says it was the first on Broadway to have an all-teenage cast and band. The cast recording was an online hit, but ‚Äú13‚Äù never quite caught fire like ‚ÄúSpring Awakening,‚Äù which has also announced its closing. When it ends its run, ‚Äú13‚Äù will have played 22 previews and 105 regular performances.

The Paul Taylor Dance Company is moving to the Lower East Side. The company, which lost its lease in a building in Soho, said it had found new quarters in a Grand Street auditorium that belongs to the East River Houses, a cooperative complex. It said it would move in next year after renovations that would create two studios with 20-foot ceilings. The lease is for 20 years. The hall, called the Ralph Lippman Auditorium, sits atop a supermarket and is used mainly by community groups and for events like weddings and birthday parties. Harold Jacob, the general manager of the East River Housing Corporation, who contacted the Taylor company about the space, said the groups could find other places homes in the neighborhood. He said his new tenant would bring regular income ‚Äî about $300,000 a year, less than what Paul Taylor is now paying ‚Äî and add a certain cachet to the area. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a prestigious name,‚Äù he said.

After 17 years, $13 million, and what feels like about 200 personnel changes, Guns N‚Äô Roses will finally release its long-awaited studio album ‚ÄúChinese Democracy‚Äù on Sunday. (If you can‚Äôt wait until then, the album is streaming here on MySpace.)

Together, Madonna and Guy Ritchie have endured trials from the nonstop scrutiny of the media to the release of Madonna‚Äôs album ‚ÄúHard Candy.‚Äù But on Friday, Madonna and Mr. Ritchie, the film director, were granted a preliminary decree of divorce by a London court, The Associated Press reported. The couple, who were married at a ceremony in a Scottish castle in 2000, were granted the decree in a brief hearing that neither attended; the divorce can become final after six weeks and one day. According to papers released by the court, The A.P. said, Madonna petitioned for divorce citing Mr. Ritchie‚Äôs ‚Äúunreasonable behavior.‚Äù The two are expected to share custody of their son, Rocco, 8, and their adopted son, David Banda, 3. Madonna also has a daughter, Lourdes, 12, from a previous relationship.

It‚Äôs the wardrobe malfunction that won‚Äôt die: four months after a federal court ruled that CBS was not liable for a 2004 incident in which Janet Jackson‚Äôs breast was partly uncovered during a televised Super Bowl halftime performance, the United States government has appealed that decision to the Supreme Court, Agence France-Presse reported. In its appeal, lawyers for the government asked the Supreme Court to reinstate a fine of $550,000 levied against CBS by the Federal Communications Commission for what the government called ‚Äúthe most widely viewed broadcast public nudity in television history.‚Äù In a statement, CBS said it hoped the Supreme Court ‚Äúwill recognize there are rare instances, particularly during live programming, when it may not be possible to block unfortunate fleeting material, despite best efforts.‚Äù

CARSON, Calif. - Chris Leitch certainly is not one of the stars of Major League Soccer and he may only be a household name in his own household, but among the Red Bulls who take the field Sunday in M.L.S. Cup '08, Leitch has a unique connection to the opposition - the Columbus Crew.

My colleague, Jack Healy, has written an eye-opening story, "Unable to Sell Homes, Elderly Forgo Move to Assisted Living," about some hidden victims of the real estate meltdown: the elderly who are eager to sell homes and condominiums so they can move to retirement communities with services and safeguards they have come to need. There are no data on how many of the 4.27 million unsold homes in America belong to men and women in this age group, but assisted living facilities report names scratched from waiting lists, old people are stuck in homes they can no longer manage or live in safely and, for some, adult day care has become the stopgap measure. Please let us know if this has happened to you, your parents, your friends or your neighbors, and what you think the bailoutmeisters should do about it.

Take a close look at this thumbnail view of all his NYT puzzles. As you scroll through them, notice how several of the patterns look nothing at all like a typical crossword.

It's hard to recall a more intriguing announcement than the recent news that Fondazione Prada was opening Double Club, a West-meets-Congo-themed pop-up restaurant, dance club and gallery space in a refurbished old dump of a nightclub in East London. Last night's opening party lived up to its eclectic promise. As part of the project's mission to give equal billing to elements from both cultures, decadent imperialist pleasures - Champagne! oysters! art-world glitz! - shared pride of place alongside Congolese party favors, including a goat-meat barbecue, plastic patio chairs, and African beer.

The other night I opened a bottle from one of my favorite German producers, Joh. Jos. Pr√ºm. It was a 2001 riesling kabinett Wehlener Sonnenuhr - the famous sundial vineyard in the town of Wehlen. It was such a beautiful wine, with a delicate, sheer texture and those benchmark Mosel flavors of slate and minerals. It's not an exuberant wine. Rather, it's restrained and gentle, fine in the strict sense of the word, like a soap bubble floating in the air or a spider web in the wind. You wonder how it can possibly hold together, but it does.

Updated | 5:33 p.m. President-elect Barack Obama will name Timothy F. Geithner to be his Treasury Secretary, according to a knowledgeable Democrat, elevating a Treasury veteran who as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has all year been at the center of the worsening economic crisis.Stocks jumped 300 points as news leaked Friday of the appointment, which Mr. Obama is expected to announce by Monday, along with the rest of his top economic advisers. The market's rise followed days of steep declines and worsening economic news that spurred the Obama transition offices in Washington and Chicago to expedite announcements about the incoming economic team in hopes of rebuilding confidence in the markets and among the public.Mr. Geithner, 47, for weeks has been the subject of speculation for the administration's top economic post, a job that has gained out-sized stature as the economy has weakened and the Treasury secretary has been put in charge of a $700 billion financial bailout program. His chief rival was his former boss at Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers, President Bill Clinton's final Treasury secretary.

A fire that killed dozens of animals in a Bronx pet store on Wednesday night revived calls for mandatory sprinkler systems in city establishments that shelter animals. (This also came up after a similar fire in Queens two years ago.)

How many times have I started these matchups with a terrible simile? If so, I am giving you a TERRIBLE SIMILE ALERT before saying that the college football season is like summer vacation. When it starts, it seems like it will never end. Long afternoons spill into evenings spent watching game after game, feeling like it will go on forever. Then suddenly you have a winter coat on and you realize that the Big Ten season is ending (I still think they wrap things up too early) and that the magic is almost over. You ask yourself, "How did that happen?" Maybe you cry a little bit. Maybe you wonder if you appreciated it enough. For you, this is a good weekend to savor the games and be thankful for all the football yet to be played.

By some estimates, the world's highest-paid hockey player is Ak Bars Kazan forward Alexei Morozov, the perennial Russian league scoring leader. Reports from Russia last year put his salary at $4 million a year, which when translated into U.S. terms comes to something like $7 million, given that players in Russia pay no taxes. That figure is unconfirmed, of course, and it's possible that Jaromir Jagr and other K.H.L.'ers now have salaries higher than Morozov's.

It's that time of year again when the whole country starts thinking about ways to make turkey more interesting: brining, deep-frying, marinating, stuffing the skin with bacon (my favorite). Well, once you've made that turkey, you need a huge platter to put all the carved meat on. On the low end of the price scale, look to the Martha Stewart Collection at Macy's. The platter, called appropriately enough, Harvest Borders Turkey Platter, is white on white embossed in that traditional English sort of way and at 18-inches it'll fit dark and light meat for the whole family. Williams Sonoma also has a new platter; it features a pair of turkeys that appear to be chatting each other up, or discussing their imminent demise. Coming in at a gigantic 21.5 inches this platter could make a great gift for your mom, or an addition to your own hipster-cool pad (in an ironic kind of way). Finally if you're going for something that you will be able to pass down to your grandchildren and your grandchildren's grandchildren (provided none of them break it) spring the $550 for Mottahedeh's Duke of Gloucester Octagonal platter. It doesn't have a turkey on it, but it has a harvest theme, making it safe for year-round use. The pattern, which was originally made for, you guessed it, the Duke of Gloucester back in 1770, is a true classic you won't regret. Whatever you do, just don't serve your turkey in the pressed tin-foil supermarket roaster you cooked it in.

There's a renegade romance to street art - sprinting from cops, working in the shadows, using an alias, all in the name of art. But Aakash Nihalani, who creates trompe l'oeil 3-D boxes using tape on sidewalks and public surfaces, isn't so cloak and dagger about things. He takes his time creating installations in broad daylight, makes videos of the process and even uses his real name. (Maybe his nonchalance relates to the fact that his artwork is easily peeled off, unlike spray paint.) His work is currently on view throughout the city and, for the next two Saturdays, at the 17 Frost gallery space in Williamsburg. For those interested in further demystification of his street art, this Saturday Nihalani will be presenting a slide show and answering questions at the gallery. In the meantime, we've slipped him a few queries of our own:

Bernanke's problem, and ours. This picture shows the target Fed funds rate, the usual tool of monetary policy; the 10-year Treasury rate; and two rates that actually matter to the private sector, the mortgage rate and the rate on Baa-rated corporate bonds. The Fed has had no success in reducing mortgage rates, and corporate borrowing costs have gone up, not down. Add in falling expectations of inflation, and in real terms monetary policy has gotten tighter, not easier.

Girls hang on Virgil Griffith. This is no exaggeration. At parties, they cling to the arms of the 25-year-old hacker whose reason for being, he says, is to "make the Internet a better and more interesting place." The founder of a data-mining tool called WikiScanner, Griffith is also a visiting researcher at the mysterious Santa Fe Institute, where "complex systems" are studied. He was once charged, wide-eyed rumor has it, with sedition. No wonder girls whisper secrets in his ear and laugh merrily at his arcane jokes.

Usually, the Caller ID feature on your phone shows only the phone number of the person who's calling you. Democratic leaders, exuberant over their Election Day victories, called Congress back to Washington with ambitious plans to push an economic stimulus measure and throw a lifeline to the struggling auto industry. Now, amid fears of deflation, soaring unemployment, plummeting stock prices and deep consumer anxiety, lawmakers are leaving town having approved only a modest extension of jobless benefits. Lawmakers may yet be back next month, but for now the meager results show why lame-duck sessions often do not work. And why some historians and scholars of Congress, not to mention some of the most prominent lawmakers over history, think that calling such sessions lame is overly generous.

WALL STREET SELL-OFF Fresh worries about rising unemployment added to investors' concerns about the economy, as the market's major indexes declined in volatile trading. This high-tech production of Berlioz's telling of the Faust tale continues at the Met. The opera employs interactive video, in which detailed images -- from grassy fields to fiery hells -- morph in response to the movements and singing of the cast.

EVERY year of my childhood, my parents took my brother and me on one big trip. A few months later our neighbors, if they couldn't think up a reasonable excuse, came over for the Slide Show. For those whose only memories of sharing photographs involve Flickr or iPhoto, I should explain that this involved tiny squares placed into an electronic projector to display oversized images as a friendly host droned on ... and on ... about what was in them. Now people share photographs through e-mailed pictures, postings on a Web site or -- for the truly ambitious -- a digital movie accompanied by Coldplay. It's all fun and easy, and I use all these modern image-sharing tools myself. But we have lost the great tradition of going on a journey and then, back home, telling your stories to friends and colleagues while they endure your 140 slides of Yellowstone.

Professional men have their own version of the manicure, the hair coloring and the other grooming rituals that demand so much time from the confident, competent-looking businesswoman. It's the shoeshine, a fussy rite that most women only occasionally indulge in, while many men regularly do. The five shoeshine stands in Grand Central Terminal alone, with their stately mahogany leather and cherry wood chairs, normally polish the shoes of some 700 customers a day, the vast majority of them businessmen.

FOR CHILDREN 'ADVENTURES OF THE PUPPET PRINCESS' (Saturday and Sunday) Can a puppet show really mollify a witch? That's the issue in this new production from the Looking Glass Theater, which draws on Balinese puppetry, masks and folklore. Written and directed by Jennifer Goodlander, the show focuses on Putu, a tomboy, who is lost in the jungle with Nyoman, a boy who is training under Putu's father, a master puppeteer. Saturday at noon and 2 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 4 p.m.; 422 West 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-9467, lookingglasstheatrenyc.com; $15; $12 for 12 and under.

Faced with a severe financial crisis, officials of the Museum of Contemporary Art have had talks about a possible joint venture or merger with several other Los Angeles institutions, including the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Broad Art Foundation and the University of Southern California. The talks come as the museum's endowment, which has been tapped several times in recent years to pay for continuing operations, has shrunk to less than $10 million, one of the lowest levels since the museum's founding in 1979, according to people who have been briefed on the museum's financial situation.

This two-apartment house has about 2,400 square feet of space altogether. It was built 12 years ago, and its concrete-block construction and flat roof are typical of the island's architecture. The property is on the northeast shore, about one block from a protected swimming area, Bastimento Beach in the Villa Borinquen area. There are views of the Atlantic Ocean, mainland Puerto Rico and Culebra from the arched and spacious upper terrace. Mature flowering hedges provide privacy. The upper unit has a living and kitchen area, three bedrooms and one full bathroom. The lower unit is similar but has only two bedrooms. Floors are tile and windows are aluminum louver-style with bars. Though the house is habitable, the buyer may want to update the windows, floors and interior walls. The house is titled. Taxes: $600 annually. Listing agent: Julie Dechter, Vieques Realty and Rentals; (787) 741-0330; www.viequesrealtyandrentals.com.

It's not every day that an actor is tapped to play a role immortalized by Gene Kelly onstage and Frank Sinatra on screen. It is not every day, either, that producers choose to revisit that role, Joey Evans in ''Pal Joey,'' given that it has a title character who uses and exploits women and has a legendarily uneven book that goes with the famous Rodgers and Hart score. Given how risk-averse Broadway is, such a role might seem reserved for a bankable, household-name star who guarantees the extraordinary charisma that the rakish, antihero Joey must project -- a Harry Connick Jr., say, or a Hugh Jackman, both rumored as potential Joeys in recent years.

SARFIN--Mannie, of Englewood Cliffs, NJ passed away on November 17, 2008. Devoted and loving husband of nearly 59 years to Florence. Cherished father of Arlene and Ken (Michele); adored grandfather of Jenna, Phil, Dave and Halle. Mannie grew up in Brooklyn, and graduated from New Utrecht High School and City College of New York. After college, Mannie served in the US Navy as Chief Petty Officer and radar technician. Following his service, Mannie owned a music, greeting cards and photography store on Long Island, and then relocated to Manhattan where his 1407 Camera and Card Shop continued for 49 years. His store was well known for its wide variety of books, cards, gifts and photo supplies. Ken worked closely with him for the past 30 years while Florence partnered with Mannie managing the book department. Friends may call on Sunday, November 23 from 5-8pm; MondayWednesday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the family home. The funeral will be held Sunday, November 23, at noon at the Schoem Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

Age and seniority gave way in Congress on Thursday, a transformational shift for an institution where tremendous power has traditionally been built on sheer longevity, accumulated and savored with the passage of years. The farewell speech of Senator Ted Stevens, 85, a 40-year member of Congress, came on the same day that House Democrats deposed Representative John D. Dingell, 82, a 53-year member, from his committee chairmanship. It was one of those moments when lawmakers could almost hear an era ending.

HONEST, dead leaves do not have to be so depressing. Stripped and skeletal trees leave more of their surroundings exposed, leading to potentially panoramic views. Forty-five years after the Supreme Court's landmark ruling established a defendant's constitutional right to counsel in state criminal proceedings, that crucial right is hanging by a tattered thread. Public defenders' offices always have been underfinanced and overburdened. With state revenues in free fall, the problem is reaching crisis proportions and creating a legal and moral challenge for the criminal justice system, state legislatures and the legal profession.

This single-story beachfront house, offered furnished, is on a bluff in the island's only gated community, the Villas at Martineau Bay, and has views of the Atlantic Ocean, El Yunque rain forest and Culebra from every room. It was built in 2006, and has 3,000 square feet. A 38-foot infinity pool sits in front of the house, and a sandy beach is at the base of the bluff. Outdoors are a poolside deck; a gazebo with a gas grill, full-sized bar, outdoor shower and half bathroom; and several covered terraces. There are floor-to-ceiling windows and Italian marble tile floors throughout the interior. Sliders on all sides lead outdoors. The four full bathrooms have marble finishing. The open kitchen has commercial-grade appliances, custom cabinetry and blue granite countertops. The master bedroom has sliders to the pool. A circular driveway serves for parking. The house is titled. Taxes: $2,000. Listing agent: Alex Mazzocca, Connections Real Estate; (787) 741-0023; www.viequesrealtor.com.

The Clash looked down from a wall-size 1978 photograph at a roomful of workmen sawing, measuring, painting and lugging. Vintage amplifiers were wheeled in from the chill outside, passing by plexiglass exhibition cases, Bruce Springsteen's tarp-covered 1957 Chevrolet and a 26-foot scale model of Manhattan. Then came the heads-up. ''Here comes the phone booth,'' somebody said, and in rolled the wooden phone box from CBGB, plastered with decades-old stickers like a punk sarcophagus. Workers stood it up beside graffitied wall sections from that landmark club, along with two of its loudspeakers and a metal frame for the ''CBGB & OMFUG'' awning that hung over 315 Bowery until the place closed two years ago.

On the morning of June 27, Virginia Hindus, 62, a soft-spoken woman with almond-shaped eyes and cropped white hair, left her orange-brick building on Wallace Avenue in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx to pick up coffee and a newspaper. A short time later, returning to the fourth-floor apartment where she had lived for almost 10 years, she found an eviction notice taped across the door. When she tried her key, she realized that the locks had been changed. A month and a half behind on her rent, she said, she had been locked out.

SULLIVAN--Mary Barrett, of Riverside, CT, at age 89, of cancer. Writer and former Democratic National Committee member who helped found the Caucus of Connecticut Democrats and who led a political reform movement that opened machine politics to rank-and-file participation. Died November 12 at the Richard L. Rosenthal Hospice in Stamford. Married to the late Walter Seager Sullivan, Jr., former science editor of The New York Times, for more than 45 years. The two met in Shanghai, China, where both worked as journalists covering the Chinese Revolution. Survived by Elizabeth, Catherine and Theodore Sullivan and by six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Sunday November 23, at 4pm at the Riverside (CT) Yacht Club.

SANTRY--Julia T., of Greenwich, Connecticut died of a stroke on November 18, 2008 at the Greenwich Hospital. She was 83 years old and is survived by her five children, Arthur J. Santry, III, Suzanne Cochin de Billy, Peter T. Santry, Charles N. Santry, and Robert T. Santry as well as 16 grandchildren. Born Julia Edna Timmins in Montreal, Quebec, she attended McGill University, graduating with a Bachelor of Science degree. In 1955 she married the late Arthur J. Santry, Jr. of Brookline, Massachusetts who would become Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Combustion Engineering and a Commodore of the New York Yacht Club. In 1985, she christened America II, the Club's challenge entry for the America's Cup in Perth, Australia. She was involved in Greenwich activities including the Green Fingers Garden Club where she served as its President from 1985 to 1987. A favorite pastime, she enjoyed gardening and worked tirelessly on her property in Greenwich. She also loved tennis, skiing, and golf and was an active member of the Round Hill Club, the Lyford Cay Club in Nassau, Bahamas, and the Colony Club in New York City. She was active in the US chapter of the Friends of McGill, an alumni outreach program. Her many friends and family will miss her warmth, positive attitude, and joyful disposition. She always carried herself with dignity and grace. A funeral service is scheduled for Saturday, November 22 at St. Mary's Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, Connecticut at 11am.

I was on Bill Moyers Journal on Friday--an enjoyable experience, by the way--and the subject was what the events of this past week told us about the state of the financial crisis. We talked about Citigroup, about the various conflicting statements coming out of the mouth of the Treasury Secretary, Henry Paulson, and about the painful collapse of stock prices. But somewhat to my surprise, we didn't talk much about the trip to Washington by the chief executives of the Big Three automakers. Given everything that happened this past week, that news tended to get short shrift.
