Re "The Perilous Intersection of Art and Religion" (Nov. 9): I appreciate your thoughtful treatment of the controversy regarding the play "Corpus Christi" and the broader issues you raise.Many instances have occurred of insults to cultures and religions by a variety of artistic works. I believe that what upsets members of these various cultures or religions is the failure of people in the mainstream media to validate that reasonable people would conclude that an insult had, in fact, occurred.Most people in the United States do not question the right of the artist to free expression. But they do take exception to the denial by the artist and the mainstream media that an insult has occurred.I was particularly bothered by the recent controversy over depicting the Prophet Muhammad as a figure to be ridiculed in the European media. The rationale that "free speech must be defended" seemed self-indulgent. Free speech, in general, is really not in danger in Western Europe or the United States. An artist or journalist would have to be comatose not to realize that the public ridicule of the Muslim prophet was guaranteed to result in an angry reaction.Tensions between societies of divergent belief systems, and among segments of a pluralistic society with different belief systems, will never be reduced until respectful treatment of all is achieved.John M. McDonaghCold Spring Harbor, N.Y., Nov. 10, 2008 ‚óèYour column was a good discussion of the tension between art (freedom of speech) and religious sensibilities. I would just add that this tension may always be with us, because the basis of the tension between the two is that a significant aspect of art is the call to reflect and think anew about cherished preconceptions.A significant aspect of the religious sensibility is not about thinking, it is about believing and following. Therefore any contrasting point of view can be experienced as offensive and disrespectful. As far as the president of the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights is concerned, we can rest assured that he does not represent most Catholics, who demonstrate the ability to be sensitive to the need for Catholics to consider alternative viewpoints about their Catholic teachings.These Catholics are informed about how often in history Catholic teachings were an abomination to mankind, for example, the teaching of Jew hatred, the murder of converted Jews and "witches" during the Inquisition, the slaughter of innocents during the Crusades, the Concordat with Hitler, the smearing of atheists and competing religionist.Santo J. AlbanoStony Brook, N.Y., Nov. 9, 2008‚óè A turn of phrase you used may create a confusion that you should not have fostered.You write, "The argument, as it did with 'Corpus Christi' 10 years ago, often gets framed as a First Amendment fight between those championing freedom of speech and those seeking to stifle speech they object to." While some may improperly frame this as a First Amendment dispute, the First Amendment specifically refers to limitations on speech or the press by Congress (interpreted more generically as government-imposed limitations).What any individual or private group says, or how it may choose to act, in opposing or seeking to stop what it may consider offensive or wrong, whether presented by a theater or written in a newspaper, has nothing to do with the First Amendment.In fact, that very First Amendment equally protects the rights of speakers and writers on both sides of such issues to make as much noise as they want in venting their views, without limitation by any heavy hand of government.Berl BrechnerCroton-on-Hudson, N.Y., Nov. 10, 2008 ‚óè I smirk at the smug definition by the executive editor, Bill Keller, that The Times concedes unto itself, but find that the newspaper even fails on that standard that you and he so happily agree on.Forget all that freedom of the press and religion-gets-no-pass stuff that even we smirkers agree with you on. What about the hypocrisy standard that even the Keller definition should hold you to?Why didn't you deal with Bill Donohue's criticism that The Times would never treat other religions (or secular idols) the way it treated Catholicism in this instance?Would you have dealt with a play in which the Prophet Muhammad was reviled in the same way? Or Moses? Or an equivalent treatment of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a nonreligious context?Maybe you think The Times would have done so. I don't. But at least I would have liked to have seen you and Mr. Keller address the hard contrast and take a public position.Malcolm A. Head, Jr.Milford, Conn., Nov. 11, 2008 ‚óè I was a bit amused by the comment of Bill Keller, the executive editor, whom you quote, in which he states that The Times is "nondogmatic." A wit once stated that it's obvious why there is so much tension between The Times and the Catholic Church: "What can you expect when you have two infallible institutions."One reason Catholics often feel that The Times is anti-Catholic is the difference in coverage between Catholic sins and the sins of other groups.For example, you had a major story a few months ago about a physician from the teaching hospital of Harvard Medical School who has been accused of sexual abuse. I have seen no follow up, although it sure sounded as if his colleagues in the medical profession acted in a way similar to the way the bishops acted.In the paper of Nov. 13, there is an article about sex abuse in the Orthodox Jewish community on an inside page. But the stories about sex abuse in the Catholic Church seem to be disproportionately on Page 1.Joseph P. ParkesNew York, Nov. 13, 2008The writer is a Jesuit priest.‚óè You write, "It is tempting for a secular and culturally liberal newsroom like The Times's to dismiss such objections."Liberal? I am not sure what you mean by that term. Do you mean "left"? If so, then you are closing in on what The Times is. Personally, I would say, "very slanted left." Why? The paper's election coverage would suffice, not to mention its treatment of Senator John McCain and Cindy McCain. The hatchet jobs on those two are staggering reproaches to The Times's editorial pose as a newspaper that attempts to report the news.Did Times reporters simply fabricate the anti-McCain rumors? I can't say they didn't, and The Times has been guilty of publishing its reporters' fabrications in the past.Culturally liberal? The Times has allowed itself to be a propaganda agency for the left. The newspaper long ago abandoned its responsibility to be objective, and has long since forgotten right from wrong.Herb YoodOrleans, Mass., Nov. 9, 2008 ‚óè I consider myself a "liberal" Catholic, but just reading the snippets in your column about Terence McNally's play nauseated me.I agree that Bill Donohue is generally over the top, but sometimes he is the only Catholic around who makes a necessary noise. The likes of a Paul Baumann is never heard from as a public voice on Catholic concerns. Liberals tend to be more subtle.Where The Times is concerned, and here we are back to a recent public editor column about bias, journalistic context has a lot to do with it. Bill Keller is disingenuous in his definition of "liberal," that is, with no preconceived value (bias) system that sees all values as equal.Puh-leez. The Times loves gays. It has spared no space to promote gay values and the gay agenda. Do you really think a negative review of "Corpus Christi," one that saw it as trash, would fly? Or that a reviewer might be inclined to consider such a play other than with a certain predisposed bias that fits the newspaper's values?‚óèOn the other hand, The Times loves negative news about the Catholic Church (the pedophile scandal) or even Christianity. Let's be honest. Anyone who reads the paper with an open mind recognizes anti-Catholic bias.One has to ask oneself if "art," however mediocre, trumps our respect for what violates or nauseates others in a human society. Does a somewhat "artist" like Mr. McNally working his "agenda" trump what others consider sacred? Is not promoting "Corpus Christi" as "art" merely a way to sabotage readers' values?Dolores D'AgostinoNew York, Nov. 9, 2008 ‚óè Your last paragraph is rich with irony. I don't know of any American daily that covers religion better than The Times, yet that smart, street-savvy religion coverage rarely informs other beats.For instance, it took The Times's political reporters too long to understand what born-again meant during Jimmy Carter's run for the presidency.Similarly, it took too long for that religion savvy to promote a political appreciation of evangelical Christianity or, more recently, to pick up on religiously coded language in George W. Bush's statements.In the same way, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska was unknown to the major news media in the lower 48, but she was a hero as governor to anti-abortion and evangelical activists nationally.Most dailies won't cover religion. Take a look at the poverty of membership in the Religion Newswriters Association. I don't mean reporting that a polygamist ranch was raided, but rather, who are the polygamists? What is the latest fight over Jewish conversion? The Times has done this. Most of the other papers haven't, unless they picked up Times wire copy.I reported from Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Central America, as well as this country. I've covered religion. Skeptical critters that we reporters and editors are, we are genetically inclined to disregard anything that others take on faith and to downgrade its importance as news. That's wrong, dumb and deadly. I don't have to cite Afrikaners and Dutch Reform Church, "black hats" in Israel and settlements, massacres of Copts in Egypt, jihadists of any conviction, 9/11, 7/7 and so on. God(s) help us, even those did not awaken most editors to the continuing importance of religion in public affairs.And I won't even start on nonbelief and its role.Ben L. KaufmanCincinnati, Nov. 9, 2008 ‚óè As a contributor to The Times, I have on more than one occasion been told that a review is not an editorial, and not, I hasten to add, when advancing a political or religious argument.This suggests to me, as does your column criticizing Jason Zinoman's review of "Corpus Christi," a basic failure on the part of The Times to acknowledge that criticism is opinion, and opinion informed by the expertise and experience critics bring to their work.There is no more reason for Mr. Zinoman to credit the Catholic Church's view on the divinity and sexuality of Christ than there is for Paul Krugman to fret that his economic analysis may offend free-market cheerleaders.It is na√Øve to think that critics should not engage with the issues the work before them raises. Given the public posture of the bellicose president of the Catholic League for Relgious and Civil Rights, Bill Donohue, it is even more na√Øve of you to believe he would not have complained had Mr. Zinoman acknowledged why the play is offensive to Catholics.Charles TaylorBrooklyn, Nov. 9, 2008 ‚óè I am pleased to see the executive editor, Bill Keller, acknowledge that The Times is a "liberal" newspaper.I also concur with his definition of liberal in the liberal arts sense. I have always read The Times and understand its worldview. I agree with very little in the paper but can read it because it is liberal in orientation and predictable. The Times always endorses the more liberal presidential candidate, and that is O.K.After nearly 30 years, I recently canceled my subscription to The Chicago Tribune. I made it a point to tell it why. The Tribune has always had a certain worldview (center right). It has undergone a reformatting, changed from center right to solid left, and has fired many of the old voices.Why get a solid-left paper when I already read The Times? I read The Wall Street Journal for a solid-right perspective. The Tribune was the center viewpoint. I understood when it endorsed Barack Obama, since he is our senator. It is the rest of the changes that I could not abide.My point is that when newspapers make sudden shifts in worldview, I think it is especially damaging to longtime readers.To The Times: Keep being the liberal lefties you are, and I will keep reading and disagreeing with you. But I will read you. When you reorient a paper after 50 years, it is really irritating and misses the point of the paper. We expect you to represent a certain worldview.Someday, we will come full circle and religion and science will not be hostile.Jim HusseyHawthorn Woods, Ill., Nov. 9, 2008‚óè‚óèRe "Reading, Writing and Reporters" (Nov. 16): I read your column about Facebook reporting. This kind of reporting seems to be rather common now. A few months ago I was contacted by a reporter from The New York Post over Facebook. The reporter was writing a story about Anisha Lakhani, the former Dalton School teacher who had written a novel purportedly about her time there. I graduated from Dalton in 1998, and imagine the reporter found me by doing a Facebook search on Dalton graduates.The reporter not only asked if I'd taken a class with Ms. Lakhani (I had not), but also asked if he could borrow some of my old high school yearbooks for the story (I declined).This kind of reporting is certainly not new, and I doubt it will go away.Jason PinterNew York, Nov. 17, 2008 ‚óè Regarding the Cindy McCain part of your column, you write that the reporter Jodi Kantor said that she wanted to contact what you call "primarily adult sources" and later quoted her as saying that she wanted to interview "anyone else" who had usable information on Mrs. McCain.This indicates to me that she would indeed have used information from minors, had it been available and relevant to her story. Am I wrong or missing something?By the way, did The Times pursue information on Michelle Obama in the same manner as was used to try to obtain information on Mrs. McCain? If the answer is no, then once again bias exists.James M. Van MetreAlexandria, Va., Nov. 16, 2008 ‚óè Thank you for your courage - yes, courage - in writing that it might not have been a good idea for the reporter Jodi Kantor to troll Facebook pages looking for a classmate of Cindy McCain's daughter to comment on Mrs. McCain's parenting skills.Since The Times did it, we out here in America thought it was acceptable. We used to think only pedophiles did things like that.It takes courage to write critically about The Times almost two weeks after the election. Evidently Ms. Kantor is unrepentant about this new tool of investigative journalism, and her editor wishes she had asked his permission first. But you come down somewhat in the middle. Very brave.Gregory TartagliaRye, N.Y., Nov. 17, 2008 ‚óè Your column did not review the methods and standards required for validating comments and interviews from adults.What happens if in a nonscientific selection process, those willing to comment have a biased opinion, either positive or negative? There is great risk when using the reporting techniques mentioned and then referring to the article as news, rather than opinion.Would the reporter have called the individual the article is about and allowed him or her to comment on the other's input and then publish both sides? The readers most likely will remember the initial article, and any future clarifications will either not be printed or be buried somewhere else in the paper.Don TenerowiczEllington, Conn., Nov. 16, 2008‚óèSome of your readers would object if The Times barred journalists from getting the information that readers expect because of the paranoia of a reader who asked whether a reporter "will be contacting my 12-year-old son, too," and that of Richard Stevenson, the Times editor in charge of campaign coverage. Though I understand that the reporter Jodi Kantor's Facebook messages didn't net any sources for her article on Cindy McCain, I'm worried that future work may be harmed by the new guideline from Craig Whitney, the standards editor, that says that approaching minors to ask about private lives requires prior consultation.Putting overrestrictive rules on reporters at the whim of a few overprotective parents doesn't serve the public interest.Nothing short of a McCain endorsement (and probably not even that) would have quieted the critics of The Times who said the paper was in the tank for Barack Obama. If your wrist-slap of Ms. Kantor was an effort to placate the Times-haters, it was a pointless one. Did I detect a whiff of disappointment over the editors' disowning of her Facebook reporting?Ian S. PortSan Francisco, Nov. 17, 2008

AVANZINO--Kenneth C., 71, of Stamford, CT, Saratoga Springs, NY and Hallandale Beach Florida, passed away suddenly on Thursday, November 20th, after a courageous battle with cancer, with his adoring wife at his side. Born in Boston, MA on January 27, 1937, he was the son of the late Laurence and Elizabeth Chisholm Avanzino. He grew up on Long Island where he graduated Roslyn High School. In 1958 he graduated from Colgate University where he was a member of Sigma NU fraternity. After working for RCA in computer sales he left to attend Columbia University School of Business where he earned his MBA degree in 1961. He then went on to Reynolds and Company, a brokerage firm. In the early 70s he and a partner formed Comprehensive Resources, an oil and gas exploration firm. He and his firm were early leaders and innovators in the development of oil and gas drilling programs from the 1970s through the 1990s. He was an enthusiastic horse owner and breeder whose stable competed in major meets, primarily, in New York and Florida. Ken Avanzino is survived by his loving wife Moira, his sons, Scott of Louisiana, James of New Hampshire and daughter Carolyn Mustin of Massachusetts, four grandchildren, his sister Adele DeMartini and his brothers Stephen and Bruce. He was predeceased by his brother Laurence, Jr. Calling hours will be held on Saturday, November 22, 2008 from 5-8pm and Sunday, November 23, from 3-7pm at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT. A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated 11am on Monday, November 24, 2008 at St. Leo Church 24 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT. Memorial contributions may be made in Kens name to Columbia University Lung Oncology Fund.

KRUGIER--Jan. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague and friend. A great dealer in major works of art, a collector and connoisseur of important drawings, he was respected and admired. Our sympathy and condolences to his wife, Marie-Ann and his children Tzilda and Avril. Roland Augustine, Pres. KRUGIER--Jan. May the earth lie lightly upon him. Jeffrey Hoffeld

ZIFFER--Irving, 90. Distinguished Member of the Military Order of the Purple Heart, decorated WWII hero and everyone's Uncle Icky. Staff Sergeant with Company A, 102nd Engineers, 27th Division, he spent over five years in combat in the Pacific, receiving two Purple Hearts, the Presidential Unit Citation, the American Defense Service Medal, the American Campaign Medal, the Asiatic Campaign Medal with Bronze Star, the New York State Conspicuous Service Cross, and many others citations for his bravery, leadership, and patriotism. He leaves behind his loving sister, Pearl Diamond, nephews and nieces Marshall and Emily, Jody and Debbie, and Harold and Wendy Karp, Dennis Diamond and Elizabeth Geiger, Matthew Diamond and Rae Kraus, and Cori DeFrancis and Steve Baustin, as well as a host of loving great-nieces, greatnephews, cousins, and adoring friends. He was predeceased by his parents, Louis and Sarah Ziffer, brother Joseph Yosi Ziffer, sister Beatrice Karp, nephew Art DeFrancis, and lifelong friend and brother-in-law, Irwin Diamond. He drank scotch, he shot craps, he told dirty jokes, and he played the horses. But his generosity, compassion, positive attitude, humor, and humility made him a loving role model to all.

SOSKIN--Sylvia, died on Thursday morning, 20 November 2008 at the age of ninety-three. She lived in Manhattan for most of her life, very happily married to Jack Soskin, her husband of fifty-four years, who died in 1993. Sylvia was a gracious and elegant lady with a keen sense of humor and a deep understanding of people. Jack awarded her many purple hearts for her stoic acceptance of life with him. She always said that she hoped she would grow up to be a mom. She did, and she was a wonderful mom to her two daughters, Benita Ober and Eileen Soskin. Sylvia's Wisdom and wit will be missed by everyone who knew her. Sylvia Soskin is survived by many people who loved her dearly, including her two daughters and her four grandchildren: Wendi Lisa Sachs and her partner Elizabeth Sachs; Paul David Sachs and his wife Heather; Naomi Elizabeth Permutt; and Samuel James Permutt. Services will be held on Sunday, 23 November 2008, at 11:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey. If you wish to honor Sylvia Soskin, please make a gift to UNICEF, the Walnut Hill School Annual Fund of a charity of your choice. The family will be at home on Sunday, 23 November after 4:00pm and on Monday,Tuesday, and Wednesday 24-26 November from 11:00am to 8:00pm

DALY--Mary C. The Robert B. Fiske, Jr. Association and the John S. Martin, Jr. Association deeply mourn the passing of our beloved and esteemed colleague, Mary C. Daly, who was an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York from 1975 to 1983. During her tenure at the Office, Mary served as Chief of the Civil Rights Unit, and Deputy Chief and finally Chief of the Civil Division from 1981-1983. In 2004, the Fiske Association awarded Mary the William M. Tendy Public Service Award. Upon leaving the Office, Mary embarked on her distinguished career in academia joining the Fordham Law School faculty where she was the James H. Quinn Professor of Legal Ethics and Co-Director of the Louis Stein Center for Law and Ethics as well as the Director of the law school's Graduate Program. While a member of the Fordham Law School faculty, Mary was a prolific author and editor publishing multitudinous articles on legal ethics with a concentration on corporate and cross-border practice. Mary's professional involvement extended beyond the law school. She served on several ABA committees and was the Reporter for the ABA Commission on Multidisciplinary Practice from 1998-2000. Among other barrelated activities, she served as the Reporter to the New York State Bar Association Task Force on the Profession from 1994-1995, served as Chair of the Committee on Professional and Judicial Ethics of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, and was a member of the Departmental Disciplinary Committee for the Appellate Division, First Department from 1990-1996. From 2003 until her death, Mary was the Dean of the School of Law at St. John's University where she was also the John V. Brennan Chair of Law and Ethics. Dean Daly was an honors graduate of Thomas More College and the Fordham University School of Law, where she was a member of the Law Review, and earned an LL.M from New York University School of Law. Although Mary reached the pinnacle of her profession, she remained the selfeffacing and down-to-earth person she was when she joined us at the U.S. Attorney's Office, relying for her success on her unstinting work ethic, humanity, and integrity and never forgetting what was most dear to her, namely her family: her husband Tony Distinti, and their children, Anthony, Stephen and Mary Margaret. DALY--Mary C. Fordham Law School records with profound sorrow the passing of Mary C. Daly, Class of 1972. Mary was an extraordinary member of the Law School faculty for more than twenty years, a brilliant and nationally-recognized legal ethics scholar who made the Stein Institute the preeminent program in the field, a gifted teacher, a superb dean of St. John's Law School, a leading member of our Dean's Planning Council, and a dear friend. Mary was beloved by all, and her warmth, generous spirit, and care for others enriched the lives of everyone she touched. Her life bore eloquent witness to Fordham's motto ''In the service of others.'' We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband Tony Distinti, Class of 1972, and their three children, Anthony, Class of 2007, Stephen, and Meg. William Michael Treanor, Dean

SARFIN--Mannie, of Englewood Cliffs, NJ passed away on November 17, 2008. Devoted and loving husband of nearly 59 years to Florence. Cherished father of Arlene and Ken (Michele); adored grandfather of Jenna, Phil, Dave and Halle. Mannie grew up in Brooklyn, and graduated from New Utrecht High School and City College of New York. After college, Mannie served in the US Navy as Chief Petty Officer and radar technician. Following his service, Mannie owned a music, greeting cards and photography store on Long Island, and then relocated to Manhattan where his 1407 Camera and Card Shop continued for 49 years. His store was well known for its wide variety of books, cards, gifts and photo supplies. Ken worked closely with him for the past 30 years while Florence partnered with Mannie managing the book department. Friends may call on Sunday, November 23 from 5-8pm; MondayWednesday from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the family home. The funeral will be held Sunday, November 23, at noon at the Schoem Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

Literature | Settling into "The Wizard of Oz" for a little escapist entertainment this Thanksgiving? Not to be a killjoy, but keep in mind the tale is seen by some as an allegory of the economic turmoil of the 1890s. See, the Scarecrow is the American farmer, the Tin Man represents the workers, the Cowardly Lion depicts the silver populist William Jennings Bryan, the Yellow Brick Road is the gold standard -- and that's not all. Come to think of it, today's economy hasn't seemed too far from fantasy lately either, has it? [American Quarterly, Journal of Political Economy, Indiana.edu, Wikipedia]

Lexicon | "Meh," an expression indicating one's lack of interest or enthusiasm, has been added to the Collins English Dictionary, but not everyone's happy about it. Isn't this just a dictionary publicity stunt? Isn't meh more sound effect than word? On the other hand, maybe that's why it makes a good word: it's onomatopoetic. [Visual Thesaurus, AFP]

Havard Bokko won the 1,500-meter race and Claudia Pechstein dominated the 5,000 in Moscow to win their first speedskating World Cup races this season. Bokko finished in 1 minute 45.46 seconds. Pechstein, a four-time Olympic champion, clocked 6:49.92 for her 22nd World Cup gold. She edged the world-record holder Martina Sablikova by 7.26 seconds.

Marcus Hellner and Charlotte Kalla of Sweden won their first World Cup cross-country ski titles in Gallivare, Sweden. Hellner edged Pietro Piller Cottrer of Italy by 1.4 seconds in the 15-kilometer freestyle, and Kalla cruised past Marit Bjorgen of Norway by 24.4 seconds in the 10k freestyle.

Douglas McGray‚Äôs article (Nov. 9) shined a light on a little discussed but promising new effort: bringing the ‚Äúunbanked‚Äù into the financial mainstream. We know firsthand of its benefits. Two years ago, San Francisco introduced the first comprehensive initiative to bank the unbanked by encouraging financial institutions to modify their products and policies to attract lower-income consumers. The results far surpassed our expectations. More than 18,000 residents have opened accounts with ‚ÄúBank on San Francisco.‚Äù This means people keep more of what they earn ‚Äî particularly important now when money is tight. That‚Äôs why almost 60 cities and states are looking to replicate our efforts.

As Katherine Zoepf illustrates, re-educating willing foot soldiers is one measure that might undermine jihadist terrorism (Nov. 9). As analysts of terrorism, we are starting to learn that one of the common characteristics ‚Äî if not the most common characteristic ‚Äî that most participants in this violent social movement share revolves around religious knowledge. Jonathan Mahler‚Äôs retrospective (Nov. 9) does an admirable job describing the Bush administration‚Äôs ‚ÄúImperial Presidency‚Äù and the reaction of Congress to this expansion of presidential authority. The piece omits a key fact, however. Mahler writes that ‚Äúthe Democrats have yet to issue a single contempt-of-Congress citation.‚Äù While that may be correct with respect to the U.S. Senate, which appears to be the focus of Mahler‚Äôs discussion, the House of Representatives did approve contempt citations earlier this year for the key White House officials Harriet Miers and Josh Bolten. Further, the House Judiciary Committee has successfully challenged the administration‚Äôs legal claims in federal court, recently winning a landmark ruling from a Bush-appointed federal judge. That matter remains pending on appeal and, like many Congressional efforts to get to the bottom of the Bush administration excesses described in Mahler‚Äôs piece, will continue into the next Congress.

BELLER--Robert Winter, 79, passed away on November 18, 2008. Beloved husband and father, he is survived by his wife of 53 years, Joan R. Beller, and their two children, Susan J. B. Hughes and Dr. Harry R. Beller. He graduated from Harvard Business School and the City College of New York, served as VP of Marketing Services at J. E. Seagram & Sons, and later founded Marketing Answers Consultants. After retiring in Carmel, California, he pursued his lifelong passions for sculpture and poetry, and volunteered as a literacy tutor. The family requests that charitable donations be made to Americas Second Harvest or Grace Church Community Center of White Plains.

BUCHALTER--Martin, 76, Medical Ultrasound Pioneer, died Monday, November 17 at home in New York. President/CEO of Parker Laboratories (New Jersey), the leading manufacturer of ultrasound and electromedical contact media. He guided Parker to international prominence through a lifetime of innovation and marketing savvy. Proud graduate of University of Sciences in Philadelphia, he also held an MSc from LIU. Survived by his wife of 45 years, Carol; three children, Vida (and Jeff) Harband, Neal (and Robin) Buchalter, Rona Buchalter (and Nathaniel Popkin); and six grandchildren; Jared and Matthew Harband, Hailey and Emily Buchalter, and Caroline and Isaak Popkin. Memorial service Sunday at Steven Wise Free Synagogue, New York City. Donations welcome to the Martin Buchalter 55 Scholarship fund at Univ. of Sciences, Philadelphia, PA 19104, or to Alzheimer's research.

ORMONT--Louis R., Ph.D., DFAGPA. The American Group Psychotherapy Association and the Group Psychotherapy Foundation mourn the loss of Louis R. Ormont, Ph.D., who died on Saturday, November 15. A Distinguished Fellow of AGPA and a leader in the field for over five decades, he was a generous teacher to a generation of clinicians worldwide. He is survived by his devoted wife, Marian Joan Ormont, his children Dr. Marian Amanda Ormont and Dr. Michael Llewellyn Ormont, five grandchildren, and hundreds of grateful colleagues, students and clients to all of whom we extend our condolences. ORMONT--Louis R., Ph.D., 90. For over five decades Lou Ormont was a pioneer in the field of group psychotherapy, as a master teacher and clinician who devoted himself to the art and science of psychoanalytic group treatment. A student of the theater, Lou developed a teaching method, a mix of didactic and experiential learning, that made his public presentations sought after events. To know Lou was to know a quick-witted, dynamic and passionate man who was tireless in his effort to understand people, connecting them to their emotional lives and to one another while navigating through obstacles that divided them. He trained a generation of practitioners around the world, affecting thousands of people daily. Lou taught many to live with immediacy and freedom. He is gone but here. Condolences to his beloved wife Joan, children Dr. Marian Ormont and Dr. Michael Ormont and five grandchildren. Mary V. Sussillo, LCSW Elliot M. Zeisel, Ph.D., FAGPA, Vice-Chair Group Psychotherapy Foundation ORMONT--Louis. The Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies mourns the loss of Louis R. Ormont, Ph.D., and offers its condolences to his family and wife Joan. In 1970 he and 21 other Psychoanalysts joined together to found the Center. Through his teaching he influenced many students who keep alive his pioneering work on group analysis. He was a bold, creative intellect who embodied his belief, living fully to the very end. He will be missed but never forgotten.

AXELROD--Rosa Ully. Holocaust survivor who embraced her adopted country, died on November 20th, 2008 at the age of 97. Devoted wife of the late Max, loving mother of Judi Bosworth and Mirell Walden, esteemed mother-in-law of Jay Bosworth and Neil Walden, treasured grandmother of Michael, Lauren and Brian Bosworth and adoring greatgrandmother of Andrew and Robin. She was an artist, intellect and good friend who lived life on her own terms; engaged and fiercely independent. She enriched the lives of all who knew her.

LaVERDIERE--Fr. Eugene, S.S.S., a leading Catholic Scripture scholar and the Senior Editor of Emmanuel magazine, died November 20th at the age of 72. Fr. LaVerdiere, a member of the Congregation of the Blessed Sacrament was born on April 7, 1936 in Waterville, Maine. He made his profession in the Congregation of the Blessed Sacrament on September 8, 1958. He was ordained to the priesthood on May 16, 1964 in Portland, Maine. Fr. LaVerdiere was the local Superior of the Blessed Sacrament Community at St. Jean Baptiste in New York. Fr. LaVerdiere was a distinguished lecturer at Fordham University. Father LaVerdiere is survived by his sister, Sr. Claudette LaVerdiere, M.M. of Maryknoll, NY, brothers, Br. Gary LaVerdiere, S.S.S., Cleveland, OH, Peter (Cheryl) of Oceanside, CA. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, November 24, 2008 in Cleveland, OH. Contributions to the Congregation of the Blessed Sacrament, 5384 Wilson Mills Rd., Highland Heights, OH. 44143. Funeral conducted by The DeJohn - Flynn - Mylott Funeral Home of South Euclid, Ohio. www.DeJohnFuneral.com

CATER--Irene Blenheim, died on November 21, 2008 at Chelsea House, Tinton Falls, NJ. A memorial service will be scheduled later at St. Georges by-the-River, Rumson, New Jersey. Burial will be at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York. Mrs. Cater was born on the 21st of July 1907 in London, England to William J. Blenheim and Rosa Pledge of that same city. She had a brother, Donald Blenheim and three sisters, Enid Richards, Vera Brigham and Beryl Marsh. On the 21st of May 1931 she married Berkeley A. Cater in East Orange, New Jersey. They had one daughter, Elizabeth, deceased, of New York City. Mrs. Cater is survived by one granddaughter, Melissa Hutchens Havercroft and two great-grandchildren, William and Chloe Havercroft all of Corona Del Mar, California and New York City. Memorial donations may be sent to St. Georges by-the-River Episcopal Church, 7 Lincoln Ave, Rumson, NJ 07760.

Carolina (8-2) is quietly sitting in the No. 2 spot in the National Football Conference, but the way the Panthers have played the past two weeks, they are probably happy no one has been paying attention to them. In wins against Oakland and Detroit, two of the league's worst teams, Jake Delhomme completed 37 percent of his passes, threw 4 interceptions and compiled 17 completions, 174 passing yards and a 26.9 passer rating. Delhomme can thank running backs DeAngelo Williams, who has three straight 100-yard games, and Jonathan Stewart for keeping the Panthers afloat.

THOMPSON--Cameron A., 56, son of Frederick and Julia Thompson, died 29 September. Service at Madison Ave. Presbyterian Church, 11 November. Survived by Kathleen, Geoffrey, Jonathan, Kimberley, Yvonne Stamler and her daughter Leah.

DALY--Mary C. The Robert B. Fiske, Jr. Association and the John S. Martin, Jr. Association deeply mourn the passing of our beloved and esteemed colleague, Mary C. Daly, who was an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York from 1975 to 1983. During her tenure at the Office, Mary served as Chief of the Civil Rights Unit, and Deputy Chief and finally Chief of the Civil Division from 1981-1983. In 2004, the Fiske Association awarded Mary the William M. Tendy Public Service Award. Upon leaving the Office, Mary embarked on her distinguished career in academia joining the Fordham Law School faculty where she was the James H. Quinn Professor of Legal Ethics and Co-Director of the Louis Stein Center for Law and Ethics as well as the Director of the law school's Graduate Program. While a member of the Fordham Law School faculty, Mary was a prolific author and editor publishing multitudinous articles on legal ethics with a concentration on corporate and cross-border practice. Mary's professional involvement extended beyond the law school. She served on several ABA committees and was the Reporter for the ABA Commission on Multidisciplinary Practice from 1998-2000. Among other barrelated activities, she served as the Reporter to the New York State Bar Association Task Force on the Profession from 1994-1995, served as Chair of the Committee on Professional and Judicial Ethics of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, and was a member of the Departmental Disciplinary Committee for the Appellate Division, First Department from 1990-1996. From 2003 until her death, Mary was the Dean of the School of Law at St. John's University where she was also the John V. Brennan Chair of Law and Ethics. Dean Daly was an honors graduate of Thomas More College and the Fordham University School of Law, where she was a member of the Law Review, and earned an LL.M from New York University School of Law. Although Mary reached the pinnacle of her profession, she remained the selfeffacing and down-to-earth person she was when she joined us at the U.S. Attorney's Office, relying for her success on her unstinting work ethic, humanity, and integrity and never forgetting what was most dear to her, namely her family: her husband Tony Distinti, and their children, Anthony, Stephen and Mary Margaret.
FERRE--Eleanor Louise, on November 13th, 2008 in Rockville, MD, former resident of New Rochelle. Survived by six nieces and nephews. Interment at Beechwood Cemetery, New Rochelle.

THE NEWS The Democratic leaders of the House and Senate said the floundering Big Three automakers had failed to persuade either Congress or the public that the $25 billion in federal aid the companies want would be well spent. BEHIND THE NEWS No one doubts that G.M., Chrysler and to a lesser extent Ford are running out of cash as they struggle with high costs and anemic sales, which fell to a 25-year low in October and are down by 14 percent for the year. But many lawmakers (and the White House) oppose a bailout, saying that throwing good money after bad won't solve Detroit's fundamental problems, which the companies have done too little to address for too long.

LEVY--Sunya, on November 10, 2008, age 97. Beloved wife of the late Julien Levy for 63 years, revered mother of Ellen, and grandmother of Hannah. A lyric soprano and award winning painter, divine cook, discerning antique collector, voracious reader, a lover of beauty and of all living things who said ''excuse me'' when stepping over our dog. Sura Mindel came to the U.S. as a girl, became Sunya, aptly called Sunny, worshiped her new country, and taught herself to speak English with eloquence and wit. Until her last days, she regaled us with Yiddish songs, Puccini Arias and Broadway melodies. Her exquisite eye and kind heart flower in Hannah, a golden legacy. Oh, Mamale...

Squeezed by increasing costs and declining tax subsidies, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has proposed a 23 percent increase in fare and toll revenues, as well as budget cuts that include the elimination of two subway lines, many station booth closings and a reduction in off-peak service. The authority's board will vote on the increases in December, and they could take effect next June. Here is some background on transit costs.

IF by chance you weren't Googling ''Yugos for sale'' in early October, you probably missed the auction of the mustard-yellow hatchback featured prominently in the recent film ''Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist.'' The car -- one of three identical Yugos procured for the film's shoot -- sold on eBay last month for $2,600. Granted, this is not exactly like owning Steve McQueen's Mustang from ''Bullitt,'' but in these austere times an aficionado has to take what he can get.

FINKEL--Donald A., 79, died November 15th, 2008. Poet in residence emeritus, Washington University, St. Louis. Author of 14 volume's of poetry. Survived by loving family: son Tom, daughters Liza and Amy, two grandchildren, halfbrother David. Memorial service December 12th, 11:30am at Washington University.

VIDEO: THE MINIMALIST TACKLES THANKSGIVING If you are plagued by recurring nightmares of Thanksgiving dinner, not to fear. A video of Mark Bittman demonstrating how to prepare a whole roasted turkey in under 45 minutes. Also, a video on how to carve a turkey to get as much meat as possible. And a Thanksgiving Topic Page of recipes (like savoy cabbage slaw with applesauce vinaigrette and mustard seeds, far left, and chocolate-pumpkin layer cake), articles and other Thanksgiving resources.

RANFTLE--Howard K. (Ken). The Board and staff of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force mourn the death of Ken Ranftle, a member of our board for five years. His involvement in the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender movement began at Stonewall and continued throughout his life. Ken was endlessly generous to the Task Force, including ensuring that we would be the beneficiary of Ascension on Fire Island and Winter Party Festival in Miami. The eldest of five boys --four of them gay --he married Craig Leiby, his partner of nearly 20 years, in Montreal last June. In his professional life, Ken ensured that domestic partnership benefits were available for gay employees during his tenure at both IBM and Towers Perrin. Ken gave ceaselessly and joyfully of his time, his astonishing intelligence and his delicious sense of humor. Ken had been fighting lung cancer and died of a heart attack in Craig's arms. Our thoughts are with Craig, who he adored, and with Ken's large and loving family.

WHILE General Motors faces a battering ram of criticism in the United States, its European brand, Opel, has won the European Car of the Year award for the Insignia four-door sedan. The Insignia beat the new Ford Fiesta by a single point in voting by European auto journalists. Neither car is available in the United States, though Ford plans to sell the Fiesta here in 2010.
New gadgets you'll want to keep for yourself. LIMITED-EDITION AQUOS LCD TV by Sharp, $11,999. At Stereo Exchange, New York.

This year's sharp decline in the stock market has delivered a shock to many older people who expected a comfortable retirement. But other New Yorkers, near or at the end of their working lives with meager or no savings, never had such expectations. Some have struggled for years to stay one step ahead of poverty, living paycheck to paycheck. Others met up with a crisis, like the illness of a spouse, that shattered a fragile financial plan. For older people, the choices are fewer, health problems are more likely, and a return to the work force is not always an option.
I'm thinking of going to Paris for Christmas. I went once before, and finding Christmas dinner was a challenge. Any ideas for Christmas lunch or dinner there? -- Geoff Russell, Houston

WACHS--Donald I., on November 21, 2008 at the age of 79. Beloved husband of Judith for 55 years. Loving father of Joel and Joane, Eric and Jane, Harriet and Joel Shaiman. Cherished grandfather of Maddy, Alyssa, Miriam, Aaron, Stephanie, Michael, Sydney and Benjamin. A life lived with love and laughter.

AT THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF CATALAN ART IN BARCELONA, OCT. 5, 2008 Kalina Tekelieva, 21, a student in Scandinavian philology from Sofia, Bulgaria. ''We were on a photography project called Signs of the City. There have been workshops in four cities -- Sofia, Berlin, Barcelona, London. Our task was to take pictures of signs that are unique for Barcelona, in contrast to our own city. We were staying near Las Ramblas: those narrow paved streets, silence, not so many people, really amazing architecture. I love that kind of labyrinth. In Barcelona you can hide if you need some time to be on your own, to listen to some street musician playing the guitar. That's hard to do in Sofia. My friends always make fun of me for traveling so much. Sometimes they joke that I'll soon forget Bulgarian. All the time, I am exploring the way people communicate. Some time ago I thought words were the most important thing. Now I know words are not at all that important. Sometimes I find people who I feel are really close to my heart, and it's not because of the words we have spoken to each other.'' As told to Seth Kugel

OVER the years Kenneth Jay Lane's fanciful costume baubles have adorned the best of them: Diana Vreeland, Jackie Onassis and Audrey Hepburn were all loyal clients. Barbara Bush wouldn't leave home without his three-strand faux pearl necklace, and it is said that the Duchess of Windsor is buried in one of his jeweled belts. Luxury, he once said, never goes out of style. And with his prices (so low they're almost ludicrous), everyone is apparently entitled to it. Recession be damned! At just over $160, his Swarovski crystal cocktail rings add a good dose of glam to your look, without a great deal of guilt. Kenneth Jay Lane Swarovski crystal ''Dome'' rings, $165 at vivre.com.

MARGOLICK--Dr. Moses, 98, on November 20 in Sarasota, FL. Husband for 59 years of Gertrude, father of Dr. Joseph (Dr. Linda P. Fried), David and Daniel, grandfather of Jonathan and Alexander. For 47 years he practiced medicine and surgery in Putnam, CT, where he was also chief of staff at the Day Kimball Hospital, and was much beloved by generations of patients. He was born and raised in Montreal, graduated from McGill University and Medical School, and trained at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. During World War II he served in the Army Medical Corps. He was active in civic affairs. He will be remembered as a man of great integrity, dedication, scholarship, compassion, curiosity and wit. Donations in his memory may be made to the Dr. Moses Margolick Fund, c/o Day Kimball Hospital, P.O. Box 632, Putnam, CT 06260.

Predeceased by sister, Helene Elhart, mother Paulyne Simon, stepfather Adolph Simon, and father Oscar Tobin/Willie Jackson, professional boxer.

ZIFFER--Irving, 90. Distinguished Member of the Military Order of the Purple Heart, decorated WWII hero and everyone's Uncle Icky. Staff Sergeant with Company A, 102nd Engineers, 27th Division, he spent over five years in combat in the Pacific, receiving two Purple Hearts, the Presidential Unit Citation, the American Defense Service Medal, the American Campaign Medal, the Asiatic Campaign Medal with Bronze Star, the New York State Conspicuous Service Cross, and many others citations for his bravery, leadership, and patriotism. He leaves behind his loving sister, Pearl Diamond, nephews and nieces Marshall and Emily, Jody and Debbie, and Harold and Wendy Karp, Dennis Diamond and Elizabeth Geiger, Matthew Diamond and Rae Kraus, and Cori DeFrancis and Steve Baustin, as well as a host of loving great-nieces, greatnephews, cousins, and adoring friends. He was predeceased by his parents, Louis and Sarah Ziffer, brother Joseph Yosi Ziffer, sister Beatrice Karp, nephew Art DeFrancis, and lifelong friend and brother-in-law, Irwin Diamond. He drank scotch, he shot craps, he told dirty jokes, and he played the horses. But his generosity, compassion, positive attitude, humor, and humility made him a loving role model to all.

SOSKIN--Sylvia, died on Thursday morning, 20 November 2008 at the age of ninety-three. She lived in Manhattan for most of her life, very happily married to Jack Soskin, her husband of fifty-four years, who died in 1993. Sylvia was a gracious and elegant lady with a keen sense of humor and a deep understanding of people. Jack awarded her many purple hearts for her stoic acceptance of life with him. She always said that she hoped she would grow up to be a mom. She did, and she was a wonderful mom to her two daughters, Benita Ober and Eileen Soskin. Sylvia's Wisdom and wit will be missed by everyone who knew her. Sylvia Soskin is survived by many people who loved her dearly, including her two daughters and her four grandchildren: Wendi Lisa Sachs and her partner Elizabeth Sachs; Paul David Sachs and his wife Heather; Naomi Elizabeth Permutt; and Samuel James Permutt. Services will be held on Sunday, 23 November 2008, at 11:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey. If you wish to honor Sylvia Soskin, please make a gift to UNICEF, the Walnut Hill School Annual Fund of a charity of your choice. The family will be at home on Sunday, 23 November after 4:00pm and on Monday,Tuesday, and Wednesday 24-26 November from 11:00am to 8:00pm

He leaned back in the wooden chair to reach into the inner pocket of his lightweight black jacket for proof. He proudly held up a glossy laminated card: his cabdriver's license.

8 P.M. (13, 49) NATURE: THE WOLF THAT CHANGED AMERICA In 1893 Ernest Thompson Seton, right, an animal trapper and naturalist, traveled into the canyons of New Mexico on a mission to kill a wolf called Lobo, the leader of a cattle-killing pack. Known as the King of Currumpaw, Lobo had a mythical ability to cheat death, and after eventually trapping Lobo, Seton found he couldn't kill him. Lobo ultimately died from his injuries, and Seton returned east, recording his findings in the book ''Wild Animals I Have Known'' and using his popularity to push for the creation of national parks and lay the groundwork for the Boy Scouts of America. ''Ever since Lobo,'' Seton said, ''my sincerest wish has been to impress upon people that each of our native wild creatures is in itself a precious heritage that we have no right to destroy or put beyond the reach of our children.'' 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS WITH CHRIS WALLACE The House majority leader, Steny Hoyer of Maryland, and the House minority leader, John A. Boehner of Ohio, discuss the proposed bailout of the automotive industry.

AVANZINO--Kenneth C., 71, of Stamford, CT, Saratoga Springs, NY and Hallandale Beach Florida, passed away suddenly on Thursday, November 20th, after a courageous battle with cancer, with his adoring wife at his side. Born in Boston, MA on January 27, 1937, he was the son of the late Laurence and Elizabeth Chisholm Avanzino. He grew up on Long Island where he graduated Roslyn High School. In 1958 he graduated from Colgate University where he was a member of Sigma NU fraternity. After working for RCA in computer sales he left to attend Columbia University School of Business where he earned his MBA degree in 1961. He then went on to Reynolds and Company, a brokerage firm. In the early 70s he and a partner formed Comprehensive Resources, an oil and gas exploration firm. He and his firm were early leaders and innovators in the development of oil and gas drilling programs from the 1970s through the 1990s. He was an enthusiastic horse owner and breeder whose stable competed in major meets, primarily, in New York and Florida. Ken Avanzino is survived by his loving wife Moira, his sons, Scott of Louisiana, James of New Hampshire and daughter Carolyn Mustin of Massachusetts, four grandchildren, his sister Adele DeMartini and his brothers Stephen and Bruce. He was predeceased by his brother Laurence, Jr. Calling hours will be held on Saturday, November 22, 2008 from 5-8pm and Sunday, November 23, from 3-7pm at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT. A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated 11am on Monday, November 24, 2008 at St. Leo Church 24 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT. Memorial contributions may be made in Kens name to Columbia University Lung Oncology Fund.

DUBROWIN--Bernice Lifton, 89, on November 14, 2008. Formerly of Hartsdale, NY, Bernice and her beloved Ray moved to San Diego, CA in 1988. She grew up in New Jersey, Brooklyn, and Manhattan, and graduated from Beaver College (now Arcadia University) in 1941. Since Ray's death in 2005, she had returned to painting, gardening, and closely following the news. Her daughters, Ellen (of Oakland, CA) and Sandy (of Richmond, CA), and hundreds of friends and family members around the country will miss her brilliant humor and her sage, if sometimes unheeded, advice. Ellen and Sandy are extremely grateful that she was able to celebrate the recent election results.

California will not win the Pacific-10's Rose bowl bid, which will go to Oregon State or U.S.C., but Jahvid Best, left, scored three times to ensure that its archrival, Stanford, would not go to a bowl at all. It was a good day for coaches on the way out. Purdue routed Indiana, 62-10, for its retiring coach, Joe Tiller. And Syracuse's Greg Robinson who had already been fired, won at Notre Dame.

NIEDERMAN--Leslie. Armed with a sharp wit and keen intellect, Leslie arrived in this country as an orphan in 1946, after surviving Dachau and Auschwitz concentration camps. He met his soul mate in 1947 while searching for relatives immigrating to New York City. Susan Niederman had just arrived in New York when Leslie tracked her down because she shared the same name. They were married for over 58 years. Leslie became a partner at the kosher meat market, Fisher Bros and Leslie in 1949. An astute businessman, he continually evolved the store to accommodate the changing needs and lifestyles of the community. Located at 230 West 72nd St., it is currently managed by his sons and son-in-law. Generations of families came to know Mr. Niederman and his establishment, his smile the ambassador to his business. Over 500 mourners at Temple Emanuel in Closter, NJ on July 8 and the police lead funeral procession that stretched across Bergen County were testimony to the legacy of good will, appreciation and affection he leaves in his wake. Leslie Niederman died July 6 at age 82 of pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife Susan, sister Magda Frohlinger, his children and their spouses, Steven and Carolyn Niederman, Mark and Gail Niederman and Marcy and Paul Whitman, and seven grandchildren. He will be remembered with a smile on his face, and for the smiles he put on the faces of others.

SHAY--Helene. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Helene Shay, beloved mother of Scott Shay. Scott is a dear friend and a leader of UJA-Federation who is deeply committed to the Jewish community, formerly serving as a chair on our Commission for Jewish Identity and Renewal, on the executive committee, and on our board of directors. Scott has enabled UJA-Federation to carry out our mission of caring for those in need, rescuing those in harm's way, and renewing and strengthening the Jewish people in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to Scott and his wife, Susan; to Helene's grandchildren, Benjamin, Ariel, Alison, and Abigail; and to her entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

To the Sports Editor: Re ''The Last Hurrah?'' Nov. 12: The regrettable tale of Ville Platte High School in Louisiana (and incidentally, its football program) described the opening day of hunting season as ''12-gauge bonding.'' The only thing produced by combining 12-gauges and squirrels is, at most, a cloud of fur and innards and a wholesale skedaddle of his cousins to the next county. A .22 is the preferred tool. Claiborne Walthall

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Tossing it All Away in Name of Teaching,'' Nov 14: I met Tom Donnelly, the Haverford College cross-country coach, when I ran at a rival college. At the 1983 N.C.A.A. championships, he stopped me as I ran to the start, wished me well and said, ''Remember to run your race today.'' Unfortunately, I was so caught up in the excitement of the event I ran terribly and finished near the back of the field.

CHRISTOPHE DECARNIN of Balmain put the idea out there, but the women of Paris and New York perfected it: the sequin jacket, casually tossed over a T-shirt and trousers for a somewhat louche, but immensely chic, day look. Of course, it also works well at night. Aimee Cho, the designer of Gryphon, included sequin jackets in her fall collection because of a void in her closet. ''I was in need of one that I could wear more as a cardigan,'' she explained, ''with an oversize men's T-shirt and jeans.'' Not surprisingly, they have become one of her best sellers. ''They speak to a consumer who is looking to wear it for day, but also to the person looking for something for a special occasion,'' she said. ''As much as a fully sequined jacket can be, I guess it has broad appeal.''

To the Sports Editor: New York is missing a piece of the equation in putting out the welcome mat for LeBron James. He's already home. He's already a megastar. And he knows that to further cement his legend, he can do that best by winning championships for his hometown Cleveland Cavaliers.

To the Editor: As a parent of a 32-year-old young woman with severe developmental disabilities, I was outraged by the article in the Westchester section concerning the group home in Eastchester (''Accepting the Retarded, as Long as They're Old,'' Nov. 16). Persons with cognitive disabilities are not predators; in fact, they are more vulnerable than others! These are young people who try to live enriching lives and deserve to live in a home in a community just like any other citizen. It is so disheartening to read about people who do not understand this.

ROBINSON--Joshua. The lawyers and staff of Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP mourn the tragic passing of Joshua Robinson, our beloved partner and friend. Josh was extraordinary by every measure. He impressed us all with his intelligence, intellect and ability to wow and he won us all over with his incredible warmth and kindness. No one could ask for more from a friend, colleague, mentor or partner. As we mourn his passing, we also are incredibly grateful for the time he was a part of the Weil Gotshal family. We are all better for that. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Heather, who provided Josh with tremendous love and support throughout their years together, and to his two beautiful young daughters, Morgan and Bridget.

On Thanksgiving, many families enjoy a lavish feast of turkey, sides and deserts, including the traditional pumpkin pie. But for some, Thanksgiving does not mean reunions or extravagant meals. Marie Hinkel, 79, a childless widow, will be at a soup kitchen within walking distance of her apartment in Port Chester, N.Y. She is thankful that she lives in a neighborhood where she can rely on the generosity of churches and community centers; otherwise, on more than one occasion, she would not have eaten.

THANKS to the Yves Saint Laurent fall runway show, which featured models with mouths like oil slicks, last year's black nail polish trend has become this year's black lipstick frenzy. In September, YSL's Pur Black lip gloss sold out while still in the preorder stage; and this weekend, Lanc√¥me's much-anticipated Piha Black gloss, a less vampiric translucent variation, hit the Bloomingdale's counter. At last count, the gloss, which is limited to 500 pieces, had a wait list of 253 people. ''It's an irreverent look,'' said Aaron De Mey, the brand's new artistic director. ''But any woman can wear it.'' He suggests that those looking for just a hint of black should layer it over Lanc√¥me's new (and also limited-edition) Aaron's Red lipstick. The more daring can rub it on their eyelids for a smoky, wet look √† la Marlene Dietrich. As legend has it, the screen goddess used to burn a cork and mix the soot with Vaseline. Today she would probably be No. 254 on that wait list.

BOND--Barry Benton, October 25, 1925--November 23rd, 2007. Devoted husband of the late Lyndsay Fradeneck Bond. Cherished father of Alexis Greer Bond and Gregor Bond, loving grandfather of Jade and Kai Bond. Proud WWII veteran, avid sailor and fisherman. Performed in original national tours of ''On Your Toes'' and ''High Button Shoes'', and toured with Mae West. He then worked on Broadway in the box office for over 50 years. Lost a year ago, loved and missed forever.

These images of kids playing video games were created by Robbie Cooper, a British photographer who employed a Red camera -- a very-high-resolution video camera -- and then took stills from the footage. Cooper, who says he was inspired by the camera technique that Errol Morris used to interview people in his documentaries, arranged his equipment so that the players were actually looking at a reflection of the game on a small pane of glass. He placed the camera behind the reflection so that it could look directly into their faces as they played. Cooper and his collaborators, Andrew Wiggins and Charly Smith, videotaped children in England and in New York. Cooper, who grew up in Britain and Kenya and played a lot of video games as a child, says he tries to capture ''people interacting with worlds that aren't real.'' In his last major project, which was published in the magazine in 2007, he photographed participants in Internet-based games with their virtual-world avatars. Cooper is particularly struck by the intensity of people's experiences while interacting with digital realms. Drew Hugh, shown above, stares so intently at the screen that he doesn't blink, and his eyes quickly fill with tears, according to his mother. Cooper says, ''It's fascinating that a world that's purely visual can have a physical effect.''

THIS WEEK'S RECOMMENDATIONS THE GREAT GEB: If you care or have ever cared about how thinking happens, you must read or reread Douglas Hofstadter's 1979 masterwork, ''G√∂del, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid.'' The latest edition, published with a new Hofstadter foreword in 1999, is available from Amazon. As Hofstadter puts it, ''GEB is a very personal attempt to say how it is that animate beings can come out of inanimate matter.'' Related links are here: geb.stenius.org. Fans chatter here: groups.google.com/group/alt.fan.hofstadter.

COOPER--Mary, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on October 22. She was born in St. Joseph, Missouri. Her Broadway credits include ''Dough Girls'', with Arlene Francis, ''Farm of Three Echoes'', with Ethel Barrymore, Moss Hart's ''Winged Victory'', ''The Late George Apley'', ''The French Touch'', and ''Harvey'', with James Stewart. She appeared in London's West End in ''Fallen Angels'', with Joan Bennett. She was also a model for the famous Powers Agency. In television, she was a regular on ''Dark Shadows.'' She was married to British producer Victor Payne-Jennings from 1952 until his death in 1962.

Dorothy Tanksley, 68, has not slept in a bed since 2004 because of back problems. A maroon reclining chair in her living room, a gift from her daughter, serves as a bed. The lever provides the extra boost she needs to get up and into her wheelchair. ''I hurt most of the time, 24-7,'' Ms. Tanksley said recently at her home in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. ''I take all kinds of things,'' she said, rattling off a pharmacy list: over-the-counter pain medications and prescriptions that include insulin for her diabetes and medication for high blood pressure, glaucoma and high cholesterol.

After tempting the legal community with the possibility of a live appearance in a London court, Michael Jackson has instead announced that he settled a lawsuit filed against him by a Bahranian prince, Reuters reported. The prince, Sheik Abdulla bin Hamad Al Khalifa, was seeking repayment of $7 million he had given to Mr. Jackson since 2005, saying in his suit that the king of pop had reneged on a contract for an album and an autobiography. Mr. Jackson first sought to give his testimony in the case by video, then announced plans to testify in person. But hours before his scheduled appearance on Monday, he and the sheik issued a joint statement saying they had reached a settlement and ‚Äúwish each other well in their own, respective endeavors,‚Äù Reuters said. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed.

The Russian conductor Gennady Rozhdestvensky abruptly pulled out of a series of scheduled concerts with the Boston Symphony Orchestra after taking offense at how the concerts were promoted, The Boston Globe reported. During a rehearsal with the orchestra on Wednesday, Mr. Rozhdestvensky told The Globe, he discovered a poster on which the cellist Lynn Harrell, a soloist at the concerts, had been given top billing. He also later found an orchestra season brochure listing ‚ÄúArtists who inspire‚Äù and ‚ÄúDistinguished Conductors,‚Äù and was discouraged to find he was not listed in either section. An announcement on the symphony‚Äôs Web site said that Mr. Rozhdestvensky was ‚Äúunable to conduct these performances.‚Äù But he told The Globe, ‚ÄúI must say that I was able to conduct. And how.‚Äù

It‚Äôs no secret how the Chinese government feels about democracy. Now it has weighed in on ‚ÄúChinese Democracy,‚Äù too. The Associated Press reported that The Global Times, the official tabloid of China‚Äôs Communist Party, published a withering critique of the new Guns N‚Äô Roses album, ‚ÄúChinese Democracy.‚Äù Without referring to the group by name, The newspaper headlined its story ‚ÄúAmerican band releases album venomously attacking China‚Äù and described the record as part of a larger Western conspiracy to ‚Äúgrasp and control the world using democracy as a pawn.‚Äù After a delay of nearly 17 years, ‚ÄúChinese Democracy‚Äù was released in the United States on Sunday, but with lyrics like ‚ÄúWhen your Great Wall rocks, blame yourself,‚Äù it is unlikely to ever reach Chinese stores.

He may have sold more than $200 million in art at a two-day auction in London this year, but not even Damien Hirst is immune to the effects of the ailing economy. The Guardian reported that several of the workers who make the pills for Mr. Hirst‚Äôs drug-cabinet artworks were told their contracts would not be renewed. A spokesman for Mr. Hirst‚Äôs company, Science Ltd., would not confirm for The Guardian how many jobs were shed but said, ‚ÄúWe have to be mindful of the current economic climate and how this may affect us in the future.‚Äù In 2007, Mr. Hirst‚Äôs work ‚ÄúLullaby Spring,‚Äù a cabinet filled with pills painted by hand, sold for $14.4 million. But at an auction this month at Sotheby‚Äôs in New York, one minor Hirst work sold for well below its estimate while a second did not sell at all.

A Matisse painting stolen by the Nazis in 1941 will be returned to the heirs of its previous owner on Thursday, during a ceremony at the French Ministry of Culture, Le Figaro reported. The 1898 painting, ‚ÄúLe Mur Rose‚Äù (‚ÄúThe Pink Wall‚Äù), was bought in Paris in 1914 by Harry Fuld, a Jewish entrepreneur who brought it home to Frankfurt. It was discovered in 1948 among the personal belongings of a Nazi SS officer charged with crimes against humanity. The painting, kept at the Georges Pompidou Center since 2000, bore a stamp from French customs in 1914, which allowed experts to identify and recover it. The painting is being donated to the London branch of Magen David Adom, the Israeli emergency medical service, a beneficiary of the Fuld heirs.

The long-running tale of a missing British musician that has fascinated rock fans for more than a decade reached a sad turn as his parents received a court order declaring him presumed dead, the BBC reported. Richey Edwards, a lyricist and guitarist for the British band Manic Street Preachers, was last seen checking out of a London hotel in February 1995; two weeks later, his car was found near a bridge between Southern England and Southern Wales. For years, fans have speculated on the whereabouts of Mr. Edwards, a romantic figure who had been treated for anorexia and alcoholism, and once cut the phrase ‚Äú4 REAL‚Äù into his arm with a razor during a magazine interview. A spokeswoman for the band said the court order was ‚Äúthe parents‚Äô choice and the band is happy to go with what the parents decide is best,‚Äù according to the BBC.

President-elect Barack Obama is expected to name Peter Orszag as director of the Office of Management and Budget. A graduate of Princeton, Mr. Orszag is currently director of the Congressional Budget Office and has focused much of his attention on health policy. A protege of the former Treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin, Mr. Orszag worked as an economic adviser to the president during the Clinton administration. Later, he became a senior fellow at the Brookings Institute.

We debated the merits of collective wisdom earlier this year, after the bettors in the the Intrade online prediction market wrongly picked Barack Obama to win the New Hampshire primary. Once again, collective wisdom backed by cash has triumphed over conventional wisdom -- at least when you compare the Intrade bettors with some of the pundits who get paid to make predictions.

For most of the last 25 years, whether I've done Thanksgiving at home or gone elsewhere, I've made James Beard's bread stuffing, a combination of freshly made bread crumbs, unconscionable amounts of butter, a good shot of real herbs and pine nuts. His truly revolutionary suggestion was that the stuffing be cooked not in the bird but outside of it, producing a light, buttery, crunchy side dish. I've tinkered a bit with Beard's recipe, though I cannot bring myself to reduce the amount of butter, which is part of what makes the thing so good.

After we published this profile of Valerie Jarrett, one of president-elect Barack Obama's closest friends and advisers, we started hearing from readers all over the country who wanted to read more of Ms. Jarrett's "life lessons." We only mentioned two in the story, but here's the full list, which Ms. Jarrett cautions is not organized in any particular order. As one of the co-chairs of Mr. Obama's transition team, Ms. Jarrett is currently interviewing potential administration hires-so study up, job applicants:1. To thine own self be true.2. All leaders are passionate about their beliefs, even the ones you don't like.3. Trust your gut after you have listened, studied and learned from those with a diverse range of opinions.4. You never know who is watching, so work as hard as you can regardless of the assignment.5. Don't stay in your comfort zone too long.6. As my grandmother would say: put yourself in the path of lightning.7. Be flexible because opportunities rarely knock at the most opportune moments.8. Take time to be kind to everyone.9. Focus on your priorities.10. In order to lead, someone must follow.11. Effective leadership depends on your ability to connect and motivate people, not on your title, position or power.12. Set high standards for yourself and your team (lead by example).13. Take the time to develop personal relationships all along the way, and really cultivate those upon whom you depend. In order for them to help you, they must know you. And you must know what will motivate them. Nurture them so they can help you lead. They must believe in not just your ideas, but you.14. Good will matters.15. Women are particularly good at listening and studying their audience.16. Have the courage to make tough decisions.17. When you lead, not everyone will follow, and that's okay.18. You will fail. Don't take your failures or your success too seriously. Learn to laugh at yourself. Trust me. It helps.19. Affiliate yourself with worthy institutions, lead by good people who share your core values.20. You can have it all, just not at the same time, and in the proportions you may want.21. To those who much is given, much is expected.

A guest post earlier this month by Daniel Callahan, the co-founder of the Hastings Center, a caldron of research on bioethical issues, dissected the hot-button issue of rationing health care based on age as a way of preventing a total collapse of the Medicare system. Rationing could, arguably, improve the quality of life for America's aged by leading us to think twice about invasive tests, cutting-edge surgery and other treatments that may extend life briefly but at a high cost, not only in health care dollars but also potential suffering for limited gain.

MAREK--Julius, 83, of Woodmere, New York was born on October 14, 1925 in Hamburg, Germany from which he fled at age 11 with his family settling in Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, New York. He passed away on November 19, 2008. A veteran of the U.S. Navy in WWII, he is survived by his beloved wife of 54 years, Ilse Marek (nee Warisch), as well as his daughter Tessie Weiss and her husband Michael, and his son Herb Marek and his wife Iris. He is also survived by his seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was the principal of Herbert Marmorek & Sons along with his late brother and partner Kurt M.A. Marmorek. The firm was a proud member of the American Spice Trade Association for 60 years.

Not surprisingly, there was a lot of talk on Tuesday about who should replace Jerry Yang as Yahoo's chief executive. Let me suggest that people are phrasing the question slightly wrong: Yahoo doesn't need a chief executive so much as an editor in chief. And I mean the sort of imperial editor who has a vision of how to create an environment that lures in both readers and advertisers, like Tina Brown, above, Clay Felker or Adam Moss.

CASTRONOVO--Joseph B., 91, passed away in Houston, Texas on November 22, 2008. He was born in New York City, the son of Antoinette and Biagio Castronovo. He resided in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and Southampton, New York, until moving to Palm Beach, Florida in 1987. He received a B.B.A. from St. John's University and an M.B.A. from New York University. A Certified Public Accountant, he was a financial adviser to the New York firm of Zirinsky Real Estate for most of his career. At the same time, he was also Professor and Director of the Evening School at St. Francis College. He was married to Francis Haley, who predeceased him. He is survived by his daughter Geraldine (Dera) Cooke of Nassau Bay, Texas, and her husband Michael Cooke, and their children Joshua and Jill, and grandchildren Christian and Sierra; by his daughter Joy Fowles of Dickinson, Texas, and her husband Robert (Jib) Fowles and their children Celeste and Nathaniel; and by his son Brian Castronovo of Simi Valley, California. He is also survived by his second wife, Jean Cahill of Wellington, Florida. He was an indomitable spirit and will be missed by all who knew and loved him. A graveside service will be held at Mt. Olivet Cemetery in Dickinson, Texas.

Advertising spending is down for American automakers, especially at Ford and Cerberus Capital, which owns Chrysler, Dodge and Jeep. Industrywide advertising dropped 6 percent through September 2008, compared with the first nine months of 2007. Spending on advertising can be hard to control. General Motors, for example, began the year promoting the Chevrolet Malibu and the Cadillac CTS, which sold well. As industry sales plummeted, carmakers could not trim advertising too much -- they had to announce the deep discounts being offered to consumers. SHELLY FREIERMAN

THE FIREMAN ''Electric Arguments'' (MPL/ATO) How does Paul McCartney, 66, follow up ''Memory Almost Full,'' his grand autumnal (but still chipper) statement on life and mortality? By hiding his name and conjuring one kind of heaven: the 1960s as reconstituted with 21st-century multitracking. For ''Electric Arguments'' he regrouped his not-so-anonymous duo the Fireman (Mr. McCartney produced by the bassist Youth), walked into the studio on 13 nonconsecutive days with no material, and finished a track at each session, playing all the instruments. (There's also a fragment hidden at the end of the last song.) Some songs have verses and choruses, while others are just fleshed-out sketches, seeking and often finding what ''Sing the Changes'' calls for: ''a sense of childlike wonder.''

SCHACK--Ann, 80, died November 13, from metastatic lung cancer. She was a pioneer in the computer programming field. Loved by many, she was a gourmet chef and wonderful hostess. Ms. Schack is survived by her son James, her daughter, Susan, two grandchildren and her companion Dan McCrary.

After Oklahoma's 65-21 rout of Texas Tech on Saturday night, a rarely jubilant Bob Stoops, the Sooners' coach, took a victory lap around the field and bowed with his arms raised to each corner of the stadium. Leading up to the game, Stoops upset some Oklahoma fans by not crediting crowd noise for his 60-2 home record and the Sooners' 24-game home winning streak, the nation's longest. He said crowds at the home games did not have as much of an impact on games as at Florida, where he was the defensive coordinator from 1996 to 1998.

A prisoner pleaded for mercy from Congolese Army soldiers on Sunday near Goma. Troops had removed 26 men from a United Nations transport convoy, saying that they were rebels and Mai Mai fighters and that the United Nations peacekeeping force was collaborating with the two groups. Government troops have been battling the rebels, led by Laurent Nkunda, and the Mai Mai militia in the eastern part of the country.
