How do you talk to a search engine? The same way you type to one. Google's new speech-recognition service for the iPhone, which I wrote about last week and which was released on Monday, understands you most accurately when you speak to it just the way you enter queries into the Google search box. So don't bother with polite formalisms like, ''What is the best pizza restaurant in San Francisco?'' Simply say, ''best pizza restaurant San Francisco.''

TRACE ADKINS X (Capitol Nashville) Country music constantly strives to reconcile its rowdy good-ol'-boy side and its virtuous family-man side, and one well-traveled route to country success is to make the homey life still sound manly. Trace Adkins's buzzing baritone and Deep South phrasing -- he grew up in Louisiana before moving to Nashville -- make him a stalwart voice of virtue on ''X,'' his 10th album (including two collections). After hits like the leering ''Honky Tonk Badonkadonk'' and the wistful ''You're Gonna Miss This,'' and a stint on ''The Celebrity Apprentice'' (he was runner-up), Mr. Adkins has released his most confident, muscular sounding album. Produced by Frank Rogers, who's also Brad Paisley's producer, ''X'' touches the country bases along with Southern rock and even a piano-and-strings ballad, ''I Can't Outrun You,'' that suggests Bruce Hornsby.

RESCUING CITIGROUP Federal regulators were considering a new rescue for Citigroup, a step that could give the government responsibility for major losses in exchange for a stake in the bank. The question, as a new week begins, is whether the government's proposal to help Citigroup will produce lasting effects not only for the bank's stock but also for the broader stock market. [B1.]

SILVERBERG--George, passed away peacefully at Ozanam Hall Nursing Home on November 22, 2008 at the age of 94. George survived his loving wives Gertrude and Bette. He leaves his adoring daughters Marilyn Gallo, Roberta Leibowitz, Leslie Blackman and step-daughter Adrienne Scheft; nine grandchildren; and fourteen greatgrandchildren.

TOM JONES 24 Hours (S-Curve) Tom Jones's patented idea of macho camp was complex enough in the 1960s. But on ''24 Hours'' -- his first album of new material in 15 years, though far from his first comeback -- his performance goes further into the sincere-insincere hall of mirrors, a game of flamboyant posing that feeds on the love and outrage of the British media. This time it's wrapped in imitation--antique R&B kitsch, with spun-sugar violins, horns, wah-wah guitars, chattering high-hat cymbals. His production team, Future Cut, has trained its focus on two targets, 40 years apart: Amy Winehouse fans and anyone fond of Mr. Jones's 1960s big-beat pop origins.

DAVID COOK (19/RCA) David Cook, the smug-grinned rocker who won the most recent season of ''American Idol,'' has exactly two settings to his voice: Regular Howl and Anguished Howl. The beauty of his ''Idol'' run was in the way he deployed them. When reworking modern pop classics -- Michael Jackson's ''Billie Jean,'' Lionel Richie's ''Hello'' -- he'd begin with Regular, shift to Anguished for an unexpected line or three midsong, then retreat. In this way Mr. Cook managed to appear meaningful, restrained and at times even clever.

8 P.M. (Logo) 365GAY NEWS SPECIAL: HARVEY MILK On Nov. 27, 1978, Milk, a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors and the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in California, and Mayor George Moscone were assassinated by Dan White, a former city supervisor who had recently resigned but wanted his job back. In this report Ross Palombo, a CBS News correspondent, ventures inside San Francisco City Hall, the scene of the crime and a setting for ''Milk,'' the new film starring Sean Penn, above right with Josh Brolin. Another segment visits Harvey Milk Civil Rights Academy, the elementary school in the Castro district of San Francisco. Among those interviewed are Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco and ''Milk'' cast members -- Mr. Brolin, James Franco, Alison Pill and Diego Luna. 10 A.M. (55); 3 P.M. (NBC) THE ELLEN DeGENERES SHOW Bette Midler and Pink perform at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas.

There is an honorable tradition in opera of singers relying on a prompter to provide cues for pitches or words. But during rehearsals for the Metropolitan Opera‚Äôs production of Wagner‚Äôs ‚ÄúTristan und Isolde,‚Äù which opens on Friday night, the German tenor singing Tristan, Peter Seiffert, has been using a personal electronic prompter: an earpiece through which he can hear the cues directly. Mr. Seiffert has sung several major Wagner roles to acclaim, including Tannh√§user for his Met debut in 2004. But Tristan is a newer role for him. When he sang it in Berlin two years ago, he also used an earpiece. The only previous time a performer at the Met has used such a device came last season in a speaking role for the new production of Donizetti‚Äôs ‚ÄúFille du R√©giment.‚Äù A Met official said yesterday that Mr. Seiffert was still deciding whether to use the earpiece on Friday, when the conductor will be Daniel Barenboim, making his Met debut.

Richard Raddon, the director of the Los Angeles Film Festival, has resigned from the position following the revelation that he donated money to support a ballot measure that outlawed same-sex marriage in California. On Nov. 13, David Poland, a blogger for the Web site Movie City News, reported that Mr. Raddon‚Äôs name had appeared on a list of donors supporting Proposition 8, which amended California‚Äôs state Constitution to recognize only male-female marriages. On Monday, the board of Film Independent, which produces the festival, announced that it had accepted Mr. Raddon‚Äôs resignation.

The Public Theater‚Äôs much-anticipated production of ‚ÄúA Free Man of Color,‚Äù a new play by John Guare, won‚Äôt be mounted this season after all. Citing the tightening economy and a loss of funding, the theater said it was postponing the play, which was scheduled to open in the winter. A hybrid of history and sex farce, it would have starred Mos Def and Jeffrey Wright mixing it up in 1802 New Orleans with Napoleon and Thomas Jefferson. In a statement, Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public, said, ‚ÄúThis is a tough and disappointing decision, but one we made with great thought and care, and one that will ensure The Public‚Äôs health and stability.‚Äù The theater said it still planned to mount the show next season.

Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman of the Shubert Organization, the largest and most powerful chain of Broadway theaters, has died, said Sam Rudy, a press representative for the organization. He was 84. Mr. Schoenfeld had shared in running the organization, which owns and operates 16 Broadway theaters, and owns or operates theaters in Philadelphia, Washington, Los Angeles and Boston, with Bernard B. Jacobs since 1972; he assumed full leadership duties following Jacobs‚Äôs death in 1996.

Terry N. Christensen, the influential Hollywood lawyer who represented many of its most powerful studios and executives, was sentenced on Monday to three years in prison on charges of conspiracy to commit wiretapping and aiding and abetting a wiretap, The Associated Press reported. In 2002, Mr. Christensen was representing the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian in a legal battle against Mr. Kerkorian‚Äôs ex-wife, Lisa Bonder Kerkorian. At that time, a jury found, Mr. Christensen hired the private investigator Anthony Pellicano to illegally wiretap Ms. Bonder Kerkorian‚Äôs telephone. Mr. Christensen remains free, pending an appeal. In May, Mr. Pellicano was found guilty of 76 charges related to racketeering and unlawful wiretaps.

The Atlantic Theater Company‚Äôs revival of the Martin McDonagh play ‚ÄúThe Cripple of Inishmaan,‚Äù which opened in Dublin and toured Britain this fall, will come to New York with its full Irish cast intact, the producers announced. The production, directed by Garry Hynes (whose Druid Theater Company is co-producing), will feature Aaron Monaghan as the title character and Kerry Condon (of the recent Atlantic Theater Company production of Mr. McDonagh‚Äôs ‚ÄúLieutenant of Inishmore‚Äù) as the desirable Slippy Helen. The cast also includes Marie Mullen (a Tony Award winner for ‚ÄúThe Beauty Queen of Leenane‚Äù), Dearbhla Molloy, Andrew Connolly (also of ‚ÄúInishmore‚Äù) and Patricia O‚ÄôConnell. ‚ÄúThe Cripple of Inishmaan‚Äù will begin previews Dec. 9 at the Linda Gross Theater, and run Dec. 21 to Feb. 1.

Music fans hoping to download their favorite Beatles songs from online services like iTunes will have to get by with a little help from their CD collection for the time being. On Monday, Paul McCartney said that negotiations to bring the Beatles catalog to Apple‚Äôs iTunes store had come to a halt, The Associated Press reported. ‚ÄúThe last word I got back was it‚Äôs stalled at the whole moment, the whole process,‚Äù Mr. McCartney said, according to The A.P. ‚ÄúI really hope it will happen because I think it should.‚Äù Though the Beatles‚Äô recordings are owned by EMI, the band‚Äôs company, Apple Corps, would have to give permission for their songs to be released digitally. In October, Apple Corps. announced an agreement with Harmonix and MTV Games to produce a video game based on the music of the Beatles.

In honor of Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman of the Shubert Organization who died Tuesday morning, all Broadway theaters will dim their lights Tuesday evening, for one minute starting at 7 p.m., a publicist for the organization said.

Amy Winehouse has sought treatment at a London clinic after suffering an adverse reaction to a medication, The Associated Press reported. Chris Goodman, a spokesman for Ms. Winehouse, told The A.P. that the 25-year-old soul singer had been admitted to the clinic on Sunday, but declined to identify the medication that caused the reaction. Ms. Winehouse, who has a history of drug problems, has been hospitalized several times this year: in June, she was admitted to a London clinic after collapsing at her home, and in July she was hospitalized, also for a reaction to medication. Her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, was recently released from prison and is now in a drug-rehabilitation program.

In an eerie reversal of fortune, it is now better to be Axl Rose than to be any of his former Guns N‚Äô Roses bandmates. On Tuesday, the band Velvet Revolver, whose membership includes the Guns N‚Äô Roses refugees Slash, Duff McKagan and Matt Sorum, announced that it had parted ways with RCA Records, which has released its two studio albums. The band had asked in June to be released from its contract. In April, Velvet Revolver announced that it had dismissed its lead singer, Scott Weiland, of the Stone Temple Pilots. The evening ride in the big bus (122 pesos, about $9.40 at 13 pesos to the dollar)had been scheduled at five hours, but as we ascended farther into the hills of Chiapas and the sky dimmed over rough valleys and recently cleared pastures, I lost track of time. Into all lives, they say, a little rain must fall. Yet for the most part, in the last few years of roaming the world as the Frugal Traveler, from Buenos Aires to Bulgaria, I've rarely fallen prey to the elements. The storm clouds, however, finally caught up to me in-of all places-the rain forest.

Victor Harbison teaches civics and history at Gage Park High School in Chicago, where he also sponsors the school newspaper. In 2000, he became the first National Board-certified high school history teacher in Chicago and he has worked on several educational reform projects during his career. Gage Park faces the all-too-common challenges of an urban school: test scores are so low that only 8% of students meet state standards; only 47% of its students graduate; and 97.4% of them live in poverty. Victor will help this blog keep education on its radar after the departure of long-time teacher and contributor Will Okun.

I believe in the theory that some people are cooks, while others are bakers. Some are truly, equally both, but that's rare. Cooks are messier and improvise more, tasting and adjusting, winging it in spirit if not actually in practice. Bakers are more meticulous and methodical, measuring and weighing, careful not to overwork their dough.

This caught my eye: Kyoshi Ito, a mathematician, has died. Ito studied random motion, and his work has played a key role in finance theory -- and even in some of my own work. I'm not much of a mathematician, tending to pick up no more technique than I need -- Avinash Dixit liked to make fun of the way I'd write down the basic Wiener process, then say "whatever that means" -- but this was really useful stuff.

This is a recreation of a dish I tasted in London in 1970 and then dreamed about for years, an all-orange soup of sweet potatoes, dried apricots and curry powder. The combination is magical: the curry powder adds spice (and heat) to the potatoes, making the soup far more complex, and the apricots contribute another dimension, not so much sweetness but fruitiness. It can be successfully made with any stock -- or even water -- though I like it best with good chicken stock.

Economy | All well and good that Obama has his economic team in place, Fareed Zakaria writes, but who's going to manage the most important issue -- China, a.k.a. "America's banker"? Can China finance a huge American stimulus and still keep its own people happy? "In effect, we're asking China to finance simultaneously the two largest fiscal expansions in human history -- theirs and ours." (P.S.: China has $2 trillion in foreign cash reserves vs. America's "relatively puny" $73 billion.) [Washington Post]
Edward L. Glaeser is an economist at Harvard.

Ivory Tower | The boom in online research is actually narrowing the range of scholarship, a new study suggests. Because the Internet's search tools favor the new and the popular, its effect is to "tighten consensus," meaning good ideas may go unnoticed. All you unheralded geniuses out there -- now you know why. [Boston Globe]

Business | The $70-an-hour Detroit auto worker is a myth, an article says; rather, average wages are less than half that, but people throw in benefits, including retiree costs, and that's misleading. Psychology | Cleanliness is not next to godliness, research suggests: "washing with soap and water makes people view unethical activities as more acceptable." (This may be why Pontius Pilate "washed his hands of it.") In one test, people primed with words associated with cleanliness were more disposed to eating the family dog. Out, out, damned Spot? [Economist]

Television | The reviews have been less than glowing for Fred Armisen, the "Saturday Night Live" veteran portraying Barack Obama: "Because the rest of the political impressions on the show have been so spot on this season-Tina Fey's Palin, Jason Sudeikis' crazy-eyed Joe Biden-an imperfect Obama stands out." So an article calls for a transition. [Daily Beast]

He might have sold more than $200 million in art at a two-day auction in London this year, but not even Damien Hirst, below, is immune to the effects of the ailing economy. The Guardian reported that several workers who make the pills for Mr. Hirst’s drug-cabinet artworks were told their contracts would not be renewed. A spokesman for Mr. Hirst’s company, Science Ltd., would not confirm for The Guardian how many jobs were shed but said, “We have to be mindful of the current economic climate and how this may affect us in the future.” In 2007 Mr. Hirst’s work “Lullaby Spring,” a cabinet filled with pills painted by hand sold for $14.4 million. But at an auction this month at Sotheby’s in New York, a minor Hirst work sold for well below its estimate while a second did not sell at all.

The long-running tale of a missing British musician that has fascinated rock fans for more than a decade reached a sad turn as his parents received a court order declaring him presumed dead, the BBC reported. Richey Edwards, a lyricist and guitarist for the British band Manic Street Preachers, was last seen checking out of a London hotel in February 1995; two weeks later his car was found near a bridge between Southern England and Southern Wales. For years fans have speculated on the whereabouts of Mr. Edwards, a romantic figure who had been treated for anorexia and alcoholism, and once cut the phrase “4 REAL” into his arm with a razor during a magazine interview. A spokeswoman for the band said the court order was “the parents’ choice and the band is happy to go with what the parents decide is best,” according to the BBC.

A Matisse painting, above, stolen by the Nazis in 1941 will be returned to the heirs of its rightful owner on Thursday, in a ceremony to be held at the French Culture Ministry, the newspaper Le Figaro reported. The 1898 painting, called “Le Mur Rose” (“The Pink Wall”), was bought in Paris in 1914 by Harry Fuld, a Jewish entrepreneur who brought it home to Frankfurt. It was discovered in 1948 among the belongings of an SS officer charged with crimes against humanity. The painting, kept at the Georges Pompidou Center since 2000, bore a stamp from French customs in 1914, which allowed experts to identify and recover it. The painting is being donated to the London branch of Magen David Adom, the Israeli emergency medical service, a beneficiary of the Fuld heirs.

After tempting the legal world with the possibility of a live appearance in a London court, Michael Jackson, above left, has instead announced that he settled a lawsuit filed against him by a Bahranian prince, Reuters reported. The prince, Sheik Abdulla bin Hamad Al Khalifa, above right, was seeking repayment of $7 million given to Mr. Jackson since 2005, saying in his suit that Mr. Jackson had reneged on a contract for an album and an autobiography. Mr. Jackson first sought to give his testimony in the case by video, then announced plans to testify in person. But hours before his scheduled appearance on Monday, he and the prince issued a joint statement saying they had reached a settlement and “wish each other well in their own, respective endeavors,” Reuters said. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed.

Greenland will vote Tuesday on whether it wants greater independence from Denmark, which colonized it nearly 300 years ago. Greenland has been steadily gaining autonomy for decades but still depends on Denmark for much of its budget and is bound by Danish decisions in a variety of policy areas. If the referendum passes, it will pave the way for eventual independence and give Greenland, an 850,000-square-mile island, control of the revenues from potential oil, gas and mineral finds.

From the hardened slums of this city to some of Venezuela's most populous and economically important states, many of President Hugo Ch√°vez's supporters deserted him in regional elections, showing it is possible to challenge him in areas where he was once thought invincible. The outcome of Sunday's vote was the second blow dealt to the president in a year, after voters rejected last December his plan to alter the Constitution to give himself more power. Although it was unclear whether the results would slow his Socialist-inspired revolution or check his power, they could complicate his ambitions to amend the Constitution to allow him to run again.

BERMAN--Margot S. , died November 23, 2008 at age 79. She was the beloved and loving mother of Melissa Berman (Richard Klotz) and Carrie Berman (Michael Foltman); wife of the late Irwin Berman; grandmother of Daniel and Rachel Klotz; sister of Harry Strauss (Ruth Strauss); aunt of Stephanie Strauss (Bill Regenold) and Andrea Strauss (Alegria Cupit); great-aunt of Simon, Nina and David Regenold and of Ari and Ian Cupit-Strauss. She was committed and devoted to her family, and that devotion lives in their hearts. Margot Berman was born in Germany, coming to New York City at age eight. Despite a lifelong battle with Gauchers Disease, she lived a life of courage, ideas and grace. She was the founding head librarian of the synagogue and school library at Temple Beth Am of Miami. Through her story hours and book programs, she inspired countless children to become lifelong readers. She served as president of the Association of Jewish Libraries, and was a mentor to synagogue librarians across the country. The funeral service will be held on November 30th at 10:30am at Lakeview Cemetery in Ithaca, NY. Donations may be made to the Association of Jewish Libraries in her memory (jewishlibraries.org) which is establishing an award in her honor.

COHEN--Norman D . The leadership and staff of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourn the passing of our dear friend, Norman D. Cohen. He was a passionate advocate for the Weizmann Institute. A member of the President's Circle and recipient of an Honorary Doctorate from the Weizmann Institute of Science, Norman also served as Chairman and President of the American Committee, and was Deputy Chairman of the Institute's Board of Governors. Over his nearly 40 years of involvement with the Weizmann Institute, Norman became a pillar of the Weizmann community. He was exceptionally generous with his time, wisdom, and energy, building not only an engaged community of supporters in the U.S., but also facilitating cutting-edge scientific research at the Institute itself. Among his many gifts to the Institute was the Norman D. Cohen Chair in Computer Science; in 2001, the Institute's Jubilee Walk, a tribute to 50 years of excellence, was dedicated in his honor. Norman's legacy at Weizmann will forever be felt, and his spirit lives on through his children, grandchildren, and the many lives he touched. We send heartfelt condolences to Norman's wife, Judith, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Exec. V.P. & CEO American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute COHEN--Norman D. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York mourns the passing of our member Norman D. Cohen and extends to his family deepest sympathies. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President COHEN--Norman, co-founder of Lechmere Sales, died on November 24 in New York City. Raised in Dorchester, MA, Mr. Cohen and his two brothers, Maurice and Philip, turned their fathers tire shop in Lechmere Square, Cambridge, into an appliance powerhouse, dominating the retail appliance and TV business in Greater Boston in the 1950s, 60s and 70s. Lechmere was one of the first discount stores, known for its merchandise, dominance, knowledgeable sales staff, and its promotions. At a time when weekly sales were unheard of, Lechmere became famous for the 22-cent cherry pies it offered on Washington's birthday; its ''picnic sale'' on the first weekend of Spring, when all its merchandise was moved into the parking lot; and its once-ayear Saturday night ''private sale.'' These events attracted thousands of people to Lechmere stores in Cambridge and Dedham. The Cohen brothers sold Lechmere to Dayton-Hudson Corporation (the predecessor of Target Corporation), but Mr. Cohen continued to work at Lechmere until he retired and moved to New York City. He then devoted himself to the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel, serving as President and Chairman of the American Committee and as International Deputy Chairman of Weizmann's Board of Governors. In 1992, the Weizmann Institute awarded him an Honorary Doctorate. Mr. Cohen also served on the board of trustees at the Boston Ballet, the Cardinal Cushing School for Exceptional Children, and Camp Young Judea. He served as a Director of Leonard Silver; Claire Stores, Inc.; and Circuit City, Inc. Mr. Cohen, is survived by his three sons with his first wife, Shirlee (nee Blum): Douglas M. Cohen of Lexington, married to Janine Cohen; Stuart Cohen of Marblehead, married to Anne Lucas and I. Scott Cohen of Framingham, married to Ronna Cohen. He is also survived by his second wife, Judith. (nee Younglieb) and her children, Leslie and Andrew Siben and David Schalit. Mr. Cohen is mourned by his ten grandchildren as well: Jonathan Cohen (with wife Liza Perkins-Cohen); Jeffrey Cohen; James Cohen; Bethany Cohen; Elizabeth Cohen; Caroline Cohen; Stefani Misiph (with husband Joshua); Matthew Cohen; Odile Schalit; and Michael Siben. He has one great-grandson, Aaron Cohen. Norman Cohen was universally loved and respected and will be greatly missed. The funeral will be held at 1pm on Wednesday, November 26, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home: 1076 Madison Avenue, New York. Donations in Norman's honor can be made to the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, 633 Third Avenue, Floor 20, NY, NY 10017. COHEN--Norman. We lost a very dear and good friend. We will miss him. Patti and Herb Frumkes COHEN--Norman D. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Norman D. Cohen. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Judith, and their family. Allan Greenblatt, President Richard Hunegs, Secretary COHEN--Norman. Dear Norman, we love you and we will miss you. You were a special person. Our very deepest sympathy to his wife Judith and to his family. Joan, Bob, Dani and David

SWEETSER--Nancy Ripa on November 22, 2008 at her home in New York City. Inspirational, vivacious, and indefatigable, Nan was a beloved daughter, mother, sister, and grandmother-''Noodle'' to Molly and Maggie, the adored and adoring granddaughters who gave her so much joy. Nan brought energy and creativity to all of her endeavors--from her pioneering philanthropic work as founder and board member of Miracle House, a non-profit institution that provides housing and support services to patients, families, and friends of patients, undergoing critical medical treatment--to her work as a real estate broker at Sotheby's International Realty. Nan is survived by her 98-year-old father Sebastian Ripa, sister Marie Maguire, daughter Caroline Parker, son-in-law Kirk Parker, son Mark Sweetser. She also leaves behind many devoted friends who along with the family will never forget her natural radiance, her generosity, and her unconditional love. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 5, at 3:30pm at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY. Donations in her memory can be made to Miracle House, miraclehouse.org.

After two election cycles in which the Democrats have gained at least 13 seats in the Senate, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York is stepping down as chairman of the party's campaign committee. Mr. Schumer, the senior senator from New York, is expected to turn the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee over to Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, keeping control of the campaign operation close to Wall Street, party officials said.
The Capitol Christmas tree was erected on Monday. It came to Washington from the Bitterroot National Forest in Montana.

Christian Hoff has withdrawn from the coming Broadway revival of Rodgers and Hart's ''Pal Joey'' and has been replaced by his understudy, Matthew Risch, the show's producers announced Monday. Mr. Hoff, who starred in ''Jersey Boys,'' injured his foot during a Friday night preview performance, the producers said; Mr. Risch took over the role for the remaining weekend performances. The character of Joey Evans, previously played onstage by Gene Kelly and on film by Frank Sinatra, had been expected to be a breakthrough role for Mr. Hoff.

The Japanese police say the motive in the stabbing deaths last week of a former Health Ministry official and his wife was not a government pension scandal, as had been widely suspected, but seemed to have been anger over a long-dead dog. On Monday, the police arrested a 46-year-old unemployed man, Takeshi Koizumi, left, after he turned himself in for the killings, carrying a blood-stained knife. The police had been investigating whether the killings were motivated by recent scandals involving tens of millions of lost pension records, which are administered by the ministry. But Mr. Koizumi said he was angry with the ministry because decades ago animal control agents had killed a stray dog that he had befriended as a child.

GREIF--Annette , 75, died of ovarian cancer Saturday, November 22, at her home on East 86th Street. Annette had an indomitable spirit. She lived for her family and the good company of her many friends, who appreciated her sharp wit, elegant style and deep engagement in life. Selfeducated, she was the ultimate New Yorker, taking every advantage of all that the city offered: film, food and culture. Born to Harry and Pauline Sanders Moskowitz, she grew up in Brighton Beach, and loved the ocean her whole life, spending summers with her family in Sag Harbor. She was a dedicated volunteer of the Mount Sinai Medical Center Ambassador Program. She is survived by her husband of 58 years, Norman Greif, her three daughters, Paula Greif, Elaine Wine and Andrea Greif, her two grandchildren, Anna Esther Zanes and Alexander Marti Fitz-Gibbon, and her nephews, Paul and Martin Moskowitz. She was predeceased by her two brothers, Jack and Julian Moskowitz, both of whom served with honor in the United States military. Donations are being made to Mount Sinai's Woman to Woman Gynecologic Cancer Support, One Gustave Levy Place, Box 1252, New York, NY 10029.

''Since summer, daylight has bathed the galleria of the new World Trade Center, pouring through the five-and-a-half-foot intervals between its rounded steel arches and creating a modernist version of the ancient, roofless hypostyle halls of Egypt,'' David W. Dunlap wrote. The arches will eventually be covered by a steel roof.

In the heat of battle, their minds clouded by fear, anger or vengefulness, even the best-trained soldiers can act in ways that violate the Geneva Conventions or battlefield rules of engagement. Now some researchers suggest that robots could do better. ''My research hypothesis is that intelligent robots can behave more ethically in the battlefield than humans currently can,'' said Ronald C. Arkin, a computer scientist at Georgia Tech, who is designing software for battlefield robots under contract with the Army. ''That's the case I make.''

UNDERWOOD--Dr. David G. II , 77, of Bow, NH, died November, 21. He was elected President of the Concord Hospital Medical Staff and later served on the hospital's Board of Trustees. In recognition of his lifetime contribution to Concord Hospital, the Underwood Trauma Center opened in 2007. Dr. Underwood, born in 1931, grew up in Leominster, MA. He graduated with honors from Amherst College as the John Woodruff Simpson Scholar. At Cornell Medical School, he was awarded the Alfred Mortitz Prize having been first in his class. Internship and residency were served at the New York Hospital, where he was chief resident. He was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship in 1960. He joined a private medical practice in Concord, NH, became Board-Certified in Internal Medicine and was elected a fellow in the American College of Physicians. In 1975 he was instrumental in developing the first full-time Emergency Department at Concord Hospital where he served as Chief of Emergency Medicine. Board-Certification in Emergency Medicine and election to Fellowship in the American College of Emergency Physicians followed. After retiring from clinical medicine he was employed by Chubb LifeAmerica, as vice-president, senior medical director and head of underwriting. He is survived by his wife, Ruth Murray Underwood, Bow, NH; six children, Geoffrey Underwood, Holliston, MA; Derek Underwood, Sugar Hill, NH; Chip Underwood, Brighton, MA; Karen Murray, East Hartford, CT; Linda Kolb, Plano, TX; Jean Stewart, Moon Township, PA; two sisters, Dr. Anita Greene, Amherst, MA; Dr. Mirrless Underwood, Brewster, MA; and nine grandchildren.

As Iraq's government pressed for Parliament's approval of a security pact with the United States, three bombs -- one a suicide device carried by a woman -- ripped into targets in Baghdad during the morning rush hour on Monday, killing at least 18 people in what seemed to be a calculated show of insurgent defiance, according to the Interior Ministry. The suicide bomber struck in the heavily guarded periphery of the Green Zone, which houses the most senior American and Iraqi officials and institutions, including the American Embassy and the Iraqi Parliament. Six people died along with the bomber, who detonated between two of the main entrance gates, the ministry said. Twelve people were wounded.

An analysis of President-elect Barack Obama's campaign fund-raising punctures one of the most enduring pieces of conventional wisdom from his presidential run: that small donors powered his record-breaking money machine. The study, released Monday by the Campaign Finance Institute, a nonpartisan group, goes deeper than previous analyses of Mr. Obama's fund-raising in examining donors who made discrete contributions of $200 or less, and found that many of them donated repeatedly to exceed that amount.

NBC‚Äôs midseason schedule is heavy on the few shows that have worked for the network this season ‚Äî that is, reality shows and ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äù ‚Äî and light on other scripted programming, The Hollywood Reporter said. On Jan. 4, NBC will introduce ‚ÄúSuperstars of Dance,‚Äù a competition created by the producers of ‚ÄúAmerican Idol,‚Äù and on Jan. 9 it will debut ‚ÄúHowie Do It,‚Äù a hidden-camera show hosted by Howie Mandel of ‚ÄúDeal or No Deal.‚Äù Two more primetime ‚ÄúSNL‚Äù specials will also be shown that month, and ‚ÄúFriday Night Lights‚Äù will begin Jan. 16. The declining economy continues to take its toll on regional performing arts companies. In Canada on Monday, Ballet BC laid off 38 staff members, including several dancers and its artistic director. The next day, the Vancouver City Council voted to give a one-time grant of $85,000 to the company, The Globe and Mail reported. That money will be used to help the struggling company pay for rental fees on the Queen Elizabeth Theater, where it has already scheduled the visiting Moscow Classical Ballet to perform ‚ÄúThe Nutcracker‚Äù in December. Elsewhere, the board of the Chattanooga Symphony and Opera in Tennessee voted on Tuesday to suspend its opera productions for the 2009-10 season, The Chattanooga Times Free Press reported. Production costs for the company‚Äôs operas run about $225,000 a show, and it has lost more that $1.1 million on 11 operas in the last six years.

Good news for fans of alternative country music who have already lost their girlfriends, dogs and pickup trucks: the magazine No Depression, which chronicled the alternative-country scene and gave early boosts to the careers of artists like Wilco and Ryan Adams, has resumed publication, The Associated Press reported. Taking its name from the Carter Family song ‚ÄúNo Depression in Heaven‚Äù (and the album ‚ÄúNo Depression‚Äù by the band Uncle Tupelo), the magazine was founded in 1995 and published bimonthly until its May-June 2008 issue. Citing the declining prospects of the magazine and music industries, it moved to a Web-only format. Now, its editors say, No Depression will come out as a twice-yearly ‚Äúbookazine‚Äù with no advertising. ‚ÄúWe had a pretty large outpouring of sentiment and support,‚Äù said Peter Blackstock, a co-editor of No Depression, according to The A.P. He added: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still a community there ‚Äî we weren‚Äôt losing readership.‚Äù

Gerard Mortier, fresh from a sudden split with the New York City Opera that left the company in turmoil, will become artistic director of the Teatro Real opera house in Madrid, the Spanish company said on Wednesday. The Teatro Real said last week that Mr. Mortier was in the running just two weeks after he and City Opera had parted ways. Mr. Mortier was designated to assume the position of general director in New York next season and had been helping run the company part-time from Paris but withdrew when the City Opera‚Äôs board said it could not provide the budget he had expected because of the economic downturn. The Belgian-born Mr. Mortier, who is in his final year running the Paris National Opera, will assume the Madrid post in January 2010.

My Thursday column is about one of my heroes, Mukhtar Mai, and the work she does in the southern Punjab region of Pakistan. It's been more than four years since my first column about Mukhtar, and since then I've repeatedly visited her little village of Meerwala. What she has accomplished -- with the support of donations from Times readers -- is truly breathtaking. In my column I give a couple of examples of the women she is helping, but I could give many such examples; indeed, right after I left Meerwala, Mukhtar was bustling about trying to save a woman from an honor killing. (Mukhtar sometimes uses the name Mukhtaran Bibi, a variant of her name.)
From rape to honor killings, extreme oppression can be the norm for Pakistani women. But Nicholas D. Kristof reports from Pakistan that a courageous woman has built an oasis of hope in her village.

There was new evidence early this week that the world has not yet absorbed just how deeply humans have depleted our "exhausted oceans." At the latest meeting of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, created under a treaty 42 years ago to manage shared fisheries in that ocean, European governments ignored a strong recommendation from the group's own scientific advisers for deep cuts in some harvests of the Atlantic bluefin tuna. On its face, that would seem to be a strange development considering that the organization's Web site says flatly: "Science underpins the management decisions made by I.C.C.A.T."

Finance | Why on earth are investors rushing to purchase American government securities when the United States is ground zero of the meltdown? (If it were a third-word country, they would be heading for the hills.) Because after the Asian financial crisis of 1998, emerging-market economies stockpiled dollars. And "potential capital losses on existing stocks keep foreign investors locked into U.S. government securities." [Vox]

With the economy in awful shape and threatening to get even worse, this seems a good time - no, make that "an appropriate time"; good times are probably a thing of the past - to look again at two books that were considerably more prescient than most others in foreseeing the current crisis. Charles R. Morris's "Trillion Dollar Meltdown" and Kevin Phillips's "Bad Money" both came out earlier this year and predicted impending disaster. From today's perspective, their warnings were, if anything, too mild - Morris's "trillion dollars," for example, was a scary number in the spring; now it looks like a mere down payment. (I confess that I reviewed "Bad Money" for The Times and thought it might have been too gloomy. My bad.)

Christensen, the Hollywood lawyer who represented many studios and executives, was sentenced on Monday to three years in prison on charges of conspiracy to commit wiretapping and aiding and abetting a wiretap, The Associated Press reported. A report in the City Room column on Tuesday about politicians who have served as both United States senator from New York and secretary of state misidentified the president who was in office when Alaska was purchased from Russia and misstated several dates in the careers of two of the politicians, William L. BERMAN--Margot S. died November 23, 2008 at age 79. She was the beloved and loving mother of Melissa Berman (Richard Klotz) and Carrie Berman (Michael Foltman); wife of the late Irwin Berman; grandmother of Daniel and Rachel Klotz; sister of Harry Strauss (Ruth Strauss); aunt of Stephanie Strauss (Bill Regenold) and Andrea Strauss (Alegria Cupit); great-aunt of Simon, Nina and David Regenold and of Ari and Ian Cupit-Strauss. She was committed and devoted to her family, and that devotion lives in their hearts. Margot Berman was born in Germany, coming to New York City at age eight. Despite a lifelong battle with Gauchers Disease, she lived a life of courage, ideas and grace. She was the founding head librarian of the synagogue and school library at Temple Beth Am of Miami. Through her story hours and book programs, she inspired countless children to become lifelong readers. She served as president of the Association of Jewish Libraries, and was a mentor to synagogue librarians across the country. The funeral service will be held on November 30th at 10:30am at Lakeview Cemetery in Ithaca, NY. Donations may be made to the Association of Jewish Libraries in her memory (jewishlibraries.org) which is establishing an award in her honor.

LEVY--Dr. Jan Marc , 59, of Manhattan, died November 24, 2008, succumbing to acute myeloid leukemia and its side effects, which he endured bravely and selflessly for the last ten months. He was a faithful, loving, loyal and valiant soul until the very end. He wanted only to live and love. We loved him so much in return. Beloved husband of Erica Gruen Levy for 22 years, adored father of Anna, cherished brother and son-inlaw, nephew, cousin and uncle. Admired colleague and trusted friend to so many. Dr. Levy was at his death on leave as an associate professor in the College of Dentistry at New York University. He earned his D.M.D. from the University of Pennsylvania and J.D. from Touro College of Law and was admitted to the NY Bar. He was an active member of Congregation Hechel Moshe. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Dr. Jan Marc Levy Fund at the NYU College of Dentistry, c/o Dr. Stuart Hirsch, 345 E. 24th St., New York, NY 10016 and The Churchill School, 301 E. 29th St., New York, NY 10016.

An article on Tuesday about pardons issued by President Bush referred incorrectly to the recipients. They are the beneficiaries of Mr. Bush's action, not the ''benefactors.''

BROUS--Muriel H. (nee Labadorf) . Born December 24, 1918, passed peacefully on November 23, 2008. Wife of 67 years to the late Richard A. Brous. Leaves loving daughters Kathy and Patricia. Beloved role model and grandmother of Katherine and Elizabeth and loving mother-inlaw to John. A life filled with humor and imagination which she employed liberally as a first grade teacher in the Baldwin school district for 22 years. She taught hundreds of our children to read and explore the world. As a lover of the beach at Silverpoint, she showed us the colors of our Brous blue souls. She brought laughter to everyone she met and filled our hearts with songs. We are glad that the beach she walked on was our beach and the sunsets she enjoyed we were able to share.

LYON--Dr. Richard K . Husband, father, research chemist and novelist, was born on December 22, 1933, and died November 21, 2008, in his home, surrounded by his family. He was a graduate of William and Mary, and received his Ph.D. in physical chemistry from Harvard, where he studied under J. B. Kistiakowsky. He had a lengthy career in chemistry, and he was responsible for many scientific publications and patents for various chemical processes. This included the Thermal DeNox Process, a technology which removes pollutants from smoke stack emissions. His contributions to pollution control and alternative energy are used throughout the world. He was honored with many awards, including the ACS Award and the IR 100. He was an avid science fiction enthusiast, and co-authored several novels. He took great pleasure in literature and writing. With all of his accomplishments, he was most proud of his family. Richard was kind-hearted, wise, moderate and giving. Richard is survived by his wife of 40 years, and his two sons. Family can be contacted: ILyonheart@cableone.net

The Shubert Organization deeply mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and Chairman, Gerald Schoenfeld. Being able to recover in three weeks from surgery on his sinus membrane was impressive enough, but Cardinals receiver Anquan Boldin is on pace to do something nearly as rare by leading the N.F.L. in receiving touchdowns while having missed two or more games. Since the N.F.L. went to a 16-game schedule in 1978, only two receivers have done so: John Jefferson with the Chargers in 1978 and Terrell Owens with the 49ers in 2002. Of the 35 players who have led the league in receiving touchdowns since 1978 (five years have ended with two players tied for the lead), 29 played every game, 4 missed one game and 2 missed two games.

New Guare Play Is Postponed The Public Theater's much-anticipated production of ''A Free Man of Color,'' a new play by John Guare, right, won't be mounted this season after all. Citing the tightening economy and a loss of financing, the theater said it was postponing the play, which was scheduled to open in the winter. A hybrid of history and sex farce under the direction of George C. Wolfe, it would have starred Mos Defand Jeffrey Wright mixing it up in 1802 New Orleans with Napoleon and Thomas Jefferson. In a statement, Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public, said, ''This is a tough and disappointing decision, but one we made with great thought and care, and one that will ensure the Public's health and stability.'' The theater said that it still planned to present the show next season.

An article on Tuesday about dark matter in the cosmos misstated the energy of proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider, a new particle accelerator at CERN, outside Geneva. When the machine is running at full strength, each colliding proton will have seven trillion electron volts of energy, not seven million.

The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their esteemed member, Norman and extend their heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Judith and their family. Board of Governors Stuart B. Wilkins President COHEN--Norman Co-founder of Lechmere Sales, died on November 24 in New York City. Raised in Dorchester, MA, Mr. Cohen and his two brothers, Maurice and Philip, turned their fathers tire shop in Lechmere Square, Cambridge, into an appliance powerhouse, dominating the retail appliance and TV business in Greater Boston in the 1950s, 60s and 70s. Lechmere was one of the first discount stores, known for its merchandise, dominance, knowledgeable sales staff, and its promotions. At a time when weekly sales were unheard of, Lechmere became famous for the 22-cent cherry pies it offered on Washington's birthday; its ''picnic sale'' on the first weekend of Spring, when all its merchandise was moved into the parking lot; and its once-a-year Saturday night ''private sale.'' These events attracted thousands of people to Lechmere stores in Cambridge and Dedham. The Cohen brothers sold Lechmere to Dayton-Hudson Corporation (the predecessor of Target Corporation), but Mr. Cohen continued to work at Lechmere until he retired and moved to New York City. He then devoted himself to the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel, serving as President and Chairman of the American Committee and as International Deputy Chairman of Weizmann's Board of Governors. In 1992, the Weizmann Institute awarded him an Honorary Doctorate. Mr. Cohen also served on the board of trustees at the Boston Ballet, the Cardinal Cushing School for Exceptional Children, and Camp Young Judea. He served as a Director of Leonard Silver; Claire Stores, Inc.; and Circuit City, Inc. Mr. Cohen, is survived by his three sons with his first wife, Shirlee (nee Blum): Douglas M. Cohen of Lexington, married to Janine Cohen; Stuart Cohen of Marblehead, married to Anne Lucas and I. Scott Cohen of Framingham, married to Ronna Cohen. He is also survived by his second wife, Judith. (nee Younglieb) and her children, Leslie and Andrew Siben and David Schalit. Mr. Cohen is mourned by his ten grandchildren as well: Jonathan Cohen (with wife Liza Perkins-Cohen); Jeffrey Cohen; James Cohen; Bethany Cohen; Elizabeth Cohen; Caroline Cohen; Stefani Misiph (with husband Joshua); Matthew Cohen; Odile Schalit; and Michael Siben. He has one great-grandson, Aaron Cohen. Norman Cohen was universally loved and respected and will be greatly missed. The funeral will be held at 1pm on Wednesday, November 26, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home: 1076 Madison Avenue, New York. Donations in Norman's honor can be made to the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, 633 Third Avenue, Floor 20, NY, NY 10017. COHEN--Norman D. A dear friend who will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to Judith and the entire family. Joan and Herbert COHEN--Norman. A kind, generous and very special human being. Our condolences and love to my dearest friend Judy. Leila Kaycoff and Dr. Sanford Pariser

9 P.M. (History) THE WHITE HOUSE: BEHIND CLOSED DOORS It's a museum, a place of business, a home and one of the most photographed sites in the country. In this 90-minute special President and Mrs. Bush, right, give the first extended televised tour of the presidential residence since Jacqueline Kennedy invited cameras inside in 1962. Stops include the Lincoln Bedroom and the Oval Office, and we're taken behind the scenes at an official state dinner. The program also looks at White House history, from its burning by the British during the War of 1812 to the construction of the West Wing by Theodore Roosevelt and the modifications undertaken during the Truman presidency. Leslie and Leigh Keno of ''Antiques Roadshow'' offer insights on the White House's historic furnishings and decorative arts. 9 P.M. SWEETSER--Nancy Ripa on November 22, 2008 at her home in New York City. Inspirational, vivacious, and indefatigable, Nan was a beloved daughter, mother, sister, and grandmother-''Noodle'' to Molly and Maggie, the adored and adoring granddaughters who gave her so much joy. Nan brought energy and creativity to all of her endeavors--from her pioneering philanthropic work as founder and board member of Miracle House, a non-profit institution that provides housing and support services to patients, families, and friends of patients, undergoing critical medical treatment--to her work as a real estate broker at Sotheby's International Realty. Nan is survived by her 98-year-old father Sebastian Ripa, sister Marie Maguire, daughter Caroline Parker, son-in-law Kirk Parker, son Mark Sweetser. She also leaves behind many devoted friends who along with the family will never forget her natural radiance, her generosity, and her unconditional love. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 5, at 3:30pm at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, New York, NY. Donations in her memory can be made to Miracle House, miraclehouse.org.

FERRER--Mary Schumacher , of NY, NY, died November 23, after a magnanimous life of 96 years that enriched every member of her large family and all her many friends. She was the loving and loved wife of the late Jose, the cherished mother of Joe, Tom, Linda, Jim and Molly, the adored grandmother of nine, and the great-grandmother of eight. Serving on the board of the Spence-Chapin adoption agency, as well as many other charities, she was a woman of style, wit and keen intuition. With her self-effacing grace and generosity, she enhanced the lives of all who knew her. A funeral mass in thanksgiving for her life will be said at 11am on Friday the 28th, at St. Jean Baptiste, on Lexington Ave. and 76th St.

The Talking Business column on Saturday, about the prospects for restructuring American automakers, referred incorrectly to the work of Edward I. Altman, a professor at the Stern School of Business at New York University, who commented on the difficulty of a prepackaged bankruptcy for General Motors. He uses mathematical models to assess the financial health of companies and the market; he does not run a bankruptcy prediction service.

KELVIN--Beatrice , 93, November 25. Early childhood educator, world traveler, fighter for peace and justice, she leaves six loving children and children-in-law--Judith Mahoney Pasternak, Joan Mahoney, Peter and Joanne Kelvin, and David and Brenda Kelvin--11 grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, and a brother and sister-in-law, Irwin and Renee Shishko. A bench in London's Tavistock Square is dedicated to peace in her name. Service 1pm, Sunday December 7, Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York.

SIEGEL--Jeffrey J. , age 62 died suddenly after a short but fierce battle from cancer on November 24, 2008. Beloved husband of Debra. Father to Jill (James) Drummond, Alison (Michael) Novara; Ashleigh, Brette and Courtney Wolf. Survived by father Martin Siegel and stepmother Nancy Siegel. Grandfather of Phoebe, Benjamin, Madeline and Charlotte. Brother of Dorian Siegel Held, stepbrother Richard Chanin, his Aunt Marilyn Fisher; nieces and nephews, Isaac, Noah and Robin. Past president Hollywood Golf Club (his passion away from work and family) site of his lowest score, 76, just last month. Services Tuesday, 12pm at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Chapel 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. Burial to follow, Beth David Cemetery, Elwood, NY. So loved so missed.

Ah, Pouilly-Fuiss√©. I remember ordering it in the age of New York's grand French restaurants, back when La Caravelle was new, and I loved Caf√© Argenteuil. Any curious expat or homesick tourist who googles "Thanksgiving in Berlin" in search of a good turkey dinner will come up with some wild mentions of Thanksgivings past spent here in the German capital. In the November 20, 1884, edition of New York Times, there's an odd rundown of an event in which 250 Americans whooped out three (remote) cheers for then President-elect Grover Cleveland at a Thanksgiving banquet held at the "American colony in Berlin". Toasts to Emperor William and the great luck of Americans privileged enough to live in Berlin were made. Sixteen years later, 400 people showed up at the same event, where they praised and even sent a telegram to President McKinley.

Coordinated terrorist attacks in Mumbai, India, have killed at least 100 people and wounded more than 250. The authorities have recovered a stolen 18-karat gold bookmark that was reportedly given to Hitler by his longtime mistress, Eva Braun. Christian Popescu, a Romanian, was arrested outside a Starbucks in Bellevue after trying to sell the bookmark to an undercover agent for $100,000, according to papers filed in the Federal District Court in Seattle. Prosecutors said the bookmark was among several items taken in an auction-house robbery in Madrid six years ago. At the time, some antiquities experts questioned its authenticity. The bookmark is engraved with a portrait of Hitler as well as an imperial eagle and a swastika, and its inscription indicates that Braun gave it to Hitler to console him after German forces surrendered at Stalingrad. ‚ÄúMy Adolf, don‚Äôt worry,‚Äù it reads in part, adding that the loss was ‚Äúonly an inconvenience that will not break your certainty of victory.‚Äù Regardless of its authenticity, officials said its theft broke the law. ‚ÄúArtifacts of historical significance are not souvenirs for illegal sale to the highest bidder,‚Äù said Leigh Winchell, special agent in charge of Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs office of investigations in Seattle.

NBC‚Äôs midseason schedule is heavy on the few shows that have worked for the network this season ‚Äî that is, reality shows and ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äù ‚Äî and light on other scripted programming, The Hollywood Reporter said. On Jan. 4, NBC will introduce ‚ÄúSuperstars of Dance,‚Äù a competition created by the producers of ‚ÄúAmerican Idol,‚Äù and on Jan. 9 it will debut ‚ÄúHowie Do It,‚Äù a hidden-camera show hosted by Howie Mandel of ‚ÄúDeal or No Deal.‚Äù Two more prime-time ‚ÄúSNL‚Äù specials will also be shown that month, and ‚ÄúFriday Night Lights‚Äù will begin Jan. 16. Missing from the line-up are the hourlong series ‚ÄúMedium,‚Äù ‚ÄúLife,‚Äù ‚ÄúChuck‚Äù and ‚ÄúHeroes,‚Äù though those shows are expected to return in February.

The Zimbabwean playwright and political satirist Cont Mhlanga has won the Freedom to Create Prize, awarded by the artistic philanthropy group ArtVenture, the organization announced. Mr. Mhlanga has been an outspoken critic of Zimbabwe‚Äôs president, Robert Mugabe, and his work has been banned by that regime. The award was given to Mr. Mhlanga at a ceremony in London on Wednesday. In a statement ArtVenture said it had created the distinction ‚Äúto highlight a forgotten frontline of artists defending their freedom of expression at great personal sacrifice.‚Äù It comes with a prize of $50,000, half of which Mr. Mhlanga has pledged to the Women of Zimbabwe Arise Group, an equal-rights organization.

Gerard Mortier, fresh from a sudden split with the New York City Opera that left the company in turmoil, will become artistic director of the Teatro Real opera house in Madrid, the company said on Wednesday. The Teatro Real said last week that Mr. Mortier was in the running just two weeks after he and City Opera had parted ways. Mr. Mortier was designated to assume the position of general director in New York next season and had been helping run the company part-time from Paris but withdrew after the City Opera‚Äôs board said it could not provide the budget he had expected because of the economic downturn. The Belgian-born Mr. Mortier, who is in his final year running the Paris National Opera, will assume the Madrid post in January 2010.

Record sales increased last week with new albums from Beyoncé, below, Nickelback and David Cook, the latest “American Idol” winner. “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) became Beyoncé’s third album in a row to open at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, with sales of 482,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Nickelback, the Canadian rock band, opened at No. 2 with its latest, “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner), moving 326,000 copies, and Mr. Cook’s self-titled album on RCA sold 280,000 to land at No. 3. Last week’s top seller, Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), dropped to No. 4, with 217,000, a decline of 63 percent. The classical crossover group Il Divo reached No. 5 with 162,000 sales of its new album, “Promise” (Columbia), and the “Twilight” soundtrack (Atlantic) slipped one to No. 6, with 125,000 sales. Sales were up 6 percent over all from last week, but down 32 percent from the same week last year.

Tom Brokaw‚Äôs last day as interim moderator of ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù is looming and could well be Dec. 7, and NBC News has not yet decided whether it will announce on that day who will become the permanent host or hosts of the program, someone who has been apprised of the network‚Äôs plans said Wednesday. The person, who spoke only on condition of anonymity because the network was not ready to make an announcement, said NBC News had yet to make a final determination on a successor to Mr. Brokaw, above, who was installed as temporary moderator after the death in June of Tim Russert, the longtime host.

The production company owned by the actor and director Tyler Perry, below, will unionize its writing staff under an agreement announced Wednesday with the Writers Guild of America. The deal comes after five months of negotiations between the guild and Tyler Perry Studios. The company produces the television shows “Meet the Browns” and “House of Payne” as well as feature films. Last month the guild staged protests outside Mr. Perry’s office in Atlanta and advised its members not to work for the company after the firing of four “House of Payne” writers who had sought union representation. Mr. Perry said his studio would work with the guild to “dramatically increase the number of minority writers working in Hollywood today.”.

A concert performed on Oct. 24 by Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble will be broadcast Thursday on WNYC (93.9 FM) in New York at 8:05 p.m. The concert, which was held in honor of United Nations Day and the 10th anniversary season of the Silk Road Project, features music from China, India, Turkey, Lebanon, Armenia, Argentina and Egypt. It will also be streamed live online at wnyc.org. ... The Dec. 2 preview performance of “Shrek the Musical” at the Broadway Theater has been canceled and tickets for this performance have been taken off sale, the show’s producers announced. The producers said in a statement that the performance was canceled so that final changes could be made to the musical before its opening on Dec. 14. Ticketholders for the canceled show should contact Telecharge.com, online or at (212) 239-6200, or the Broadway Theater box office.

The declining economy continues to take its toll on regional performing arts companies. On Monday Ballet British Columbia laid off 38 staff members, including all of its dancers, above, and the artistic director. The next day the Vancouver City Council voted to give a one-time grant of $85,000 to the company, The Globe and Mail reported. That money will be used to help the struggling company pay the rental fees for the Queen Elizabeth Theater, where it has already scheduled the visiting Moscow City Ballet to perform “The Nutcracker” in December. Elsewhere the board of the Chattanooga Symphony and Opera in Tennessee voted on Tuesday to suspend its opera productions for the 2009-10 season, The Chattanooga Times Free Press reported. Production costs for the company’s operas run about $225,000 a show, and it has lost more that $1.1 million on 11 operas in the last six years.

The model and television personality Brooke Burke, below, won the seventh edition of “Dancing With the Stars,” on the show’s season finale Tuesday on ABC. The network easily earned the night’s most viewers as 20.6 million people tuned in, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Ratings declined, however, among adults 18 to 49, falling to a new low compared with previous finales of the reality series. The fifth-season finale last November attracted a larger overall audience, of 24.9 million viewers, though Tuesday’s broadcast did outpace the show’s sixth-season finale in May. In the 8 p.m. hour ABC’s “Charlie Brown Thanksgiving” (11.1 million) finished in third place behind CBS’s “NCIS” (18.2 million) and Fox’s “House” (12.5 million). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers, with “The Mentalist” (15.9 million) and “Without a Trace” (10.4 million). Fox was third, but a close second behind ABC in the 18-to-49 set.

Good news for fans of alternative country music who have already lost their girlfriends, dogs and pickup trucks: the magazine No Depression, which chronicled the alternative-country scene and gave early boosts to the careers of artists like Wilco and Ryan Adams, has resumed publication, The Associated Press reported. Taking its name from the Carter Family song “No Depression in Heaven” (and the album “No Depression” by the band Uncle Tupelo), the magazine was founded in 1995 and published bimonthly until its May-June 2008 issue. Citing the declining prospects of the magazine and music industries, it moved to a Web-only format. Now, its editors say, No Depression will come out as a twice-yearly “bookazine” with no advertising. “We had a pretty large outpouring of sentiment and support,” said Peter Blackstock, a co-editor of No Depression, according to The Associated Press. He added, “There’s still a community there — we weren’t losing readership.”.

When you title a Batman comic book storyline “R.I.P.,” it’s understandable if readers worry about the fate of that Gotham City hero. The story’s final chapter, in Batman No. 681, written by Grant Morrison and illustrated by Tony Daniel, arrived in stores Wednesday. It features a scene in which Batman is caught in a helicopter crash and only his cowl is recovered. But that’s all part of the plan by DC Comics, which has devised several months of stories without the caped crusader. “You realize in their absence how valuable the character is,” said Dan DiDio, DC’s senior vice president and executive editor. “Bruce Wayne will always be back as Batman someday.”.

LenDale White did not even take the time to dress after the Titans' first loss before he complained about how he had been used in it, not a good sign for a team hoping to rebound quickly. Coach Jeff Fisher could soothe White's bruised feelings -- he was on the field for only three plays against the Jets -- with a few extra touches against the woeful Lions. Detroit gives up more points (31.5 a game) than any team and ranks last against the run. Its pass defense has been slightly better (19th over all), but why would an opponent -- especially one with the Titans' backfield -- pass when it's so easy to run? The second game of Mismatch Thursday, as Thanksgiving should be known this season, could be a showcase for Tony Romo. He has passed for 539 yards and 4 touchdowns, with two interceptions, in two games since returning from a broken finger, and he said Tuesday that the finger was feeling so good that he thought he could play without the splint that has protected it. That would not be good news for the Seahawks, who rank next to last against the pass and have already surrendered 300-yard games to J. T. O'Sullivan and Donovan McNabb.

AGIN--Steven Marc ''Uncle Stevie'' ''Porky'' we will miss you, mourn with your wonderful loving family and friends and celebrate a special life. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. We mourn the loss of a great leader, a faultless partner, and a beloved friend. Our profound sympathies extend to Pat and the family at this time of profound loss. Scott Rudin and John Barlow SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Jerry enriched New York, its cultural institutions, and the theater worldwide. He enriched our lives even more. We celebrate his life and mourn his passing. Our love and sympathy go to our beloved Pat and to Carrie, Fiore, Julia, and Sam. Marjorie, Jeffrey, Andrew, and Daniel SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Artists, Board, Staff, Musicians and stage crews of Lincoln Center Theater sadly mourn the sudden and untimely death of our greatly admired friend and beloved chairman of the Shubert Organization, who for the last thirty-five years has fearlessly and valiantly advanced the interests of the theater, the entire theater, Broadway, the Road, off-Broadway, the notfor-profits of New York and throughout the United States, and wherever theatrical enterprise and creativity were poking their way through the surface of everyday life. During the 70s he was a veritable Carrie Nation of his time extirpating the forces of darkness and evil and turning on the lights of the Broadway marquees to the brightness of the best years. The Shubert Foundation has been a fountain of hope and sustenance providing funds for theaters throughout the country with subsidies greater than those of the National Endowment for the Arts. He was an exemplary person of the theater and we extend condolences to his beloved wife Patricia, his daughter, Carrie and the grandchildren, to President of the Shubert Organization Philip J. Smith and all his colleagues at The Shubert Organization and The Shubert Foundation. Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer John Beinecke, Chairman Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman Emeritus John Chalsty, President SCHOENFELD--Gerald. There are no friends like old friends. After 71 years, just nine of us remain. We will miss you Jerry. The Centuries SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Public Theater mourn the passing of our good friend and partner Gerald Schoenfeld. For nearly four decades, Jerry's support and wisdom have helped The Public reach unimagined heights. Most notably, from our partnership on A Chorus Line to the recent production of Passing Strange, Jerry was always an advocate for the Public's work and mission to bring great art to everyone. His contribution to the American theater is legendary, and he will be missed by all. We offer our deepest sympathy to Pat, the entire Schoenfeld family and the staff of the Shubert organization. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. You were One Singular Sensation. We will miss you terribly. Susan V. Booth, President Teresa Eyring, Executive Director Theatre Communications Group SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Gerald Shoenfeld. Gerald, chairman of the Shubert Foundation, was a philanthropic leader in the New York community. A past honoree and longtime supporter of our Theater Group, Gerald demonstrated extraordinary generosity, enabling us to carry out our mission and help those in need in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Board of Directors of the American Theatre Wing mourns the passing of our long-standing friend and colleague. The Tony Awards have benefited from Jerry's wisdom and good humor through the years and we will miss his presence on the Tony Administration Committee. We send our condolences to Pat and the rest of the family. As part of Jerry's vast Broadway family, we feel we too have lost a member of our family. Ted Chapin, Chairman of the Board Howard Sherman, Executive Director SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Roundabout Theatre Company mourns the passing of Gerald Schoenfeld. His generosity toward the non profit theatre through the Shubert Foundation has had a profound impact on our field and in ensuring arts education in all NYC public schools. We express our deepest condolences to his family, Shubert Organization and Shubert Foundation. Thomas Tuft, Chairman Todd Haimes, Artistic Dir. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Long before the footlights and the fame we were family: Floria, David, Emily, Dara, Jerry, Pat, Carrie. We are so sad. With all our love. Emily and Dara SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Board of Directors and staff of Manhattan Theatre Club mourn the loss of Gerald Schoenfeld, our longtime friend, colleague, supporter. Jerry had an unparalleled commitment to Broadway, the nonprofit theaters and regional theaters, and he had an unwavering commitment to arts in the schools. We at MTC, along with countless others, were the beneficiaries of his wisdom, leadership and generosity of spirit for over three decades. We will miss him deeply and extend our sympathy to Pat, Carrie, the entire Schoenfeld family and the Shubert Organization. Lynne Meadow, Barry Grove and Peter Solomon SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Producers of ''Equus On Broadway'' mourn the loss of our partner and friend, Gerald Schoenfeld. This theatrical giant will always be an inspiration. Our thoughts and prayers go out to Pat and his Shubert colleagues. Elizabeth Ireland McCann, Roger Berlind, John Gore, Hirschfeld Productions, Bill Kenwright, Emily Fisher Landau, Arielle Tapper Madover, Peter May, Chase Mishkin, Spring Sirkin SCHOENFELD--Gerald. In the entertainment jungle, Jerry's devotion for truth and fairness was rare. His expert testimony was crucial for an independent producer's $1,500,000 jury victory against an overbearing theater owner. Robert Markewich SCHOENFELD--Gerald, was a founding member of the Times Square Alliance and not just a fighter for but a friend of all in Times Square. Times Square will hugely miss a strong man with a gentle soul who through his tenacity and persistence did more than anyone to fight for one of New York City's most important industries and to make the theater district and Times Square safer and more welcoming to all. Michael J. Stengel, Chairman Tim Tompkins, President Times Square Alliance SCHOENFELD--Gerald. We mourn the loss of a good friend, colleague and mentor. Our hearts go out to Pat, his family, and all at the Shubert Organization. Nina Lannan Associates SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Center for Court Innovation mourns the passing of our longtime supporter Jerry Schoenfeld. His leadership inspired the creation of the Midtown Community Court, a model of problem-solving justice that has been replicated locally and nationally. We extend our condolences to the Schoenfeld family and the Shubert Organization. Greg Berman, Director SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The entire theatre world is deeply saddened by the passing of Gerald Schoenfeld, known to all true New Yorkers as the ''Mayor of Times Square.'' Jerry championed the cause of cleaning up the Theatre District beginning in the early 1970s and became the Chairman of the Mayor's Midtown Citizens Committee appointed by Mayor Abe Beame and continued by each succeeding mayor. He either chaired or was a member of the Board of Directors of every major organization involved with the theatre, including The Broadway League and The Broadway Association, among others. He created the Midtown Community Court and spearheaded most initiatives that were beneficial to the health of live theatre. One of his most noteworthy accomplishments was his championing of the construction of the Marriott Marquis Hotel that shifted the hotel center of gravity of the city to Times Square and greatly improved tourism. His wit, wisdom and compassion will be sorely missed by all. New York City has suffered the great loss of a true gentleman. The Board of the Directors and members of the Broadway Association SCHOENFELD--Gerald. With a deep sense of loss, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the death of its esteemed Fellow. From ''Chorus Line'' to ''Cats'', from ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' to ''Gin Game'', his presence towered over Broadway for more than forty years. His unbending determination renewed Times Square, and his philanthropy benefited countless nonprofit theaters and dance companies. The Academy expresses its sincere condolences to his wife, Patricia, his family, and all those who were fortunate to know his brilliance, generosity, and passion for the theater and for the City of New York. Emilio Bizzi, President Louis Cabot, Chair of the Academy Trust and Vice President Leslie Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer

A car bomber struck a convoy of foreign troops near the United States Embassy in Kabul on Thursday, killing one civilian and wounding six others, the Kabul police chief said. The police chief, Mohammad Ayoub Salangi, said the suicide attack took place near the embassy and the Health Ministry.

Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his entire family. His warm smile, abundant sense of humor and wry wit will be missed by all of us who knew him. ''IF you get more than two women in a hat, it's a party,'' Linda Pagan likes to say. If you get more than 10, it's a parade. Ms. Pagan, who designs vivacious little cocktail hats in downtown Manhattan, organized a party of fellow milliners last week, which quickly swelled to pageant-like proportions. Dozens of eccentric hatters marched along Fifth Avenue and around Rockefeller Center, showing off chapeaus bedecked in ribbons, plumes and lace. Some were the cr√®me of the milliner's art; others could have passed as nesting stations for the pigeons overhead. And, like Tziporah Salamon's Lincolnesque topper (above), most were conversation starters.

If the Senate race in Minnesota seems as though it has slogged on like ''Groundhog Day,'' well, it has. The five-member State Canvassing Board on Wednesday unanimously rejected Al Franken's appeal to count rejected absentee ballots. Mr. Franken, a Democrat, was hoping those ballots would propel him to victory; he was 238 votes behind Norm Coleman, the incumbent Republican, on Tuesday night.

BARCO--James William. Deputy Ambassador of the United States to the United Nations during the Eisenhower administration, died in New York, NY, on November 20, 2008, age 92. James Barco was born on April 5, 1916 in Benton Harbor, MI, the son of William John and Maude Bryan Barco. A graduate of the University of Michigan (1938) and Harvard Law School (1941), he served in the U.S. Navy from 1942 to 1946, and then joined the U.S. State Department, serving on the U.S. delegation to the UN Good Offices Commission for Indonesia. In 1948-1949 he was acting deputy U.S. representative to the UN Conciliation Commission for Palestine. From 1956-1961, he was deputy representative of the U.S. on the UN Security Council-serving as counselor of the U.S. delegation (1955-1959), and as deputy permanent representative of the U.S. to the UN and the UN Security Council (1960-1961). In 1961, he became special assistant to the President of Time, Inc. He was a founding partner in 1962 of the law firm of Barco, Cook & Patton (now Patton Boggs LLP); later he served as Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the American University in Cairo and with the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia. In retirement, he lived in Ivy, VA, Baltimore and New York. He leaves no surviving relatives but many devoted friends. Graveside services will be held in Ivy, VA, and a memorial service will be held there in January.

IN 1963, while my dad was on leave from the Air Force, my parents took a trip to Copenhagen. The Danish krone was worth about 14 cents, so my mother bought a black leather Swan chair with a footstool and two orange Egg chairs, designed by Arne Jacobsen. Along with a simple chrome-framed sofa, she spent a total of $959, plus shipping. Forty-five years later, Arne Jacobsen is known as a master of midcentury modern design, and this furniture looks as good as new. The Egg chairs still spin around effortlessly without squeaking, the sofa hasn't sagged, and the Swan chair's leather hasn't cracked. I always go into the living room when I'm home and marvel at how this was money well spent, and how my mother is pretty much the Aretha Franklin of shopping.

Iran said Wednesday that its main uranium enrichment plant was now equipped with 5,000 centrifuges, a sharp increase from the 4,000 it announced in August. Centrifuges spin incredibly fast to enrich uranium into nuclear fuel. The announcement was made amid growing international concern over Iran's nuclear program, which it says is for energy production but the West fears is intended to produce weapons. The official who announced the increase, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, head of the Atomic Organization, brushed off international demands that Iran suspend enriching uranium. The ISNA news agency quoted him as saying, ''Suspension has no meaning at all in Iran's culture, and no such thing exists.''

Having outscored its opponents by an average of 30 points, No. 10 Purdue faced its first test of the season in Wednesday's semifinals of the N.I.T. Season Tip-Off tournament. The Boilermakers (5-0) passed, but not necessarily with a high mark. The Boilermakers almost let a 20-point lead slip away in the second half, but they held on to beat Boston College, 71-64, at Madison Square Garden. Leading by 60-40 after Marcus Green made a short jumper with 7 minutes 16 seconds left, Purdue went cold over the next five minutes as Boston College trimmed the lead to 9 points. But the Eagles (3-2) could not regroup after Corey Raji was called for an offensive foul with 1:01 to play.
