GAUJEAN--Dr. Max Pierre, died November 21, 2008. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Dr. Emmelyne St. Germain Gaujean, their children: Max G. Gaujean, Nadine Gaujean, Natasha Gaujean-La Mar, and Martine-Pascale Gaujean May, his brother Gerard Gaujean, six grandchildren, extended family and friends. Dr. Gaujean was born June 11, 1929 in Croix des Bouquet, Haiti, the youngest child of Pierre Gaujean and Octavia Jean Pierre Gaujean. In 1966, he immigrated to the United States and settled in Cleveland, Ohio where he practiced medicine for 42 years as an OB/GYN and ER physician. Dr. Gaujean practiced his profession much the way he lived his life, with patience, honesty, skill, caring, and courage. The mayor of Vladikavkaz, a southern city in Russia's North Caucasus region, was assassinated by a sniper on Wednesday morning near his home, law enforcement officials said. Investigators said they believed that one shot was fired at the mayor, Vitaly Karayev, above, who had been in power for less than a year. Mr. Karayev, 46, was hit in the chest and died at a hospital, officials said. Vladikavkaz is the capital of North Ossetia, a Russian republic.

FLEECE fabrics made from recycled plastics have been available for about 15 years. But two years ago, less than 1 percent of the polyester fleece yarn that is a staple of outdoor apparel was recycled. ''Today 20 percent of our yarns are made from recycled materials,'' said Nate Simmons of Polartec, a leading manufacturer of fleece fabrics, based in Lawrence, Mass. Wool is enjoying a renaissance as well. ''Our business has grown an average of 27 percent a year for the last nine years,'' said Keith Anderson of Ibex Outdoor Clothing, a manufacturer of wool apparel based in Woodstock, Vt. Wool has been prized for its warmth and durability for thousands of years, but only in the last decade have manufacturers addressed a major shortcoming: inherent, even maddening itchiness. For now, consumers have to depend on manufacturers' disclosures to know how eco-friendly their outdoor apparel is. But that will likely change soon. ''Leaders in the outdoor apparel industry are working on establishing standards so that apparel can be rated, the way appliances are with the Energy Star label,'' Mr. Simmons said.

Days away from the gala opening night of La Scala, the traditional Dec. 7 celebration of the Milanese opera house‚Äôs new season continues to be threatened by a labor dispute, Bloomberg News reported. Italy‚Äôs Fials union, which represents about half of the orchestra musicians and chorus singers at La Scala, has been on strike since July, and rejected new contracts in October, demanding a larger share of the opera house‚Äôs broadcast revenue. Management has so far refused to negotiate further. The strike has already forced the cancellation of productions of ‚ÄúLa Dame aux Camelias‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Merry Widow,‚Äù costing La Scala about $772,000, and its annual opening gala, held on a holiday for St. Ambrose, the patron saint of Milan, is a substantial source of fundraising. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm convinced that La Scala will face and overcome this situation,‚Äù said Stephane Lissner, the managing director of La Scala, Bloomberg News reported. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm as always an optimistic person.‚Äù

As the lyrics to the Beatles song say, Eleanor Rigby died in the church and was buried along with her name. But a 97-year-old document, on which thename ‚ÄúE. Rigby‚Äù appears, has sold at an auction in London for almost $177,000, Reuters reported. The manuscript, a 1911 salary register from the Liverpool City Hospital on which a scullery maid named E. Rigby signed for her wages, was sold Thursday by Annie Mawson, the founder of Sunbeams Music Trust, a charity for people with special needs. Ms. Mawson told Reuters that the document was sent to her by Paul McCartney in 1990, in response to a request for money for the trust. ‚ÄúIt was nine months after I‚Äôd written to him,‚Äù she said, according to Reuters, ‚Äúwhich was part of the mystery because you always think it ended up in the wastepaper basket.‚Äù The name Eleanor Rigby was also discovered on a grave at St. Peter‚Äôs Church in Woolton, Liverpool, near Mr. McCartney‚Äôs birthplace.

A British archbishop has asked the National Gallery in London to give up a 15th-century painting, saying that the work instead belongs in his cathedral, the BBC reported. The artwork, ‚ÄúThe Baptism of Christ,‚Äù was painted by Piero della Francesca in the 1450s and has been part of the National Gallery‚Äôs collection since 1861. In a lecture for the Royal Fine Art Commission Trust, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O‚ÄôConnor, the Archbishop of Westminster, said, ‚ÄúIt is a mistake to treat it as a work of art, it is a work of faith and piety,‚Äù according to the BBC. The archbishop added: ‚ÄúIt is an expression of the Church‚Äôs life and a way into prayer. I will willingly offer Westminster Cathedral as the new home for this painting.‚Äù The painting was temporarily moved from the National Gallery during World War II, but is said to be too delicate to be loaned to other institutions. The museum told the BBC that visitors were welcome to pray in front of the painting where it currently hangs.

Looking for a holiday gift for your favorite ballet fan who has already seen ‚ÄúThe Nutcracker‚Äù several dozen times? American Ballet Theater is offering a few more original (if a bit pricier) options in an online auction. Beginning Monday, Ballet Theater will auction several items and opportunities, from limited-edition photographs and signed pointe shoes to backstage visits and dinners with soloists and principal dancers, including Nina Ananiashvili, who will give her final performances with Ballet Theater in the spring. Is the British royal family composed of diehard science-fiction geeks? We may never know for certain, but the Windsors do seem to appreciate the work of Russell T Davies: on Thursday, they appointed Mr. Davies, the executive producer of the sci-fi television series ‚ÄúDoctor Who,‚Äù to the Order of the British Empire, the BBC reported. Mr. Davies, who resuscitated the long-dormant ‚ÄúDoctor Who‚Äù to great success in 2005, received his OBE from Prince Charles at a ceremony at Buckingham Palace. In October, Mr. Davies said at a literature festival in Cheltenham, England, that the Prince had turned down an invitation to appear on ‚ÄúDoctor Who,‚Äù calling him ‚Äúa miserable swine.‚Äù Mr. Davies has previously announced that he is stepping down from the television series in 2009.

He may be only the second most-famous depiction of David in sculpture, but he‚Äôs entitled to a little cosmetic surgery, too: Donatello‚Äôs ‚ÄúDavid,‚Äù a bronze statue of the biblical giant-slayer and future king, has been treated to its first full restoration in a century and is once again on full display in Florence‚Äôs Museo Nazionale del Bargello, The Associated Press reported. The restoration used laser technology to remove dirt from the sculpture, which remained partly on view to patrons during this time; the entire process took a year and a half and cost about $257,000. ‚ÄúWe could only intervene now with the newest laser techniques,‚Äù Beatrice Paolozzi Strozzi, the Bargello‚Äôs director, told The A.P. ‚ÄúEven the most delicate mechanical procedure would have hurt it.‚Äù Michelangelo‚Äôs ‚ÄúDavid,‚Äù a marble sculpture in Florence‚Äôs Galleria dell‚ÄôAccademia, underwent its own restoration in 2004.

My goal this week was to get out of New York and Washington and see how the financial crisis was affecting an old-line middle American company. The company I chose to focus on -- not quite randomly, but pretty close -- was Navistar, the country's last remaining independent truck maker. As I discovered, Navistar itself is well-positioned to weather the storm, thanks in part of having obtained some low-cost financing that will carry it through 2012. But it's customers -- everyone from independent truck drivers to big trucking companies -- are being hit hard by the crisis. They are the subject of this week's column.

This is rivalry week in college football. It's a time when records are thrown out the window and the chance to play spoiler means the chance to redeem a disappointing season. Look at the Iron Bowl for instance. Auburn has had a terrible year. No one is going to argue with that. Meanwhile, Alabama has been one of the biggest surprises of the college football season and is comfortably perched at the top spot in every poll. Regardless, an Auburn victory puts a dent in Alabama's national title hopes and gives half of the state bragging rights for an entire year. Of course Alabama is a big favorite, but Auburn has won the last six Iron Bowls and you know that anything can happen in college football. The same script holds true from Oregon/Oregon State, Florida/Florida State and Oklahoma/Oklahoma State. All of these games have B.C.S. implications in addition to the madness that surrounds these kinds of rivalries. Oklahoma/Oklahoma State is a whole other beast, with complex B.C.S. arguments swirling around that game as well as the Big 12 South in general.

WEBER--Arthur P. , on November 24, 2008 at the age of 88. In 1961 he co-founded the non-sectarian Old Westbury Golf and Country Club, and more recently his ''Code of Environmental Conduct'' for golf course maintenance was adopted by th USGA and recognized by the Audubon Society. In his youth, Mr. Weber played harmonica on the Horn & Hardart Children's Hour radio program and was a champion speedskater. He holds both chemical and nuclear engineering degrees and during World War II was part of the small team of experts assembled by the U.S. Government to work on the Manhattan Project. Beloved husband of Jean, loving father of Geoffrey and Diane, cherished grandfather of Sunny and Martin, brother of David.

LEITER--Max , passed peacefully in his sleep on November 26, 2008, at the age of 86, after a brief illness. A man of few words, Max led an unselfish life, always putting his family before himself and positively and powerfully affecting his family and friends with his goodness of heart and his actions. He is survived and deeply missed by his devoted wife of 60 years, Susi, his loving sons Steven and Richard, daughter-in-law Elizabeth and grandchildren Samantha, Alexandra and Jake.

On Wednesday, if all goes as planned, Martin Chalfie will fly to Stockholm for a batch of celebrations leading up to a ceremony on Dec. 10. That is when he will accept the 2008 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. It should be exciting. But he will miss the scheduled opening of a new film back home in New York. In the scheme of things, that may seem like an exceedingly minor concern. But this movie happens to be about a scientist who wins the chemistry prize.

Notable Lang Lang recordings, all on Deutsche Grammophon: LANG LANG LIVE AT CARNEGIE HALL (B000218936) Works by Haydn, Schumann, Schubert, Liszt and more. Mr. Lang's recital debut at Carnegie Hall in November 2003 was expeditiously released as a two-disc set and quickly became a top seller. A DVD of the recital soon followed. This is a defining Lang Lang performance. Whether you find his account of Schumann's ''Abegg'' Variations full of color and imagination or contorted with expressivity, whether you find his Schubert ''Wanderer'' Fantasy absolutely exhilarating or incoherent, and so on, you will have support for your point of view. $18.98.

DANIELS--Ada (Schoenberg) , age 95, died peacefully on November 22 in her Brooklyn Heights home. She was the beloved mother of Jim (Martha Gifford) and Molly, grandmother of Justin (Stacey) and Caitlin (David Israel), great-grandmother to five, and sister of Reva Rarig. She also leaves three nieces, a nephew and many loving friends. A graduate of Wellesley College, the Graduate School of Jewish Social Work and Bank Street College, Ada had a distinguished career in family planning, public health and parent education. Her achievements included establishing curricula and training faculty in parent education at leading schools of nursing. Private memorial gathering will be announced. She was greatly loved and will be deeply missed.

FAY--Richard J. , New York investment banker and 50year resident of Pleasantville, New York, died Sunday, November 23, after a long illness. He was 86. Born and raised in Batavia, New York, Mr. Fay entered Syracuse University with the class of '44. He left a year before graduation to serve as an army infantry officer in World War II and graduated with the class of '48. Mr. Fay joined Goldman Sachs and Company in 1952 and was promoted to partner in 1962. A life-long lover of the Adirondacks, he served as a trustee of the Adirondack Museum in Blue Mountain Lake, New York. He also served for many years on the Syracuse University Board of Trustees. Mr. Fay's wife, Joann Olson Fay (Syracuse '44), died in 1991. He is survived by his three children, Stephen Fay of Newtown, CT; Laurence Fay of Katonah, NY; Wendy Starling of Blue Mt. Lake, NY and Queensbury, NY; and three grandchildren, Sara, Aron and Chelsea Fay. The family will receive friends at the Beecher Funeral Home, Inc. in Pleasantville on Monday December 1st from 2-4 and 7-9pm. A Funeral Service will be held at the funeral home on Tuesday at 11am. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to the Adirondack Museum and The Richard J. and Joann Olson Fay Scholarship Fund of Syracuse University.
LITT--Stacey , 11/28/07. You are always in our heart. You will be loved and missed forever. -Abeles and Zacks

FRUSTRATING: That's what it is. At a time when homes -- especially second homes in some regions -- are dropping in price, it's getting harder to get a loan to buy one. Banks, naturally skittish after this year's mortgage crisis, are tightening their purse strings, and it takes a lot to tug them open. ''The interesting part is that you're going to get some of your best buys in your second-home markets right now,'' said Marc Schwaber, president of Preferred Empire Mortgage, a Manhattan-based brokerage. In his own search for a property in Florida, Mr. Schwaber has found prices that have dropped 50 percent in the past two to three years. ''The second-home market in many ways holds its value really well, and people want second homes. But banks can't seem to ease up on their guidelines.''

LOVE TRAIN: THE SOUND OF PHILADELPHIA Maybe the Philadelphia International label, founded by the producers Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff, started out intending to be another Motown, making hits by putting gospel-rooted voices atop a hard-charging studio band. That's what Mr. Gamble and Mr. Huff did with Jerry Butler's 1969 ''Only the Strong Survive,'' which is included on this set along with other early Gamble-Huff productions. By 1971, when the label started, their ideas were already leading elsewhere.

Six days a week, Alma Ortiz, a petite woman who worked for Con Ed for years, waits patiently in front of her home on West 97th Street for a private bus that picks her up and takes her across town to the C.V. Starr Adult Day Services center, a program for people living with Alzheimer's disease or dementia. Ms. Ortiz, 86, who suffers from dementia and lives alone, considers the center a second home. One day this summer, the bus that takes her there was a little late; so determined was Ms. Ortiz to get there, she decided to take the next bus she saw. Lost and disoriented, she eventually ended up at Metropolitan Hospital Center, where someone called her son, who picked her up and took her where she wanted so badly to go.

CHILDREN'S CENTER, NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY Patience and Fortitude, the serenely majestic lions who serve as sentinels at the New York Public Library, have recently acquired a host of animal neighbors. Residing inside the building, they include a fox with a luxurious tail, a brilliant blue bull, a cocoa-colored bear and an aardvark wearing glasses. On Saturday owls, hawks and falcons will join the mix.

IT'S game over for the American consumer. Inflation-adjusted personal consumption expenditures are on track for rare back-to-back quarterly declines in the second half of 2008 at a 3.5 percent average annual rate. There are only four other instances since 1950 when real consumer demand has fallen for two quarters in a row. This is the first occasion when declines in both quarters will have exceeded 3 percent. The current consumption plunge is without precedent in the modern era.

Two recent studies have shown the promise of using data from search engines to provide early warning of influenza outbreaks -- and the pitfalls and limitations, as well. Privacy considerations aside, it is a technology that will need refinement if it is to be used by public health officials for early warning duties. One study, published by the journal Clinical Infectious Diseases, examined the relationship between searches for influenza-related terms on the Yahoo search engine and the actual occurrence of influenza over a four-year period in the United States. The searches spiked one to three weeks in advance of a sharp rise in laboratory cultures testing positive for influenza and up to five weeks in advance of a rise in mortality due to influenza.

In northern Maryland, Thanksgiving means it is time for the annual Greenspring Valley Hunt Club outing. It is described as a fox chase, not a fox hunt, but otherwise is in keeping with traditions going back for generations. The day began with a blessing of the hounds that drew more than 125 dogs and more than 50 horses. Then the hunt -- er chase -- was on.

ATLANTA wears its catchphrase ''the capital of the New South'' well because by the standards of Eastern cities it is just that -- new. Founded in 1837 as the end of a railroad line, nearly burned off the map during the Civil War and blossoming in the past few decades into a thriving business center, the city has a noticeable lack of history running through its traffic-clogged streets. Still, there is a way to catch a glimpse of the South's old patina in the gleaming boomtown. All you have to do is go shopping. Many fans of antiquing already know that Atlanta is fertile ground for both serious collectors and knickknack fanatics. What far fewer realize is that outside the urban island, in a handful of country towns where the feel of the Old South has hardly faded, more excellent shops offer pieces of the past for sale. In a few days of exploring, a shopper can gather some gems, taste unbeatable Southern cooking and stay in charming hotels, first in the city and then beyond.

RABKIN--Dorothea , who with her husband Leo Rabkin amassed a unique and highly influential collection of American whirligigs and folk sculpture, died at her Manhattan home on November 25 at the age of 87. Her death was confirmed by John Guiton, attorney and lifelong family friend. Born Dorothea Herz in Berlin, Germany, she emigrated to New York in 1949 ''with an empty suitcase,'' as she often described. She found employment initially as an expert on rare books in a variety of languages. Her natural connoisseurship found its life companion when she met her husband, artist Leo Rabkin, whom she married in 1958. Dorothea served on the Collections Committee of the American Folk Art Museum for many years. An accomplished cook, she was widely acknowledged for her skill in Chinese and European cuisine. She is survived by her husband. A memorial service is to be held at a later date.

We really need to start thinking about the way we throw around the word ''sustainable.'' In ''A Cabin Is Not a Shack,'' the writer speaks of a variety of cabins ''being reimagined in sustainable yet stylish ways.'' While it's better for the environment (and the owners) to use lower-cost reclaimed and recycled materials, and employ solar panels and other energy-saving devices, clearly there's more to consider before deeming something sustainable. Surely the size of the cabin and the amount of building materials used (even the gentler materials) has to count for something. No√´l Merino Seattle

F ROZEN squid was on the menu. Sardines, silver-skinned and dusted with frost, were already sliced up and on a plate. It was just after sunrise on a cool morning in late October, time to feed the fish at the Bonneville Seabase, an aquatic center in, of all places, the desert outside Grantsville, Utah. ''Hope the sharks are hungry,'' said Lynn Findlay, an employee, his hand outstretched and clenching raw meat. In the water below, from the pit of a saltwater spring called Habitat Bay, dark shapes were emerging from the deep.

HAVING polished off all the historic house tours within a hundred miles of New York City, I've found another way to satisfy my passion for prowling around sturdy and interesting old houses. All it takes is a car, some nerve, and the real estate listings on the Internet. Even as a child growing up in a 1950s split level on Long Island, I had a nose for cheap construction. That house, much as I loved it, gave me a lifelong antipathy toward hollow-core doors, streaky vinyl tiles and Formica. Then, in the '80s, I became immersed in six-over-six windows, decorative plasterwork and marble fireplaces. My husband and I bought a derelict Greek Revival in an iffy Brooklyn neighborhood, and then an 1850s mews house, eventually renovating each of them three times over. More recently, on my own, I've revivified two early 19th-century row houses in Philadelphia.

FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N . The members of the Council of the Grolier Club are deeply saddened by the loss of Helmut N. Friedlander, a member since 1975, counselor from 1987 to 1999, and an Honorary Member of the Grolier Club since 1999. We will sorely miss the friendship, guidance and sage advice of this extraordinary bookman, and our condolences go to his family and his many friends in the world of books. FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut. American Securities is deeply saddened by the death of our former leader, friend and colleague, Helmut N. Friedlaender, who died yesterday in Maine at the age of 95. Helmut was a well-known book collector, investment banker and retired senior financial advisor to the William Rosenwald family. Born on June 17, 1913 in Berlin, Germany, Helmut joined William Rosenwald in 1944. As the Rosenwald interests and activities expanded, he headed an ever - growing organization and served on a number of Boards of Directors of public and private corporations. Helmut was a key factor in the financing of 1407 Broadway, the first skyscraper built in New York City after World War II; the purchase of the Empire State Building from the Raskob estate by the Rosenwald group; and the creation of Western Union International in 1963 under congressional mandate as an independent company. He was for 25 years an active member of the President's Council of the Center for International Studies at NYU Law School. From 1992 to 1996, he served on the Council of the Fellows of the Morgan Library and from 1984 to 1999 on that of the Grolier Club. In 2003, he became a member of the President's Council of the New York Public Library. In November 2005, Reg Carr, President of the Bodleian Library, Oxford, England, conferred the Bodleian Medal on him in recognition of his services to the book world. He was a founding member of the Friends of the Parker Library (Cambridge, England) in 2004. An active member of Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Helmut was a director of the AMETEK and Gumpel - Lury Foundations and President of the Eugen Friedlaender Foundation. For more that 50 years, Helmut served as Director of AMETEK, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange listed company, and was named a director emeritus after he stepped down from the board. He served as the first eastern director of the Union Stockyards of Omaha in their then 120year history and was also a director of numerous other companies. Helmut, his father, mother and sister left Germany within two months of Hitler's rise to power. Educated in Germany and Switzerland, where he obtained a Doctor of Law degree from Lausanne University, Helmut learned international arbitrage in London, England. On arrival in New York in 1936, he joined Abraham & Co. as Continental aribitageur. During World War II, he was a writer and announcer for NBC (the Voice of America). In 1944, Helmut became a U.S. citizen, joined the William Rosenwald family, and also married Ernestine Fried, a native New Yorker and longtime President of the Women's City Club of New York. She died in 1982. American Securities sends heartfelt condolences to Helmut's two daughters, Dr. Jane Lury of New York, and Judith G. Friedlaender and her husband, Yosi Yaari, and a granddaughter, Catherine Ann Friedlaender. Services will be held on Monday, December 1 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. >FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. died age 95 on November 25. Born in Berlin, he left Germany 2 months after Hitler rose to power in 1933. After completing a Doctorate of Law at the University of Lausanne, he learned international arbitrage in London and then began his career as a financier at Abraham & Co in New York. In 1944 he became Financial Advisor to William Rosenwald. He was instrumental in a range of transactions which helped to shape New York City: the financing of 1407 Broadway, the first skyscraper built in NY after WWII, the purchase of the Empire State Building by the Rosenwald group and the creation of Western Union International. He served as a Director and then Director Emeritus of AMETEK for over 50 years as well as, at various times, a director of the Union Stockyards of Omaha, Aeolian, American Banner Lines, Cherry-Burrell, Haveg Industries, Mangood and others. His traditional European education, which included 8 years of Greek and 10 years of Latin, led him to many avocations. For 25 years he served as a member of the President's Council of the NYU School of Law Center for International Studies. In 1970, he began collecting rare books, amassing a significant collection which was sold at auction at Christies in 1992. Almost immediately after the sale, he began collecting again, taking great pleasure in buying back some of his favorites at vastly lower prices, as he had managed to sell at the top of the market. Over the years, he served on the Council of Fellows of the Morgan Library, was elected an Honorary Member (one of 47 in its 124 year history) of the Grolier Club. In 2005, he was awarded the Bodleian Medal by the Bodleian Library of the University of Oxford, England, in recognition of his services to the book world. He was an active member of Congregation Shearith Israel. Mr. Friedlaender was married to Ernestine nee Fried from 1944 until her death in 1982. He is survived by his daughters Jane Lury of New York City, Judith Friedlaender of Yarmouth, Maine and Harpsden, England, and by his granddaughter Catherine Friedlaender of Salvador, Brazil. The funeral will be at Riverside Funeral Chapel in New York City on Monday, December 1st at 11:45. Burial will be private. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Eugen Friedlaender Foundation, Suite 1501, 60 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10165. FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. The Board of Directors of AMETEK, Inc. expresses their deepest sorrow at the passing of their esteemed colleague and friend, Helmut, and offers their heartfelt sympathy to his family. Hal was an individual of unquestioned character and integrity. He served as a Director of AMETEK for more than 50 years, and, while his business achievements were impressive, his personal stature is best measured by his public spiritedness and generosity. Hal long and actively supported a wide range of public and private causes. Hal's long association with AMETEK began in 1955, when he was elected to the Board of Directors. Since then, his contributions to AMETEK have been innumerable. Five AMETEK Chairmen and Chief Executive Officers have benefited from his wisdom and counsel during his five decades on its board. His understanding of the business and financial worlds has been an invaluable asset to the Company and its shareholders. Indeed, in its nearly 80-year history, there probably has not been a single individual who has had a greater, or more positive, impact on AMETEK than Hal Friedlaender.

SCHOENFELD--Gerald . Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) mourns Jerry, a great man of the theater and for all the arts. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Artists, Board, Staff, Musicians and stage crews of Lincoln Center Theater sadly mourn the sudden and untimely death of our greatly admired friend and beloved chairman of the Shubert Organization, who for the last thirty-five years has fearlessly and valiantly advanced the interests of the theater, the entire theater, Broadway, the Road, off-Broadway, the notfor-profits of New York and throughout the United States, and wherever theatrical enterprise and creativity were poking their way through the surface of everyday life. During the 70s he was a veritable Carrie Nation of his time extirpating the forces of darkness and evil and turning on the lights of the Broadway marquees to the brightness of the best years. The Shubert Foundation has been a fountain of hope and sustenance providing funds for theaters throughout the country with subsidies greater than those of the National Endowment for the Arts. He was an exemplary person of the theater and we extend condolences to his beloved wife Patricia, his daughter, Carrie and the grandchildren, to President of the Shubert Organization Philip J. Smith and all his colleagues at The Shubert Organization and The Shubert Foundation. Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer John Beinecke, Chairman Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman Emeritus John Chalsty, President SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Actors Fund deeply mourns the loss of Gerald Schoenfeld, a tireless champion for everyone in the performing arts and entertainment professions. Through both The Shubert Organization and The Shubert Foundation, Jerry raised millions of dollars for The Actors Fund, allowing us to continually provide assistance to our colleagues in need. His constant and unbending support will be greatly missed. Brian Stokes Mitchell, President Joe Benincasa, Executive Director SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Jerry enriched New York, its cultural institutions, and the theater worldwide. He enriched our lives even more. We celebrate his life and mourn his passing. Our love and sympathy go to our beloved Pat and to Carrie, Fiore, Julia, and Sam. Marjorie, Jeffrey, Andrew, and Daniel SCHOENFELD--Gerald. We mourn the loss of a great leader, a faultless partner, and a beloved friend. Our profound sympathies extend to Pat and the family at this time of profound loss. Scott Rudin and John Barlow SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Peter Martins and the Board of Directors of the New York City Ballet mourn the passing of Gerald Schoenfeld. A former member of the NYCB Board of Directors, and a longtime friend to the Company, he cared deeply not only about the arts, but about their viability as successful businesses. All of us in the performing arts are forever grateful for his many contributions to our field, and we extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Pat and family. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. Teacher, adviser, supporter, colleague, mentor and inspiration. The faculty, staff, students and alumni of the Columbia University School of the Arts Theatre Program remember Gerald Schoenfeld with love, respect and gratitude. Along with Bernard Jacobs, he revitalized theatre at Columbia University and founded our Shubert Internship program. He was an adjunct professor, teaching Friday afternoons for almost 30 years, and influenced a legion of theatre producers, managers, directors, dramaturgs and playwrights who are currently making theatre in New York City, across the country and around the world. No matter how busy he was, he always found time for his students, past and present, and he took great pleasure in their success. Friday afternoons will never be the same. We will all miss him greatly. Steven Chaikelson, Chair, Theatre Program; Carol Becker, Dean, School of the Arts SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The family of the late Gerald Schoenfeld request that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in his name to The Fund for Public Schools (52 Chambers St., Room 305, NY, NY 10007) to help support arts education initiatives that were so important to Jerry. The family will receive visitors at the Schoenfeld residence on Sunday, November 30th from 4pm to 8pm. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The artists, staff and Board of New York Theatre Workshop are deeply saddened by the loss of Gerald Schoenfeld. He was an extraordinary man of the theater, his impact on the New York theatrical community has been immense. SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The Board and Staff of The Shubert Foundation deeply mourn the passing of our Chairman whose vision and leadership inspired us endlessly and lives on through the exceptional philanthropy of the Foundation; it is a mission we feel privileged to serve. His passionate efforts to keep the art form of theatre alive will long be manifest on the lit stages of notfor-profit theatres nationwide. We will cherish the countless occasions on which we were treated to his wit, wisdom, storytelling and poetry recitations, and take comfort that his legacy will loom large as an ongoing tribute to this extraordinary man. Our heartfelt condolences go to Pat, Carrie, Fiore, Sam and Julia. The Board and Staff of The Shubert Foundation SCHOENFELD--Gerald. No matter how high and far you went in life, you never forgot your law school classmates. You gave a helping hand when it was most needed. Thank you. Love, A. Joseph Tandet SCHOENFELD--Gerald. The board, volunteers, staff and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City mourn the death of Gerald Schoenfeld and offer our condolences to Pat, the family, The Shubert Organization, and The Shubert Foundation. Gerald Schoenfeld and the Bernard Jacobs always reserved a special place at their bountiful, generous table for people with disabilities and we remember both of them with our heartfelt thanks. Martin C. Hausman, Chairman Jerome Belson, President Edward R. Matthews, CEO Ronald J. H. Napal, Chief Development Officer

My Sunday column is about acid attacks on women in Asia. These represent a kind of brutality that never gets much attention but that certainly constitutes terrorism if you're a woman in Pakistan, Afghanistan, India, Bangladesh or Cambodia -- the main countries where the attacks occur. I had already written a draft when the Mumbai attacks occurred, but the acid underscores a different kind of terrorism that never gets attention (without of course taking anything away from the horror of what did unfold in Mumbai). And do look at the video of Naeema, it should be just to the right of this post, and also on the left side of the column itself online; video has a power to build empathy that print sometimes does not.

The educated guess is that the terrorists behind the Mumbai attacks were from Lashkar-e-Taiba or Jaish-e-Muhammad, both Pakistani groups that have focused on Kashmir. The result is that we face a real danger of escalating tensions that will be bad for India and bad for Pakistan and Afghanistan. The risk is that Indian nationalists, such as the hot-headed chief minister of Gujarat, Narendra Modi, use the Mumbai attacks to gain ground and be more confrontational toward Pakistan. That in turn would empower Pakistani nationalists and radicals, and we would see more terror attacks in Pakistan and India alike. Moreover, since Afghanistan is one of the fields of competition between India and Pakistan, Afghan's future would be compromised as well.

President Mikheil Saakashvili, left, testified Friday for nearly five hours at a government commission on the August war with Russia, saying that ordering an attack on Tskhinvali, the capital of the breakaway region of South Ossetia, was ''the most difficult decision I've ever made.'' Testifying in Tbilisi, Georgia's capital, he contradicted testimony this week by Erosi Kitsmarishvili, Georgia's former envoy to Moscow. Mr. Kitsmarishvili said Georgian leaders believed in the spring that they had received a ''green light'' from American officials to take back Abkhazia, another separatist region, by force, and that this had encouraged them to act in South Ossetia. The president countered that he ''did not seek a green light from anyone'' before starting the campaign, which he said had prevented ethnic massacres and the toppling of his government. ''The decision was taken by us independently,'' he said. ELLEN BARRY

KARP--Martin E., age 86, considered among his greatest life achievements the raising, with his wife Naomi, of three loving and accomplished children; his participation as a naval officer following WWII in the delivery of life-saving cargo to war-torn countries around the world; and his success as chairman of the Action Committee for Reasonable Real Estate Taxes and Board Member of the New York Council for Cooperatives and Condominiums in the passage of legislation for equitable taxation. Martin was a graduate of CCNY and elected to Tau Beta Pi, the national engineering honor society. His professional career began as a quality control engineer for General Electric and culminated as a Corporate V.P. at ITT. He was a past president of Congregation Beth El in Norwalk, Connecticut and served for 17 years on the Board of his NYC co-op, including terms as president and treasurer. He was predeceased by his brother Irwin Karp, Esq., and leaves his wife of 60 years, his children, Betsy, Leslie and Jonathan and their partners, six grandchildren, one greatgrandchild, as well as nieces, nephews, cousins and good friends. Funeral services will be held at 10am at the Plaza Funeral Home at 91st and Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday November 30th, followed by interment at congregation Beth El Cemetery, Richards Avenue, Norwalk, Connecticut.

FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. A great public citizen and private man whose combination of superior intelligence, broad experience, and depth of feeling made him wise. Accomplished and brilliant, but never an elitist, Hal knew that the good of one is linked with the good of all. SPERRY--Ann, sculptor and feminist, died peacefully at home on November 27 of leiomyosarcoma. By her side were her husband, tenor Paul Sperry, sons Ethan, Joshua, and Raphael, daughters-inlaw Siri, Ilinisa, and Laura, and grandchildren Max, Cayesh, Milo, Solomon, Rebecca, and Diran. She will be sorely missed by her family and many recent and life-long friends. Ann's steel sculptures transformed toughness into softness, femininity and beauty. They adorn the collections of the Storm King Arts Center, the Skirball Museums in Los Angeles and Cincinnati, the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis and many others; her large sitespecific sculptures are installed in Seattle, Boston, Aspen, and other places. She served on the board of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts and the Sculpture Center (contributions to either would be welcome) as well as in political campaigns from Eugene McCarthy's to Barack Obama's. A memorial service will be announced.

Chosen for: White House staff secretary Brings to the job: A lawyer's eye for detail to an office that experts describe as the nerve center of the White House. She will be the gatekeeper for nearly every piece of paper that reaches the president's desk.

Is known for his passion in fighting for unions and on income inequality issues. Serves as board chairman of American Rights at Work, a pro-labor group.

Weber, predeceased her in 2007. She is survived by her children, Carl, Ellen, and Joy Weber, and Marilyn Marsden, 10 grandchildren, and 18 great - grandchildren. The funeral service will be held on Sunday November 30, 2008 beginning at 9am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, New York, NY 10024 (212-769-4400). Being considered for: Climate czarina, a new position Would bring to the job: Strong r√©sum√© in environmental protection, law and management consulting, and a clear determination to break from the Bush record, which she has called ''the worst environmental administration ever.'' She was administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency under President Bill Clinton for nearly eight years, the longest anyone has held that position.

TESCHNER--Merle Freya (nee Berkowitz), 74, died the morning of Thursday, November 27, 2008 at the Kindred Hospital of Morris County in Dover, NJ. Mrs. Teschner was born November 13, 1934 at St. Mary's Hospital, Orange, NJ to Betty Berkowitz (nee Marcus) (Jordan) and Max Louis Berkowitz. Mrs. Teschner received a B.S. in Education from Montclair University in 1957 and an M.S. in Special Education from Columbia University in 1969. She began a program leading to a Ph.D. in Education, which was never completed. She taught at the Willis School, Plainfield, NJ and when it closed she and a group of dedicated teachers founded the Center School for children with learning disabilities. There she taught and was a Board Member. The school is now located in Highland Park, NJ. At the Center School, Mrs. Teschner taught the first class for preschool children with learning disabilities in NJ. She later completed the requirements for and was designated a Learning Disabled Teacher-Consultant. In 1985, Mrs. Teschner left Center School and returned to teaching in public schools in New Brunswick, NJ where she taught at grade school levels 5-8. She also was certified to teach at levels preschool to 12. Mrs. Teschner is survived by her husband David Teschner; a son Michael H. Teschner; a daughter-in-law Dona S. Teschner; a daughter Allison Scott Teschner and a granddaughter Cassandra Ryan Teschner. Mrs. Teschner will be entombed at the Temple of Israel Memorial Mausoleum in Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Services will be held at the Mausoleum on Sunday, November 30, 2008 at 11am.

Mississippi State Coach Sylvester Croom has resigned after five years at the college. He was the first black head football coach in the Southeastern Conference. Croom resigned a day after 45-0 loss to No. 25 Mississippi in a rivalry game. Croom led the Bulldogs to an 8-5 finish and the Liberty Bowl in 2007. But the team struggled a year later, finishing 4-8. Croom went 21-38 overall.

Daniel B. Smith‚Äôs wonderful profile of Lewis Hyde (Nov. 16) refers to ‚Äúthe so-called Copy Left‚Äù when describing people who wish to limit the scope and terms of copyright protection. The interview with Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice (Helene Cooper and Scott L. Malcomson, Nov. 16) underscores the shortsightedness (if not downright blindness) of the foreign policy of the Bush administration. Regarding the changes of government in Lebanon, Ukraine and Georgia, Rice thinks that the only problem with those ‚Äúrevolutions‚Äù is that people expect too much too soon. But the more fundamental problem is that a successful democracy requires strong institutions to survive and deliver a better life for its citizens. None of those countries have such institutions. As a result, beginning the democratization process by holding elections before such institutions are built is likely to lead to chaos and poverty, widening the gulf between rich and poor. What has actually transpired in these countries over the last few years demonstrates this point.

So there is money to be raised.

COHEN--Raye, former NYC Legal Secretary. Raye Cohen (nee Rotter) formally of Monticello, New York and Queens, New York passed away on Friday, November 28, 2008 after a long illness. Raye was born in Poland in 1924 and moved to the United States shortly thereafter. She was raised in Brooklyn where she met her lifetime best friend, Rose Pesetzner. Raye was the second of six children born to Chaim Zev Rotter and Devorah Perel Rotter. After marrying Arnold Cohen (deceased), Raye moved to Monticello, NY and raised their three children, Joel, Rhonda and Amy. While in Monticello, Raye was employed as a legal secretary to Mal Cohen, Esq. In 1978 Raye moved to Queens and was employed as legal secretary to John Gardner Esq., of the NYC Law Firm of Bower and Gardner. Raye retired to Florida in 1987. Raye was a loving mother and devoted her life to her children and grandchildren. Raye was known for her non judgemental personality and her ability to make friends and conversation with anyone. She enjoyed reading, doing crossword puzzles, playing scrabble and spending time with her children and grandchildren. Raye is survived by her three children, Joel Cohen, Rhonda O'Leary and Amy Rosenthal, as well as five grandchildren, Ahron Rosenthal, Malky Ben David, Leba Rosenthal, Anne O'Leary and Andrew O'Leary and her great - grandchild, Tova Rosenthal. Raye is also survived by her life long best friend, Rose Pesetzner. Raye was laid to rest on Friday, November 28, 2008 at the New Montefiore Cemetery in West Babylon, NY. She was 84 years old.

HORAN--Hubert J. III, former banker, died on November 25, 2008 at the age of 86. He was born on January 13, 1922, in Philadelphia, PA. His father was the President of the Continental Bank of Philadelphia and a longtime civic leader in Philadelphia. He served in the 1st Armored Division in WWII, awarded the Purple Heart. He graduated in 1948 from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. He married Mary Ellen McNichol in 1954. They resided in Chestnut Hill, PA, and Scarsdale, NY. He had a long career as a banker with the Fidelity Trust Company and Continental Bank, Philadelphia; President, Scarsdale National Bank; Peoples Bank for Savings and Manhattan Saving Bank. Hubert and Mary Ellen moved to Williamsburg, VA, where he taught at the Christopher Wren Association. Mary Ellen Horan died from cancer in 1994. Hubert was a dedicated Democrat and ardent civil rights advocate. He was a skilled raconteur with an avid love of history and politics. He had an infectious personality and his generosity, capacity for friendship and dedication to social justice will be greatly missed. He is survived by Janet Wallace Horan, whom he married in 1997; his children Hubert Horan (Pamela Hamilton), Ellen Horan, Ted Horan (Barbara Horan), Casey Horan and Betsy Horan (Tom O'Malley); stepchildren Julee and Jim Kaplan; five grandchildren: Sara and Katie Horan, Ji Tan Haines, Grace and Henry O'Malley and step-grandchildren: Jamie, Claire and Thompson Kaplan. Funeral Services to be held on December 4, at 11am at The Catholic Chapel of the William and Mary Campus, 500 Richmond Rd., Williamsburg, VA 23185. In his memory donations can be given to Lamp Community, 527 Crocker St., Los Angeles, CA 90013, 213.488.0879.

NISSAN and Infiniti are the latest automakers to pull out of the North American International Auto Show, scheduled for Jan. 11-25 in downtown Detroit. Their withdrawals brought to seven the number of car companies that are skipping an event that has become North America's premier showcase for the industry. In addition, Honda said it was canceling its plan to have a formal press conference and product introduction at the show for the production version of its Insight hybrid sedan. Instead, Kurt Antonius, a Honda spokesman, said executives would be made available for interviews during the show.

THE FLORENCE OF E. M. FORSTER Enjoying Florence, Italy, can take endurance, with the throngs of tourists invading its narrow streets. But if you ditch the guide book and use ''A Room With a View'' by E. M. Forster, you will find it easier to get along. Written 100 years ago, the book reminds us that the Tuscan city is a capital of art, not just an overcrowded museum. Left, the skyline of Florence, dominated by the Duomo and Brunelleschi's Dome.

CROSSING THE SWISS ALPS ON THE BERNINA EXPRESS, Aug. 19, 2008 Ans Mooi, 64, a high school Latin and Greek teacher from Amsterdam. ''I have been a widow since 2001. I don't think that traveling is a 'healing' process; if you are grieving, you first have to come to terms with it, which takes time and rest. Only then can you open yourself to new impressions and start enjoying things again. Grief is like a wound, and you don't normally go on a holiday with a wound. But after a hard period of grief, I have come to enjoy life again. This photograph is from my holiday this summer, which was a combination of walking and enjoying Swiss trains with a group of 10 people. On the train you can hang out of the window, see all the bends come and go, and you're daydreaming happily like a child. I was pleasantly musing, enjoying the peace and beauty, and again and again I was astonished. To quote a Dutch author: 'When you are traveling, you live double,' and this is just my own experience too. You are happy, enjoying yourself, living more intensely and freely.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

THE NEWS Federal regulators announced a plan to shore up the teetering financial giant Citigroup, with the government investing about $20 billion directly and guaranteeing $306 billion in loans and securities on Citigroup's balance sheet. The company effectively suspended its dividend for three years and agreed to limit executives' pay. BEHIND THE NEWS Reports of the plan halted a punishing run on the stock of Citigroup, a company considered too big and central to the financial system to be allowed to fail. The next day, regulators announced $800 billion in new lending programs meant to ease credit strains on other banks and consumers and to push down mortgage rates.

KOEGEL--James Erwin, 91, of Armonk, NY, passed away November 27, 2008, in Purdys, NY, from complications following a fall at his home. He was born in Washington, D.C., on August 7, 1917, the son of Otto E. Koegel and Rae F. Koegel. His formative years were in Wilmette, IL, and Bronxville, NY. He attended Culver Military Academy and Bronxville High School and graduated from Williams College in the Class of 1939 and Fordham Law School 1942. He served in the Army in World War II and upon his discharge began the practice of law with Dwight, Harris, Koegel & Caskey in Manhattan. As an associate and partner he served in the corporate department of the firm until 1976 when he retired. The firm was then Rogers & Wells and is now Clifford Chance. In 1946 he married Christina N. Williams. She survives him as do his children, Christina K. Granrud of Kalispell, MT, Sarah N. Koegel of Armonk and James A. Koegel of Bedford, NY, as well as grandchildren, Phillip and Jennifer Granrud. He is also survived by sister, Ruth K. Macreery of Redding, CT and a brother, William Koegel of Somers, NY. For 27 years he had a home in Granite Springs, NY, on the large farm owned by the family for almost fifty years. He was a superb horseman and rode in many hunter and jumper classes in horse shows throughout Westchester. He continued to ride into his eighties. In Somers he was active in civic affairs and in development. He was Justice of the Peace from 1947 to 1962 and served as President of the Westchester County Magistrates Association. He also served as Chairman of the Red Cross drive for Somers/North Salem, as Chairman of the Westchester County Committee on Youth Services and Vice President of the United Way of Northern Westchester. He also developed a number of properties in Somers including West Somers Park in Granite Springs. He was an avid golfer and his Armonk home bordered the 15th green of the Whippoorwill Country Club to which he belonged. Jim was devoted to his family, his horses and golf, in that order, and he will be sorely missed. The service for him and the interment will be private.

RABKIN--Dorothea, who with her husband Leo Rabkin amassed a unique and highly influential collection of American whirligigs and folk sculpture, died at her Manhattan home on November 25 at the age of 87. Her death was confirmed by John Guiton, attorney and lifelong family friend. Born Dorothea Herz in Berlin, Germany, she emigrated to New York in 1949 ''with an empty suitcase,'' as she often described. She found employment initially as an expert on rare books in a variety of languages. Her natural connoisseurship found its life companion when she met her husband, artist Leo Rabkin, whom she married in 1958. Dorothea served on the Collections Committee of the American Folk Art Museum for many years. An accomplished cook, she was widely acknowledged for her skill in Chinese and European cuisine. She is survived by her husband. A memorial service is to be held at a later date.

MIRSKY--Irving. Born in Brooklyn, passed on November 25 at the age of 88 in West Palm Beach, surrounded by family. Beloved and loving husband of Adele (Berkowitz) for 67 years, father of Sheila Stalder, grandfather of Jason and Adam Mirsky, and David and Danielle Stalder, greatgrandfather of Alissa, Trevor, Alex, Sierra and Sam, brother of Lillian Levine, and wonderful uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by his beloved son Alan, parents Isidore and Dora (Gorenstein), brother Hyman and sister Besse (Wachtel). Irving proudly served as a First Lieutenant in Europe during WWII. Among his many talents, his greatest was his amazing ability to make people happy. His warmth, humor and love will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. Memorial services Sunday, 3pm at I.J. Morris, West Palm Beach, FL. 561-683-8676.

HOFF--Margo. Modernist artist Margo Hoff died Sunday, August 17th, in the Spartan, Manhattan loft which served as both her painting studio and home. She was 98 years old. Her work is in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Metropolitan, Art Institute of Chicago, the Victoria and Albert Museum (London), the Biblioteque Nationale (Paris) and many other public and private collections worldwide. Ms. Hoff was born (1910) and raised in Tulsa, Oklahoma. As a six-year-old she modeled small figures from the clay the well-drillers left behind. At 14 she won a silver medal in "Free Hand Drawing." After two years at the University of Tulsa, she relocated to Chicago to pursue the study of art. She first found success with her edgy, figurative work while still a student at the Art Institute of Chicago in the mid-1940s; a one-man show at the Wildenstein Galleries in Paris (1955) brought international recognition. She moved permanently to NYC in 1960, where her more abstract collage paintings attracted immediate institutional and critical attention; "The Crowd" (1960), a 40" x 30" paper collage and acrylic on canvas, was purchased by the Metropolitan Museum of Art that same year. She would later exhibit with Betty Parsons. As artist-in residence she taught at numerous American universities as well as in China, Brazil, Lebanon and Uganda. She is survived by a daughter, Mia, of Edinburgh, Scotland. A memorial service is pending. (More information about Margo Hoff's life and career is available at MargoHoff.com.)

KARP--Martin E., age 86, considered among his greatest life achievements the raising, with his wife Naomi, of three loving and accomplished children; his participation as a naval officer following WWII in the delivery of life-saving cargo to war-torn countries around the world; and his success as chairman of the Action Committee for Reasonable Real Estate Taxes and Board Member of the New York Council for Cooperatives and Condominiums in the passage of legislation for equitable taxation. Martin was a graduate of CCNY and elected to Tau Beta Pi, the national engineering honor society. His professional career began as a quality control engineer for General Electric and culminated as a Corporate V.P. at ITT. He was a past president of Congregation Beth El in Norwalk, Connecticut and served for 17 years on the Board of his NYC co-op, including terms as president and treasurer. He was predeceased by his brother Irwin Karp, Esq., and leaves his wife of 60 years, his children, Betsy, Leslie and Jonathan and their partners, six grandchildren, one greatgrandchild, as well as nieces, nephews, cousins and good friends. Funeral services will be held at 10am at the Plaza Funeral Home at 91st and Amsterdam Avenue, on Sunday November 30th, followed by interment at congregation Beth El Cemetery, Richards Avenue, Norwalk, Connecticut.

FAY--Richard J., New York investment banker and 50year resident of Pleasantville, New York, died Sunday, November 23, after a long illness. He was 86. Born and raised in Batavia, New York, Mr. Fay entered Syracuse University with the class of '44. He left a year before graduation to serve as an army infantry officer in World War II and graduated with the class of '48. Mr. Fay joined Goldman Sachs and Company in 1952 and was promoted to partner in 1962. A life-long lover of the Adirondacks, he served as a trustee of the Adirondack Museum in Blue Mountain Lake, New York. He also served for many years on the Syracuse University Board of Trustees. Mr. Fay's wife, Joann Olson Fay (Syracuse '44), died in 1991. He is survived by his three children, Stephen Fay of Newtown, CT; Laurence Fay of Katonah, NY; Wendy Starling of Blue Mt. Lake, NY and Queensbury, NY; and three grandchildren, Sara, Aron and Chelsea Fay. The family will receive friends at the Beecher Funeral Home, Inc. in Pleasantville on Monday December 1st from 2-4 and 7-9pm. A Funeral Service will be held at the funeral home on Tuesday at 11am. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to the Adirondack Museum and The Richard J. and Joann Olson Fay Scholarship Fund of Syracuse University.

Should the Kremlin open up the archives of Stalin's security services, which have become increasingly off limits since Vladimir V. Putin took power in Russia? Or would such unfettered access inflame tensions over issues that should be put to rest? And how should Russians today regard the darkest chapters of Soviet history? Russian bloggers debated those questions after reading a version of an article that appeared in The New York Times on Thursday that described how the Kremlin has prevented researchers from examining the security archives and has often played down the atrocities of Stalin's time. A translation of the article was posted on a Russian-language blog run by The Times on livejournal.com It received more than 750 comments.

McKELVEY--Andrew. The staff members of Roads to Success are saddened by the passing of our founder and benefactor, Andrew McKelvey, whose generosity and leadership led to the creation of our program. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and friends. McKELVEY--Andrew J., loving father, generous friend, philanthropist, entrepreneur and the founder and CEO of Monster Worldwide, died November 27, 2008 after a lengthy battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan. In 1967, using borrowed office space and a part time assistant, Andy started Telephone Marketing Programs, which grew to capture 30% of the United States national yellow pages advertising business. In the early 1990s, TMP expanded into newspaper help wanted advertising and in 1995, TMP acquired The Monster Board, the world's 454th website which became Monster.com. Andy believed that if you make money in this country, you have an obligation to give it back. His success enabled him to support and fund several charitable endeavors. The McKelvey Foundation has thus far supported over 600 students to attend college. Since 2001, he has generously funded the Andrew J. McKelvey Lung Transplant Center at Emory University in Atlanta, GA. He has also provided funds for the Andrew J. McKelvey Lower School at the Hewitt School in Manhattan. In addition, he provided funding for Big Brothers Big Sisters of America and for the Andrew J. McKelvey Campus Center at Westminster College in PA, his alma mater. Andy worked with our nations elected officials on initiatives such as Americans for Gun Safety and the 9/11 educational fund, Families for Freedom. Andy was equally passionate, disciplined and determined in business and in his personal life. He was a lifelong entrepreneur, starting his first business at age 11. He lived by his own rules and believed that ''timing is everything.'' He was humble, trusting, generous, curious and driven. He was also an adventurer who traveled to every continent, often organizing exotic trips with all of his closest friends and family. Andy will be greatly missed and is loved by his four children: Geoffrey, Stuart, Christine, Amanda as well as his six grandchildren: Zachery, Dylan, Gray, Andrew, Siena and Alex. A memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in to either of the following charities, which he was very passionate about. McKelvey Foundation, 200 Park Ave., 44 Floor, New York, NY 10166. The McKelvey Center at Emory University, 1364 Clifton Road, NE, Room F-520, Atlanta, GA 30322.

To the Editor: Your ''36 Hours'' column about Santa Barbara (Nov. 16) missed one of Santa Barbara's best attributes. Santa Barbara is the rare small American city that is easy and pleasant to visit without a car. In fact, Santa Barbara is the even rarer city that encourages and rewards visitors without a car. You can get to Santa Barbara on Amtrak's Pacific Surfliner, which runs five trains a day from Los Angeles (most trains also serve San Diego).

CROSSMAN--Edgar Orrin II, of New York City and Goshen, CT died on November 26th at his home in New York City after four long years with esophageal cancer. Eddie was born in New York City, the son of Edgar G. Crossman and Helen Farrell Crossman. He is survived by his wife, Ann Marie (Flynn) Crossman, his two brothers, Patrick Farrell Crossman of New York and John Gibson Crossman of San Diego, and by his four sons from a previous marriage, Edgar Orrin Crossman III of Beijing, China; William Labrot Crossman of Spring Island, SC; Timothy Farrell Crossman of Brunswick, GA; Patrick Scott Crossman of Annapolis, MD and six grandchildren. His son Peter Gibson Crossman predeceased him. Eddie was born March 14th, 1930 in New York City where he attended St. Bernard's School before going to Groton School. He graduated from Yale in 1953 and was the bow oar in the winning boat in the four mile hundredth anniversary Yale Harvard race in 1952. Eddie spent his working life on Wall Street, first with J.P. Morgan, then with Clark Dodge & Company and then Kidder Peabody & Company from which he retired as a vicepresident in 1982. As a noncommissioned officer, he commanded an M4 Sherman tank in the Third Armored Calvary Regiment, ''Brave Rifles'' in Fort Meade, GA. He was a member of the Yale Club, the Balsam Lake Club, Squadron A, and the City Midday Club where he was president for a number of years. Eddie loved fly fishing, all of the outdoors and especially being at his home in Connecticut. He will be remembered and missed by his family and many friends for his bonhomie and enthusiastic love of life. Burial will be in Litchfield, CT. A Memorial service is planned for January 5, 2009 at 2:00pm at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, New York, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Goshen Land Trust, 16 Mill Street, Goshen, CT 06756.

In recent weeks, two larger-than-life personalities, the basketball star Shaquille O'Neal and the right-wing Israeli politician Benjamin Netanyahu, joined the social-networking site Twitter, allowing them to send frequent messages to fans who subscribe to their ''tweets.'' With its strict limit on the length of messages (roughly two sentences) and ease of transmission, Twitter was created to allow people to update friends with the answer to the age-old question, ''What are you doing?'' It is the kind of correspondence usually reserved for friends who use a cellphone to textmessage over the choice of a restaurant. With the arrival of Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. O'Neal, Twitter is providing an intimate glimpse into the life and thoughts of the rich and famous. Be careful what you wish for. NOAM COHEN

Classical Allan Kozinn

Nobuyoshi Araki and Sawa Suzuki make a splendid pair. He is one of Japan's most infamous art photographers, known for his vision of erotica -- sexy, color-saturated close-ups of flowers, overripe fruit and overripe geishas, not to mention nubile young wom en tied up into explicit knots. She, on the other hand, is notorious for her roles in Japanese films like ''New Love in Tokyo'' (she plays a girl who is both amateur actress and professional dominatrix), ''Watch Me'' and ''Karaoke Terror.'' (It should come as no shock that Quentin Tarantino is a fan of her work.) Here, Araki and Suzuki come together to play out their own rendition of ''Belle de Jour,'' Luis Bu√±uel's 1967 cult classic. Suzuki steps into a specially selected fall wardrobe and Catherine Deneuve's legendary shoes as S√©verine Serizy, a sexually repressed housewife who finds an outlet from her stultifying bourgeois marriage in a day job as a high-class call girl. Fashionwise, it's certainly the right moment -- rife with ladylike dresses and skirt suits in a conservative palette of black, beige, gray and white, undercut by subtly kinky details like a keyhole back, a touch of plumage or lace, even the occasional bondage strap.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Dog Show's Best Friend,'' Nov. 27: Uno is, indeed, a beagle who leads a charmed life. Tell that to the purebred beagle puppy I saw last week at the Oyster Bay animal shelter. Or to all of the other purebred beagles who wind up in shelters or medical labs. The American Kennel Club, which is merely a registering organization, enables puppy mills and backyard breeders to churn out purebred dogs, most of whom will not find homes. For every Uno, there are a thousand more who will be killed or abandoned. Judith Zinn

METHOD: These days Jessica Fridrich teaches electrical and computer engineering at the State University of New York at Binghamton, where she specializes in digital forensics. But she's best known for having discovered the popular Fridrich method of cube-solving in the early '80s. And the knack has stayed with her: she's still among the fastest cubers in the world. See the Fridrich spread here: www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/cube.html BIG BOX: The real one-stop for Rubik's Cube magic isrubiks.com. There are other cube sites, but this one just has it all: tournament information, videos, a preview for the documentary ''Cubers'' and an online Rubik's academy. Make it your home page? Lively YouTube channels include: Michael Gottlieb's Cubing (qqwref2) and Rob's World (RobH0629).

SPERRY--Ann, sculptor and feminist, died peacefully at home on November 27 of leiomyosarcoma. By her side were her husband, tenor Paul Sperry, sons Ethan, Joshua, and Raphael, daughters-inlaw Siri, Ilinisa, and Laura, and grandchildren Max, Cayesh, Milo, Solomon, Rebecca, and Diran. She will be sorely missed by her family and many recent and life-long friends. Ann's steel sculptures transformed toughness into softness, femininity and beauty. They adorn the collections of the Storm King Arts Center, the Skirball Museums in Los Angeles and Cincinnati, the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis and many others; her large sitespecific sculptures are installed in Seattle, Boston, Aspen, and other places. She served on the board of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts and the Sculpture Center (contributions to either would be welcome) as well as in political campaigns from Eugene McCarthy's to Barack Obama's. A memorial service will be announced.
To the Sports Editor: Re '' 'Sports in This City Are Just Terrible,' '' Nov. 21: The article moaning about the state of sports in Seattle missed an important factor. Not all sports are men's sports.

VEG--Ervin, died November 22, 2008 at his home Paris, France. Loving husband to Anja Klabunde Veg, beloved father of Sebastian and Nicholas. Ervin was born in Budapest, Hungry on July 19, 1936. A graduate of Baruch College of City College of New York. He was a senior executive in charge of the signing and recording of classical music in both Western and Eastern Europe, at CBS Masterworks, which then merged into Sony Classical. Ervin, for the past ten years was the musical director-Impresario of the Stressa Music Festival. A renowned water polo player, he was on the United States water polo team participating twice in the Olympics and in the Maccabi Games. Further, he was a member of the New York Athletic Club and a member and Captain of their water polo team. It was through Ervin that hundreds of New Yorkers were able to make dinner reservations in Paris at the restaurant L'ami Louis. Ervin was a cigar aficionado and had a vast collection of the world's finest cigars. Services were held on November 29, 2008 at Cemetery Pere Lachaise Crematorium Paris, France. Sue and Stephen A Levy Howard Miller and Lee Miller

FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. A great public citizen and private man whose combination of superior intelligence, broad experience, and depth of feeling made him wise. A man with an unparalleled joie de vivre, with an elegant exterior that clothed a tender and loving heart. A devoted and loyal friend. Accomplished and brilliant, but never an elitist, Hal knew that the good of one is linked with the good of all. His ability to love people, the world, and life itself continues to inspire all of us whose lives he touched. Nora Lavori, Liana and Alex Sterling FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. died age 95 on November 25. Born in Berlin, he left Germany 2 months after Hitler rose to power in 1933. After completing a Doctorate of Law at the University of Lausanne, he learned international arbitrage in London and then began his career as a financier at Abraham & Co in New York. In 1944 he became Financial Advisor to William Rosenwald. He was instrumental in a range of transactions which helped to shape New York City: the financing of 1407 Broadway, the first skyscraper built in NY after WWII, the purchase of the Empire State Building by the Rosenwald group and the creation of Western Union International. He served as a Director and then Director Emeritus of AMETEK for over 50 years as well as, at various times, a director of the Union Stockyards of Omaha, Aeolian, American Banner Lines, Cherry-Burrell, Haveg Industries, Mangood and others. His traditional European education, which included 8 years of Greek and 10 years of Latin, led him to many avocations. For 25 years he served as a member of the President's Council of the NYU School of Law Center for International Studies. In 1970, he began collecting rare books, amassing a significant collection which was sold at auction at Christies in . 2001. Almost immediately after the sale, he began collecting again, taking great pleasure in buying back some of his favorites at vastly lower prices, as he had managed to sell at the top of the market. Over the years, he served on the Council of Fellows of the Morgan Library, was elected an Honorary Member (one of 47 in its 124 year history) of the Grolier Club. In 2005, he was awarded the Bodleian Medal by the Bodleian Library of the University of Oxford, England, in recognition of his services to the book world. He was an active member of Congregation Shearith Israel. Mr. Friedlaender was married to Ernestine nee Fried from 1944 until her death in 1982. He is survived by his daughters Jane Lury of New York City, Judith Friedlaender of Yarmouth, Maine and Harpsden, England, and by his granddaughter Catherine Friedlaender of Salvador, Brazil. The funeral will be at Riverside Funeral Chapel in New York City on Monday, December 1st at 11:45. Burial will be private. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Eugen Friedlaender Foundation, Suite 1501, 60 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10165. FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut. American Securities is deeply saddened by the death of our former leader, friend and colleague, Helmut N. Friedlaender, who died yesterday in Maine at the age of 95. Helmut was a well-known book collector, investment banker and retired senior financial advisor to the William Rosenwald family. Born on June 17, 1913 in Berlin, Germany, Helmut joined William Rosenwald in 1944. As the Rosenwald interests and activities expanded, he headed an ever - growing organization and served on a number of Boards of Directors of public and private corporations. Helmut was a key factor in the financing of 1407 Broadway, the first skyscraper built in New York City after World War II; the purchase of the Empire State Building from the Raskob estate by the Rosenwald group; and the creation of Western Union International in 1963 under congressional mandate as an independent company. He was for 25 years an active member of the President's Council of the Center for International Studies at NYU Law School. From 1992 to 1996, he served on the Council of the Fellows of the Morgan Library and from 1984 to 1999 on that of the Grolier Club. In 2003, he became a member of the President's Council of the New York Public Library. In November 2005, Reg Carr, President of the Bodleian Library, Oxford, England, conferred the Bodleian Medal on him in recognition of his services to the book world. He was a founding member of the Friends of the Parker Library (Cambridge, England) in 2004. An active member of Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Helmut was a director of the AMETEK and Gumpel - Lury Foundations and President of the Eugen Friedlaender Foundation. For more that 50 years, Helmut served as Director of AMETEK, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange listed company, and was named a director emeritus after he stepped down from the board. He served as the first eastern director of the Union Stockyards of Omaha in their then 120year history and was also a director of numerous other companies. Helmut, his father, mother and sister left Germany within two months of Hitler's rise to power. Educated in Germany and Switzerland, where he obtained a Doctor of Law degree from Lausanne University, Helmut learned international arbitrage in London, England. On arrival in New York in 1936, he joined Abraham & Co. as Continental aribitageur. During World War II, he was a writer and announcer for NBC (the Voice of America). In 1944, Helmut became a U.S. citizen, joined the William Rosenwald family, and also married Ernestine Fried, a native New Yorker and longtime President of the Women's City Club of New York. She died in 1982. American Securities sends heartfelt condolences to Helmut's two daughters, Dr. Jane Lury of New York, and Judith G. Friedlaender and her husband, Yosi Yaari, and a granddaughter, Catherine Ann Friedlaender. Services will be held on Monday, December 1 at 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. The family of William and Mary Rosenwald deeply mourn the passing of Helmut N. (Hal) Friedlaender, our partner and advisor, an extraordinary investor and a great man, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. From 1944 through the next 40 years, Hal brilliantly guided the family's investments and investment bank, then known as American Securities Corporation. Hal's goal was to create opportunities with a defined limited risk and an unlimited potential, building such businesses as Western Union International and AMETEK, Inc. We celebrate Hal for his integrity, his values, and his enjoyment of life. We are forever grateful for his visionary guidance and his deep friendship. He continues to inspire us. Nina Rosenwald Elizabeth R. Varet Alice Rosenwald

AN exhibition examining the evolution of automotive design since the 1930s opened here last week at the Petersen Automotive Museum. The exhibition, ''Imagining the Future: The Southern California Automotive Design Studio,'' includes, of all things, a functioning transportation design studio, created by the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena.

STURKEN--Robert C., 89, passed away at his home in Princeton, NJ on November 24, 2008. He was an engineer and executive who pioneered paper - coating technology used worldwide. Born and raised in Brooklyn, he received an engineering degree in 1940 from the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, and did graduate work at Columbia and Yale. During WWII, while at DuPont, he worked on a classified government project developing anti-radar technology. In 1950 he joined the Egan Machinery Company of Somerville, NJ as a partner, becoming vice president and CFO. His design for an extrusion coating machine received a US patent in 1952, forming the basis for a line of paper and plastic coating machines licensed internationally. He later worked as an engineering and management consultant and in 1980 was elected to the board of directors of the New Jersey Savings Bank of Somerville. He served as a trustee of Stevens Institute and president of its alumni association, and on the boards of directors of the Unitarian Church of Princeton and the Friends of the New Jersey State Museum. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, the artist Marie Sturken (nee Ryan); his son Carl and daughter-in-law CherylAnne Sturken of Katonah; daughters and sons-in-law Barbara and William Peterson of Hastings on Hudson, and Marita Sturken and Dana Polan of Manhattan; grandchildren Kelly and Kyra Sturken, Leigh and Moira Peterson, and Leo-Andres Polan. A memorial service is scheduled for 1pm on Saturday, December 13 at the Unitarian Church, Princeton followed by a reception at the Nassau Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Princeton Area Community Foundation, 15 Princess Rd., Lawrenceville, NJ 08648.

SALEM--Patricia Marand. Tony Award nominated Broadway star, Patricia Marand, who graced the stage opposite such theatre greats as Yul Brynner, Alfred Drake, Jack Cassidy and Dan Dailey, passed away on November 27th, due to brain cancer. Marand was nominated for the Tony Award in 1966 for her role as Lois Lane in the Hal Prince - directed Broadway production of ''It's a Bird, It's a Plane, It's Superman,'' composed by Charles Strouse which The New York Times once called ''the best musical of the season.'' A statuesque, red haired beauty with an unforgettable rich and melodic soprano voice, Marand's performances epitomized Broadway theatre with memorable grace and style. Marand began her career in the hey-days of Broadway playing leading roles in ''Wish You Were Here,'' ''Kiss Me Kate,'' ''Pajama Game,'' ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''Oklahoma,'' ''Man of La Mancha,'' ''Kismet'' and ''South Pacific,'' to name a few. While the Broadway stage was her true home, Marand's voice enchanted thousands in acclaimed concert solos with the Chicago, Cleveland, Pittsburgh, New Haven and Minneapolis symphony orchestras, as well as during engagements at the Cotillion Room at New York's Hotel Pierre and La Maisonette at the St. Regis. She frequently appeared on television on the Merv Griffin, Johnny Carson and Ed Sullivan shows. She also appeared recently on the small screen as Helen Barone in ''The Sopranos.'' A native New Yorker, Marand always lit up the room at operas, theaters, charitable benefits and political events around the world. Daughter of the late Patrick and Justine Marandino, she leaves behind her loving husband and love of her life, Irving Salem, brother Robert, sister-in-law Joan, nephew Rob, and nieces Missy, Kimberly and Cristin. Viewing will be held Tuesday, December 2, 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, (212) 288-3500, with funeral services Wednesday, December 3rd, 10am at St. Monica's Church, 413 East 79th Street, (212)288-6250. Private burial to be held at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Harrison, New York.
