HOFF--Margo. Modernist artist Margo Hoff died Sunday, August 17th, in the Spartan, Manhattan loft which served as both her painting studio and home. She was 98 years old. Her work is in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Metropolitan, Art Institute of Chicago, the Victoria and Albert Museum (London), the Biblioteque Nationale (Paris) and many other public and private collections worldwide. Ms. Hoff was born (1910) and raised in Tulsa, Oklahoma. As a six-year-old she modeled small figures from the clay the well-drillers left behind. At 14 she won a silver medal in "Free Hand Drawing." After two years at the University of Tulsa, she relocated to Chicago to pursue the study of art. She first found success with her edgy, figurative work while still a student at the Art Institute of Chicago in the mid-1940s; a one-man show at the Wildenstein Galleries in Paris (1955) brought international recognition. She moved permanently to NYC in 1960, where her more abstract collage paintings attracted immediate institutional and critical attention; "The Crowd" (1960), a 40" x 30" paper collage and acrylic on canvas, was purchased by the Metropolitan Museum of Art that same year. She would later exhibit with Betty Parsons. As artist-in residence she taught at numerous American universities as well as in China, Brazil, Lebanon and Uganda. She is survived by a daughter, Mia, of Edinburgh, Scotland. A memorial service is pending. (More information about Margo Hoff's life and career is available at MargoHoff.com.)

ROLL--Irwin C. ''Win'', The head of several New York advertising agencies bearing his name, who first conceived the marketing potential for the 800 number in 1965, and launched the first nationwide information utility accessible through a single toll-free call from anywhere, any time, died November 20 at his home in Henderson, Nevada. He was 83. The cause was complications of Parkinson's Disease. Win Roll was a beloved and influential figure in the many lives he touched during his long life. He liked to say he entered advertising because it combined his love of words, music, art, and ideas. After serving in Europe during World War II, he graduated first in the Advertising class at City College. At Fuller & Smith & Ross (FSR), a major midtown agency during the golden years of New York advertising agencies, he headed up accounts including Time Incorporated, Raytheon, and Air France. In 1965 he decided to buy into a smaller but well established ad agency which became Henderson & Roll serving clients including Union Camp, Standard Packaging, Morgan Guaranty Bank, Diamond International, and Republic National Bank of New York. Mr. Roll then created the innovation that literally changed the world. He launched Listfax Corporation in 1966, pioneering the concept of the toll-free number together with 24/7/365 instant information retrieval, any time day or night, which enabled advertisers to connect prospects instantly to more information or their nearest local dealer. An understated man with a self-effacing modesty, Mr. Roll had the audacity, both intellectually and emotionally, to believe things were possible that had never been done before. His revolutionary concept, now ubiquitous, presaged the advent of the information age and the internet. Shuttling between his home in White Plains, the ad agency in New York, and the Listfax operations center in Norwalk, CT, he took Listfax public the same year, earning industry kudos. It was featured in Time Magazine as one of the 5 fastest starting stocks of 1966. An avid theatre goer with his late wife Marilyn, and a tennis and piano playing enthusiast, Mr. Roll devoted much time to community service leadership, as President of Beta Gamma Sigma, the national business honor society; President of AdNet, an advertising industry volunteer service organization; and the Boards of Kol Ami Synagogue in White Plains, NY, and the P.R. Board of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Mr. Roll's wife Marilyn, to whom he was devoted for 58 years, died in 2006. He is survived by two sons, Richard Roll, of Fairfield, CT, and Douglas Roll, of Henderson, NV, two sisters, Constance Grace and Joyce Scheer, daughter - in - law Christine, and two loving granddaughters, Allison and Rebecca Roll. Donations may be made to the Parkinson's Foundation, and the National M.S. Society.

NICHINSON--David Bernard, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Great Neck, New York, passed away at age 87 on September 5, 2008 following complications of heart surgery. He was the beloved husband of Arline Judith Nichinson for 54 years and the admired, caring and respected father of Laurel Nichinson and Dr. Bradley Nichinson. Dave was the son of Benjamin and Gertrude Nichinson, born on April 11, 1921 in Boston, Massachusetts. He attended Boston Latin School prior to graduating with a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from M.I.T. in 1942. After graduation he became a Staff Member at the M.I.T. Radiation Laboratory. He holds several patents including the Automatic Astrocompass, the Mechanical Resonant Scanner, and the Precision Tachometer System. After M.I.T. he joined Kollsman Instruments, a leading international developer and manufacturer of aviation instruments, where he later became President and CEO. He was a member of the Apollo Space Mission Navigation and Guidance Team. He was a member of the Young President's Organization and a Director of the Metropolitan President's Organization. Of the many other organizations he served on in a leadership role he was most proud of his contributions through his work as Chairman of the Long Island Chapter of The National Alliance of Businessmen, for which he received special recognition from Presidents Johnson and Nixon. After leaving Kollsman he became President and a Director of Aiken Industries which subsequently was acquired by Norlin Industries and then Amstar Group. He later served as a special adviser to Weiss, Peck and Greer's buyout activities and was on the Board of Directors of several companies. In his personal life he was a devoted husband to the love of his life, Arline, an original June Taylor Dancer, and was always a very supportive and giving father. He was artistic in his own right but also enjoyed opera, theatre, music, art, tennis, golf, bridge and fixing countless things with rubber bands and paper clips. He was an extraordinarily kind man with unparalleled integrity, ethics, modesty, not to mention his great sense of humor. Despite the sadness of his leaving us he had a wonderful and rich life. He loved and was loved without reserve. He was healthy throughout his life and always possessed, even in his final days, a strong and sharp mind. Donations may be made in his name in continued honor of his wife to the: Boca West Cancer Research Unit, c/o Nancy Fried 20621 Links View Circle, Boca Raton, FL 33434.

For Leslie O. Collier, the operator of a 600-acre grain farm, it was not so much the felony conviction for killing two bald eagles that stung the most, and that stung plenty. It was the loss of his hunting rifles that went with it. For his mother, June S. Collier, it was the pain of seeing her son's name sullied in their town of roughly 5,000 people in southeastern Missouri, where the family had lived, farmed and hunted for four generations.

HEADING HOME Growing up, I didn't have the story of picking up my glove and tossing a baseball with my father. He was in his 40s when I was born and, because of a chronic neck problem, limited in his sports activities. I remember my dad sitting in a chair with some water-bag contraption, trying to alleviate some of the pain. Most of my early baseball memories involve my big brother Ken dragging me out in the rain to play, and my parents supporting from afar. From what my parents told me, my brother could not wait to have a playmate when I was born. He knew that a little brother has no choice but to follow along with whatever big brother has planned. We are seven and a half years apart, but he competed with me as if I were his age -- very little mercy and high expectations. He gave me my competitive spirit.

MUNROE--John, Jr., died on November 9, 2008 in Montego Bay, Jamaica after a long illness. He was born in Paris, France May 8, 1924 where his father was associated with Munroe & Co., a private bank. His mother, Adelaide Sedgwick, was descended from many early founders of the United States. On his father's side he was descended from both early American stock and persons prominent in the French business community. Partly raised in Paris, he was educated in this country at the Buckley School in New York: St. Mark's School in Southborough, Massa chusetts: and Harvard College in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He was loyal to these institutions as well as Brantwood Camp in Peterborough, New Hampshire, the St. Mark's School camp for those who might not have had a camping experience otherwise, where he served as counselor and for many years as trustee. Entering Harvard in the fall of 1942, he soon like so many of his generation was in the Armed Forces. He ended his military career as a Lieutenant in charge of Gen. Hap Arnold's staff at the Potsdam Conference in 1945. Graduating from Harvard in 1949, he taught briefly at St. Mark's School. He lived frequently at Montego Bay in Jamaica where he was an early advocate of its delights, and where he dealt in real estate. He was a raconteur of note, a writer and reciter of a wide variety of limericks, and he enlivened every event to which he went and invariably raised the tone. He was loyal to those he was close to and to the institutions of which he had been part.

Doing the Times Sunday puzzle (Nov. 16) and watching ''The Simpsons'' are two things my teenage son and I enjoy doing together. When this Sunday's episode made several references to clues that appeared in that day's puzzle, we ran to get the magazine and thought it was a huge coincidence. At the end of the show, ''The Simpsons'' revealed the puzzle with the answers. Then we knew it was the same puzzle that we had just done in The Sunday Times. Very clever and fun. MICHELLE NEWMAN-DICKEY Cranbury, N.J.

Further problems in the renovation of the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow have delayed its planned reopening until 2011, Agence France-Presse reported. The theater, the historic home of the Bolshoi Ballet and Bolshoi Opera, was closed in 2005 to begin a $700 million renovation project to create underground dressing rooms and modernize its stage; the work was to be completed this year, but that target date was later pushed back to 2009. On Monday, Natalya Uvarova, a spokeswoman for the Russian culture ministry, told Agence France-Presse that the latest delays could be ‚Äúexplained mainly by the ground quality, which made it necessary to reinforce the foundations further.‚Äù The culture minister, Alexander Avdeyev, told the newspaper Izvestia that the delays were the fault of poor management.

The Live Earth India concert scheduled for Saturday in Mumbai has been canceled after last week‚Äôs deadly attacks on that city, The Guardian reported. The environmentally themed concert series, founded last year by the producer Kevin Wall and supported by former Vice President Al Gore, had planned a performance at Mumbai‚Äôs Andheri Sports Complex that would have featured rock and pop stars like Roger Waters and Will.i.am alongside Bollywood stars like Aishwarya Rai. But its promoters announced Monday that the sold-out event had been canceled, as concerns lingered after last week‚Äôs attacks, carried out by gunmen at hotels and other sites across Mumbai, raising questions about security and prompting some scheduled performers to call off their travel plans.

Paris‚Äôs labyrinthine underground Les Halles marketplace is about to get a new destination that even American visitors will be able to ask for by name. Cinema Street (known locally as ‚ÄúRue de Cinema‚Äù) will be dedicated on Friday by Mayor Bertrand Delano√´, Agence France-Presse reported, to celebrate the completion of renovations on the marketplace‚Äôs historic Forum des Images movie theater. The street offers visitors a modern 16-screen multiplex cinema and a library named for the director Fran√ßois Truffaut, with a collection of 17,000 books and 10,000 DVDs; the renovated Forum will also have a vault of 5,500 films, all newly transferred to digital format. ‚ÄúThis is the first time that a city has said to itself that its memory does not only exist in books but also in images,‚Äù Laurence Herszberg, the director of the Forum, told Agence France-Presse.

The musician Travis Barker and the DJ Adam Goldstein have announced that they will play their first show together since they were in a post-concert plane crash in September, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Goldstein, who performs as DJ AM, and Mr. Barker, the drummer for the punk band Blink-182, were flying together on a private plane on Sept. 19 after playing a free concert in Columbia, S.C., when the plane crashed, injuring them and killing Mr. Barker‚Äôs bodyguard and his personal assistant, as well as the plane‚Äôs pilot and co-pilot. Mr. Barker recently filed suit against several companies in connection with the crash. According to The A.P., Mr. Barker and Mr. Goldstein will perform together as TRVSDJAM at a New Year‚Äôs Eve party at The Lot in West Hollywood.

Within the theater world, the question of who will succeed Gerald Schoenfeld, the longtime chairman of the Shubert Organization and probably the most influential figure on Broadway, after his death last week has all the high drama and mystery of a seat-gripping whodunit. Tuesday night the board of directors will announce, if not whodunit, then whoisit, Phil Smith, the president of the Shubert Organization, said. The board will meet and ‚Äúimplement the succession plan,‚Äù he said. Until then, guessing is encouraged.

‚ÄúBritney: For the Record,‚Äù the MTV documentary about Britney Spears, which was shown Sunday night, turned out to be a pretty big disappointment. No question was supposed to go unanswered but still there are lots of questions, like, how come Britney Spears let one of her toddlers pretty much drive a car? She was sad. She was lonely. She was having a hard time. But how is she doing now? She has no regrets. Everything happens for a reason. It is what it is. This is Britney reflecting. Madonna steps in momentarily to do some analyzing for Britney and when she does, she sounds like Harold Bloom in comparison. Britney can‚Äôt go excavating deep inside but also, she has a problem with English. When did Kevin Federline start to disappear from her life? When ‚Äúhe started doing an album for his-self.‚Äù She knows she is to blame for some of her misfortunes but she also wants to blame photographers because ‚Äúpaparazzi has taken my whole cool slang away from me.‚Äù Whoever is out there with Britney‚Äôs cool slang, you know who you are, now, go give it back.

Can a man approaching the age of 50 still credibly stand on a stage, strip naked and perform songs with titles like ‚ÄúWheelchair Epidemic‚Äù? Audiences will soon find out as the Jesus Lizard, the provocative and unpredictable Chicago rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll band, has announced it is reuniting, Billboard reported. Founded in 1987 by the yelping vocalist David Yow, 48, the band became as famous for studio albums recorded by Steve Albini as for live shows in which Mr. Yow would expose his genitals to the crowd for entire songs, or entire sets. Mr. Yow plans to perform with his bandmates Duane Denison, David Wm. Sims and Mac McNeilly at an All Tomorrow‚Äôs Parties festival in Minehead, England, in May, and in the United States in the following months.

Having successfully directed period pieces like ‚ÄúThe Light in the Piazza‚Äùand ‚ÄúSouth Pacific‚Äù for Lincoln Center‚Äôs Vivian Beaumont Theater, Bartlett Sher will soon be directing, not surprisingly,another period piece. His next project for Lincoln Center Theater will be a revival of the August Wilson play ‚ÄúJoe Turner‚Äôs Come And Gone,‚Äù its producers announced. One of 10 plays in Wilson‚Äôs Century Cycle, ‚ÄúJoe Turner‚Äôs Come And Gone‚Äù is set in the year 1911 and tells the story of a man who finds himself in an unusual Pittsburgh boarding house on a journey north. The play is scheduled to begin previews on March 19 and open on April 16; a cast and a theater have not been announced.

The terror attacks in Mumbai have led to the cancellation of the annual Sangat Chamber Music Festival, but the three concerts will go on, in Sweden. Alan Gilbert, the music director-in-waiting of the New York Philharmonic, arranged to have the festival moved to Stockholm, where he lives because of his stint as music director of the Royal Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra. Mr. Gilbert had planned to attend the festival this December, because his wife, the cellist Kajsa William-Olsson, is a performer. Sponsors, including the Stockholm Philharmonic‚Äôs concert hall, have stepped forward to pay for travel and accommodations for the musicians, who are donating their fees. The festival is run by the Mehli Mehta Foundation, a major promoter of classical music in Mumbai. One of Mehli Mehta‚Äôs sons is Zubin Mehta, the conductor, and another is Zarin Mehta, the president of the New York Philharmonic. The concerts take place Dec. 15, 17 and 18.

Mark Leckey, a multimedia artist whose exhibition ‚ÄúIndustrial Light & Magic‚Äù combines recreated images of Felix the Cat, Homer Simpson and the movie ‚ÄúTitanic,‚Äù won the 2008 Turner Prize on Monday, the BBC reported. The annual prize, presented by the Tate Gallery in London to a British artist under the age of 50, comes with an award of about $37,000, and is often given to creators of untraditional and provocative works. Mr. Leckey, a professor of film studies at the St√§delschule in Frankfurt, was presented with the prize by the rock musician Nick Cave at a ceremony. According to the judges, Mr. Leckey‚Äôs work ‚Äúcelebrates the imagination of the individual and our potential to inhabit, reclaim or animate an idea, a space or an object,‚Äù the BBC said.

Internet | Anti-spam efforts are threatening free speech, a newsletter publisher says. Anti-spam software is indiscriminately screening out contextually benign formulations of "young adult," "getting nasty" and the like. This imposes self-censorship on writers or, worse, leaves both sender and recipient unaware what's been censored. [Washington Post]

The New York State Commission on Judicial Nomination on Monday morning nominated seven prominent lawyers and jurists as potential successors to Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye, who will step down at the end of this year, having reached the mandatory retirement age of 70.

That is the news on yesterday's front page, where Juliet Macur wrote about a newly released product from Atlas Sports Genetics, which allows parents learn whether their child carries the version of a gene, called ACTN3, that makes for physical power or the version that makes for endurance.

Filmcouch is a weekly podcast of the Spoutblog and this week, a few of the Spoutees talk about the backlash to their backlash. Paul and Kevin take some heat and dish it back for dissing Danny Boyle and "Slumdog Millionaire," and we also learn that Karina was asked to take down her review of "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button." It is all very inside but super juicy and fun to listen in on, which is more than he can say about almost any podcast you could mention. The Bagger has been away from the beat for so long, he forgot that people get into, um, feelings about this stuff.

Minnesota and Wisconsin just can't seem to find a balance. The Golden Gophers started the season up and the Badgers were down. Now, Minnesota is winless in its last three games after starting the season 7-0-4 and the Badgers, who were winless in their first seven games of the season, are 7-1-1 in their last nine. (In Wisconsin's defense, the opening eight games of its schedule were beyond brutal: at Boston College, at New Hampshire, two games at Denver, two home games vs. Minnesota and a weekend trip to North Dakota. That is the stuff bad dreams are made of.)

Johnson & Johnson said Monday that it would buy Mentor Corporation, the maker of the MemoryGel breast implant, for $1.07 billion, as the health conglomerate makes its second cash-based acquisition in two weeks.

Is the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences actually starting to reflect the industry as it exists in the current century? Reporting by Michael Cieply in this morning's Times seems to suggest that slowly, over time, the 5,800 or so members are becoming a less creaky, more indie bunch, even though much of the Hollywood establishment hopes to make it more commercial.

Ivory Tower | Technology is driving down the cost of teaching undergraduates -- so why are tuition bills going up? an article asks. Because, it says, "virtually none of those savings are being passed along to students and parents in the form of lower prices." It's a "classic unsustainable trend"; colleges eventually will need to compete just like other businesses, or "they'll be hammered simultaneously by a frustrated public and new competitors eager to steal their customers." [Washington Monthly]

Terrible news to start the morning. Doris Dungey, aka Tanta, has died. She was Calculated Risk's co-blogger -- a real expert on the actual practice of banking, a shrewd commentator, and blessed with a wonderful dry wit. We'll all miss her contributions greatly.

Monday, 7:30 p.m. Use your sorrows to entertain a crowd of hipsters at a "Sob StorySlam" hosted by a modish storytelling collective called the Moth. KOEGEL--James Erwin, 91, of Armonk, NY, passed away November 27, 2008, in Purdys, NY, from complications following a fall at his home. He was born in Washington, D.C., on August 7, 1917, the son of Otto E. Koegel and Rae F. Koegel. His formative years were in Wilmette, IL, and Bronxville, NY. He attended Culver Military Academy and Bronxville High School and graduated from Williams College in the Class of 1939 and Fordham Law School 1942. He served in the Army in World War II and upon his discharge began the practice of law with Dwight, Harris, Koegel & Caskey in Manhattan. As an associate and partner he served in the corporate department of the firm until 1976 when he retired. The firm was then Rogers & Wells and is now Clifford Chance. In 1946 he married Christina N. Williams. She survives him as do his children, Christina K. Granrud of Kalispell, MT, Sarah N. Koegel of Armonk and James A. Koegel of Bedford, NY, as well as grandchildren, Phillip and Jennifer Granrud. He is also survived by sister, Ruth K. Macreery of Redding, CT and a brother, William Koegel of Somers, NY. For 27 years he had a home in Granite Springs, NY, on the large farm owned by the family for almost fifty years. He was a superb horseman and rode in many hunter and jumper classes in horse shows throughout Westchester. He continued to ride into his eighties. In Somers he was active in civic affairs and in development. He was Justice of the Peace from 1947 to 1962 and served as President of the Westchester County Magistrates Association. He also served as Chairman of the Red Cross drive for Somers/North Salem, as Chairman of the Westchester County Committee on Youth Services and Vice President of the United Way of Northern Westchester. He also developed a number of properties in Somers including West Somers Park in Granite Springs. He was an avid golfer and his Armonk home bordered the 15th green of the Whippoorwill Country Club to which he belonged. Jim was devoted to his family, his horses and golf, in that order, and he will be sorely missed. The service for him and the interment will be private.

SPERRY--Ann, sculptor and feminist, died peacefully at home on November 27 of leiomyosarcoma. By her side were her husband, tenor Paul Sperry, sons Ethan, Joshua, and Raphael, daughters-inlaw Siri, Ilinisa, and Laura, and grandchildren Max, Cayesh, Milo, Solomon, Rebecca, and Diran. She will be sorely missed by her family and many recent and life-long friends. Ann's steel sculptures transformed toughness into softness, femininity and beauty. They adorn the collections of the Storm King Arts Center, the Skirball Museums in Los Angeles and Cincinnati, the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis and many others; her large sitespecific sculptures are installed in Seattle, Boston, Aspen, and other places. She served on the board of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts and the Sculpture Center (contributions to either would be welcome) as well as in political campaigns from Eugene McCarthy's to Barack Obama's. A memorial service will be announced.

WOLIN--Rochelle. Beloved mother of Haley and Brian, devoted brother of Kenneth, adoring daughter of Theda and the late Marvin Spitz, indeared grandmother of Madison and Brett. Your courage and strength will live with us forever. Funeral today 11:30am, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

KELLY--Leah (Dorfman), 44, beloved daughter of Iris and Dan Dorfman, stepdaughter of Harriet and cherished wife of John Kelly. She passed away peacefully on November 30. World traveler with a lust for life, visited all seven continents. Lover of animals. She will be greatly missed by those whose lives she touched.

CYNIC ''Traced in Air'' (Season of Mist) Death metal scours the old values and meanings of song structure. Verse, chorus and bridge may remain, but if they do, they're not signifying in the normal ways: home, away, the development and draining of tension. There's lots of detail, lots of sections, but the music feels tense and dire all the way through. The drama, the moments of safety and release in a song's cycles, don't exist for it.
WEINBERGER--Howard, died peacefully November 27, 2008, age 91. Father to Carol, David and Mendel. Grandfather to 10.

FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut. We mourn the loss of Helmut Friedlaender, our beloved friend, great philanthropist, extraordinary business leader, and masterful book collector. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Jane, Chuck, Andy and Libby Klein FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. The Board of Directors of AMETEK, Inc. expresses their deepest sorrow at the passing of their esteemed colleague and friend, Helmut, and offers their heartfelt sympathy to his family. Hal was an individual of unquestioned character and integrity. He served as a Director of AMETEK for more than 50 years, and, while his business achievements were impressive, his personal stature is best measured by his public spiritedness and generosity. Hal long and actively supported a wide range of public and private causes. Hal's long association with AMETEK began in 1955, when he was elected to the Board of Directors. Since then, his contributions to AMETEK have been innumerable. Five AMETEK Chairmen and Chief Executive Officers have benefited from his wisdom and counsel during his five decades on its board. His understanding of the business and financial worlds has been an invaluable asset to the Company and its shareholders. Indeed, in its nearly 80-year history, there probably has not been a single individual who has had a greater, or more positive, impact on AMETEK than Hal Friedlaender. FRIEDLAENDER--Helmut N. The family of William and Mary Rosenwald deeply mourn the passing of Helmut N. (Hal) Friedlaender, our partner and advisor, an extraordinary investor and a great man, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. From 1944 through the next 40 years, Hal brilliantly guided the family's investments and investment bank, then known as American Securities Corporation. Hal's goal was to create opportunities with a defined limited risk and an unlimited potential, building such businesses as Western Union International and AMETEK, Inc. We celebrate Hal for his integrity, his values, and his enjoyment of life. We are forever grateful for his visionary guidance and his deep friendship. He continues to inspire us. Nina Rosenwald Elizabeth R. Varet Alice Rosenwald

GROSSMAN--Dr. Jacob, a physician died on November 29. He was 92 years old. Born on August 6, 1916, to Isaac and Anna Toner in New York City, he attended Stuyvesant High School, the City College of New York, Columbia University, and he received his M.D. from the University of Louisville in 1940. Following his service in World War II, he began a long association with Montefiore Hospital. He also served as Director of Internal Medicine at the Hospital for Joint Diseases and as a Police Surgeon with the New York City Police Department. On August 9, 1948 he married Frances Gaezer. She died on November 14, 1990. A resident of Scarsdale, New York for more than forty years, he took great pride in his four children who survive him: Arthur (Jeanette) of North Reading, Massachusetts, Victor (Jamie) of Brewster, New York, Daniel (Debbie) of Topanga, California, and Walter (Vered) of Fairfax Station, Virginia, and nine grandchildren. Services will be held Tuesday, December 2, at 12:00, at The Riverside Chapel 21 W. Broad St., Mount Vernon, New York 10552.
BOXER--David H. Dec 1, 1994. Always remembered. Beloved husband, father, fatherin-law, grandfather and great grandfather.

AKON ''Freedom'' (SRC/Universal Motown) Despite appearances Akon has always been unfaithful to the hip-hop/R&B collaborations he's made his name with. For every mournful hook he's lent to a tough rapper, he has had a blithe song that glides past urban radio and up the pop charts: the Bobby Vinton-sampling ''Lonely,'' the cheeky Gwen Stefani duet ''The Sweet Escape.''

LITMAN--Belle, at the age of 93. Loving wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, and aunt, proud and consummate New Yorker. Survived by daughter Carol and son-in-law Frank Valentine, son Alfred and Betty Jane Jacobs, grandchildren Jeanne and Paul Karlitz, Josh and Lisa Valentine, Joseph Litman, and Juliet Litman, and great - grandchildren Lane Karlitz and Jackson Karlitz. Funeral Tuesday, December 2, 2008 at 11am at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

Amazon.com has found a way to pass on to users one of the most tedious tasks of the holiday season: answering questions from reporters trying to pad Thanksgiving week newspapers and airwaves with stories about hot products to buy. The company has announced what it calls its ''Holiday Customer Review Team.'' These are six Amazon customers who are particularly active in writing product reviews whom it has offered to reporters to discuss gift picks.

WEINER--Golde, nee Enzer, 86, after a brief illness at Hudson Pointe. Widow of Bernard, mother of Barbara Abrams and Roni Davidi and the late Jan Weiner. Motherin-law of Barry and Elli; sister of Dr. Hyman Enzer, grandmother of Taryn and Jacob Abrams and Ilana and Avi Davidi. She was a talented designer of Sesame Street puppets, Strawberry Shortcake dolls, and other toymakers, and had many friends, and was devoted to Hadassah, Ort, and other social causes. Funeral services will be held 11:30am. Monday at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

BONAMUSA--Josep Maria. A True Catalan, soulmate and partner to his wife Rosalynn, on November 29th, 2008. Survived by daughter Elizabeth Ann Hyatt and son John Joseph Bonamusa, son-inlaw James and daughter-inlaw Jill. Beloved grandfather to Jessica, Caroline, Michael, Deborah and Laura.

FRANK--Tillie (Miller), age 94, on November 30. Wife of the late Nelson. For many years she was an Information Assistant at the New York Public Library. In addition she was featured on Alstair Cooke's America on PBS teaching English as a second language. A loving mother, she is survived by her three children, William, Johanna Hurwitz and Suzanne Ruta, seven grandchildren: Nomi, Ben, Ted, Daniel, Sebastian, Garance and Vanessa and six great-grandchildren: Ethan, Juliet, Fiona, Simran, Jai and Luca. The middle sister of seven, she is survived by her younger sisters Virgina and Dorothy, nieces and nephews and many many friends. She will always be remember for her warmth, wit and the world's best macaroni and cheese.

One of the few constants in Silicon Valley has been a giant billboard set on a hill beside Highway 101, near San Francisco airport. For eight years, the billboard has carried a variety of messages from Autonomy, a high-end search company that few people know. On Jan. 1, Autonomy will move across the highway, from the west side to the east side, ending an era. (It won't stop advertising: the new billboard position is considered a great spot to catch the eye of taxi riders on the way to San Francisco.)

This game lacks playoff implications, but it will provide a national audience for two underrated Texans: the rookie running back Steve Slaton (774 yards) and receiver Andre Johnson (81 catches, 1,071 yards). A Monday night game is a rarity for Houston, which has not hosted one since 1994, when the Giants beat the Oilers in Jeff Fisher's first game as Houston's interim coach. (Jack Pardee had been fired a week earlier.) The Jaguars' descent from an 11-5 playoff team to a struggling also-ran has been swift, but it can probably be traced to the crumbling of its offensive line. Jacksonville lost its starting guards to season-ending injuries in Week 1 and played without center Brad Meester for the first six games. While the Jaguars have searched for solutions, David Garrard has been sacked 30 times and Maurice Jones-Drew and Fred Taylor have failed to gain 1,000 yards between them. ANDREW DAS
Correction Appended Tennessee's third-ranked rushing offense couldn't move the ball against Chicago, but it didn't matter in a 21-14 victory.

HEALY--Thomas, on November 29, 2008, at 87, of Stuart, Florida and Lido Beach, New York. Beloved husband of Catherine, devoted father of Deirdre, Terence and Aileen, loving grandfather of Catherine H. Littlefield, gracious father-in-law to Elaine Healy, Bob Littlefield and Stephen Notarnicola. A man of unusual insight and intelligence, his energy had no limit. He was quick to laugh and his kindness was without reservation or boundary. His example will ever inspire all of us who were privileged to know him.
Shops at a timber market in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city, were ablaze on Sunday after being attacked by rioters. Fighting between ethnic groups over the weekend left at least 13 people dead.

The top Thanksgiving weekend films earn less than half of opening-weekend giants like ''The Dark Knight'' (2008), which took in $158 million, or ''Shrek 2'' (2004), which opened at $124 million. Eventual totals are hard to predict based on the Thanksgiving gross. ''Toy Story,'' for example, opened strong and went on to earn $272.6 million. ''Spy Game'' (2001) reached a domestic gross of $76.3 million after opening at $26.5 million. ''Transporter 3,'' above, with Jason Statham, can only hope to copy Bad Santa, which opened in 2003 with $14.5 million and went on to earn $70.7 million. SHELLY FREIERMAN

KATZ--Rosalie Abrams (Roz), on Saturday, November 29, 2008. Adored mother of Susan, Stephen, Peter and wife, Erica. Loving grandmother of Alex, Lucy, and Will Berman, Franny and Caroline Kimball-Katz, Samuel and Theodore Katz. Daughter of the late Samuel and Frances Abrams, sister of Harold Abrams, niece of Pearl Joseph. Devoted and loyal friend to all. Wherever Roz went there was beauty and fun. Private interment. The family will be receiving at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave (81st), Monday December 1st, 7-9pm.

Trojans Smelling Roses On Saturday, Southern California will travel to the Rose Bowl, where a victory over U.C.L.A. will probably send the Trojans on a return trip to play Penn State there on New Year's Day.

DeAngelo Williams, left, scored four touchdowns -- all on 1-yard runs -- in the Panthers' 35-31 win over the Packers. He scored the winner with 1 minute 30 seconds remaining. Mark Clayton made a one-handed catch on a 70-yard touchdown and also threw a 32-yard scoring pass on a reverse as the Ravens rolled against the Bengals, 34-3.

NOLAN--Edward A., of Sarasota FL, formerly of Wantagh, NY passed away peacefully on November 28, 2008 in the 88th year of a wonderful life. Born February 25, 1920 he graduated from Chaminade High School in 1938 and St. Johns University in 1942. At the time of his death, he was Chairman of Nolan Glove Co Inc. Founded by his father William (Dutch) Nolan in 1920, it was the first children's glove company in the US. He served as President from 1960 to 1999. It was his tremendous dedication and hard work that sustained the company successfully into the fourth generation of Nolan's. His reputation in business as a man of honor remains a legend to this day. He loyally served in the Army Air Force in England, during WWII, providing air traffic control and radio support of the battles of Ardennes and Normandy. He was one of the first American soldiers to track and report the arrival of the V-1 missiles launched by Germany over the English Channel in 1944. Edward was a man of exceptional grace and a courtly gentleman at all times and in all situations. The twinkle in his blue eyes charmed the world and kept it warm. He was married and deeply devoted to his wife of 53 years, Alice Joan Stouges, who predeceased him in 2002. He is survived and missed deeply by his four children: Mary Alice Joss, Edward, Michael and William as well as seven grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. He taught us all, through the course of his distinguished life, the importance of integrity, humility and kindness. ''The word is...love'' Friends and family may visit at the Wantagh Abbey, Inc. corner of Park Ave. and Beech St. Wantagh on Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday 10am at St. Frances de Chantal R.C. Church interment to follow Holy Rood Cemetery.

MILLER--Rev. Francis X., S.J. College of the Holy Cross mourns the passing of Fr. Frank Miller, vice president emeritus for development, who died November 25 at Campion Center in Weston, MA at 82. An alumnus (Class of 1946) and long a beloved member of the College Community, he so sustained the development program during his 22 years of service that Holy Cross continues to benefit from a consistently high level of annual alumni support. His funeral will be held Wednesday, December 3, feast of St. Francis Xavier, at Campion Center at 10am, followed by burial at Holy Cross at 2pm. Wake at Campion Center from 3-5pm on Tuesday, December 2. Donations in his memory can be made to the Francis L. Miller Scholarship Fund, named for his late father, at Holy Cross.
COLE--Lewis, 62, died on October 10 from complications of ALS. He was a beloved friend, teacher, father and partner. We will miss him more than we can say.

BRITNEY SPEARS ''Circus'' (Jive/Zomba) A fake newscaster names Britney Spears the Queen of Pop on her sixth studio album, ''Circus.'' She must know what became of the self-anointed King of Pop, Michael Jackson: a globally popular hitmaker now reduced to tabloid fodder. With ''Circus,'' as on her 2007 album, ''Blackout,'' Ms. Spears bets that she can balance stardom and notoriety better than he did: holding attention with peculiar, even self-destructive behavior, while recording and performing to channel that attention toward sales. (If it should all come crashing down, she'll have plenty of catalog to fall back on.) ''You say I'm crazy -- I got you crazy,'' she taunts in her current single ''Womanizer,'' which reached No. 1.

Sooners' Bradford Is Hurt Oklahoma quarterback Sam Bradford has torn ligaments in his nonthrowing hand and is likely to need surgery after next Saturday's Big 12 championship game, Sooners Coach Bob Stoops said.

HEALTHY SHOPPING START People flooded the nation's stores over the weekend, to the relief of retailers that had been expecting a holiday period as slow as the overall economy. BEST USE OF STIMULUS Now that the government has decided to spend nearly $1.4 trillion to stabilize the financial system, economists, policy makers and the president-elect are trying to figure out the best way to use the money. [B1.]
LAZIN--Hannah Mendelsohn. 3/5/1924 - 12/1/2007. Missed dearly by family, friends and all those whose lives she touched

STURKEN--Robert C., 89, passed away at his home in Princeton, NJ on November 24, 2008. He was an engineer and executive who pioneered paper - coating technology used worldwide. Born and raised in Brooklyn, he received an engineering degree in 1940 from the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, and did graduate work at Columbia and Yale. During WWII, while at DuPont, he worked on a classified government project developing anti-radar technology. In 1950 he joined the Egan Machinery Company of Somerville, NJ as a partner, becoming vice president and CFO. His design for an extrusion coating machine received a US patent in 1952, forming the basis for a line of paper and plastic coating machines licensed internationally. He later worked as an engineering and management consultant and in 1980 was elected to the board of directors of the New Jersey Savings Bank of Somerville. He served as a trustee of Stevens Institute and president of its alumni association, and on the boards of directors of the Unitarian Church of Princeton and the Friends of the New Jersey State Museum. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, the artist Marie Sturken (nee Ryan); his son Carl and daughter-in-law CherylAnne Sturken of Katonah; daughters and sons-in-law Barbara and William Peterson of Hastings on Hudson, and Marita Sturken and Dana Polan of Manhattan; grandchildren Kelly and Kyra Sturken, Leigh and Moira Peterson, and Leo-Andres Polan. A memorial service is scheduled for 1pm on Saturday, December 13 at the Unitarian Church, Princeton followed by a reception at the Nassau Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Princeton Area Community Foundation, 15 Princess Rd., Lawrenceville, NJ 08648.

FEDER--Leon, known as Bud to all that knew him. Passed peacefully in his sleep on Sunday, November 30, 2008 after having a wonderful Thanksgiving dinner with all his family. Beloved husband of Betty, and loving father of Warren and David and daughter-in-laws Judith, Lisa and Susan and adoring grandfather of Sarah, Julianne, Katie, Robbie and Cassidy. He is also the loving brother and survived by Ben Feder and sister-in-law Phyllis. He will be missed by all. A decorated veteran of WWII. He was known to all for his uncompromising honor, dignity and goodness. Services will be held Tuesday at Riverside Chapel 180 W 76th St. For service times please contact Riverside Chapel.

Traditional social bookmarking sites like Digg and Del.icio.us are great for finding articles and other text that other Web surfers have tagged as interesting. But for the visually oriented, the pickings have been slim. Now, however, a handful of photo-oriented bookmarking sites are emerging to entertain the eye as well as the mind. The sites -- We Heart It, FFFFound and Vi.sualize.us -- resemble constantly changing art installations. The sites work similarly to their text-based brethren. When members discover an image worth preserving, they bookmark it, either by right-clicking or using a site-specific browser button. Here's a bit more about each of the sites. Please note that images on all of them can be slightly not safe for work, so proceed with caution when browsing.

WHITAKER--C. Sylvester, Jr., 73, the former dean of social sciences at the University of Southern California, passed away on November 29 in Waterville, ME, after a struggle with cancer. A native of Pittsburgh, PA and graduate of Swarthmore College, he received a doctorate from Princeton University and became an expert in the political development of Africa, publishing a study of Nigeria, ''The Politics of Tradition,'' in 1970. A practicing Quaker and lifelong sports fan (particularly of his beloved USC Trojans and Pittsburgh Steelers), he had also served as a professor and administrator at the University of California at Los Angeles, at Princeton, and at Rutgers University. He is survived by his wife Shirley Whitaker, his sons Mark and Paul, his stepsons Jason and James, his grandchildren Rachel and Matthew, and his sister Cleo McCray. According to his wishes, he will be cremated and his ashes will be buried in a memorial service to be scheduled near his home in Canaan, ME, in the springtime.

The Penn State women's volleyball team became the first team in the history of N.C.A.A. women's volleyball to win every set of every match during the regular season. By sweeping Ohio State and Michigan over the weekend, the No. 1 Nittany Lions finished with a 32-0 match record and extended their win streak to 58 matches, an N.C.A.A. record.

CONTE--Ben, 81, of New York and Lakeville, CT on November 26th. Dearly beloved husband of Margo. Devoted father to Louise and husband Andrew Swanson, Eric and wife Jen. Adoring grandfather to Parker, Baxter and Logan Conte. Loving brother of Salvatore and the late Fabio. Ben was the former New York State Director of the Corporation for National Service. Calling hours at Andrett Funeral Home will be November 30th and December 1st from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Service at Epiphany Church, Tuesday, December 2nd at 10am. Interment at Greenwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Visiting Nurse Association of NY, The Salisbury, CT Ambulance Squad or the Julliard Scholarship Fund would be appreciated.

(ABC) BOSTON LEGAL In the penultimate episode of the series, Denny Crane (William Shatner) learns disturbing news about the progression of his Alzheimer's disease, and Alan Shore (James Spader) tries to persuade the Massachusetts Supreme Court to let his best friend Denny have access to a drug that could slow his deterioration -- but that isn't approved by the F.D.A. Loving husband of Shirley, adored father of Fredlyn Heller (Scott) and Michael Album (Kelly) and proud grandfather of Sophie, Amelia, Katie and Max. Derek Anderson, starting in place of the injured Brady Quinn, sprained the medial collateral ligament in his left knee. Trent Edwards was replaced by J. P. Losman in the Bills' loss because of a groin injury.

GILBERT--Irving, passed peacefully at age 90 on November 30, in Florida after a long struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. In his active life he was for many years an executive in the trucking industry. He is survived by his loving and beloved wife of 67 years Lee; sons Larry and Richard; daughters-in-law Arlene and Jane; grandchildren Eric and Assunta, Adam and Christie, Tracy, and Jay; great-grandchildren Marinda and Katherine; brother Milton. He was predeceased by his sister Bernice (Buncy). A graveside service for his family will be held on Tuesday at Mount Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of gifts of flowers or food, the family would appreciate contributions be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

MATTHEWS--Henry McEldowney (Harry) Born July 3, 1926 in Pittsburgh, PA of Charles Hale Matthews Jr. and Annabel McEldowney Matthews -Died suddenly November 24, 2008 in New York, NY. Loving husband of Catherine Caldwell Teague Matthews. Loving father of Charles Hale Matthews IV (Chip) of Palm Beach, FL, William Gordon Gibson Matthews (Bill) of NYC, and James Newell Matthews (James) also of NYC. Also survived by his former wife and their mother Sylvia Ondek Hudson of Palm Beach, FL. Proud graduate of Culver Military Academy and Yale University (Class of '51). Veteran of the US Army in the Philippines in 1945. Principal and co-founder of Matthews Mitchell, a member firm of the NYSE. Avid researcher into all things Scottish both here and in Scotland. Could be found collecting books on all phases of Scottish culture or dancing at Scottish Country Dances almost anywhere in the United States, Canada, and Scotland. Officer, trustee, director, and life member of many Scottish and AmericanScottish organizations, including the New York Branch of the Royal Scottish Country Dance Society and Scotia Dancers; the American-Scottish Foundation, the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York and the New York Caledonian Club; the National Trust for Scotland, the Scottish Tartans Society, the Museum of Islay Life, the West Highland Museum in Fort William, and many others. Very active in he development and concerned with the ultimate progress of Clan Donald USA, the Clan Donald Foundation, and the Clan Donald Lands Trust. Believed you should participate in your heritage and share your culture actively. There is no joy without Clan Donald was not just a poet's declaration to him, it was Harry's lifeline. The highlight of each year was a month-long tour of the west coast of Scotland, each year featuring a different island or two. The museums along the way will remember how he would explore everything, asking questions, chatting about the prospects, and leaving a donation behind. In lieu of flowers, please help continue his educating efforts with donations to the Clan Donald Foundation (PO Box 24008, Milwaukee, WI 53224) or to the Library of the Clan Donald Visitor Center at Armadale (see www.clandonald.info). Blockbuster has announced a three-year deal with the concert production company Live Nation to sell tickets and merchandise for Live Nation events in 500 of its retail stores, Reuters reported. The announcement comes as Ticketmaster‚Äôs contract to sell tickets for Live Nation concerts is set to expire at the end of the year, and Live Nation prepares to start its own ticketing operation in 2009. Blockbuster has faced increasing challenges as it battles with other video rental services and a decline in DVD sales, but Nathan Hubbard, the chief executive of Live Nation Ticketing, told Reuters that the two businesses were compatible. ‚ÄúThe fan who buys his ticket offline has a lot of demographic overlap with the consumer who rents his DVD offline,‚Äù he said.
Among the shows announced on CBS‚Äôs midseason schedule is ‚ÄúGame Show In My Head,‚Äù a reality series whose executive producers include Ashton Kutcher.

It‚Äôs back: the dreaded curse of ‚ÄúTristan.‚Äù The Metropolitan Opera said Gary Lehman would sing in place of an ill Peter Seiffert in Tuesday night‚Äôs performance of ‚ÄúTristan und Isolde.‚Äù Last season, Mr. Lehman was one of four tenors to sing Tristan in a six-performance run, because of various illnesses and mishaps. Mr. Seiffert drew attention during the current run for wearing an earpiece to receive electronic cues, instead of relying on the usual stage prompter. The opera continues through Dec. 20.

Unlike many airline flights, a Broadway show lets you know exactly when it‚Äôs departing. In this case, ‚ÄúBoeing-Boeing,‚Äù the revival of Marc Camoletti‚Äôs comedy about an American architect juggling affairs with three European airline hostesses, will play its final performance on Jan. 4, its producers announced. The comedy, directed by Matthew Warchus, won the Tony Award for best revival of a play, and Mark Rylance, who plays the architect‚Äôs visiting friend, won a Tony Award for best leading actor in a play. At its closing, ‚ÄúBoeing-Boeing‚Äù will have played 280 performances and 17 previews at the Longacre Theater; a national tour is planned for the fall.

The American Musical Theater of San Jose, which last week laid off all of its employees and is likely to file for bankruptcy, has said that the Theater of the Stars in Atlanta, with which it planned a joint production of the Disney musical ‚ÄúTarzan,‚Äù has instead used its investment on other shows. ‚ÄúIn essence, they cancelled the show without giving us any warning, and we discovered that the funds we had paid for ‚ÄòTarzan‚Äô were spent on another production of theirs, which lost a significant amount of money,‚Äù said Michael Miller, the chief executive of American Musical Theater, in a statement.
UPDATE: Read Patricia Cohen‚Äôs full report on the new leaders of the Shubert Organization here.

The American Musical Theater of San Jose has laid off all of its employees and is likely to file for bankruptcy, The Silicon Valley/San Jose Business Journal reported. A spokesman for the theater told The Journal that the theater had lost $1.7 million in a deal with Atlanta‚Äôs Theater of the Stars to produce an adaptation of Disney‚Äôs ‚ÄúTarzan‚Äù musical that would have played in San Jose in February. The American Musical Theater‚Äôs coming productions of ‚ÄúTarzan‚Äù and ‚Äú42nd Street‚Äù have been canceled, but the theater said it would honor tickets for a January production of ‚ÄúChicago,‚Äù and was still seeking ways to produce ‚ÄúAvenue Q,‚Äù which is scheduled for March.

It‚Äôs the rare opera finale that doesn‚Äôt include bloodshed: A new deal between La Scala opera house and an Italian performers union will ensure that La Scala‚Äôs gala opening night will take place Sunday as scheduled, the Associated Press reported. The Fials union, which represents about half of the orchestra musicians and chorus singers at La Scala, had been on strike since July and rejected new contracts in October, forcing the cancellation of productions of ‚ÄúLa Dame aux Camelias‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Merry Widow.‚Äù La Scala‚Äôs new season will begin with a production of Verdi‚Äôs ‚ÄúDon Carlo,‚Äù directed by Daniele Gatti. The opera will be broadcast live in high definition in movie theaters, including the Miller Theater at Columbia University; tickets can be purchased online at ovationtix.com.

At the end of a weekslong itinerary that included talks in the Middle East on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and a farewell speech to NATO foreign ministers in Brussels, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice stopped at Buckingham Palace to enjoy a classical musical recital with Queen Elizabeth II at which Ms. Rice was the main attraction, the Associated Press reported. Accompanied by Louise Miliband, the wife of the British foreign secretary, David Miliband, on violin, and three members of the London Symphony Orchestra, Ms. Rice performed Brahms‚Äôs piano quintet, Op. 34, and received a recording of the performance as a gift from the queen. A classically trained pianist, Ms. Rice performed with the Denver Symphony Orchestra at the age of 15, and accompanied the cellist Yo-Yo Ma in 2002 when Mr. Ma was awarded the National Medal of the Arts.

More guys and dolls have been joined the cast of the coming Broadway revival of ‚ÄúGuys and Dolls,‚Äù the show‚Äôs producers announced. The part of the compulsive gambler Sky Masterson will be played by Craig Bierko, whose resume includes the 2000 Broadway revival of ‚ÄúThe Music Man‚Äù and the comedy viral video ‚ÄúBathing With Bierko.‚Äù Sarah Brown, the straight-arrow leader of the Save A Soul Mission, will be played by Kate Jennings Grant, who has appeared on Broadway in ‚ÄúProof‚Äù and ‚ÄúAn American Daughter,‚Äù and who plays Diane Sawyer in the film adaptation of ‚ÄúFrost/Nixon.‚Äù They join Oliver Platt, who will play Nathan Detroit, and Lauren Graham, who will play Miss Adelaide. The revival of ‚ÄúGuys and Dolls‚Äù is scheduled to begin previews on Feb. 3 and open on March 1 at the Nederlander Theater.

The great thing about science fiction is that the future never runs out. As it prepares for the final season of its television space opera ‚ÄúBattlestar Galactica,‚Äù the Sci Fi channel has announced it is preparing a spinoff that will take place in the decades before ‚ÄúBattlestar Galactica.‚Äù The new show, ‚ÄúCaprica,‚Äù will be set 50 years earlier (in the future), and will follow the fortunes of two competing families, the Adamas and the Greystones, leading to the events of the ‚ÄúBattlestar Galactica‚Äù series. The cast of ‚ÄúCaprica‚Äù includes Eric Stoltz and Esai Morales, and its executive producers include Ronald D. Moore and David Eick, the producers of the ‚ÄúBattlestar Galactica‚Äù revival. Production on ‚ÄúCaprica‚Äù is scheduled to begin next year, and the show is expected to make its debut on Sci Fi in 2010.

Early one humid morning in October, I stood with a guide named C√©sar on a muddy path surrounded by thick, damp foliage. Mahogany, cedar and fig trees shot up and out, their tops invisible, while twisted, rope-like liana dangled down. Small mushrooms grew like pink suction cups on branches, and orchids clung to trunks. Birdsong, the chirring of insects and the rush of nearby water blended into a white noise that was broken on occasion by the saraguatos, or howler monkeys, high above us, whose deep, haunting cries echoed throughout the rain forest.

Our flight arrives at Heathrow on Christmas morning, and I've just found out that both the rail line and the Tube are shut down completely on Dec. 25. I've tried contacting private car companies, but those that are available want over ¬£100 for the trip. Do you have any other suggestions for getting to our hotel, the Mayfair Hotel, on Stratton Street? (I've also tried contacting the hotel, which will send a car for ¬£120s.) Go over to Diner's Journal to read the Thanksgiving post-mortems and you see a few quite sophisticated cooks using flour to thicken their gravy. And they're complaining about lumps and mess. Cornstarch, people! Cornstarch! You use 1 tablespoon cornstarch mixed with 1 tablespoon cold water for each cup of gravy you want to thicken (you can use a little more if you want it extra thick but don't overdo it.) Just stir until the mixture becomes milky; when your gravy is done, lower the heat, stir in the cornstarch slurry, and watch the magic. Add more, always mixed with cold water first.

Ann and Chris Burke knew nothing about dating violence when their daughter, Lindsay, took up with a man Ann calls "possessive from the start," five years ago. A few weeks later, she was murdered by her jealous ex when she went back to the apartment they'd shared to retrieve some stuffed animals. She was 23 years old.

[On Tuesday evening, the authorities announced that the man, Horace D. Moore, 20, of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, had been charged with murder in the driver's death. Please read the updated article.]

This Southern recipe opens the door to a world of possibilities, because the principal ingredients can be substituted without missing a step. Increase the amount of meat to a half pound, double the amount of greens and cook the soup until it's thick, and you can call it a stew. Don't forget the corn bread.

Thanks to increasing worldwide sales and economies of scale, a wide range of large-screen HDTVs are now available for three-figure prices.
Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, an adviser in lots of marquee mergers and buyouts, has named five new partners. In a sign of the times, none of them is a New York-based deal lawyer.
An authority on school reform, educational equity and teacher quality, Ms. Darling-Hammond is being considered for education secretary.

More old-fashioned buses are hitting the roads. Joining the new double-decker buses for a limited period for the holiday season are a number from the city's historic bus fleet. The vintage buses will be running during the morning and evening rush today through Jan. 1. Unfortunately, you won't be paying vintage prices. The buses have been upgraded to accept MetroCards, and they will be taking the standard fare. The buses will be used on the M8, M14, M20, M23, M34, M42, M57, M79 and Q32 bus routes.

Watching Clint Eastwood growl his way through "Gran Torino" here on Monday night, it was hard not to think about the prominence of dogs, old and young, in the season's movies. Mr. Eastwood's ride-along in this one was a sweet, labbie-looking mutt who was way more personable than Clyde the orangutan ("Every Which Way But Loose"), or even Mr. Eastwood's grumpy war vet Walt Kowalski in this one.
(Carlo Van de Roer)

For the holidays, The New York Times has put together a special tech section called Circuits. In it, you'll find articles written by some of our fellow bloggers, namely Roy Furchgott (on mobile phones that make good gifts and how to find the right turntable for old (and new) vinyl), Steve Williams (on the netbook phenomenon) and Eric Taub (on novelty tech items that work well as stocking stuffers), not to mention a generous helping of additional content from other fine folk. We may be a bit biased, but we think it's really, really good. Hope you enjoy it.

With so many adherents to different beliefs, it is hard to buy a holiday gift that doesn't risk causing offense. After all, some follow iPhone, some BlackBerry, others G1, and there are even those who adhere to the strict severity of a flip phone.
Hybrids aren't just about Toyotas.

Kennedy Jr., an environmental lawyer and son of the onetime senator from New York, said this morning that he had telephoned Gov. David A. Paterson and explained that he was not interested being appointed to the United States Senate.More in City Room ...

Indian police and government officials are beginning to speak on the record about the information they have gleaned from Ajmal Amir Qasab, the only gunman to be captured in the Mumbai terrorist attacks last week, as well as other aspects of the ongoing investigation.

The Bagger does not really have any movie star friends. George Clooney once said hi to him at the Four Seasons bar, which made the Bagger skip with joy, but then he noticed that press agent Stan Rosenfeld was just off Mr. Clooney's elbow. So maybe not.

Health news from around the Web.

Writing in the blog Some Came Running, Glenn Kenny says that "Doubt" may be one of the scarier movies of the year, due in no small part to a lurking monster named Sister Aloysius Beauvier, played with an almost spectral malevolence by Meryl Streep.
A coaching change, a few suspensions and the announcement of some players of the week are the highlights of the junior report after a quiet night in which all four major junior leagues were dark.

Those "Trans Fat-Free" crackers pictured at left seem to have magical calorie-reducing properties on the whole meal, as I found in an experiment described in my Findings column. Foods or restaurants with virtuous reputations seem to be imbued with a "health halo" that makes us underestimate calories, and I'd like to hear Lab readers' thoughts on how to deal with this effect.
The Clinton Administration alumni on the Obama transition team have been amazed at the sheer increase in the size of the defense apparatus.

China is one of the most expensive places in the world to play golf, according to a new study of the fledgling market. The average initiation fee for a course is more $50,000 and it typically costs about $160 to play a round on weekends, firmly establishing golf as an "elitist" sport, according to the study of China released Monday by the Budapest-based KPMG Golf Advisory Practice.

Voters in Georgia are heading to the polls -- again -- today. They will determine whether Democrats will add to their majority in the United States Senate by electing Jim Martin or if the Republican incumbent, Saxby Chambliss, will hold on to his seat. Either way, Tuesday represents the final gun for a contested Senate race that had gone into overtime.

At a recent press breakfast, someone asked top executives of Sony Electronics about their plans to let their televisions show video delivered by the Internet. While the company has an early effort, called the Bravia Internet Link, Stan Glasgow, the president of Sony Electronics in the United States, said the company can now introduce better products because it has reached an agreement with the cable industry.

General Electric said Tuesday that it expects its fourth-quarter profits to be at the low end of its previous guidance and warned that restructuring and other charges were likely to top $1 billion after taxes.

The Bagger was doing some idle, goofy surfing research (ED: Don't you mean research of the deep, careful kind?) on YouTube and noticed that the presentation had been altered last week, from the traditional 4:3 aspect ratio to the more cinematically friendly 16:9. Beyond being the wave of the future, it must makes previews look sweller. With the new wide-screen format, the official trailer for Revolutionary Road looks really moody and cool, like an actual film except one shown in a very small theater without annoying punks texting their loser friends. (One catch though - when the videos are embedded, they revert to their boxy, bar-encrusted old ways. So when the Bagger embeds, it will be the old format that will appear, not the new.)

Is Big Oil again the big winner? "President-elect Barack Obama's choice for national security adviser, retired Marine Gen. Jim Jones, is giving hope to energy companies that backed Republican John McCain that their concerns may still get an airing in the new administration," reports the Politico.

The New York police said on Monday that a hospital failed to notify them when Giants receiver Plaxico Burress arrived there early Saturday morning with a gunshot wound to his thigh, despite a state law requiring a doctor or hospital to report such violence to the authorities "at once."
Edward L. Glaeser is an economist at Harvard.

Tuesday night, the renamed and rejiggered Gotham Independent Film Awards - they used to just be called the Gotham Awards - will take place at Cipriani Wall Street. The Bagger will be there, although he's having troubling choosing between the sportcoat with a huge burn in the sleeve he picked up at the Men's Warehouse or the checked one from Burlington Coat Factory with a little bit of a vestigial wedding cake issue. And early West Coast time this morning, the Independent Spirit Awards will announce their nominations, and the Bagger's vast journalistic organization has mobilized to cover it.

British Airways said Tuesday that it is discussing a potential merger with Qantas Airways of Australia. The deal, which it warned may not happen, would be done through a dual-listed structure, it said in a statement on its Web site.

Anonymous Banker, who is fast becoming Executive Suite's new best friend, is back, this time with a first-hand explanation about why banks aren't making small-business loans. A.B. -- who, as I've mentioned in previous posts, works for a major bank but does not want to be identified -- sent me this e-mail message a few days after a previous expos√©, about the coming credit-card debt, was published here. I've come to think of these missives as eyewitness reports from inside the belly of the beast. By the way, we need to find a better pseudonym than Anonymous Banker. Any suggestions?
The global credit crunch has finally hit Japan.

Finance | Were class tensions the undoing of Lehman Brothers? A profile of Lehman's now-villainized C.E.O. suggests so. The intense Dick Fuld had long nurtured traders with a working-class resentment against all those bankers with their Ivy league diplomas (some of whom called Fuld "gorilla"). So when things went sour, Lehman wasn't connected to tony high finance like other big banks were. Fuld "was not even at the table" when the present and future heads of Treasury presided over Lehman's demise. [New York]
With taxpayers' money now sunk into struggling banks, can Main Street stomach the high salaries that some argue it takes to keep Wall Street's leaders in place?

The Bureau of Land Management, the regulatory gateway through which energy companies must often pass to drill for oil and gas on public land, last month seemed to be planning a leasing binge in Utah and Wyoming as the final act of the Bush administration.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts plans to invest $100 million in a Chinese dairy-farm business, Bloomberg News reported.
Goldman Sachs will probably report a net loss of as much as $2 billion for the fourth quarter, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing industry insiders.

At least three groups submitted offers on Monday to the Tribune Company in the latest round of bidding for the Chicago Cubs baseball team, Reuters reported, citing two sources familiar with the process.
Hawaiian Telcom Communications, the largest telephone company in Hawaii, said Monday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Maurice R. Greenberg can't let his old firm go.

Science | The conservative writer John Derbyshire asks why "state dogma" still insists that human evolutionary change ceased when Homo Sapiens emerged from Africa 50,000 years ago -- in the face of new genetic "biohistories" to the contrary. It's because, he says, the dogmatists want to preserve the "psychic unity of mankind" by explaining human differences as superficially "cultural." [Taki's Magazine]

The United States economy officially sank into a recession last December, which means that the downturn is already longer than the average for all recessions since World War II, according to the committee of economists responsible for dating the nation's business cycles.

For the Big Three automakers to win over Washington lawmakers in their bid for federal aid, they will have to address a critical question in the business plans they give to Congress on Tuesday, The New York Times's Bill Vlasic writes.

Daimler, the German automaker, sold 1 billion euros ($1.27 billion) of three-year bonds on Monday, paying sharply higher interest costs than it did for a similar issuance three months ago, Reuters reported.

The head of a new Congressional panel set up to monitor the gigantic federal bailout says the government still does not seem to have a coherent strategy for easing the financial crisis, despite the billions it has already spent in that effort, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reported.

Che Guevara has been put on a pedestal in Manhattan. This is something not lacking in irony, since Manhattan might not exist today had the Argentine-born, Cuban-tested revolutionary had his way and unleashed the Soviet nukes against the United States during the 1962 missile crisis.

The Justice Department has expanded its criminal investigation into foreign banks that sell offshore private banking services to include Credit Suisse and HSBC, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported, citing people briefed on the matter.

Printed materials weigh a lot. From books to corporate brochures, these bulky materials are costly to ship and costly for the environment in terms of emissions from the planes, trains and trucks that transport them.

Deutsche Bank fancies itself a shining exception to the prevailing view that giant banks need rescuing by governments. But, The New York Times's Carter Dougherty writes, the financial markets will have the final word, and so far they are not buying the story, or Deutsche stock.
Yahoo should call Microsoft's bluff, Breakingviews says.
The European Union will this week take the first step toward new rules governing high-risk hedge funds, the E.U.'s financial services chief said Monday, according to The Associated Press.
ExtendMedia has raised $10 million in Series C funding from previous backers TVM Capital, Atlas Venture and Venrock Associates.
Stocks fell Tuesday in Europe and Asia amid deeply bearish sentiment stoked by expectations of a protracted global recession, The New York Times's David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.
December blew in with a mighty chill on Wall Street.

In an endorsement for wireless video networking, Panasonic and Samsung said Monday that they have invested an undisclosed amount into SiBEAM, the maker of high-speed networking chips. According to VentureBeat, which cited a source close to the matter, the amount is $40 million.

The Australian government plans to increase the level of foreign ownership allowed in flagship carrier Qantas Airways but will not permit a takeover, The Associated Press reported, citing a policy document released Tuesday.

Federal prosecutors are passing on their last chance to reinvigorate a criminal tax-shelter proceeding, once billed as the largest in history, after a string of setbacks in the case, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning writes.
Detroit's automakers are focused this week on convincing Congress to provide them $25 billion in federal aid.
As policy makers push banks to help struggling homeowners, some angry investors are pushing back.

[Guardian]
Images of the Bob Baker Marionette Theater in Los Angeles, which has been hit hard by the slumping economy.
Every week, New York Times editor Dana Jennings shares his experiences coping with prostate cancer.

The unpaid services of America's family caregivers amounted to some $375 billion in 2007, up from $350 billion in 2006. Those are the latest findings from the AARP Public Policy Institute, which recently updated a similar report it conducted last year.
