Rice Krispies paella, anyone? [Smart Set]

If you live in Bangkok it may be time to go shopping for life's little luxuries - before they disappear from supermarket shelves. Anything that is normally air-freighted into Thailand may be in short supply soon if the airport seizures drag on. Shipments of Australian beef, Canadian lobsters, French cheeses and lots of temperate-climate produce were stranded on airport tarmacs when Suvarnabhumi airport was taken over by yellow-shirted protesters.
Castro‚Äôs Cuba is turning 50. It‚Äôs been dying for years. What can Obama ‚Äî or anyone else ‚Äî do to help bring the island into the 21st century?
For some, Enchantments, the witchcraft store in the East Village, may be a handy place to visit during times of anxiety.
Atheer A. Kakan writes on the historical lesson from a century ago which left many among Iraq's Shiite leadership majority determined to pass the recent security agreement with the Americans.

Clemson upgraded Dabo Swinney from interim coach, giving him a five-year contract to replace Tommy Bowden. Swinney‚Äôs salary and possible incentives in the deal will not be released until the contract is approved by the university‚Äôs Board of Trustees Compensation Committee. Swinney took over as interim coach Oct. 13 after Bowden resigned. The Tigers won four of their final five games under Swinney to become bowl eligible.

Scott Speed will race full time next season in Nascar‚Äôs Sprint Cup Series, a move anticipated since Red Bull Racing released A. J. Allmendinger to make room for Speed, a former Formula One driver. The team will change the Toyota to No. 82 from No. 84 to accommodate Speed, who has been training for Nascar since his release from Red Bull‚Äôs Formula One team in the summer of 2007. Jimmy Elledge will be his crew chief.

Ownership of Curlin, the reigning Horse of the Year, remained divided after a judge‚Äôs surprise ruling rejected a proposed sale that would have consolidated control of the horse under Jess Jackson. Jackson‚Äôs Stonestreet Stables owns 80 percent of Curlin, the richest North American racehorse in history. It had offered $4 million to buy out the remaining 20 percent interest from William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham Jr., who are under a court order to pay $42 million to former clients they represented in a settlement over the diet drug fen-phen.

Cristiano Ronaldo, whose 42 goals last season helped Manchester United secure Champions League and Premier League titles, won the Golden Ball award for soccer‚Äôs best player. Ronaldo, 23, a winger from Portugal, became the first United player to receive the award since George Best in 1968.

The Houston Comets, who won the W.N.B.A.‚Äôs first four championships, are disbanding, according to Donna Orender, the league‚Äôs president. Orender told the Houston television station KRIV that the Comets would be shut down because new owners could not be found. The W.N.B.A. took over the franchise earlier this year.

Cristiano Ronaldo, whose 42 goals last season helped Manchester United secure Champions League and Premier League titles, won the Golden Ball award for soccer‚Äôs best player. Ronaldo, 23, a winger from Portugal, became the first United player to receive the award since George Best in 1968.

Carla Sarkozy, the wife of President Nicolas Sarkozy, announced that she would serve as a good-will ambassador to fight AIDS with the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do it as ambassador of the global fund, by using the exceptional people that my new position makes possible to meet,‚Äù she said Monday at a news conference. Mrs. Sarkozy‚Äôs brother, Virginio Bruni, died of AIDS in 2006.

The government has rejected a ruling by an African regional court that ordered the return of land confiscated from 78 white farmers, the state-run newspaper The Herald said. Didymus Mutasa, the minister in charge of land reform, was quoted as saying that a tribunal empowered by the 15-nation Southern African Development Community was ‚Äúdaydreaming‚Äù if it thought the government would comply. That was a cold splash of reality for farmers who had been rejoicing since Friday‚Äôs judgment. President Robert Mugabe‚Äôs government seized the land of 4,600 farmers in the past decade, creating upheaval that most analysts say sent Zimbabwe‚Äôs economy into the free fall it suffers today.

In the midst of a cholera epidemic that has already killed more than 425 people, the government has cut water supplies to Harare, the capital and the epicenter of the outbreak, according to the state-run media. On Monday, news reports from the country said the national water authority had run out of essential chemicals to treat the water supply. With the capital dry, some government buildings have closed because of a lack of sanitation. Many of the poor are wandering the streets with containers, above, searching for spare water.
A decade ago, exhibitions linking Africa and the Americas were not uncommon. They are now, though, which may be a reason ‚ÄúS & M: Shrines and Masquerades in Cosmopolitan Times‚Äù looks fresh.

Russia plans to upgrade its missiles to allow them to evade American weapons in space and penetrate any prospective missile shield, a Russian officer said Monday. The officer, Col. Gen. Nikolai Y. Solovtsov, chief of strategic missile forces, said Russia‚Äôs intercontinental ballistic missiles would be modernized to protect them from space-based components of the United States missile defense system, the news agency Interfax reported. He also said the military would commission new RS-24 missiles with systems to help penetrate a missile shield. The Kremlin has fiercely opposed the United States plan to deploy 10 missile interceptors in Poland and a related radar system in the Czech Republic.

Brazil pledged Monday that, to fight global warming, in the next decade it would halve the rate of destruction of its Amazon rain forest. Brazil said it would aim to reduce clearing of the rain forest to 2,260 square miles a year by 2018. Brazil, which had refused to adopt targets until wealthier countries offered more help, hopes the plan will help allay criticism that it has done too little to fight burning and clearing by loggers, farmers and ranchers. Rain forest destruction has made Brazil one of the top greenhouse gas producers because trees release carbon dioxide when they are cut down or burned. Environment Minister Carlos Mins announced the plan, which is to be presented this week at a United Nations climate conference in Poland.

Turkish warplanes bombed Kurdish separatist positions in northern Iraq on Monday. The head of Iraq‚Äôs border guards in Dahuk Province, Col. Hussein Tamor, said no civilians were hurt. The Turkish military confirmed the strike.
Residents and tourists waded through knee-deep water as they navigated the city's narrow streets and alleys, inundated by high tides.

Mexican and Guatemalan drug traffickers arguing about a horse race in a rural border town began a series of gun battles in which 17 people died, the Guatemalan National Police said Monday. A police spokesman said the traffickers were drinking in the town, Santa Ana Huista, on Sunday when an argument broke out over bets on a horse race, leading to a pursuit in which the gunmen shot at one another from trucks racing down roads.

A Libyan ship headed to the Gaza Strip with 3,000 tons of aid, flouting an Israeli blockade, was turned back Monday by the Israeli Navy, ending the first high-profile attempt by an Arab country to break the blockade. Analysts said the incident showed that Arab and Islamic nations, while eager to end Gaza‚Äôs isolation, would not risk military confrontation with Israel. The freighter Al Marwa was approaching the Gaza coast when it was stopped by an Israeli Navy vessel and ordered to turn back. The Israeli Foreign Ministry said that the ship had complied and that no force had been used. Israel imposed the blockade after Hamas, a violently anti-Israel militant group, seized power in Gaza last year.

Opponents of a plan to develop land inside Valley Forge National Park filed suit in federal court in Philadelphia, saying that a local planning authority unlawfully approved the proposal to build a museum and visitor center on land where George Washington‚Äôs troops camped during the Revolutionary War.

Bureau of Land Management offices in Cheyenne, Wyo., and Salt Lake City have reversed their decisions to allow energy companies to lease some lands bordering on national parks in Utah and near the Flaming Gorge, a popular recreation area in Wyoming.
A rookie customs inspector in California has pleaded guilty to letting smugglers drive hundreds of pounds of marijuana into the country for $200,000 worth of bribes.
A judge in Raymondville has dismissed indictments against Vice President Dick Cheney and former Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.
An armored truck guard was shot to death at a suburban Miami mall, and the police were searching for two gunmen.
The police in Los Angeles said they made two arrests and rescued 17 dogs in the breakup of a dogfighting operation.
The estranged brother-in-law of the entertainer Jennifer Hudson has been arrested in the deaths of her mother, brother and 7-year-old nephew.
The United States military is investigating whether two of its soldiers abused a detainee in Afghanistan.
Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, was available Tuesday from 9 a.m. to 10 a.m. to answer questions from readers.
Niall Ferguson‚Äôs latest book, ‚ÄúThe Ascent of Money: A Financial History of the World,‚Äù went to press in May 2008, but it shrewdly anticipates many aspects of the current financial crisis.
On Monday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg excoriated hospital officials, Plaxico Burress and the Giants. He was on a roll, and you can watch video of the news conference above.
Plaxico Burress‚Äôs agent, Drew Rosenhaus, was in self-absorbed-agent mode during halftime of ‚ÄúMonday Night Football,‚Äù caring only about himself and his client.

The Yankees declined to offer arbitration to any of their free agents before Monday's midnight deadline, saying their decision was based primarily on their wish to control payroll.
David Carr, The Carpetbagger, gives his own daily take on awards season news.

Because of a production error, the Week 13 N.F.L. highlights on Monday included a game summary from an earlier week in some editions. Tennessee defeated Chicago in Week 10, not on Sunday.
At least 400 people were killed on Friday after angry Christian and Muslim mobs protested what they said were rigged local election results.
Senator Charles E. Schumer and advocates reported on Monday that as many as 60,000 apartments are in danger of falling into disrepair because of "shoddy lending practices."

An article on Monday about the investigation of Giants receiver Plaxico Burress, who accidentally shot himself while at a Manhattan nightclub, referred incorrectly to a New York State gun law. Carrying a loaded gun without a permit could carry a sentence of 3 ¬Ω to 15 years in prison whether or not prosecutors prove that the individual intended to use the weapon on another person; the sentencing range is not ‚Äúup to seven years‚Äù if prosecutors fail to prove intent.

The Talking Business column on Saturday, about the effect of the credit crisis on truck manufacturers and dealers, misstated the singularity of Navistar, a Chicago-based maker of trucks and buses. It is one of two independent American truck makers, not the only one. The other is Paccar, which makes the Kenworth and Peterbilt brands and is based in Bellevue, Wash.
Police said a hospital failed to notify them when Plaxico Burress arrived with a gunshot wound, despite state law.

The Shifting Careers column on Thursday, about artists who develop related careers that allow them to earn a living from their art, misstated the position of Larry Thompson, who created an art business program at the Ringling College of Art and Design in Sarasota, Fla. He is the college‚Äôs president, not its dean.

An article in some editions on Monday about a security issue that has prevented U.S. Helicopter from shuttling passengers between the Downtown Manhattan Heliport and the New York region‚Äôs airports omitted credit for an online travel site that previously reported the news. It is NewYorkology.com.

He is president of International at Ocean Spray, the company‚Äôs international division, not president of the company.

Barack Obama and his team should put into action a foreign policy doctrine that builds on some of the ideas developed during George W. Bush‚Äôs term.

Paul Pierce scored 17 of his 24 points in the third quarter to lead the Boston Celtics to their ninth straight victory, 107-88 over the Orlando Magic on Monday night.

Pekka Rinne made 30 saves for his first career shutout and the Nashville Predators scored twice in the third period for a 2-0 victory over the Sabres in Buffalo.
If the pact is successful at dislodging the Conservatives, it will be the first time since 1926 that the federal government has changed hands without a vote.
Epiphanny Prince scored 25 points and Kia Vaughn had 10 points and 8 rebounds to help No. 15 Rutgers end a two-game losing streak by rallying past host Temple, 64-60.

MARGIOTTA--Joseph. Honorable Joseph M. Margiotta. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Joseph M. Margiotta, Class of 1950, former member of the Hofstra University Board of Trustees, past president of the Hofstra University Alumni Association, and founder and past president of the Hofstra Pride Club. Twice honored by the University for his dedicated service to Hofstra, Joseph Margiotta was named Hofstra Alumnus of the Year in 1966, and in 1967 was awarded the distinguished George M. Estabrook Award. In 1992 Mr. Margiotta received a Presidential Medal and in 2001, he received a Doctor of Humane Letters from the University. During his political career, Mr. Margiotta long served as a member of the New York State Assembly and as a leader of the Republican Party in Uniondale, the Town of Hempstead, and Nassau County. He was the senior partner at the firm of Margiotta and Ricigliano, and served on the boards of several non-profit organizations. A former student leader and member of the football team at Hofstra University, Mr. Margiotta was generous with his advice and counsel throughout the decades of Hofstra's expansion, assisting with projects such as the establishment of the School of Law, the construction of the first Unispan and the development of Hofstra Stadium. He was a devoted fan of all Hofstra athletic programs and a dedicated leader of the Hofstra Pride Club. In recognition of his dedication and service, Hofstra University dedicated Margiotta Hall in 1992. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy, his son Michael, his daughter CarolLynn (Charchalis), and three grandchildren. In tribute to the memory of Mr. Margiotta, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half staff. Marilyn Monter Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University

10 P.M. (National Geographic) MARIJUANA NATION It's the most widely used illicit drug on the planet and illegal in most countries. In the United States the federal government places marijuana in the same category as heroin. Still, the plant, above -- one of the most complex, with 400 active chemicals and compounds -- is grown with abandon in national forests and parks and in suburban homes converted to greenhouses. In California alone, the marijuana trade outpaces the wine industry, making it one of the largest cash crops in the country. In this ''Explorer'' report, Lisa Ling examines the culture and economics of the plant. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICABritney Spears celebrates her 27th birthday.

President-elect Barack Obama released the list of donors to his inaugural committee on Monday, and they included noteworthy names like the movie director George Lucas and Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google. Out of the 1,777 people who contributed a total of $1.2 million, more than 130 gave the maximum contribution of $5,000. In capping donations at that amount, Mr. Obama's aides have said they are trying to reduce the influence of big money in the festivities.

BERRY--Eliot Ward, died of heart failure on November 29, 2008, age 59. Beloved father of Christopher, son of Nancy and Rynn Berry, and brother of Charles, Peter and Rynn, Jr. Eliot graduated from Buckley, Choate, the University of Pennsylvania (BA '71) and King's College, London University (Ph.D.) and received a Fulbright at Kassel University in Germany. He was a superb natural athlete and insightful and elegant writer. Author of Tough Draw, regarded by Arthur Ashe and Herbert Warren Wind as one of the best books ever on the game of tennis and the psychology of competition, Eliot brought to his craft a novelist's eye and ear, a scholar's encyclopedic knowledge and joy of literature, and an accomplished competitive athlete's awareness of the exhilaration and lonely struggles of athletic competition at the highest levels. He was inducted into the University of Pennsylvania Athletic Hall of Fame in 2000 in recognition of his achievements in football, squash and tennis. He was All-Ivy in all three sports. As a place kicker, he was signed to both the Pittsburgh Steelers and Atlanta Falcons; a gifted tennis player from a young age, he won the New York State 16s, was third-ranked in the East and played on the 1970 ECAC Championship Team; and in squash he played on the international tour, was number one for the U.S. Team at the World Championships in 1977 and won the Metropolitan Squash Singles Championship in 198082. Eliot's other published works included a novel, literary criticism and Topspin, another acclaimed book on the professional tennis tour. At the time of his death Eliot had recently completed an authorized screenplay of Albert Camus's iconic The Stranger. He was founder and principal of Eliot W. Berry & Co., real estate appraisers. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, Friday, December 5, at 12 noon. Contributions may be made to the Al Molloy Squash Fund at the University of Pennsylvania's Weightman Fund.

China's Health Ministry acknowledged Monday that the toll from adulterated baby formula was much higher than it previously reported, with six possible deaths and nearly 300,000 infants sickened. The figures were the first released since Sept. 21, when health authorities said three babies had died and 53,000 had been sickened as a result of consuming the formula, which had been tainted with melamine, a chemical often used to manufacture plastics, apparently to disguise low-quality milk products.

BECKLEY--Paul V., age 98, passed away Saturday, November 29, 2008. Paul was born on February 17, 1910 in Tulsa, OK. He was preceded in death by his wife Frances on November 11, 1993. He is survived by his three children Michael, Patrick and Laurel; seven grandchildren Michael, Patrick, Paul, Kathleen, Susan, Thomas and James and 13 great - grandchildren. Paul worked as a reporter for the Kansas City Journal and moved to New York in 1941 to begin working as a reporter for the New York Herald Tribune. During WWII he served in the 75th I.D. as Cmdr. of a heavy weapons platoon in the European Theatre of Operations before being discharged from Ft. Bragg as a 1st Lt. of the 82nd A.D. After the war Paul returned to the Herald Tribune as a reporter and eventually became one of New York City's finest movie critics. It was often said that his review would make or break a film. Paul left the Tribune to become a senior writer for the CBS news at 6 o'clock. Paul was a lifetime member of the American Legion Post 1033 Elmont and VFW. The family will receive friends Thursday 2-4 and 79pm at Perry Funeral Home Inc., 118 Union Ave., Lynbrook, NY. Service Friday 10:00am at the Funeral Home with interment to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park.

ABELES--Joseph. The Division of Rheumatology at the NYU School of Medicine expresses deep sorrow on the loss of Joseph Abeles. Joseph Abeles will be remembered as a warm and loving person, always proud of his wife Sophia and devoted family. He made everyone joyous whenever in his presence. We offer sincere sympathy and condolences to the entire family. Steven Abramson, M.D., Director of the Division of Rheumatology at NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases ABELES--Joseph Charles, died peacefully in his Pleasantville home on November 30, 2008 at age 93. Joe is survived by his sister, Helen Levanthal, his daughters Lucille Werlinich and Barbara Abeles, his grandson, Greg Werlinich, and his three great - grandchildren, Nola, Lily and Ezra. Joe was born in New York City on January 6, 1915 and lived his entire life in the New York area. He was a devoted husband for over 60 years to his beloved Sophia who passed away in 2001. Joe will be remembered for many things: his love for his family, his business acumen and his investment prowess; his love of golf, Johnnie Walker scotch, and along with Sophia, an abiding belief in philanthropy. After completing high school at age 15, Joe earned a B.S. in chemical engineering from NYU. He then worked briefly for Parker-Kalon as an industrial engineer. In 1936 he joined Faesy & Besthoff as a sales agent. In 1950 he co-founded the Kawecki Chemical Company. In 1968 KCC joined with the Beryllium Corporation to form Kawecki Berylco Industries, or KBI. For 28 years he led the company through domestic and international growth, culminating in the sale of the company to the Cabot Corporation in 1978. KBI then employed over 2,000 people and had sales in excess of $200 million. After retiring from Cabot in 1980, Joe spent the better part of the next 25 years focused on the stock market, making private equity investments, and helping to guide a number of small companies through his position on their Boards of Directors. Some of those companies included Ultralife Batteries, a company he helped to co-found, Intermagnetics General, Bluegreen and Igene Biotechnology. Outside of his family, work and the stock market, Joe's greatest passion was golf. He took his clubs with him wherever he traveled in the world. Some of the great life lessons that he imparted to family, friends and colleagues were that: ''fast payers make good friends'', ''it's better to one putt than three'', and of course, ''drive for show but putt for dough''. Then after the round, it would be time for a Johnnie Walker Black, on the rocks, with a twist. Joe and Sophia established the Joseph and Sophia Abeles Foundation 39 years ago. They used this charitable foundation to support their numerous philanthropic activities. They supported local causes important to them, principally education, the arts and medicine. They tried to give their money to causes where they could do the most good and have the greatest impact. The greatest examples of their work can be seen at Westchester Community College where they have endowed more than two dozen teaching chairs and where they set up the Nancy Jo Abeles Scholarship Fund, in memory of their daughter Nancy, to create opportunities for people who may not otherwise have been able to receive an education. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of people around the world who have received, and likely still have, a pocket diary and/or a penlight given by Joe. There are at least as many people who have shared a round of golf, discussed the stock market, or simply been given some simple words of wisdom by Joe. He was an honest, loyal and generous man. He will be missed by all who knew him. Contributions can be made in his name to the Nancy Jo Abeles Scholarship Fund through the Westchester Community College Foundation, 75 Grasslands Rd., Valhalla, NY 10595. 914-606-6670. A service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 Broad St., Mt. Vernon, on Wednesday, December 3, at 12:00. The family will greet friends at the home, 1055 Bedford Rd., Pleasantville, NY, after the service, and again from 4:00 to 7:00 on Thursday.

KUSSOY--Paul, 74, of Wantagh, New York and Boynton Beach, Florida passed away peacefully on November 30, 2008. Paul was the cherished son of the late Betty and David Kussoy and brother of the late Gerald Kussoy. He is survived by his loving wife of 53 years, Doris, devoted daughter and son-in-law Jayne and Steve Gordon, son Andrew, adored granddaughters Rebecca and Rachel, and his special corgi, Alex. Predeceased by his children Patricia and Eric. During his life he strove to become self employed and successfully achieved his goal of becoming the owner of Palizzio Accessories, a ladies handbag manufacturing business. He proudly served as a veteran of the US Navy. Paul was a very special and generous man whose impact on his family will never be forgotten.

MORRIS--Blanche Funke, November 29, in New York City at the age of 94. She was the devoted husband of Eugene J. Morris. A graduate of Hunter College and Colombia University, she was a former math teacher who inspired her students and friends. GROSSMAN--Dr. Jacob, a physician died on November 29. He was 92 years old. Born on August 6, 1916, to Isaac and Anna Toner in New York City, he attended Stuyvesant High School, the City College of New York, Columbia University, and he received his M.D. from the University of Louisville in 1940. Following his service in World War II, he began a long association with Montefiore Hospital. He also served as Director of Internal Medicine at the Hospital for Joint Diseases and as a Police Surgeon with the New York City Police Department. On August 9, 1948 he married Frances Gaezer. She died on November 14, 1990. A resident of Scarsdale, New York for more than forty years, he took great pride in his four children who survive him: Arthur (Jeanette) of North Reading, Massachusetts, Victor (Jamie) of Brewster, New York, Daniel (Debbie) of Topanga, California, and Walter (Vered) of Fairfax Station, Virginia, and nine grandchildren. Services will be held Tuesday, December 2, at 12:00, at The Riverside Chapel 21 W. Broad St., Mount Vernon, New York 10552.

SWEENEY--Mary Elizabeth, RSCJ, former Provincial Superior of the Society of the Sacred Heart, died November 26, 2008 at Teresian House, Albany, NY. She was a member of the Society of the Sacred Heart for 72 years. Born in Rochester, NY, Sister Sweeney was a graduate of Newton College of the Sacred Heart. Sister Sweeney was noted for her financial acumen. She served the Society in financial management and investment throughout her life. She was Treasurer of Newton College of the Sacred Heart and of the United States Province of the Society of the Sacred Heart. She served on the investment committee of the New England Jesuits. She was President of the Newton Country Day School Corporation and a Trustee of Stuart Country Day School in Princeton, NJ and Newton Country Day School of the Sacred Heart. Sister Sweeney lived in retirement at Kenwood Convent of the Sacred Heart, Albany, NY. Sister Sweeney is survived by her sisters Mrs. Anne Sweeney Johantgen of Brockport, NY and Miss Jean B. Sweeney of Rochester, NY. She was the daughter of Michael Edward Sweeney and Helen Hammond Sweeney and sister of the late Sr. Helen Sweeney, RSCJ. The funeral Mass was celebrated in Albany. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated Thursday, December 11, 6pm at Newton Country Day School of the Sacred Heart, 785 Centre St.

SPERRY--Ann. The Board of Directors and Staff of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts mourn the untimely passing of esteemed Board Member Ann Sperry. We extend our deepest condolences to Ann's husband, Paul Sperry, her children, her grandchildren, and other members of her family. Ann was a gifted artist and vigorously represented, with great knowledge, conviction and passion, the artist community that VLA serves. As the longest-serving member of VLA's Board and a long-time member of VLA's Executive Committee, Ann was truly an essential member of VLA's Board. She will be greatly missed by the Board and Staff, and we know that she will long be remembered by the many whose lives she touched.

SALEM--Patricia Marand. Tony Award nominated Broadway star, Patricia Marand, who graced the stage opposite such theatre greats as Yul Brynner, Alfred Drake, Jack Cassidy and Dan Dailey, passed away on November 27th, due to brain cancer. Marand was nominated for the Tony Award in 1966 for her role as Lois Lane in the Hal Prince - directed Broadway production of ''It's a Bird, It's a Plane, It's Superman,'' composed by Charles Strouse which The New York Times once called ''the best musical of the season.'' A statuesque, red haired beauty with an unforgettable rich and melodic soprano voice, Marand's performances epitomized Broadway theatre with memorable grace and style. Marand began her career in the hey-days of Broadway playing leading roles in ''Wish You Were Here,'' ''Kiss Me Kate,'' ''Pajama Game,'' ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''Oklahoma,'' ''Man of La Mancha,'' ''Kismet'' and ''South Pacific,'' to name a few. While the Broadway stage was her true home, Marand's voice enchanted thousands in acclaimed concert solos with the Chicago, Cleveland, Pittsburgh, New Haven and Minneapolis symphony orchestras, as well as during engagements at the Cotillion Room at New York's Hotel Pierre and La Maisonette at the St. Regis. She frequently appeared on television on the Merv Griffin, Johnny Carson and Ed Sullivan shows. She also appeared recently on the small screen as Helen Barone in ''The Sopranos.'' A native New Yorker, Marand always lit up the room at operas, theaters, charitable benefits and political events around the world. Daughter of the late Patrick and Justine Marandino, she leaves behind her loving husband and love of her life, Irving Salem, brother Robert, sister-in-law Joan, nephew Rob, and nieces Missy, Kimberly and Cristin. Viewing will be held Tuesday, December 2, 4-8pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, (212) 288-3500, with funeral services Wednesday, December 3rd, 10am at St. Monica's Church, 413 East 79th Street, (212)288-6250. Private burial to be held at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Harrison, New York.

Abeshouse of Baltimore, MD; beloved mother-in-law of Rhonda S. Leonard and Irv Tark; loving sister of Morris W. Offit; dear sister-in-law of Nancy S. Offit and Jane A. Feiler; loving grandmother of Marnie L. Abeshouse and Michael E. Abeshouse. Belvedere Avenue, Baltimore, MD 21215. Services by Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc., Baltimore, MD 1-800-338-1701 sollevinson.com

Summer heat, boy and girl meet, but uh-oh: those closing notices. The current revival of ‚ÄúGrease‚Äù has become the latest Broadway show to announce that it will close soon after the new year; it will play its final performance at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Jan. 4. This latest revival of the musical tribute to fast cars, faster women and 1950‚Äôs nostalgia was spawned by the NBC reality series ‚ÄúGrease: You‚Äôre The One That I Want,‚Äù whose winners, Laura Osnes and Max Crumm, became the show‚Äôs original Sandy and Danny; the ‚ÄúAmerican Idol‚Äù contestants Taylor Hicks and Ace Young have also played key roles in the show. Kristen Stewart, the young star of the hit film adaptation of ‚ÄúTwilight,‚Äù has decided to have her rebellious rock ‚Äòn‚Äô roll moment in full view of the movie-going public: she has signed on to play the rock musician Joan Jett in a biographical film about the 1970s-era band the Runaways, The Hollywood Reporter said. The film, tentatively titled ‚ÄúThe Runaways,‚Äù will tell the story of the all-female band that made songs like ‚ÄúCherry Bomb,‚Äù and provided a launching point for the careers of Ms. Jett (of ‚ÄúI Love Rock N‚Äô Roll‚Äù fame) as well as Lita Ford. The music video director Floria Sigismondi will write and direct the film, and Ms. Jett is serving as an executive producer. Ms. Stewart is expected to start filming in between production of two coming ‚ÄúTwilight‚Äù sequels.

A five-day auction of Asian artwork at Christie‚Äôs in Hong Kong sold 35 percent less than its presale estimates in another sign of the declining economy‚Äôs impact on the global art market, Reuters reported. The auction ended on Wednesday with total sales of $146 million but was expected to sell more than $225 million, and more than 30 percent of its 2,400 lots went unsold; a Christie‚Äôs Hong Kong auction in May ended with total sales of $310 million, an all-time high for its Asian offerings. ‚ÄúLike all markets we are affected by confidence and we‚Äôve definitely seen less confidence in our world in the last two or three months,‚Äù Edward Dolman, the chief executive of Christie‚Äôs International, told Reuters.

Two quirky crime series and a remake of a short-lived 1990s romantic comedy are among the new shows that ABC has announced in its midseason schedule. The first of the network‚Äôs new scripted series is ‚ÄúCastle,‚Äù about a mystery novelist (played by Nathan Fillion of ‚ÄúFirefly‚Äù) who forges a relationship with an NYPD detective (Stana Katic); it is scheduled to premiere on March 9. On March 24, ABC will offer the debut of ‚ÄúCupid,‚Äù starring Bobby Cannavale (of ‚ÄúThe Station Agent‚Äù) as a human who may or may not be the Roman god of love; it‚Äôs a reworked version of a 1998 series that starred Jeremy Piven of ‚ÄúEntourage.‚Äù Finally, ‚ÄúThe Unusuals‚Äù stars Amber Tamblyn (‚ÄúJoan of Arcadia‚Äù) as another NYPD detective in a homicide department full of secrets; its premiere will be April 8.

Federal immigration officials returned more than 80 ancient artifacts to the Egyptian government on Wednesday, pieces that had been stolen from a museum near Cairo in 2002 by a United States Army helicopter pilot and later sold to an antiquities dealer. The antiquities, seized by Immigration and Customs Enforcement after a 2006 investigation, were among 370, dating to 3000 B.C. or earlier, that were discovered missing from a museum in Maadi, a suburb of Cairo. At a ceremony in Chelsea, Peter J. Smith, special agent-in-charge of the immigration department‚Äôs Office of Investigations, returned the artifacts to Egypt‚Äôs consul general in New York, Hussein Mubarak, and Attiya Radwan, who oversees the Central Department for Upper Egypt Monuments.

A hand-written and hand-illustrated copy of J. K. Rowling‚Äôs newest book, ‚ÄúThe Tales of Beedle the Bard‚Äù was unveiled on Wednesday at the New York Public Library, to promote the book‚Äôs commercial release on Thursday.

The week of Thanksgiving is usually one of the music industry‚Äôs biggest and most important, but sales were low this year despite several high-profile new releases. Guns N‚Äô Roses‚Äô ‚ÄúChinese Democracy‚Äù (Geffen), an album 14 years in the making that was sold through an exclusive deal with Best Buy, sold 260,000 copies; some early estimates for it were nearly triple that amount. ‚ÄúChinese Democracy‚Äù opens at No. 3 on the Billboard album chart, behind Kanye West‚Äôs new ‚Äú808s & Heartbreak‚Äù (Def Jam), which sold 450,000, and Taylor Swift‚Äôs ‚ÄúFearless‚Äù (Big Machine), which moved 267,000 in its third week. Last week‚Äôs No. 1, Beyonc√©‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Am ‚Ä¶ Sasha Fierce‚Äù (Columbia), dropped to No. 4 with 257,000; Ludacris‚Äôs ‚ÄúTheater of the Mind‚Äù (Def Jam) opens at No. 5 with 213,000; and the Killers‚Äô new ‚ÄúDay & Age‚Äù (Island) opened at No. 6 with 193,000. Over all sales were down 13 percent from the week of Thanksgiving last year.

My theory is that the best hope for newspapers to build a business model and recover their economic strength is through the power of the Internet and social networks. Partly that's because I look at the valuation of newspaper companies going one way and the value of social networks (Myspace, Facebook and so on) going the other. That's why I was the first Times blogger, and why I have a facebook page and Youtube channel. (If you haven't fanned me at facebook or subscribed to my Youtube channel, please do check them out.)

The real estate run-up and ensuing credit crisis has exacerbated an already grim housing situation for New York City immigrants, according to a report issued today by the New York Immigrant Housing Collaborative and Pratt Center for Community Development.According to the report, "Confronting the Housing Squeeze: Challenges Facing Immigrant Tenants, and What New York Can Do" [pdf], foreclosures have been concentrated outside of Manhattan in neighborhoods with large immigrant populations -- such as Jamaica and Queens Village in Queens, and Flatlands, East Flatbush, and Bushwick in Brooklyn. Immigrants who own homes pay far more of their incomes for housing, on average, than native-born New Yorkers, and may have been vulnerable to subprime lending.

One year after the national economy officially fell into a recession, New York City and State have joined it, according to an influential research firm. On Wednesday, Moody's Economy.com said that the city and state, like almost all other parts of the country, are now in a recession. For the last several months, Economy.com had said the city and state were "at risk" of recession but had not yet begun shrinking. Almost all the rest of the tristate area, including all metropolitan areas in New Jersey, are also in recession, according to Economy.com.

Anyone interested in world culture or the history of mankind should take a look at "One Thousand Languages: Living, Endangered, and Lost," edited by Peter K. Austin, the director of the endangered languages program at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London. I know I found it irresistible. It's not a book for reading from cover to cover. It's organized more like a reference work, with brief descriptions of various languages around the world. Admittedly, it has a slight musty academic tone, much like a PBS documentary.

To me, cookie-baking season is year-long. But since some people consider the winter holidays a particularly apt time for making cookies, it comes as no shock that Anita Chu's "Field Guide to Cookies: How to Identify and Bake Virtually Every Cookie Imaginable" was released just before the holiday season. It looks more like a stocking-stuffer than a serious cookbook, but, surprisingly, its classic field-guide-style package (thank you, Roger Tory Peterson) comes pretty close to delivering on its bold subtitle.

Funny or Die, the lavishly capitalized humor-video site started by Will Ferrell and Adam McKay and now run with HBO, has always kind of bugged me. The site typically forfeits laughs with overproduced, overthought videos that are all-too-ready-for-prime-time. Below, this star-studded affair, for example, could be a comedy sketch on the Oscars or an outtake from "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip." It just looks like old TV, with TV politics and TV villains (in this case, venal Bible-y people who oppose gay marriage until they think they might make money off it).

Shortly before Thanksgiving, I boarded Jet Blue ($440) for Austin to spend some time with Katy and Matt Culmo, who own a store called By George. I wanted to see how an independent retailer was coping with the recession, and I thought I'd get a more honest view outside of hyper, impress-me-silly New York. At "wheels-up," there was a rustle of paper in the cabin as my fellow passengers fished out their breakfast rolls and sandwiches and began to eat over eastern Pennsylvania. I thought about the trips in the late 70s, on the still-ancient European trains-Madrid to Barcelona, Palermo to Rome-when the thing to do was to load up on bread and cheese and wine at the local market. I made a mental note to stop in at Whole Foods in Austin to pick up something for the return flight. I certainly preferred the food I could bring onboard to the strange vittles the airlines now serve, and there's no stigma attached to bringing your own. It just makes sense. We know that.

Have you seen this video? Entitled Peter Schiff Was Right, 2006-2007, it is an amazing, nine-minute compilation that features Mr. Schiff, the president of Euro-Pacific Capital, suffering the slings and arrows of various market gurus like Arthur Laffer, as he bravely predicts -- again and again and again -- in various television appearances that the housing bubble is going to lead to economic disaster. One thing that makes it amazing is how unflinching Mr. Schiff is, how unyielding, how matter-of-fact, no matter how scornful and sneering the response from the other talking heads. Even when they laugh at him, he keeps coming back. The other thing that makes it amazing, of course, is that Mr. Schiff absolutely nailed the current crisis -- and did so many, many months before the rest of us could feel the first tremor.

There was a time when hockey players were known as the classiest of all professional athletes. They conducted themselves as gentlemen in public and were proud to do so. They extended themselves to help promote a sport and the profession that was their livelihood. They recognized that among similar businesses, hockey lagged behind the others in popularity in the U.S. and they weren't going to do anything to bring into disrepute a game that was already greatly misunderstood. The well being of hockey as a whole was foremost in their minds.

The official public opening of Art Basel Miami Beach is in a few hours, but the satellite shows around town are already up and running. The Sagamore Hotel - which has a year-round arty edge thanks to owner Marty Taplin showcasing his private collection onsite - has another public art project under way following last year's Spencer Tunick-directed mass strip-off. The impish Swiss artist Olaf Breuning, tapped as this week's guest creative, is ramping up the raunchiness with an abstracted 150-ton sphinx-like sand sculpture of a reclining woman. "Miami has something, not sleazy or cheesy about it, but you see people walking around in very tight bathing suits, big breasts, plastic surgery so I thought I'd make something about the relationship between sexuality and art history," he said.

In a sign of the economic times, Harvard has sent a letter to its deans saying that the university's $36.9 billion endowment fund lost 22 percent of its value in the last four months, or about $8 billion, and could decline as much as 30 percent by the end of the fiscal year on June 30, The New York Times's Geraldine Fabrikant reports.

Well, it looks like there's no need for Bangkok's expats to hoard the French cheeses and Dutch tomatoes after all. The protesters say they are dispersing - for now - and the airports may be open by week's end. Supermarkets will get new shipments of avocados and the trashy weekly magazines from the U.S. And Thai orchid growers may yet be able to export in time for the holiday season. Something tells me this is only a hiatus, though. Functioning airports: Live it up while it lasts.

New Mexico State fired Coach Hal Mumme on Tuesday, ending a tumultuous four-year run. The Aggies lost seven straight games to end the season 3-9 and 1-7 in the Western Athletic Conference. They lost, 49-0, at home to Boise State and ended the season last weekend with a 47-2 defeat at Utah State.

A full World Series share was worth $351,504 for the Philadelphia Phillies, below the record $362,173 set by the St. Louis Cardinals two years ago. Major League Baseball said the players‚Äô pool for the postseason was $51.16 million, down from $52.46 million last year and a record $55.60 million in 2006. Phillies players received $18.42 million and split it among 45 full shares, 7.039 partial shares and 15 cash awards.

The world record-holder Paula Radcliffe will return to the London Marathon next year in a bid to win the event for a fourth time. Radcliffe, a British runner, has missed the London race the past four years. On April 26, she will face a strong field that includes the defending champion, Irina Mikitenko of Germany, and two other former London winners. Radcliffe, the winner in 2002, 2003 and 2005, will aim to match Norway‚Äôs Ingrid Kristiansen, who won the London Marathon four times between 1984 and 1988.

Moscow regional prosecutors said an ice arena manager and a hockey club director were negligent in the death of the rising Russian star Alexei Cherepanov. Prosecutors said in a statement posted on their Web site that the manager of the Moscow region arena where Cherepanov was playing failed to coordinate proper emergency medical services before the game.
The following request was sent to marines via Baghdad Bureau from a student on a course at Illinois State University. Answers at your discretion.
Nearly 300,000 Afghans returned home from Pakistan in 2008. With winter approaching, many are on the brink of desperation in the eastern desert.

A museum review on Nov. 7 about the aircraft carrier Intrepid, at Pier 86 on the Hudson River, referred incompletely to a World War II Avenger torpedo bomber on display. While the Avengers were designed and originally built by Grumman, production was expanded to the Eastern Aircraft division of General Motors, which built the plane on display.

A dance entry in the Listings pages on Friday about performances of works by Jonah Bokaer and Rashaun Mitchell at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in Greenwich Village this Thursday, using information provided in a news release, erroneously included a performer in the work by Mr. Mitchell. Elizabeth Streb, the choreographer and dancer, will not be performing.

A report in the City Room column on Nov. 25 about politicians who have served as both United States senator from New York and secretary of state referred incorrectly to the resolution of the disputed presidential election of 1876, in which one such politician, William M. Evarts, played a role. A 15-man electoral commission found that the Republican candidate, Rutherford B. Hayes, was the winner, and the Senate confirmed the commission‚Äôs vote. The election was not decided by the House.

An article in some editions on Nov. 20, about a meeting of New York‚Äôs Congressional delegation that brought together several people mentioned as possible successors to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton if she joined President-elect Barack Obama‚Äôs cabinet, referred imprecisely to the role of the United States Constitution in filling a Senate vacancy. The Constitution allows state legislatures to empower governors to select a replacement until voters select a successor themselves; it does not itself grant governors the authority to name a replacement.

An article on Friday about Rabbi Gavriel and Rivka Holtzberg, a couple from Brooklyn taken hostage when the Jewish center they ran in Mumbai, India, was seized by terrorist gunmen, who later killed them, referred incorrectly to the women swaying on their knees in a room at the world headquarters of the Lubavitch Hasidic movement in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The women were holding prayer books, not reading the Torah.
